XML.Hansard-Body: The Legislative Assembly met at 9.30 am.
Mr Speaker (Hon. John Mickel, Logan) read prayers and took the chair.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Standing Orders Committee and Schedule 2 of the Standing Orders
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, part 9 of the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 2010 amends the Parliament of Queensland Act by, amongst other things, setting up a statutory basis for the Register of Members’ Interests and the Register of Related Persons’ Interests. The part commences on proclamation. Recently Standing Orders Committee members agreed by correspondence to a replacement schedule 2, which is necessary to harmonise the new statutory regime and schedule 2. The changes do not affect the current registration requirements upon members.

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, today at 12 noon I will be officially dedicating and launching the Speakers’ Corner--a space devoted to encouraging Queenslanders to speak and engage in open and vigorous debate. Located in the George Street forecourt just outside of Parliament House, the Speakers’ Corner is a legacy project for the people of Queensland to mark their parliament’s 150th anniversary. In May of this year we celebrated this significant anniversary with a number of events and activities including an open day, wine launch, dinner debate and book launches. During the highly successful open day held on 22 May 2010, I unveiled the Speakers’ Corner project.

In 1860, members of Queensland’s first parliament assembled for the first time and 150 years of peaceful democracy has followed. As Speakers’ Corners around the world are based on the philosophy of freedom of speech and grassroots democracy, it was appropriate to unveil the creation of a legacy project encouraging the people of Queensland to come to their parliament and have their say, to engage in vigorous debate and to gather for peaceful protests. I invite all members to attend this significant dedication and launch event.

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, the recently released conservation plan for Parliament House highlights the ‘formal and aesthetic qualities’ of Parliament House and its surrounds, specifically stating--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Parliament House is an important visual element in its setting. The main entrance aligns with the entrance to the Botanic Gardens opposite ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: It continues--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Components of very high significance are those which are central to the historic use of Parliament House and its social and symbolic value. These components include:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: The George Street facade viewed from the street and from the Botanic Gardens.
XML.Hansard-Body: As honourable members may be aware, the Brisbane City Council is in the process of implementing a CityCycle bicycle hire program and is installing CityCycle stations over inner-city Brisbane. Approximately 10 months ago, incidentally whilst seeking approval from the Brisbane City Council for the installation of Speakers’ Corner, the Parliamentary Service became aware of plans to install CityCycle stations in the parliament’s forecourt. Over the past 10 months there have been a number of meetings to discuss the CityCycle installations and correspondence with regard to their proposed location. I believe the Parliament House forecourt is unsuitable for such a facility for a number of reasons. Chiefly, it would be seriously incompatible with the present use of the Parliament House forecourt, for example its use on ceremonial occasions such as the opening of Parliament; as a focal point for demonstrations; as a pedestrian mall for large numbers of people accessing the Queensland University of Technology; and it would have a seriously detrimental impact on the visual amenity of Parliament House, the state’s premier heritage building.

After a meeting between Councillor Jane Prentice and myself in late May of this year and following discussions with council officers and the Clerk and the Lord Mayor’s office and my office, I was under the impression that a satisfactory resolution had been reached. It is my understanding that the idea of locating CityCycle infrastructure in the forecourt area had been knocked on the head and was dead and buried. However, in recent weeks it has come back to life. On 12 and 18 October 2010 the Parliamentary Service received correspondence outlining the proposed installations and locations which contradicted what had been agreed to. The Parliamentary Service was completely unaware of the disclosures in the correspondence--namely, the installation of City Lights billboards in the Parliament House forecourt area and two CityCycle stations.

I have sought urgent clarification of these matters from the Lord Mayor. I believe the Parliament House forecourt must be preserved and protected from moves to install structures of one kind or another that can seriously compromise the heritage values and visual amenity of this historic location. I have written to the Lord Mayor stating that, whilst I understand that the CityCycle project is a significant project to reduce transport environmental impact, the implementation of billboards and CityCycle stations that are not in keeping with the heritage nature of the precinct and potentially may impede peaceful protests and other uses of the area should not proceed. I await the Lord Mayor’s response. However, I signal to the House that, should a satisfactory resolution not be found, I will have no hesitation in asking this House to implement whatever legislative protection is required to protect the heritage of Parliament House and ensure access to peaceful protest in our forecourt is unimpeded. I trust in this Assembly to provide that support.
Honourable members: Hear, hear!

Mr SPEAKER: Honourable members, on 15 October I was delighted to attend the Parliamentary Lions Club’s Jazz on the Green 2. I was joined at this event by a number of honourable members. I am sure that those members will agree with me when I say that it was an excellent evening. Unfortunately, bad weather forced a venue change to the Premiers’ and Speakers’ halls, but this did not detract from the event. Of course, the event had a serious purpose, and that was to raise money for the Royal Flying Doctor Service. I understand that events such as this will be held each year to raise money for charity, and I encourage all honourable members to attend the next event.

XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Vaughan, Mr A; McCulloch, Mr J, OAM
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.38 am): Today we mark the passing of two distinguished Queensland political personalities--former AMWU State Secretary, Austin Vaughan, and former tireless Parliamentary Library member, John McCulloch. These were two men who in different ways played important roles in Queensland’s political landscape throughout their lifetimes and both will be laid to rest today in what I am sure will be well-attended funeral services.

Austin, affectionately known to us all as ‘Aussie’, was an extraordinary man with many achievements. He served as the State Secretary of the AMWU for 20 years--one of its longest serving senior officers. He was born in 1929 in the small town of Pinnacle at the base of the Eungella Range in the Mackay sugarcane growing region. In truly fitting Rocky style, Aussie did his apprenticeship as a fitter and turner at the Rockhampton railway workshops and he continued to work there until 1970, when he moved to Brisbane as an organiser and later became State Secretary of the newly formed Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. Aussie was one of a prominent group of colourful Labor leaders to emerge from the Rockhampton railway workshops during that period. He joined such names as Jack Edgerton, Jack Deveraux, Bryant Burns, Harry Hauenschild and Ron ‘Buster’ Keating to name a few. Some might say they have a lot to answer for! These were his peers--all metalworkers, fitters, turners and boilermakers, all from the trades that Aussie himself came from and which he represented with distinction over his 20 years as State Secretary of their union. Aussie served as the President of the Queensland peak union movement, currently called the Queensland Council of Unions, from 1990 until his retirement in 1994. He was also a delegate to the ACTU during his time as State Secretary of his union.

Aussie was known for his quiet achievement. He was always involved in the industrial and political events of the day, always encouraging reforms to better the lives of working Australians and society at large, but rarely in the media. Such dignity in his work afforded widespread respect. He also mentored an entire generation of trade union officials and aspiring politicians. Aussie is survived by his wife, Jean, herself a prominent community and peace activist in her time, their children Claudia and John, three grandchildren and three great-grandchildren.
Mr Schwarten: We’ll be going to the funeral today.
Ms BLIGH: I will be at the funeral today, as will other members of the government.

Equally, the achievements of Mr John McCulloch are also extraordinary. John was known to many on both sides of the chamber. He was a senior parliamentary research officer, joining the Parliamentary Library in 1984 and remaining there for 10 years. John was an excellent research officer and he wrote several research background publications for general distribution to members and also to a wider audience. His Parliamentary Library background papers stood out, particularly his paper Women members of the Queensland parliament 1929-1994 , published in 1994 by the Parliamentary Library. The library produced an exhibition in association with this publication and at its opening all women members to that date were present, apart from the two who had passed away. I believe the Leader of the House would have been present at the exhibition in 1994. That was the year before I was elected. John’s paper was a very important record of the political history of the House and the chamber to date.

John was born in London in 1938 and moved to Australia with his parents when he was 12 years old. As a young man he worked at Bayards--and some of us will remember Bayards--as a shop assistant and managed to complete his senior through night school. John was a researcher with a special interest in the advancement of gender equity in politics and as part of his research into women in politics John identified the original petitions in Queensland that called for women to get the vote. It was an important piece of research.

John was awarded an Order of Australia Medal in January 2000 for service to youth, especially his 17 years of voluntary work for the Queensland and Australian Youth Hostels Association. In addition to his work on women and politics, John served as convenor of the Homelessness Taskforce 99. He was also a part-time researcher for St Vincent de Paul.

John co-convened with Mary Crawford the International Women in Politics conferences for many years in association with QUT and, as the Speaker outlined yesterday, he was scheduled to give the welcome address at the next conference to be held on 5 November as part of the Queensland parliament’s 150th celebrations. The word ‘progressive’ is bandied about constantly in political circles and its definition is widely argued, but to my mind John McCulloch was a true political progressive. He was a deep thinker, an activist and a doer. I extend my condolences and those of the government to the families of both Aussie and John.

Hon. AM BLIGH (South Brisbane--ALP) (Premier and Minister for the Arts) (9.43 am): The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures show that Queensland businesses are embracing research and development and, through that R&D, embracing innovation. From 2006-07 and 2008-09, Queensland companies increased their expenditure on R&D by $231 million to a total expenditure of more than $2.3 billion. That tells us that Queensland businesses see research and development as absolutely critical to their future.

Both the Queensland government and the Australian Industry Group could not agree more. That is why the government and the Australian Industry Group have joined forces to deliver a new grants program that aims to help businesses put their bright ideas into action. The program, which is an initiative of this year’s budget, is now developed and will be available. The program, titled ‘What’s Your Big Idea Queensland?’, is a $2.5 million pilot program designed to help individual companies innovate and invest in innovation or R&D to improve their performance and, in doing so, strengthen Queensland’s economy.

I want to thank the Ai Group for partnering with the government on this important project that is aimed at small to medium sized enterprises employing up to 200 people. One million dollars will be spent in the current financial year supporting businesses to introduce innovative new processes and systems and commercialise their new ideas. Businesses will be able to apply for up to $50,000 to access the expertise they need to put their ideas into action to grow their business. Applications for the program open today and will be judged by a panel of business and innovation experts, including Brett Godfrey, the former CEO of Virgin Blue; Arun Sharma, QUT’s Deputy Vice-Chancellor; Jim Walker, the CEO of QMI Solutions; and Kate Morrison, the principal of Vulture Street Consulting. I want to take this opportunity to acknowledge and thank our expert judging panel whose experience is highly valued not only by the government but also by the Ai Group.

‘What’s Your Big Idea Queensland?’ will bring together the business and research communities to develop and implement new products and services that can help make Queensland businesses even more productive and profitable. ‘What’s Your Big Idea Queensland?’ recognises that businesses are often best placed to come up with the bright ideas needed to boost the performance of their specific business. This program rewards innovators by providing the funds they need to turn their bright ideas into action. Applications are available on the government’s website and they close on 10 December 2010. I am sure there are a number of members on both sides of the chamber who know of small and medium sized business operators in their own area who would find this grants program very beneficial to their businesses. I encourage them to actively promote the program in their local areas.

Hon. PT LUCAS (Lytton--ALP) (Deputy Premier and Minister for Health) (9.47 am): Recently I had the opportunity to visit Beaudesert Hospital, along with the local member, Aidan McLindon. Together the member for Beaudesert and I met the staff, reviewed the facilities firsthand and discussed the critical issue of maternity services for the region--an issue of high importance to the local community. I would like to take this opportunity to acknowledge the continued commitment that the member for Beaudesert has had in advocating on behalf of the community, in particular for the return of maternity services to the hospital. I would also like to thank and acknowledge the staff at Beaudesert Hospital who play a vital role in the delivery of health services and who are to be commended for their continued hard work and dedication.

This recent visit has further firmed my view that the Beaudesert Hospital has an important role to play in servicing the health needs of the growing Scenic Rim community, as the member and others here know too well. Bringing back birthing services to Beaudesert is a complex issue and a matter that we are taking very seriously. I am committed to ensuring that the Beaudesert community, as a growing community, has access to safe and sustainable maternity services, including birthing. Already we have begun work in this space in an effort to provide a greater range of services and support to mothers and their newborns in the area.

At the last election this government committed to enhancing maternity services to support pregnant women in regional and rural Queensland, improving access to antenatal and postnatal care and, where possible, allowing pregnant women the opportunity to give birth within a closer proximity to home, which is of particular importance to Indigenous women wanting to give birth on country. This commitment included service enhancements of the existing antenatal clinics in the Logan-Jimboomba-Beaudesert area.

Already these service enhancements have seen additional antenatal and postnatal care for women in the Beaudesert community and outreach to the outlying community. A continuity of care model--midwifery group practice--commenced in May this year at Beaudesert Hospital. Midwifery-led continuity of care models use a primary healthcare philosophy. The Beaudesert midwifery group practice is enabling Beaudesert women to develop a meaningful and supportive relationship with the same midwife throughout pregnancy, birth and the postnatal period. I am extremely supportive of the midwifery-led continuity of care model that acknowledges that pregnancy health care is not solely about the birth of the child but the support and health care the woman receives through the pregnancy, including before, during and after birth.

The midwifery group practice is currently providing Beaudesert women access to the same midwife providing antenatal and postnatal services through the Beaudesert Hospital with birthing services at Logan Hospital. An Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health worker is also assisting to support this initiative.

From 1 July all women with low-risk pregnancies have been able to receive all pre and postnatal care at the Beaudesert Hospital, only having to travel to Logan for the actual physical delivery. However, as the member for Beaudesert knows, the community is calling for the further enhancement of these maternity services--the ability for low-risk birthing to occur at Beaudesert Hospital.

I would like to thank the member for Beaudesert for enabling a meeting between myself and members of the Beaudesert community where I was able to hear firsthand the importance of access to birthing at Beaudesert Hospital. I would also like to acknowledge the document presented to me by the senior group health services task force, a task force built of partnerships between residents, local service providers and the local government. I would like to thank a number of members of the Scenic Rim council who were there as well. I reiterate to the Beaudesert community that we are listening to you.
Mr Rickuss: Was John Brent there?

Mr LUCAS: No, John was not able to get there, but I acknowledge John’s strong interest in the area. Check your facts before you interject. He was not able to be there. But I am not going to put him in it. His deputy and others were there. I always say do not ask a question that you do not know the answer to. A project funded through the Rural Maternity Initiative was tasked with examining the feasibility of primary birthing services at Beaudesert for women not expected to have birthing complications. Queensland Health is now currently giving consideration to the safest and most appropriate manner to introduce birthing services at Beaudesert Hospital for low-risk birth, enhancing the midwifery-led continuity of care model.

While these efforts are underway, I wish to further reassure the House, especially the member for Beaudesert and the Beaudesert community, that the Bligh government remains absolutely committed to returning birthing services to Beaudesert as soon as possible. But we must always remember that the most important consideration is the safety of women, families and their babies and ensuring that we get this process right to provide the safest and most appropriate delivery of these services in the future. As I am sure the community would also agree, safety remains the key determinant in the timing and method of reintroducing services to Beaudesert. It is important that we look at all of these issues in full and that is why we are looking at when and how we can introduce these services over time.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development)
(9.52 am): In 2006 the then Beattie government proposed to apply a five per cent ethanol mandate across the fuel supply in Queensland. The mandate was proposed from 31 December this year. The Bligh government has conducted a full regulatory impact statement and public benefit test process, along with the publication of an exposure draft of proposed legislation. The exposure draft of the legislation did not mandate that all fuel would be required to contain ethanol. The mandate was to apply to only those retailers with 10 or more sites--that is, small business operators were excluded from the proposed mandate. The mandate as drafted does not require that regular unleaded petrol be removed from sale.

There has been a significant debate amongst key stakeholders about the mandate. It is accurate to say that the proposal’s merits and disadvantages are more finely balanced than other policy proposals. The public benefit test itself concluded the proposal to be essentially neutral. Many groups, including some ethanol producers, do not favour mandates. The Australian Lot Feeders’ Association, other primary producers and service station owner representatives do not support a mandate. The peak motoring group in Queensland does not support a mandate, with opposition also coming from boaties and the Queensland Historic Motoring Council. Cane growers are supportive, recognising the diversification benefits potentially available from an ethanol mandate.

The mandate was proposed at a time when taxation arrangements were settled firmly in favour of domestic ethanol. Under the current taxation regime the full 38 cents of federal fuel excise is effectively not applied to ethanol produced domestically. This provides an enormous advantage to domestic ethanol production and enables blended fuel to be sold marginally below regular unleaded prices. Since that time many changes--more mooted than implemented--have been advanced in relation to taxation arrangements for ethanol and other biofuels. As it stands today, domestic ethanol remains effectively free of federal excise, with a zero effective excise arrangement in place.

It has long been proposed--originally by the former federal government--to transition to introduce federal fuel excise on domestic ethanol. In the last federal budget a timetable was proposed to introduce excise on domestic ethanol. The proposed phase-in was set through to 2015. After the federal election a new timetable through to 2020 was proposed in correspondence underpinning the formation of the new federal government. Under the proposed arrangements the current 38 cent differential to the advantage of domestic ethanol will be progressively closed to nil by 2020, with both domestic and imported ethanol to be subject to an effective 12.5 cents per litre federal excise.

A discussion paper on these issues was issued by the federal government on 15 October 2010. Submissions on new taxation arrangements have been called for by 12 November 2010. Draft legislation is proposed in 2011. It is, of course, the case that passage of these changes will require support from both houses of the federal parliament. The already complex recent history of proposed new fuel excise arrangements, coupled with the reality of the structure of the new parliament, makes these matters far from settled. The potential here is clear. New federal taxation arrangements will reduce the competitive advantage of domestically produced ethanol. Given supply constraints in the market, there is a potential for the regional development goals of the policy to be frustrated by the mandate being met through imported ethanol. All of these uncertainties provide cause for caution.

The government has therefore resolved to suspend the implementation of the ethanol mandate. The initial suspension will be in place for at least 12 months. The government will be making a formal submission to the Commonwealth’s call for submissions. I table a copy of the Commonwealth’s taxation discussion paper.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Australian government discussion paper, dated October 2010, titled ‘Implementation of alternative fuels taxation policy’ [ 3452 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Our support for the ethanol industry has seen ethanol now form about 2.5 per cent of the total fuel supply in Queensland. The government itself--a large consumer of fuel--utilises around half a million litres of ethanol per month. It is worth noting in this context that, as the government fleet has been recalibrated to focus on greener cars, the uptake of diesel has formed a larger part of our fuel usage. Queensland government consumption has increased from 180,000 litres per month at the end of 2005 to 660,000 litres per month now. We are essentially half-way through to the proposed percentage without yet providing for it to be mandated. Some 550 service stations offer motorists the choice of an ethanol blend. We will continue to support development of all-important second generation technologies.

The government sought to advance the cause of ethanol as a cleaner fuel stock with regional development opportunities. The potential changes to taxation arrangements contained within the latest proposals do require careful consideration. The suspension being announced today does not derogate from our ongoing commitment to support increased use of renewable fuels. The policy path to securing such diversification does, however, require reconsideration.

The suspension of the ethanol mandate is a decision not taken lightly. It is, however, a decision that is in the public interest in the circumstances today. This government has not and will not shy away from making the tough policy decisions. I look forward to the debate which will ensue from today on how best to promote renewable fuels.

Hon. PG REEVES (Mansfield--ALP) (Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport)
(9.57 am): I would like to acknowledge in the gallery members of the Queensland Special Olympics team and their families. On behalf of everyone in the House, I welcome them here today. The Bligh government has placed a high priority on making Queenslanders Australia’s healthiest people. It invests more in sport and recreation than any other state or territory. We provide funding and deliver programs designed to maximise opportunities for all Queenslanders to lead a healthy and active lifestyle.

In line with this commitment, I announce today that we will support our Special Olympics athletes who are attending next year’s Special Olympics World Summer Games in Athens, Greece. We are fortunate to have some of those athletes here in the gallery today. I am proud to announce that we will support each individual athlete with the same financial assistance given to Queensland members of the Olympic, Paralympic and Commonwealth Games teams--that is, $5,400 per athlete.
Acclamation from the public gallery --

This will be a total of $175,000 to support the 31 athletes. As members can see, the athletes and their families did not know about it until the announcement just then. This funding will help the Queensland athletes meet costs such as travel, uniforms and training to attend and compete in Athens. I particularly thank the member for Sandgate, Vicky Darling, who brought to my attention the plight of these athletes with intellectual disability.

I would also like to acknowledge the attendance in the gallery today of Shaun McKee, a constituent of the member for Sandgate--I had the great pleasure to meet him and his carers--and his fellow athletes and families who will be absolutely delighted to receive this funding. We wish them all well on their journey and the best of luck in the competition. I would also like to acknowledge other members, including the member for Brisbane Central, for their representations.

The Bligh government is also providing $50,000 to Special Olympics Australia to assist with a range of activities including employing qualified trainers and coaches, training volunteers and raising awareness of disability. We are very happy to get behind these special Queenslanders and Special Olympics Australia, which does a great job in providing access to training and quality sporting opportunities for people with an intellectual disability.

On another matter, I am happy to announce the securing of a V8 round for Ipswich in 2011, to be held from 19 to 21 August. The arrangements were negotiated by the Queensland government via Queensland Events and the Ipswich City Council with the V8 Supercars. The announcement means that Queensland will host three rounds of V8 Supercars--Townsville, Gold Coast and Ipswich events.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations) (10.00 am): In 2011, for the first time in the history of Queensland’s public holiday legislation, Easter Monday and Anzac Day will fall on the same date--25 April. Both Easter Monday and Anzac Day are nominated as public holidays under the Holidays Act 1983. As the minister responsible for the administration of that act, I can designate a substitute public holiday for any of the public holidays listed.

In accordance with those provisions, I have decided--after considerable public consultation--that a substitute public holiday for Easter Monday will be observed on Tuesday, 26 April 2011. This means that Queenslanders will enjoy a rare five-day long weekend as a result of this once-in-a-generation clash of dates. This is the first time this has occurred in the three decades that we have had public holiday laws. These days represent two of the most significant religious and national events on our calendar, and the government firmly believes that the community should have the opportunity to celebrate both. However, this decision will not result in an extra public holiday. It is merely transferring a public holiday, which workers are entitled to, to the following day.

This decision is good news for workers, particularly those who are employed in occupations that tend to operate over holiday periods. Our decision means that employees working on either 25 or 26 April, or both, will get public holiday penalty rates according to their relevant award or agreement. This will not increase overall wages costs for employers because, as I have already said, the decision maintains the same number of public holidays as in 2010. This decision has been made after consultation and consideration of submissions from a range of stakeholders including unions, employer organisations, religious organisations and the RSL. It means that public holidays in Queensland for the 2011 Easter period will be: Good Friday on 22 April, Easter Saturday on 23 April, Anzac Day on 25 April, and a substitute public holiday for Easter Monday on Tuesday, 26 April.

Workers deserve a consistent number of public holidays each year to allow for rest, relaxation and celebration of significant religious and cultural events. The decision also ensures consistency with most of the other states and territories. These changes mean that the Anzac Day public holiday will remain on 25 April. The limitations on business operations that occur on Anzac Day because of its special nature will continue to apply.

As a Labor minister for industrial relations, I also want to express my condolences to the family of Aussie Vaughan, a stalwart of the Queensland union movement. Aussie was a humble, honest and honourable man, respected by workers, employers and governments alike. I salute his life’s work which was dedicated to improving the lives of Queenslanders.

Hon. KJ JONES (Ashgrove--ALP) (Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability) (10.03 am): Today I am pleased to release the Climate change in Queensland: what the signs are telling us 2010 report--the second in this publication series from the Queensland Climate Change Centre of Excellence. I seek leave to table this report.
Leave granted.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Publication titled ‘Climate Change in Queensland: What the Science is Telling us--Office of Climate Change, October 2010’ [ 3453 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: This edition expands on the previous 2008 report with more detailed information on the impacts of climate change in Queensland and on the implications for key sectors, together with suggestions on some of the adaptation options.

It draws on more than 220 peer reviewed climate science reports released over the last four years to describe what climate change will mean for Queensland’s environment, industries and communities. There have been a number of climate change reports published recently by national and international bodies. Whilst these reports are useful to give an overview of the climate change impacts expected globally and across Australia, the report I am releasing today provides a uniquely Queensland perspective.

The report tells us that Queensland is getting hotter, sea levels are expected to continue to rise and the impact of extreme weather events will increase. Of particular concern is advice that our iconic Great Barrier Reef will be impacted by increasing acidification and warming of the ocean due to more carbon in the atmosphere. This means greater threats to the unique corals of the reef because, as the water gets more acid, coral growth is reduced and as it warms it encourages the kind of algae which blocks essential light to coral.
Mr Messenger: The federal government will solve it all!
Ms JONES: It is our job to help Queenslanders prepare for and understand these changes in temperature, rainfall and extreme weather events.
Mr Lawlor interjected.

Ms JONES: I take the interjection of the member for Southport. This is why today, to coincide with the release of this report, all members of parliament will have the opportunity to hear from some of Australia’s top climate scientists about the latest research. I am very pleased to report to the House that more than 30 members of parliament from all sides of politics will be coming to the event today. I am not sure if the member for Burnett is coming, but I suggest he should.

Five members of the independent Climate Scientists Australia network, including Professor Ove Hoegh-Guldberg from the University of Queensland, will be here to answer MPs’ questions and to provide us, as decision makers and community representatives, with the facts about what climate change means for Queensland. The Bligh government is committed to providing current and accurate information to help all Queenslanders understand what climate change means for us and our communities. This informs our government’s commitment to investing in climate change programs.

While action at an international and national level is vital to combat climate change, the Bligh government is already helping Queenslanders to make a difference. We are already taking action to help communities adapt to climate change through our $196 million ClimateQ climate change strategy--a nationally recognised package of programs to help all sectors of the community reduce greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to climate change.

Hon. KL STRUTHERS (Algester--ALP) (Minister for Community Services and Housing and Minister for Women) (10.06 am): We know Queensland’s population is set to double within 50 years. That is why we made liveable and affordable communities a fundamental part of our response to the Queensland Growth Management Summit. We have a plan to keep housing affordable for people on low and middle incomes and we are taking action now. The member for Sunnybank knows that seniors and families in her area want an affordable place to live. And I have great news. We are turning almost 10 hectares of state owned land in Coopers Plains into a master planned urban village with a mix of affordable and social housing, shops and green spaces.

It means affordable homes for around 800 seniors, students, families and singles just 12 kilometres from the Brisbane CBD. This innovative development has train stations and buses within walking distance that connect it to the nearby Sunnybank and Garden City shopping centres, as well as the nearby Griffith University and the QEII Hospital. A key feature of this development will be safe, accessible and affordable homes for seniors.

We are working with a specialist design inquiry group, including the Council of the Ageing and others, to design and build high-tech homes for seniors. We are building modern, six-star energy efficient homes that are fully accessible for people with mobility issues. We will investigate the use of assistive technologies to help seniors live independently in their homes. Seniors will be just metres from public transport and other important services, making independence more manageable.

We are in the early planning stages, but we are determined to see this rolled out quickly to keep housing affordable and keep generating jobs for builders and tradies. By early next year we will be ready for expressions of interest from developers and by mid-next year we will start building. We have a strong policy for housing affordability in Queensland. Where is the policy from those opposite? I ask the question again: would the Coopers Plains housing development be on the chopping block of the LNP?

Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (10.08 am): These days people are constantly bombarded by all sorts of advertising, so to cut through all this you need to bring a product front and centre into people’s minds. You cannot rely simply on traditional media and that is why Tourism Queensland is pursuing innovations such as Facebook. Tourism Queensland’s Passport to Shine Facebook campaign--it has nothing to do with the member for Toowoomba North--which I launched in the UK earlier this month is making its mark around the world.

Since we launched the campaign in London two weeks ago, the number of connections on the Queensland Facebook page has climbed from 34,000 to more than 134,000 from 118 countries--with the highest number of entries coming from Australia, Taiwan, the US, Malaysia and the UK. As part of this campaign, Facebook’s 500 million users worldwide have the opportunity to win a Queensland holiday worth up to $100,000 for themselves and up to nine friends simply by entering their experiences into a virtual passport.

Passport to Shine is innovative because it attracts people from all over the world to the Queensland Facebook page and exposes them to our state’s great holiday experiences. By entering their details, Facebook users allow Tourism Queensland to talk to them about our state’s holiday options in the future. Special bonus prize weeks are taking place in the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Australia this week, where Facebook users who enter Passport to Shine will be in the running to win other Queensland holiday prizes as well.

While I was in the UK, I launched Tourism Queensland’s new brand, ‘Queensland--Where Australia Shines’, to an enthusiastic response. I also saw firsthand Tourism Queensland’s ongoing marketing work in the UK, where nearly $1 million worth of campaign activity is taking place in October, November and December. Tourism is a competitive industry across the world but Queensland is well served by its creative and innovative agency, Tourism Queensland. By staying ahead of the pack, we will keep attracting tourists to Queensland and protect tourism jobs through the good times and the bad.

Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (10.11 am): The Bligh government values and encourages multiculturalism in Queensland. We recognise the huge benefits that people from culturally diverse backgrounds can bring to our state. There was no better evidence of this than on Tuesday night when over 600 members of the Indian community, as well as members of the Ethnic Communities Council of Queensland and members of this parliament turned out to our own Speaker’s Green to celebrate the Festival of Light. The local Indian community makes a huge contribution to Queensland’s economic, cultural and social life, and only last month I presented the Indian community with a Queensland multicultural award at our annual multicultural ceremony.

We also recognise that people from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds face challenges when arriving in a new region. As we move towards the warmer weather, I am pleased to report to the parliament on the tremendous success of the Bligh government’s On the Same Wave program. In January this year, the tourism minister, the Minister for Sport and I announced $100,000 in funding towards a multicultural surf safety program. This program, which is run by Surf Live Saving Queensland, has resulted in more than 8,760 individuals receiving beach safety education talks, with 20,000 people being exposed to key messages through Surf Live Saving Queensland’s participation at festivals and public forums. Surf Live Saving Queensland has distributed more than 20,000 multilingual resources at these events and a further 10,000 have been distributed to other areas.

More than 100 classroom sessions have been conducted throughout South-East Queensland, Townsville and Cairns, but we are not stopping there. I am pleased to announce that Multicultural Affairs Queensland, in conjunction with Queensland Tourism and Surf Lifesaving Queensland, is planning a Multicultural Water Safety Forum on the Gold Coast on 7 December to increase the engagement of culturally and linguistically diverse communities in water safety messages. We want to ensure that there is a very clear message to all Queenslanders, especially those in our multicultural community, to ‘swim between the flags’.

Hon. D BOYLE (Cairns--ALP) (Minister for Local Government and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Partnerships) (10.13 am): Today I am pleased to announce $2 million in grants to show societies. This is good news for these show societies. It will ensure that these important local country events--even though they may be modest in size--can continue across Queensland, in cities and towns, small communities, far and wide. These grants are going to 129 agricultural show societies and the Rockhampton Regional Council--the only council to run a show--for events planned in 2010-11. Grants also support the Queensland Chamber of Agricultural Societies, which I have to say is ably managed by chief executive officer, Mark Bryant.

Each grant varies depending on the size and location of the event. The Isis Show Society, for example, will receive $5,000, the Hughenden Show Society will receive $8,130, the Herbert River Show Society will receive $21,372, and the Gold Coast Show Society will receive an injection of $69,844. Other grant beneficiaries include the Alpha Show Society, which is getting $6,213, and the Redcliffe Agricultural, Horticultural and Industrial Society, which will receive $29,726. I am today pleased to announce ahead of this weekend’s community cabinet that the Mount Isa Agricultural Show Society will receive $19,171. These grants may go towards running the show events or they may be applied to building and maintaining show related assets.

I am very pleased to report that the grants--however large or small--are recognised as important by organisers. Take, for example, the Sunshine Coast Show Society--last year’s grant helped it develop an agriculture education program. Then there is the Caves Progress and Agricultural Society just outside of Rockhampton, which used its grant to upgrade the cattle arena.

Annual shows are drawcards for communities. They bring old friends together as well as inspire some friendly competition. They also showcase to visitors the very rich and diverse contribution that primary industries and the agricultural sector continue to make to today’s Queensland. I take this opportunity to acknowledge the many workers behind the scenes--the show volunteers who work hard throughout the year right across Queensland to make sure the show goes on.

Hon. TS MULHERIN (Mackay--ALP) (Minister for Primary Industries, Fisheries and Rural and Regional Queensland) (10.16 am): Queensland scientists recently began a $930,000 three-year project to investigate a bacterial infection that has killed more than 80 giant Queensland gropers. Gropers can grow to over three metres in length and weigh in at more than 600 kilograms. They are one of the largest reef-dwelling fish in the world. This protected species is a popular tourist attraction along the North Queensland coast. Over the past few years, the bodies of these marine giants--some weighing nearly 200 kilograms--have been washed up on beaches from Weipa in Far North Queensland to Yeppoon on the Central Coast. These fish can live for a very long time. It is a sad sight to see these magnificent creatures floundering or dead in shallow waters on some of Queensland’s most popular beaches.

This research project aims to shed some light on the cause and spread of this bacterial infection which to date has been a mystery to scientists and marine biologists. Investigations into the deaths will focus on how gropers became infected with the bacteria and how it spreads between fish. Tests will be conducted to determine if the disease is spread by the gropers eating contaminated food, by fish-to-fish contact or by infected waters. This research will also benefit the Queensland aquaculture industry, as the tests will be used to help diagnose aquaculture fish kills.

The Queensland groper is an iconic species that holds a special place in the hearts of Queenslanders so it is important that we learn all we can about what is causing these deaths. Dr Rachel Bowater, a Biosecurity Queensland veterinarian, will lead a team of some of the best veterinarians, scientists and aquaculturists in Australia. She has carried out postmortems on some groper carcasses that have already been recovered. From the samples, she has determined that many are dying from bacterial septicaemia and meningitis. This emerging bacterial disease has also been found in marine fish and stingrays. The $930,000 in funding for this project is part of Fisheries Queensland’s commitment to protecting and preserving Queensland’s valuable fisheries resource.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.18 am): Tomorrow is World Teachers Day. It is a special day set aside each year to once again celebrate our great teachers and recognise their wonderful work. Today in the House on behalf of all members I would like to get in an early ‘thank you’ to every Queensland teacher for their hard work every day to give our kids a flying start in life. In Queensland we have more than 38,000 full-time teachers working in more than 1,230 state schools across the state, and we have many thousands of teachers in the quite considerable number of non-state schools in the Catholic and independent sectors.

While a teacher’s job can be very rewarding, the job of educating kids is a challenging one, particularly here in Queensland as we live in the most decentralised state in the country. More than half of Queensland state schools are in rural and remote communities and about 25 per cent of all state school students are enrolled at these schools. I would like to highlight the great work and dedication of our teachers working in those areas.

The Bligh government continues to support two scholarship programs designed to ensure children in rural, remote and Indigenous communities have access to quality education. The Bid O’Sullivan and the Pearl Duncan Teaching Scholarships encourage dedicated, quality teachers from diverse cultural backgrounds to work in rural and remote areas. Bid O’Sullivan was a teacher in a little bush school before the Second World War and in 1959 she pioneered the School of the Air in Cloncurry. Pearl Duncan became the first tertiary trained Aboriginal schoolteacher in Australia in 1951. These scholarships, valued at up to $20,000 each over four years, are open to students undertaking an education degree at a Queensland university. Applications are currently open for both scholarships and will close on 19 November.

The Bligh government is committed to ensuring all students, no matter where they live, have access to high quality education and training. Through these scholarship programs, aspiring teachers will be supported to obtain teaching qualifications and begin their rewarding careers in Queensland schools.

XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Amendments to Standing Rules and Orders
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. JC SPENCE (Sunnybank--ALP) (Leader of the House) (10.21 am), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the Standing Rules and Orders of the Legislative Assembly be amended:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • by replacing Schedule 2 of Standing Rules and Orders with the amendment circulated in my name; and
• that such amendment take effect upon the commencement of the Integrity Reform (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: Standing Order, Schedule 2 (Registers of Interests)--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Part 2A of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 establishes a statutory requirement for a Register of Members’ Interest and a Register of Related Persons’ Interest. This schedule to Standing Orders provides for the administrative arrangements for the registers and the particulars of interests that must be disclosed.1

The purpose of the Register of Members’ Interests is to place on the public record any pecuniary or other relevant interests of a member which may give rise to a conflict of interest or a perception of a conflict of interest between a member’s private interests and the public interest. The register seeks to provide information which might be thought by others to affect a member’s public duties, or to influence their speeches or votes in the Legislative Assembly.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. It is vital that in a representative democracy the public have confidence in the integrity of their elected representatives.
2. It is also vital that elected representatives be continually reminded that they exercise a public trust which should not be subject to any private interest.
3. It is also in the interests of elected representatives that they be able to demonstrate that at all times they have made scrupulous disclosure of their private interests.

4. The Legislative Assembly requires its members to demonstrate a commitment to maintain the highest possible standard of propriety and to avoid, or where required to disclose, register or declare, any potential conflict of interest.
5. The Register of Members’ Interests and Register of Related Persons’ Interests are mechanisms to encourage and foster transparency, accountability and openness.
6. The Register of Members’ Interests is a continually evolving primary record of members’ registrable interests as submitted by members under the Standing Orders.
7. The tabled Register of Members’ Interests gives public notification of members’ registrable interests as at the date of publication.

8. The following provisions are the minimum registration required by members and are not intended to be an exhaustive list of all possible financial arrangements which are required, in the spirit of the Standing Orders, to be registered.

1. In this schedule, unless the contrary intention appears--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: “calendar month” means a period commencing at the beginning of a day of one of the 12 months of the year and ending immediately before the beginning of the corresponding day of the next month or, if there is no such corresponding day, ending at the end of the next month;
“child”, in relation to a member, is defined by s.69A of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 ; 2
“Clerk” means the Clerk of the Parliament;
“Committee” means the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee;
“company” means a company, whether a private company or a public company;
“debenture” includes debenture stock, bonds, notes and any other document evidencing or acknowledging indebtedness of a company in respect of money that is deposited with or lent to the company;
“de facto partner”, in relation to a member, has the same meaning as s.32DA of the Acts Interpretation Act 1954 ;
“gift” means--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) the transfer of money, property or other benefit--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) without recompense; or
(ii) for a consideration substantially less than full consideration; or
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (b) a loan of money or property made on a permanent, or an indefinite, basis;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: but does not include upgraded travel provided by an airline;
“joint venture” means an undertaking carried on by two or more persons in common otherwise than as partners;
“member” means a member of the Legislative Assembly;
“month” means a calendar month;
“nominee company” means a company whose principal business is the business of holding marketable securities as a trustee or nominee;
“officer”, in relation to a company, means--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) director or secretary of the company; or
(b) any other person who is concerned, or takes part, in the management of the company;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: “partnership” includes a joint venture;
“private company” means a proprietary company, whether incorporated in Queensland or elsewhere;
“private superannuation fund” means a superannuation fund which meets the definition of a self-managed superannuation fund (SMSF) under the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (Cth);
“public company” means a company, other than a private company, whether incorporated in Queensland or elsewhere;
“Register” means the register defined by s.69A of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 ;3
“Registrar” means the Registrar of Members’ Interests;
“related person”, in relation to a member, is defined by s.69A of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 ;4
“ share ” means--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) a share in the share capital of a company;
(b) stock;
(c) a convertible note; or
(d) an option;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: “sitting day”, in relation to the Parliament, means a day on which the Parliament meets;

“sponsored travel or accommodation” means any travel undertaken, including accommodation incidental to the travel, or any accommodation benefit received, by the member or a related person in respect of which a contribution (whether in cash or kind) to the cost of the travel (including incidental accommodation) or the accommodation is made by a person other than the member or a related person but does not include:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) travel or accommodation received in an official capacity;
(b) upgraded travel provided by an airline, or upgraded accommodation;
(c) meals or sporting or cultural entertainment;

(d) a benefit received from a family member or family friend where the contribution made by the sponsor is received in a purely personal capacity, and there is no connection or possible conflict of interest between the member’s duties and the interest of the sponsor;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: “spouse”, in relation to a member, includes a de facto partner of a member;
“statement of interests” is defined by s.69A of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 ;5
“statement of interests (member)” see s.69B(1)(a) of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 ;6
“statement of interests (related persons)” see section s.69B(1)(b) of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 ;7
“trade or professional organisation” means a body (whether incorporated or unincorporated) of--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) employers or employees; or
(b) persons engaged in a profession, trade or other occupation;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: being a body the object, or an object, of which is the furtherance of its own professional, industrial or economic interests or those of any of its members;
“year” means a period of 12 months commencing on 1 January.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 2.(1) A person is taken to have a controlling interest in shares in a company if the person is able--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) to dispose of, or to exercise control over the disposal of, the shares; or
(b) where the shares are voting shares--to exercise, or to control the exercise of, any voting powers attached to the shares.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) The question whether a company is a subsidiary of another company is to be determined in the same manner as the question whether a corporation is a subsidiary of another corporation is determined for the purposes of the Corporations Law of Queensland.
(3) A reference in this schedule to the holding company of another company is a reference to a company of which that other company is a subsidiary.
3.(1) In this schedule, a reference to a form by number is a reference to the form so numbered in Part 6.
(2) Strict compliance with a form in Part 6 is not necessary and substantial compliance, or such compliance as the circumstances of a particular case allow, is sufficient.

4. In accordance with s.69C of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 , the Clerk is to be the Registrar of Members’ Interests and keep the register of members’ interests and the register of related persons’ interests up to date.8

5.(1) Members are required in accordance with s.69B(1) of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 to give to the Registrar statements of interests of the member and related persons within 1 month of taking their seat.9

(2) Members are required in accordance with s.69B(2) of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 to notify the Registrar within 1 month of any changes to their interest or the interests of related persons.10

(3) In addition to the requirements in s.69B of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 , each member shall within 1 month of the 30th day of June in each subsequent year during the life of that Parliament, provide to the Registrar a confirmation of correct particulars.

(5) The Committee may, by resolution, alter any forms for use under this schedule, and such forms are to be tabled in the Legislative Assembly by the Chairperson of the Committee within five sitting days.

7.(1) Nothing in this schedule shall require a member to specify: the number or monetary value of shares; the monetary value of investments or beneficial interests; the full street address of property; the financial amount of liabilities, donations or other income; the account number of, or financial amounts held in, savings or investment accounts; or the monetary value of assets, sponsored travel or accommodation, or gifts.
(2) A statement of interests required to be given by a member must contain the following details--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) in respect of any company in which the member or a related person is a shareholder or has a controlling interest in shares--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) the name of the company;
(ii) where the shareholding or interest constitutes a controlling interest in the company--the shareholdings of the company in any other company;
(iii) where the shareholding or interest is held in a private company, the investments or beneficial interests of the company; and
(iv) where the shareholding or interest is held in a private company that is the holding company of another company--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent4: (A) the investments or beneficial interests of the holding company;
(B) the name of any company that is a subsidiary of the holding company;
(C) the name of any company that is a subsidiary of any company that is the holding company’s subsidiary; and

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (b) in respect of any company of which the member or a related person is an officer--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) the name of the company;

(iii) the nature of the activities of the company;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (c) in respect of any family or business trust or nominee company in which the member or a related person holds a beneficial interest--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) the name or a description of the trust, or the name of the company, as the case requires;
(ii) the nature of the activities of the trust or company;
(iii) the nature of the interest; and
(iv) the investments or beneficial interests of the trust;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (d) in respect of any family or business trust in which the member or a related person is a trustee--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) the name or a description of the trust; and
(ii) the nature of the activities of the trust;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (e) in respect of any private superannuation fund in which the member or a related person is a trustee or director--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) the name or a description of the fund;
(ii) the nature of the activities of the fund;

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (h) in respect of any liability (excluding department store and credit card accounts) of the member or a related person or a trust of which a member or a related person is a beneficiary or a private company of which a member or a related person is a shareholder--

(b) if the name of the member has been disclosed to it--give the member the opportunity to be heard;
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: after which it must decide whether the matter should or should not be included by the member in the statement of interests concerned.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (4) The Registrar must immediately notify the member of the decision of the Committee.
(5) If the member informs the Committee in writing that they do not agree with the decision of the Committee, the Committee must--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) make a report to the Legislative Assembly; and
(b) with the report, recommend the action that should be taken in relation to the matter.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (6) A report under subclause (5)--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) must be made in general terms; and
(b) must not disclose the name of the Member.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (7) The Committee, both on its own initiative or upon the request of the Registrar, may produce and publish explanatory notes to further explain the requirements of this schedule and the information to be included in the Registers.
9.(1) The Registrar must keep, in such forms as the Registrar considers appropriate--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) a Register of Members’ Interests; and
(b) a Register of Related Persons’ Interests.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) As soon as practicable after receiving a statement of interests from a member, the Registrar must--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) in the case of a statement of interests (member)--enter in the Register of Members’ Interests the relevant details contained in the statement; and
(b) in the case of a statement of interests (related persons)--enter in the Register of Related Persons’ Interests the relevant details contained in the statement.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (3) As soon as practicable after receiving a notice of change of details under subclause 5(2), the Registrar must make such alteration to the details entered in the relevant Register as is necessary to reflect the change.
(4) As soon as practicable after a member resigns, dies or is removed from office during the course of a parliament, the Registrar must--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) in the case of the member--remove from the Register of Members’ Interests details of the member’s interests; and
(b) in the case of the member’s related persons--remove from the Register of Related Persons’ Interests details of the related persons’ interests.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (5) As soon as practicable after the dissolution of a parliament, the Registrar must--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) in the case of members of that parliament--remove from the Register of Members’ Interests details of all members’ interests; and
(b) in the case of the members’ related persons--remove from the Register of Related Persons’ Interests details of all related persons’ interests.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 10. The Registrar is to have the custody of--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) each Register;
(b) each statement of interests received by the Registrar under subclause 5(1);
(c) any notice of change of details received by the Registrar under subclause 5(2); and
(d) each confirmation of correct particulars received by the Registrar under subclause 5(3).

Hansard-Body-Small-Font.Hansard-Bold: Tabling of Register of Members’ Interests

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 11.(1) As soon as practicable after--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) the first sitting day of each Parliament; and

(b) the 30 th day of June in each subsequent year during the life of that Parliament; the Speaker must table in the Legislative Assembly a copy of the Register of Members’ Interests (“The Annual Report of the Register of Members’ Interests”).
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) The Annual Report of the Register of Members’ Interests is a copy of the Register of Member’s Interest as at a particular date specified in the report.

Hansard-Body-Small-Font.Hansard-Bold: Publishing of Register of Members’ Interests

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 12.(1) The Registrar is to ensure that a copy of the Annual Report of the Register of Members’ Interests is published on the Parliament’s internet website.

(2) The Registrar is to ensure that the Register of Members’ Interest, as updated from time to time, is published on the Parliament’s internet website as soon as practical after each update occurs and no later than one week after the latest update.

(3) The Registrar is to determine the form the publication on the Parliament’s internet website will be in, taking into account factors such as accessibility, transparency and administrative efficiency.

(4) The publication of the Register of Members’ Interest on the Parliament’s internet website and the Annual Report of the Register of Members’ Interests tabled in accordance with clause 11 above are deemed parliamentary records that the Legislative Assembly has authorised for publication.
13.(1) The Registrar must, at the request of a person, permit the person to inspect the Register of Members’ Interests during normal business hours of the office of the Clerk.
(2) The Registrar must, on request, make the Register of Related Persons’ Interests available to--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) the Speaker;
(b) the Premier;
(c) any other Leader in the Legislative Assembly of a political party;
(d) the Chairperson and members of the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee;
(e) the Crime and Misconduct Commission;
(f) the Auditor-General; and
(g) the Integrity Commissioner.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (3) The Registrar must, on request, make details removed from the registers in accordance with 9.(4) or 9.(5) available to--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) the Speaker;
(b) the Premier;
(c) any other Leader in the Legislative Assembly of a political party;
(d) the Chairperson and members of the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee;
(e) the Crime and Misconduct Commission;
(f) the Auditor-General; and
(g) the Integrity Commissioner.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (4) The Registrar must advise the relevant member or former member, in writing, that details removed from the registers have been inspected in accordance with 13.(3)(a)-(d), (f) or (g).
14.(1) A member may make an allegation against another member that the other member has failed to comply with the requirements relating to the registration of a matter.
(2) The allegation must be made, in writing, to the Registrar.
(3) The Registrar must--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) refer the allegation to the Committee; and
(b) give the details of the allegation to the member against whom the allegation is made.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 15.(1) The Committee must consider each allegation referred to it and, for that purpose, may--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) give each member concerned the opportunity to be heard; and
(b) obtain information from such other persons, and make such inquiries, as it thinks fit;
after which it may--
(c) make a report to the Legislative Assembly; and
(d) with the report, recommend the action that should be taken in relation to the matter.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) The Committee must not make a report unless--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) it has given the member against whom the allegation has been made the opportunity--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) to be heard; and
(ii) to make written submissions; and
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (b) it has given the persons that the member nominates the opportunity to be heard.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 16.(1) A person may make a complaint alleging that a member has failed to comply with the requirements relating to the registration of a matter.
(2) The complaint must be made, in writing, to the Registrar.

(3) The Registrar must, before taking any further action in relation to the complaint, inform the complainant in writing that parliamentary privilege does not extend to any communication between the complainant and the Registrar.
(4) The Registrar may require the complainant to give to the Registrar--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) details of the complainant’s name and address;
(b) details, or further details, of the complaint; and
(c) copies of any documents or other material available to the complainant supporting the complaint.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (5) The Registrar may refuse to take any further action in relation to the complaint if the complainant refuses or fails to comply with a requirement under subclause (4).
(6) If the Registrar believes on reasonable grounds that there is evidence to support an allegation the subject of the complaint, the Registrar must--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) refer the matter to the Committee; and
(b) give the details of the complaint to the member concerned.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 17.(1) Where a complaint is referred to it, the Committee--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) may request the member concerned to provide an explanation of the allegation the subject of the complaint; and
(b) must, if the member disputes the allegation--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: (i) give the member the opportunity to be heard;
(ii) give the persons that the member nominates the opportunity to be heard; and
(iii) obtain information from such other persons, and make such inquiries, as it thinks fit.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) The Committee must make a report to the Legislative Assembly in respect of the complaint--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) if the member concerned disputes the allegation the subject of the complaint--on completion of its consideration of the complaint;
(b) if the member confirms the allegation--on receiving notice to the effect; and
(c) if the member does not, within a reasonable period, respond to a request given to them under subclause (1)(a)--on the expiration of the period.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (3) The Committee must, with the report, recommend the action that should be taken in relation to the matter.
(4) The Committee must not, in the report, make a finding that is adverse to the member concerned unless it has given the member--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) full particulars of the complaint; and
(b) the opportunity to be heard in relation to the complaint.

Hansard-Body-Small-Font.Hansard-Bold: Effect of failure to comply with requirements

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 18. A member who--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) knowingly fails to give a statement of interests to the Registrar as required;
(b) knowingly fails to notify the Registrar of a change of details contained in a statement of interests; or
(c) breaches s.69B(4) of the Parliament of Queensland Act 2001 12
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: is guilty of a contempt of the Parliament and may be dealt with accordingly.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The following prescribed forms for the purpose of this schedule have been approved by the Legislative Assembly--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: Form 1 Statement of interests of a member
Form 2 Statement of interests of a member’s related person/s
Form 3 Change of details of member / member’s related person/s
Form 4 Confirmation of correct particulars.’
XML.Hansard-Body: Motion agreed to.
Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Commissioner Report
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP) (10.22 am): I lay upon the table of the House a report of the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Commissioner, Mr Gary Long SC, on the work and activities of the Crime and Misconduct Commission under chapter 11 of the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000. These activities relate to controlled operations carried out by the CMC in the exercise of its crime function. The parliamentary commissioner is required to inspect the CMC’s records at least annually to ascertain the extent of the CMC’s compliance with the controlled operations provisions.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Office of the Parliamentary Crime and Misconduct Commissioner: Report of the work and activities of the Crime and Misconduct Commission under chapter 11 of the Police Powers and Responsibilities Act 2000 [ 3454 ].
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Public Accounts and Public Works Committee
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WENDT (Ipswich West--ALP) (10.23 am): I lay upon the table of the House the Public Accounts and Public Works Committee’s discussion paper on its inquiry into Review of Auditor-General’s reports: remote council issues . Councils in remote areas of Queensland face unique challenges due to their location and low population base. This inquiry has been initiated in response to reviews conducted by the Auditor-General into the local government sector, including Aboriginal and island councils over a number of years which have identified a number of concerns.

The committee will consider topics such as financial sustainability, funding, accountability and governance, financial statements, consultants and financial controllers, bureau service provider and resource-sharing systems, Indigenous council champions, legislative compliance and non-traditional local government business.

The committee is seeking to actively involve remote communities and, to this end, it is now seeking public submissions from all interested parties on any aspect of the committee’s inquiry relevant to them. We encourage all members to consider and disseminate the discussion paper throughout their electorates. I commend the paper to the House.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper : Public Accounts and Public Works Committee: Discussion paper titled ‘Review of Auditor-General’s reports--remote council issues’, Discussion Paper, October 2010 [ 3455 ].
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SHINE (Toowoomba North--ALP) (10.24 am): As chair of the Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee, I table report No. 112, Review of Code of Ethical Standards . I commend the report and the committee’s recommendations to the House.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Integrity, Ethics and Parliamentary Privileges Committee: Report No. 112--Review of Code of Ethical Standards, October 2010 [ 3456 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr CRIPPS (Hinchinbrook--LNP) (10.24 am): I lay upon the table of the House a report pertaining to the 56th Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference attended on behalf of the Queensland branch of the CPA by me and the member for Toowoomba North from 10 to 19 September 2010.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Report of the 56th CPA conference Nairobi, Kenya on 10-19 September 2010 [ 3457 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MOORHEAD (Waterford--ALP) (10.24 am): In accordance with the notice given on 7 October, I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House notes report No. 4 of the Economic Development Committee.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WETTENHALL (Barron River--ALP) (10.25 am): I rise to support the motion to take note of the report moved by the member for Waterford. I take this opportunity to commend the member for Waterford as chair of that committee and also all of the members of the committee for producing that report. It is extremely important that the parliament keeps its focus on issues of road safety. A couple of the recommendations did catch my eye because they were issues that were raised at the Cairns Road Safety Summit, which I convened in November of last year in response to a dreadful period on the roads in Far North Queensland.

One of the issues that was raised and is reflected in one of the recommendations of the report is the idea of rewarding Queensland drivers for good behaviour. A constituent of mine, Mr Chris Wighton, raised that issue at the Road Safety Summit. It is interesting that it has been picked up in the report of the committee. I think that that is something that is certainly worthy of further consideration.

One of the other issues that was raised at the Road Safety Summit that is picked up in part in the report is the use to which revenues from fixed speed camera detected offences can be put. It is important to note that in Queensland the revenue from speed cameras over and above administrative costs must be used for road safety education awareness programs, road accident and injury rehabilitation programs, and road funding to improve the safety of state controlled roads. I think it is fair to say that there is a perception in some quarters in Queensland that revenue from camera detected offences goes into general revenue. I think there are some important recommendations in the report that are worthy of consideration about the further use to which revenue can be put.

Happily, as at 17 October this year, the Far North regional road toll is 15 fatalities fewer than it was at the same time last year. Whilst, of course, every road fatality is a tragedy, I am hopeful that this decrease represents a sustained turnaround from last year’s trend.
