In conclusion, I wish to again commend all of the members of the committee for producing a thoughtful and interesting report containing recommendations that I think are worthy of further consideration.
Motion agreed to.
Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (10.28 am): I give notice that I shall move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That subordinate legislation No. 294 of 2010, Urban Land Development Authority Amendment Regulation No. 5 of 2010, tabled in the House on 26 October 2010, be disallowed.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (10.28 am): I give notice that I will move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That this House notes that:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. Draft Wide Bay Burnett Regional Plan whose purpose is to control, manage and shape regional growth, has been released by this government.

2. The plan, if implemented in its current form, has the potential to destroy the thoughtful plans and hopes of many Burnett communities, including Coral Cove, Elliot Heads and Childers and make some ‘lucky’ people multimillionaires overnight.
3. The plan is managed and overseen by powerful state public servants who do not have to disclose their pecuniary interests, unlike democratically elected members of council and Parliament.
4. The plan will limit the power of local councillors to make transparent, honest decisions, regarding regional growth and increases the potential for corruption and maladministration.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: And calls on the Premier to scrap the draft plan, start again and negotiate a better more transparent and honest way to manage growth, with all the democratically elected local representatives in the Wide Bay-Burnett.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPEAKER: Before I call question time, I advise honourable members that in the House today we will be visited by St Paul’s Lutheran Primary School at Caboolture in the electorate of Pumicestone, The Caves State School in the electorate of Keppel and the Gowrie State School in the electorate of Condamine.

Mr LANGBROEK (10.30 am): My first question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to Labor Party bagman Brendan John McKennariey, who corruptly paid off a Labor minister right under the Premier’s nose. I ask: has the Premier sought assurances from her current Labor cabinet colleagues about any dealings they had with Mr McKennariey between 2001 and 2006? Will the Premier reveal what those assurances are?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the honourable member for the question. I think everybody would join with me in saying that the revelations that we have seen in the recent court case have been, frankly, sickening and appalling. The revelations that a former member of this House has been involved in something as deeply corrupt as this conviction indicates is a poor reflection on the person concerned and, frankly, shocking to those who worked in this chamber with him.

In response to the member’s question, I would refer him to the evidence brought forward in the court case on a number of occasions. One of the reasons the involvement of this gentleman with the former minister was entered into in such a secretive manner was that members of the Labor cabinet, predominantly the member for Rockhampton but others, had refused to deal with this gentleman and his company.
Mr Schwarten: And criticised by you lot for doing it, I was.

Ms BLIGH: I take the interjection from the Minister for Public Works. As I recall, both the Minister for Public Works and the government were criticised at the time for refusing to deal with this company. In terms of any suggestion that there is any involvement, if members go and have a look at the court transcripts and the evidence brought forward by the CMC what they will--
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left, the Premier is answering to question that was put to her. The Premier has the call.
Ms BLIGH: The very reason for the secrecy and the cover-up between these parties was precisely that this government had taken the view that this was a company we did not want to do business with.

Mr LANGBROEK:
My second question without notice is also to the Premier. I refer the Premier to statements made in this House by her current education minister in 2005, at the height of when Gordon Nuttall was receiving corrupt payments from Brendan John McKennariey. The Premier’s cabinet colleague admitted that he had personally opened the office of Labor bagman Brendan John McKennariey and personally congratulated the bagman and wished him great success. What can the Premier tell us about this close relationship between her current education minister and Labor’s bagman?
Mr SPEAKER: I call the Premier.
Honourable members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order!
Both sides of the House, the Premier has the call.

Ms BLIGH: I refer to my previous answer on this issue. I make the point that, as I understand it, this business is in the electorate of the member that is referred to in the member’s question. As he would know, it is not unusual for members to be invited to open or be part of these sorts of businesses in their electorate. That does not mean, and nor does it provide any evidence, that there is any business between the member for Ferny Grove and this business in his electorate.

This government has been absolutely clear in its dealings on this issue. It is absolutely clear from the evidence produced not only in this trial but also in the previous trial. In fact, the charges on which Mr Nuttall was convicted in the previous instance were receiving secret commissions. One can only be convicted of that if the court is satisfied and the jury is satisfied on the evidence that they were secret. If the Leader of the Opposition is suggesting that they were not secret then he should be demanding a retrial. The government will not be.
Mr Wilson: Now ask me a question, you gutless wonders.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! You will have to withdraw.
Mr WILSON: I respectfully withdraw what I have just said. The truth is still the same--
Opposition members: Sit down!
Mr WILSON: They can ask me a question but they have not got the courage to do so.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! There are other provisions for the honourable minister to take up the grievance if he has one, and that is by way of personal explanation subsequently. But the language is unparliamentary. I call the honourable member for Mount Isa.

Mrs KIERNAN: My question without notice is to the Premier. Can the Premier please inform the House about the level of interest in this weekend’s community cabinet meeting in Mount Isa and Cloncurry in the mighty electorate of Mount Isa?

Ms BLIGH: I thank the mighty member for the mighty electorate of Mount Isa for the question. As anybody knows, Betty Kiernan is a very enthusiastic member for this extraordinary electorate. I thank her for her assistance in making sure that her constituents understand the opportunity they have to meet with ministers. In fact, the very first community cabinet that I chaired as Premier in 2007 was in Mount Isa. It is the last time that the whole cabinet was there.

At that time, ministers held 94 separate meetings with local groups and individuals. This weekend there will be 170 deputations. So the interest has almost doubled. I think it is a huge vote of confidence in this form of grassroots consultation. This number of deputations comes on a weekend when one of the biggest events of the year is being held in Mount Isa--the region’s most prestigious fishing competition, the Lake Moondarra Classic. There is $45,000 up for grabs to someone who can snag the specially tagged barra. I wish the competitors the best of luck. I am very pleased that, even with that sort of competition, we will still see people out for a very big community cabinet.

I think one of the questions we can ask ourselves this week is whether community cabinets are on the chopping block of the Leader of the Opposition. How would I know the answer to this question? On Tuesday the Leader of the Opposition revealed his cunning plan. He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I tell you what you do: you give me something that you want to know if--if I’ll assure that it’ll stay there and I’ll give you the answer about whether it will or not.
XML.Hansard-Body: That had an awfully familiar ring to it. I went back and looked in the history books and what did I find? During the investigations of the Fitzgerald inquiry former Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen was asked--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: What do you understand by the doctrine of the separation of powers?
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: He said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Well you tell me. And I’ll tell you whether you’re right or not.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is straight out of the National Party playbook. But there is one fundamental flaw in the cunning plan: he cannot answer these questions at a press conference unless he has a press conference. True to prediction, there was no press conference yesterday.

Like thousands around the world, I was saddened yesterday to hear of the death of Paul the psychic octopus. But we do not need Paul the psychic octopus to know that there will not be a press conference today, either. No, he will be back hiding under bed saying, ‘Don’t let them find me. I don’t want to answer any questions.’ He does not know what he would cut. In that environment, we know that he will cut everything.
Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to--

Mr Schwarten:
Ask me about McKennariey. I hope you do.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Minister.
Mr SPRINGBORG: You should have passed on your concerns to your mate. You obviously did not.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has the call to ask a question. Ask the question.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Those on my right will cease interjecting and the deputy leader will ask the question.
Mr Schwarten: You thought he was a great bloke.
Mr SPEAKER: I warn the honourable Minister for Public Works under standing order 253A(1). If there is a repeat, you will be out for 10 minutes.

Mr SPRINGBORG: Thank you, Mr Speaker. My question without notice is to the Premier. I refer to Labor Party bagman Brendan John McKennariey, who corruptly paid off a Labor minister right under the Premier’s nose. Will the Premier reveal if she has moved to establish what donations, gifts-in-kind or cash-for-access arrangements were made by Labor bagman Brendan John McKennariey or any of his businesses with the Labor Party or Labor MPs?
Mr Lucas: I thought we had a ruling on that.
Ms BLIGH: Mr Speaker, I thought we had a ruling about imputations in questions and I believe that question does have such an imputation. I would ask for your consideration.
Mr SPEAKER: Sure. Could I have a look at the question, please? I will ask the Clerk for advice as well.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I will ask the honourable member to rephrase the question. The objection is to the words ‘Labor Party bagman’. I think the objection is that the person is no such thing.

Mr SPRINGBORG: My question without notice is to the Premier. Will the Premier reveal if she has moved to establish what donations, gifts-in-kind or cash-for-access arrangements were made by Brendan John McKennariey or any of his businesses with the Labor Party or Labor MPs?
Ms BLIGH: This is a question from someone who says that his mentor in politics is Joh Bjelke-Petersen!
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Just resume your seat.
Mr Hobbs: Did he go to jail?
Mr SPEAKER: Those on my left will cease interjecting.
Government members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: I did not catch who yelled out although I was on my feet. I just did not catch who it was. I simply say to both sides of the House that the temperature is rising today. If you want me to rise up to the occasion with you, I certainly will. When I am on my feet respect it, or otherwise I will toss you. I call the Premier.

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I take the interjection that was made during that interchange where the question was asked, ‘Did Bjelke-Petersen go to jail?’ Of course we all know the answer is that, no, he did not. Why? Because you rorted the jury.
Opposition members interjected.

Ms BLIGH: You rorted the jury by another mentor of the member for Southern Downs. You could not get a more stark contrast. Under Labor when a minister lies and commits perjury, the jury is not rorted and they go to jail. What happened under the National Party? In order to keep the mentor of the member for Southern Downs out of jail, they had to rort the jury.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms BLIGH: Thank you, Mr Speaker. I make the point again that probably one of the biggest defenders of Mr McKennariey and his company is in fact the member for Southern Downs and the team that he led during the time that the member for Rockhampton was terminating the contract with them. The member for Rockhampton endured weeks and months of criticism from those opposite for what? Terminating a contract with Brendan McKennariey. Who were the great defenders?
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Ms BLIGH: When a minister like the Minister for Public Works sought to terminate a contract with this company, unsatisfied with the quality of the work and having deep concerns about them, what happened? Those opposite defended them, and they defended them week in and week out, month in and month out. I say this to all of those opposite: if you believe that there are matters that have not been investigated or there are matters which should come to the attention of the CMC, you have an obligation to refer it. Why is Gordon Nuttall in the situation he is today? Because our government referred the complaints to the CMC.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left!
Ms BLIGH: The matters were referred by the government to the CMC--the CMC set up by a Labor government to clean up the dirt that was left by the National Party.

Ms DARLING: My question without notice is to the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. Can the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health outline to this House how the Queensland Children’s Hospital will benefit sick Queensland kids and are there any risks to its continuation?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. Can I just note that today an Access Economics report notes that Queensland has recorded the highest value of definite health infrastructure projects across Australia totalling $5.7 billion. This was well above other states, with the second highest value recorded by Western Australia at $3.2 billion and followed by New South Wales at $2.5 billion. Across our forward estimates period our government is building $7.33 billion worth of health infrastructure--the largest health capital program in the nation which is creating 40,000 jobs. We know with those opposite that each and every project and every job is under threat from the cape to the Gold Coast and west to Mount Isa. We know about their secret plan to cut the building program, cut jobs and cut health services.

We have seen a lot of discussion and decision and announcements across the other side of the chamber. On policy we saw the Leader of the Opposition on 9 July last year saying, ‘We’ll be rolling out our policies.’ Then of course on 18 September this year in the Gold Coast Bulletin he said, ‘We’ve got a number of initiatives. I don’t count them in terms of notating them off, but there are numerous ones.’ So a year later we have heard nothing in relation to policy. Then of course we heard about reshuffles. On 15 January this year we heard about a clean out of shadow cabinet in the Gold Coast Bulletin . On 23 September this year he was planning a reshuffle. We have still got members sitting on the front bench who do not occupy positions. They are still sitting there in the back still silent. Yesterday of course when asked about particular programs he would cut, the Leader of the Opposition said, ‘I’ll tell you what I will do. You give me something you want to know if I’ll assure that it will stay there and I will give the answer about whether it will or not.’ One day later there was silence--except that he had the member for Caloundra yesterday getting up there and talking about the Children’s Hospital. The first opportunity after the Leader of the Opposition was put on the map and he said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The LNP will consider very closely its policy in relation to the Queensland Children’s Hospital but acknowledges the difficulty involved.
XML.Hansard-Body: So we see the member for Caloundra doing exactly what the Leader of the Opposition said they would not do. They cannot commit to it. I just say this: Douglas Adams said 42 was the secret to the universe. I say the number is 26, because everybody opposite knows that in a 26-day election campaign the Leader of the Opposition will blow up. They know it upstairs. You know it. He cannot last the 26 days. He will blow up as soon as he is put under scrutiny--and so will the member for Caloundra, as he did last time, and so will the member for Callide when he saw the member for Moggill do it as well.

Mr SEENEY: My question without notice is to the Premier, and I remind the Premier of the day that this parliament was recalled to exonerate the former member for Sandgate and I remind the Premier of the words that she said on that day when she seconded the motion to exonerate the former member for Sandgate when she said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... for those of us who have sat with him around a cabinet table and know him to be a decent man--a man of integrity ...
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: My question to the Premier is this: does the Premier now regret those words and will the Premier apologise for them?
XML.Hansard-Body: Ms BLIGH: I thank the member for the question. As is often the case with questions from the member for Callide, the question itself includes something which is not in fact true. What this parliament did when it met--
Opposition members interjected.
Ms BLIGH: It is tactically untrue.
Mr Seeney: What’s untrue? Do you forget recalling the parliament? Is that untrue? Did I just imagine it?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Callide! The Premier has the call.

Ms BLIGH: Of course this parliament met and it considered the matter. What it did not do is exonerate the then member for Sandgate. In fact, the parliamentary record, as I recall, will show that this parliament resolved to admonish him for his behaviour in an estimates committee. Subsequently, when further matters were drawn to the attention of the government they were sent to the CMC for investigation. If this had happened under the National Party, which is so revered by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, it would never have got to the CMC. It would have been actively covered up by the Premier.

Of course I recall the words that I said on that day. Do I regret them? Of course I do, because when I made them I had no idea of the sort of activities that this person was up to. As I outlined earlier, he is in jail because he has been convicted of receiving secret commissions. By definition--
Mr Hobbs: You legalised lying in this place.
Mr SPEAKER: That is unparliamentary. Withdraw it.
Mr HOBBS: I withdraw.

Ms BLIGH: By definition Mr Nuttall could not be in jail if it had not been produced in evidence that he had secretly covered up his activities. It is the secrecy of his activities that brought him into the problem that he is in. The very matter that has been considered by the privileges committee of this parliament is that he failed to declare when he should have declared. The courts have heard evidence now over the last couple of weeks of further cover-ups. This entire saga has come to pass because this was secret, it was covert, it was covered up by everybody involved in it. So did I know about it? No, I did not and, as I said yesterday, I am sickened and appalled that as people sat around a cabinet table, believing that they were sitting with someone genuine, they were being so deceived.

Mrs ATTWOOD: My question is to the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. Can the minister outline to the House how the Bligh government’s commitment to infrastructure is benefiting Queenslanders and are there any risks to its continuation?

Mr FRASER: I thank the member for Mount Ommaney for her question and for her support for this government to continue to put jobs into the Queensland economy through its commitment to funding a $17 billion building program--a $17 billion building program that is supporting 100,000 jobs around this state, 100,000 jobs that would not be there if this government had taken the decision to stop the building program, to turn up on work sites and turn off the bulldozers, to withdraw our support and to do what those opposite would have done and that is to cut the capital program. The risk to the capital program, the risk to the Queensland economy, the risk to jobs in the Queensland economy sits on the other side of the chamber.

Of course, what we have seen during this week is a number of recommendations on the economic recovery in this state. Today, we see in Access Economics’ investment monitor that investment--public and private--in Queensland is up. It was $31 billion higher in the last quarter--up to 20 per cent. Where is that on a year ago? It is $51 billion higher than it was a year go. That is up 38 per cent. Of all private investment around the nation, Queensland has had the second highest increase, with $124 billion of known investment. That is $100 billion ahead of the next placed state, Victoria--$100 billion ahead of where Victoria is. That is because of the economic policies that this government is pursuing.

But, of course, what we are seeing opposite is a commitment to engage in a capital ‘Kill Bill’--they would take out the sword to the capital program. The Leader of the Opposition has invited the media to participate with him in some sort of evil bingo where you get to nominate the projects that get knocked off. We know, of course, from this week that a tory is a tory, because if you look across the waters to the UK you see that they have just abolished as part of their cuts the Infrastructure Planning Commission. That would be a pursuit that the Leader of the Opposition would love, because he has abolished the shadow infrastructure and planning minister. After so long has he had the time to replace him? Of course he has. So instead of sitting under a desk with the thumb in, cuddling the teddy bear, it is about time he got around to appointing a shadow minister for infrastructure and planning. We know that while he has been sulking a few others have been sulking as well. A few of them have that old sinking feeling. The old déjà vu is coming back. They think they just might be, once again, ‘Flegging’ a dead horse. While they are ‘Flegging’ the dead horse over there, they have seen it happen to the member for Southern Downs, who could not explain the cuts. They have seen the Leader of the Opposition do it. Finally we know. On this side: jobs--100,000 jobs in a building program, a jobs target of 100,000, more than halfway to it, and on the other side, cuts to jobs, cuts to the capital program, cuts to public services. The choice is now clear.

Mr McARDLE: My question is the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health. I refer to seminars given by Queensland Health to various unions and staff on the contents of the latest Ernst and Young report into the payroll debacle. Is it correct that the report states that it may take up to three years to fix this diabolical payroll system?

Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for taking an interest in the Health payroll into the third day of this sitting week. It speaks volumes about their interest in relation to these matters. I make this point and I make this point quite clearly: I have indicated to people that we will release this report, as we have released all other reports, when it has been considered and has been the subject of consultation. Reports are aids to government--
Mr McArdle: It will take three years to fix it.
Mr SPEAKER: The member for Caloundra will cease interjecting.
Mr LUCAS: We have seen him here for 18 months and not one policy announced. So he certainly has not taken--

Mr McArdle:
Will it take three years to fix it?
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Mr LUCAS:
We will determine the correct course of action to undertake on the basis of the various advice that we receive. Some people have suggested previously that we should look at a new system. Others have suggested that we should look at the existing system and the like. All of these are matters that we will appropriately consider on the basis of the various feedback that we receive.

I have made it very clear that, although we have had significant improvements in the rollout of the payroll system thus far, we have further to go yet. I have repeatedly made it clear that it is not only a matter of stabilising the system--
Mr McArdle: Will a new system be made?
Mr SPEAKER: I now warn you under 253A(1). If there is a repeat, you will be out.

Mr LUCAS: I have repeatedly made it clear that we want to have the system stabilised and working effectively. I have also made it clear that I see the process of payroll as one of continuous improvement. We know that the previous system was not perfect. We know that there were overpayments with the previous system. This is about making sure that the new system is as accurate as possible as soon as possible, that it retains the benefits of personal service which we have rolled out in terms of that model, and also making sure we can do that in the longer term. We will continue to consult with the unions. Like all other reports, we are more than happy to release it in due course and that it be the subject of debate. The honourable member can do that and make whatever assertions he wants. I see the question of payroll, like any software, as being something of long-term and continued improvement over an indefinite period of time.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Department of Public Works, Backflow Unit
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WENDT: My question is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. Can the minister advise what it actually took to terminate the National Party established backflow unit within his department?

Mr SCHWARTEN: I thank the honourable member for his question. On 15 July 1996 BHF Australia Ltd, owned by Brendan McKennariey, submitted a proposal to the then director-general, Kevin Davies, to manage the backflow prevention program at a whole-of-government level. The rest, as they say, is history. Who is this Brendan McKennariey? Brendan McKennariey was then working for one Mick Veivers, who was the emergency services minister. That is who Brendan McKennariey is.
Ms Bligh: Was he a Labor minister?

Mr LUCAS: No, he was not a Labor minister. He was a tory minister. I always wondered what the connection was there. How could this great Labor bloke have ended up on the staff of a cabinet minister in the National Party? I still do not know the answer to that. But guess what else happened? There was a bloke called Graham Doyle, also a member of the Labor Party, who was pushed into this backflow unit over at the Department of Public Works when the tories were in, when Borbidge was in--when you were a cabinet minister in that government
Mr Lucas: Who was the director-general again?
Mr SCHWARTEN: Kevin Davies.
Mr Lucas: Oh, Kevin Davies--a National Party mate.

Mr SCHWARTEN: A National Party mate. He snookered this Doyle in there. When I got there, of course hail-fellow-well-met McKennariey wanted to have a drink over in the Strangers Bar and all the rest of it. I would not go near him with a barge pole.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Mr SCHWARTEN: There is no doubt about that. That is what I thought of him. He is scum. He is one of the lowest people I have ever met, and I told him so. And guess what? You asked the question. The honourable member who just interjected, the member for Callide, was the one who got up and asked the question in defence of McKennariey over that incident. I remember it very well. So do not come in here with your mealy-mouthed, high posturing and this nonsense because you gave these people a job, and when they were plundering over in the public works department on your watch I put an end to it. And guess who defended them? You did. You defended these people.

If we had not won government in 1998 this rort would have continued. It was a rort that went by McKennariey. McKennariey was actually sitting on a panel when his company was receiving work as a result of it. When I shut it down, I put it before the honourable member who was then in charge of the public works committee to find out whether there was any evidence whatsoever to convince people--which he had done to those opposite; he had convinced all of you people over there and that grub Mike Munro--that backflow killed people. You people stood up here and defended it and parroted it off in this chamber to protect a crook, grub and bully like him.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The honourable minister’s time has expired. Minister, the term ‘grub’ is unparliamentary. Please withdraw it.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I cannot think of a lower one, but I will withdraw it.
Mr SPEAKER: If you could withdraw it unconditionally that would be better for the whole parliament.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I withdraw.

Mrs STUCKEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology. I refer to documents revealing that over $2 million was spent on wages for two individuals working as consultants on the Health payroll project, a letter and contracts, which I now table.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: CorpTech Business Case Submission and Sole Offer Approval, Contractor Engagement document for Integration Tool (XI) (Specialist) [ 3458 ].
Tabled paper: CorpTech Resource Request Form for Vidulin Consulting [ 3459 ].
Tabled paper: Submission to the Associate Director-General regarding expenditure approval for re-engagement of two CorpTech contractors [ 3460 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Can the minister explain how Labor justifies paying consultants who have not delivered a fully functional computer system around $2,500 per day when Labor cannot get the pay right for nurses and other health workers?

Mr SCHWARTEN:
In relation to McKennariey, I would also like to say that--
Mrs Stuckey: That is not the question I asked.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I am getting these verified. Anything that you put up I get double-checked.
Mrs STUCKEY: I rise to a point of order. I find the minister’s words offensive. I ask him to withdraw
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, the member found the words offensive.
Mr SCHWARTEN: I withdraw it. Suffice it to say, if she told me that today was Thursday I would check the calendar. That is why I am having this checked.
Mr SPEAKER: Minister, please withdraw the words unconditionally.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I withdraw it. I am told that this is merely the contractors who are trying to get the system to operate, to fix the flaws in it, which we have given a commitment to doing--nothing more, nothing less. It is part of the competitive tendering system that we have.
Mr Stevens interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Member for Mermaid Beach, can you please cease interjecting.

Mr SCHWARTEN: You can come in here and defame these people if you like. I do not even know who they are. They are obviously contractors who have some expertise and they get paid the going rate. The suggestion you are making is that you would leave the thing unfixed, that some divine intervention will prevail and as a result it will be fixed. Of course you have to get contractors in to fix it. If you do not know that much I do not know what sort of a government you will make. I could get a fair idea, given your defence this morning of Brendan McKennariey. I have a fair idea, having seen what you did in relation to backflow, of just how crooked you lot would be if you ever got back into government. Just a couple of weeks ago the honourable member said that you should always take the lowest price. I think that is how McKennariey got the job.
Mrs STUCKEY: I rise to a point of order. I find the minister’s reference to me offensive. I ask him to withdraw.
Government members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The member finds it offensive.

Mr SCHWARTEN: I withdraw. The competitive process that I talk about when we got SAP and all those involved in it did not prevail in McKennariey’s deals, of course. Just lowest price did there. They just worked out how to get free money out of workers in this state. As far as I am concerned, that is the lowest thing I can think of that any Labor minister or any Labor person could do. What he actually did was recycle money into the pockets of Nuttall and McKennariey out of workplace health and safety. In reality, we get an indication from those who sit opposite today when they talk about this payroll matter. What would they have us do? Leave the thing just sit there? Don’t fix it?
Opposition members interjected.
Mr Nicholls: What did the Auditor-General say you should do?
Mr SCHWARTEN: The Auditor-General said that it should be fixed. That is exactly what we did. Presumably, given the date on this, he was aware of this document and this process.

Mr O’BRIEN: My question without notice is to the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services. Can the minister advise the House how the recent graduation of police recruits is benefiting Queensland, and are there any risks to its continuation?

Mr ROBERTS: I thank the member for his question and for his support of the Queensland Police Service. Last Friday I had the pleasure of being at a police graduation, where 45 new recruits were inducted into the service. Four of those recruits are going into the member’s electorate in the Cairns area and others will be spread across the state. To list them, there will be four into Rockhampton, eight into Metro North, three into Oxley, four into South Brisbane, two into Wynnum, eight into the Sunshine Coast, six into the south-east, one into Roma and five into the Toowoomba district. This will take the Police Service strength to around 10,500 police officers.

This government went to the election with a commitment to increase police numbers by around 600 over this term. What is the policy of the LNP on this issue and what is at risk if it gets into government? Yesterday or the day before we saw the Leader of the Opposition stand and tell the people of Queensland through the media that he was going to tell us what will stay and what will go. If he has any guts as a leader he will stand up now and tell us what will stay and what will go, particularly in the police and emergency services portfolio.

Everybody knows that there is going to be a change in the leadership of the Liberal National Party. It is common knowledge. They are all talking about it. Next week, as we know, is the Melbourne Cup. If you were a betting person you would have a dollar quinella on the odds-on favourite, the Nicholls-Gibson team, but there is a roughie--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order!

Mr ROBERTS: Have a dollar on the Nicholls-Gibson team, but there is an old horse in the stable that you should have a roughie bet on: the member for Southern Downs. He is waiting to come down the straight at the last minute and knock him off. Then there is the dark horse, of course: the member for Hinchinbrook.

The LNP went to the last election with a promise to cut 12,000 jobs from the public sector and $1 billion a year out of department budgets. That is absolutely consistent with what the Liberals are doing in Western Australia and absolutely consistent with what the Liberal Kennett government did in Victoria many years ago and what the UK government, the epitome of the Liberal Party, is doing now. That is what the opposition will deliver if it ever gets into government in this state.

Mr NICHOLLS: My question is to the Minister for Health. When serious instances of workplace bullying and intimidation were alleged last week by Mr Alan McGraw, the person appointed to fix the botched Queensland Health payroll system, did the minister think it was appropriate that his director-general could dismiss the allegations of bullying within hours of the claims surfacing and without a thorough and proper investigation?
Mr LUCAS: I thank the honourable member for the question. You have the letter in front of you. Read out what instances he alleges.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Direct your comments through the chair.
Opposition members interjected.

Mr LUCAS:
The letter alleges no instances. You are not even capable of reading a letter.
Mr SPEAKER: Through the chair.

Mr LUCAS: It alleges no instances, Mr Speaker. What it said was that requiring him and his team, in his opinion, to adhere to what he was required to do could constitute that--not ‘This is what happened.’ But of course, having the letter, the honourable member would not actually want to say what the letter says. It does not allege one instance. In fact, if you are a senior manager in Queensland Health and you are party to that, it is incumbent upon you to act on it. That is why it does not allege it. We treat it very, very seriously. It is very easy for my director-general to dismiss that when there is no allegation of a specific instance made in that letter and, as far as I am aware, none that the manager in question ever referred for action. So I thank the member for Clayfield for being typically uninformed on these issues.

I thought it might be worthwhile to have a little trip down memory lane in relation to some of the matters of conduct of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and his mates in the past. I can remember--maybe some people here can or cannot--the relationship between the Police Service and the judiciary--good old Eric Pratt and others--

Mr SEENEY: Mr Speaker, I rise to a point of order. I refer you to standing order 118 and the issue of relevance. The minister was asked about an issue within his Health portfolio. We all know he hates being health minister.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! You are debating the point of order.
Mr SEENEY: My point of order is that this minister’s answer is totally irrelevant and I ask you to rule accordingly.
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable the minister, I am listening to your reply.

Mr LUCAS: One thing to know about the member for Callide is that the more you get under his skin, the more you hit him, the more he gets up and complains. He is the classic school bully. If anyone was ever characterised as a bully, it is the member for Callide. The more that he reacts, the more he shows that you get under his skin. Yesterday, when it came to the remarkable performance from the Leader of the Opposition, the member for Callide was at high noon.

We remember the Mundingburra MOU when the Deputy Leader of the Opposition was around the cabinet table when they did a deal with the Police Union to scuttle the CMC. We remember Connolly-Ryan. We remember when former Liberal member of parliament Peter Connolly said, ‘We’ll see how their little experiment of the CJC goes,’ in the light of what he was doing and got struck off for ostensible bias in the Supreme Court. There is one side of politics that has the runs on the board. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition knew everything about Joh when he came in here and called him his mentor. He knew he had faced a perjury charge when he called him a mentor.

I say this about Nuttall: he ought to be condemned. He sickens me. He has devalued the name of my party membership and he should stand condemned for that forever. On the other hand, you defend those sorts of people. You take them on board.

Mr PITT: My question without notice is to the Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs. Will the minister outline to the House how funding from her department is benefiting Queenslanders and are there any risks to its continuation?

Ms PALASZCZUK: I thank the honourable member very much for his question. Of course we all know that this government is investing record funding into disability services--$1.6 billion in disability services and home and community care services right across this state. Today I am also pleased to announce that we have allocated the $40 million for young people with a disability leaving school for the next financial year. As part of that, we allocated an additional $4 million to help approximately an extra 300 school leavers right across this state. This funding is benefiting young people with a disability who are leaving school to gain opportunities in employment, in education and in training. It is being utilised in every seat right across this state. So not only do members of this side benefit but members of that side benefit as well.

I am very concerned. I am very concerned about what could happen if the other side got into power. We have seen what has happened in other parts of Australia and also in other parts of the world. I was very disturbed to see that in the UK recently the first thing to get cut when the opposition gets into power is those services that protect the most vulnerable in our community.
Opposition members interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Those on my left will cease interjecting.
Ms PALASZCZUK: That is in relation to disability services. So what did they do in the UK? Listen to this, Mr Speaker. ‘Charities also say cuts to council--
Opposition members interjected.
Ms PALASZCZUK: They do not want to hear it.
Mr Johnson: Who created it?
Ms PALASZCZUK: Show some respect for what they say.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Gregory will cease interjecting.

Ms PALASZCZUK: ‘Charities also say cuts to council budgets and social housing provision will disproportionately affect disabled people, while benefit reform may damage the chances of people getting back to work. Services like transport for children with special educational needs may also face cuts.’ $2 billion of services in the UK were cut.

What essential services are here? There are essential services for people with a disability right across the state. What would you cut? In the member for Coomera’s electorate there is $3 million for a brand-new centre, moving young people with a disability out of residential aged care. Would you cut that? In the member for Bundaberg’s electorate there is a new autism service. Are you going to cut that?
Opposition members interjected.

Mr SPEAKER: Order! Just resume your seat, Minister. Those on my left will cease interjecting. It is impossible to hear. I understand that there is provocation in the way the minister is going. It is impossible to hear. The honourable the minister.
Ms PALASZCZUK: They do not want to hear it, Mr Speaker.
Mr Dempsey interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: I warn the member for Bundaberg.
Ms PALASZCZUK: Services for children with a disability would be cut--$1 million in Bundaberg.

Mr SPEAKER: Stop the clock. Minister, resume your seat. I will deal with this matter. I warn the member for Bundaberg under standing order 253A(1). The honourable the minister, direct your comments through the chair.

Ms PALASZCZUK: Mr Speaker, in Maroochydore we are putting more funding into the YPIRAC program, moving young people with a disability out of aged-care residential facilities. Would that be cut if those opposite came into power? What else are we doing? Right across this state we are investing in disability services. In Hervey Bay there is a new all-abilities playground. Would you cut that? There is new housing in Ingham for ageing carers of children with a disability.
Mr Cripps: Don’t talk about Ingham and that housing project--$1 million cut!
Ms PALASZCZUK: No, no. We are funding that. It is very clear.
Mr Cripps: The minister for communities dropped that project.
Ms PALASZCZUK: While we continue to enhance services, all they want to do is cut.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The minister’s time has expired. The member for Hinchinbrook will cease interjecting.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Premier. Will Queensland voters be given a say about any proposed changes to electoral laws at a referendum, as is the case in New South Wales? Or will Queenslanders be denied a say, with Queensland Labor prepared to change the laws before the next election in a blatant and cynical attempt to cling to power?
Mr SPEAKER: Order! I would like to see the wording of that question because I think there is an imputation in there. Can you rephrase it because the last bit does contain an imputation.

Mr CRIPPS: My question without notice is to the Premier. Will Queensland voters be given a say about any proposed changes to electoral laws at a referendum, as is the case in New South Wales? Or will Queenslanders be denied a say, with Queensland Labor prepared to change the laws before the next election in an attempt to cling to power?
Ms BLIGH: I am sorry if the honourable member has not been listening to the debate which has proceeded about this matter this week.
A government member interjected.
Ms BLIGH: Did he speak in it?
Mr Robertson: He voted in it.
Ms BLIGH: He certainly voted in it.
Ms Boyle: It doesn’t mean he listened to anybody else.
Ms BLIGH: If he had paid any attention, he would know that the government has sought advice through the Attorney-General about matters pertaining to this issue. The government has not--
An opposition member interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: The honourable the Premier has the call.
Ms BLIGH: The government has not received that advice, has not formed a view on the issue and has made--
Opposition members interjected.
Ms BLIGH: And when we do form a view and make a decision, then those are the sorts of issues we will include in our deliberations.
Mr FINN: My question without notice is to the Minister for Transport. Can the minister outline to the House how Cross River Rail will benefit Queenslanders? Are there any risks to its continuation?

Ms NOLAN: I will. I thank the honourable member for the question. Cross River Rail is an enormously significant public transport project for all of South-East Queensland. It will very significantly expand the capacity of the rail network, particularly on the Gold Coast line and across the Merivale Street bridge and through the middle of Brisbane, where capacity constraints are emerging. It will give Brisbane for the first time an underground rail network, like the metros of the world cities that Brisbane aspires to be.

It is an enormous project which is 100 per cent supported by this government, which is doing the planning work in partnership with the federal government. I would have thought that all political leaders would support such a critical project for our public transport future. Indeed, I thought we were getting that support. Just a few weeks ago, the Leader of the Opposition indicated that it was his view that it was the highest priority project for South-East Queensland--albeit, when he said it, he was ‘backdooring’ the member for Maroochydore on the way through because he was comparing it to the Redcliffe rail project which she has put on a slightly higher platform. Unfortunately, the Lord Mayor of Brisbane seems to hold a different view. On Saturday, in what Channel 9 described as ‘a savage attack’, the Lord Mayor launched into Cross River Rail, describing the project as too expensive and as destroying character housing on the south side of Brisbane.

So I think the question for this House is: what is the real LNP position on this project? The member for Maroochydore seems to think it lies somewhere behind Redcliffe rail. Her leader, the Leader of the Opposition, has described it quite unequivocally as the highest priority project for the south-east. But down at City Hall, the Lord Mayor has described it as too expensive in ‘a savage attack’ and as destroying character housing.

The question for us is: will the Leader of the Opposition stand up to the Lord Mayor on this one? Does he really think this is so critical that he should in fact assume a leadership position within his party? Or will his leadership be wavering and unpredictable, as has so often been the case? The Leader of the Opposition has an obligation to the people of South-East Queensland to seek to bring the Lord Mayor into line over this one and to stand up for what is best for all of South-East Queensland.

Mr FOLEY: My question without notice is to the Minister for Main Roads. The Cooroy to Curra section of the Bruce Highway remains a constant frustration with the speed being limited to 90 kilometres an hour. I asked a question in parliament on 25 November 2009 as to whether there have been any demonstrable decreases in statistics; it is my understanding there has not. Will the minister, in light of those statistics, consider reinstating it to 100 kilometres an hour?

Mr WALLACE: I thank the member for Maryborough for the question, and the short answer is, yes, we will look at that suggestion. I want to thank him for constantly keeping me informed about what is happening on that section of road. As he and other members of the House would know--the member for Gympie would certainly know--that section of road was rated as the most dangerous section of the Bruce Highway in Queensland, indeed one of the most dangerous sections of road in Australia. That is why I welcomed that funding commitment from the Labor government in Canberra, which we have joined--over $600 million on that first section of road to do Cooroy to Curra.

I do not make the decisions in terms of safety and the speed limits. That is a decision made by engineers in my department, the department of transport, and we work very, very closely with the Queensland Police Service. There have been a number of serious accidents on that section of road, and that is why the decision was made to reduce speed limits by 10 kilometres in late 2008 but we will certainly take that suggestion on board. The other thing we have done on that section of road--and the member for Maryborough would certainly be aware of this--is that we have installed six VMS signs to help motorists through that section of road if there is congestion or an accident.

How did the Bruce Highway get to this state? It was caused by chronic underfunding of the Bruce Highway by the Howard government for over a decade. Let us look at the record of the Howard government. It provided $825 million for the Bruce Highway in its last five years--compare that to Labor’s $2.6 billion for the Bruce Highway. That is why I was so gobsmacked last week when I was told by my department that a Queensland Liberal senator--Senator Ian Macdonald--phoned a Main Roads staffer not once but twice to complain about roadworks on the Bruce Highway rolling out around Townsville. He told the staffer he was having a bad day and he wanted her to have one too. Shame on him! As the Treasurer has said and as we say: a tory is a tory, they don’t change their spots. They will attack roadworkers across the state. They will attack roadworkers trying to fix up the Bruce Highway after a decade of neglect by the Howard government.

I will come into this place and I will defend roadworkers day after day. I say to Senator Ian Macdonald: you are lower than a snake’s belly for attacking my roadworkers. These are good men and women who are trying to fix up the mess on the roads--just like at Cooroy to Curra and just like those sections south of Townsville. I make no apologies for what we are doing on the roads across Queensland. We will work with Labor in Canberra to fix up Cooroy to Curra and we will work with Labor in Canberra to fix up the roads across this state.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! Minister, the expression you used was unparliamentary.
Mr WALLACE: I withdraw.

Ms JARRATT: My question is to the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning. The state government allocated $7 million to upgrade and refurbish the Whitsunday Airport. This is a vital project for the tourism industry in my electorate which will bring an enormous economic benefit. Can the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning outline to the House how this investment is benefiting Queenslanders and if there are any risks to its continuation?
Mr SPEAKER: You have two minutes.

Mr HINCHLIFFE: I would like to thank the member for Whitsunday for a question. She has been an avid campaigner for this. This was an election commitment made by the Bligh government during the election campaign and this is evidence of us delivering--delivering on jobs, not cuts.

I am pleased to advise the whole of the House that not only has the successful tenderer for the refurbishment and extension been selected, that is TF Woollam and Son Pty Ltd, but also the contractor’s works have begun. They are underway. This is yet another great example of the Bligh government standing up for jobs, not cuts, in our regions. Our priority has always been to protect jobs to build a stronger Queensland economy, and here we are delivering for the Whitsunday region, delivering for the tourism industry, delivering for Queenslanders.

As I said, the contract for the upgrade works has been awarded to TF Woollam and Son. They bring 20 construction jobs and abundant opportunities to local businesses. I encourage local businesses in the region to get on board and look to what they can do to be part of the story about delivering this $7 million renovation. It is obviously a great investment in the region and we will see flow-on benefits for the whole of the tourism industry for decades to come.

This is clearly evidence of our commitment to delivering what we committed to--to delivering jobs, not cuts. There is $17.1 billion in our infrastructure program this year alone on top of $18 billion last year and $16 billion the year before. This shows that we have an economic plan that is about delivering for Queensland--delivering jobs, delivering to our regions--and ensuring that we take the response that was required to the global financial circumstances in which we found ourselves. What is the alternative? We could go through a pick-a-box process with the Leader of the Opposition to find out whether this or that is going to be cut.
Ms Simpson interjected.
Mr HINCHLIFFE: There is ‘Ms Asterisk’. I cannot believe that I have been interjected on about a funding commitment from ‘Ms Asterisk’.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Further Answer to Question; Queensland Health, Payroll System
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (11.31 am), by leave: I have now had an opportunity to peruse all of the documents that were tabled here this morning and to expose the fraudulent nature of the question.
An opposition member: Ooh!
Mr SCHWARTEN: Is there something wrong with you? I am sure there is, making a noise like that. You ought to get to a doctor, man.
Mr Hobbs: What’s wrong with you? You should go to the doctor.
Mr Springborg: I could go with you. We could get bulk rates.
Mr SCHWARTEN: There is enough for a seminar of psychiatrists in you.
Mr SPEAKER: Those on my left will cease interjecting. Let us get through the ministerial statement.

Mr SCHWARTEN: As I say, I can now expose the fraudulent nature of the question. The suggestion in the question was that while nurses were not getting paid these people were. The reality is that the documents explain the need to continue an arrangement--a contract--for two individuals who were involved in the implementation of the program. Why? The answer is that the program did not go live in December 2009; it went live in March 2010, which is a well-known fact. Why did it not go live in 2009? Because it was not ready to go live. That was the advice to the state.
An opposition member interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: It did not go live in December 2009 because they said that it was not ready to go.
An opposition member: It’s still not alive.
Mr SCHWARTEN: It is much more alive than you.
An opposition member interjected.
Mr SCHWARTEN: If I can just continue, please. An allegation has been made about these contractors basically rorting it. That is the allegation, that these people--
Mrs Stuckey interjected.
Mr Nicholls: There was no such allegation.
Mr SCHWARTEN: The allegation was that these people were being paid while nurses were not, and that is not correct.
Mrs Stuckey: Correct.
Mr SCHWARTEN: That is not correct.
Mrs Stuckey interjected.
Mr SPEAKER: Order! The member for Currumbin will cease interjecting.

Mr SCHWARTEN: These people were employed to continue the contract when the go-live date was moved from December to March. For them not to be employed would have meant that whatever changes had to be made to the system could not be made. So the Associate Director-General, Natalie MacDonald, signed off on 8 December on the contract being re-extended. That is all the matter relates to. It is simply a matter of identifying that the project was going to go on longer. Therefore, the costs were going to be more and, as a result, these people would have to be paid. I do not set the rates at which these people get paid. That is a matter for the market. There is nothing untoward whatsoever in that matter.
Resumed from 27 October (see p. 3965).
Mrs MENKENS (11.35 am): I move the following amendment--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: 5 Clause 6 (Amendment of s 9 (Obligation of public authorities to consider carers charter))

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: ‘(1) Section 9, after ‘charter’--
(2) Section 9(1)(b) and (2), after ‘carers’--
(3) Section 9(2)--
(4) Section 9--

‘(2) A public authority, to the extent its internal human resources policies may significantly affect an employee in carrying out the employee’s role as a carer or grandparent carer, must ensure the policies are developed taking into consideration the principles of the carers charter and the grandparent carers charter.’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: This amendment deletes clause 6 and replaces it with a proposed new section to add grandparent carers to section 9, ‘Obligation of public authorities to consider carers charter’. It adds a new subclause, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (2) A public authority, to the extent its internal human resources policies may significantly affect an employee in carrying out the employee’s role as a carer or grandparent carer, must ensure the policies are developed taking into consideration the principles of the carers charter and the grandparent carers charter.
XML.Hansard-Body: This amendment seeks to include the Grandparent Carers Charter in addition to the Carers Charter. The addition is to ensure that both charters have a role in policy making. It is intended to give them a greater priority than a simple tool of recognition. It is a follow-through of the intended process relating to all the amendments that the grandparents charter is acknowledged alongside the Carers Charter in all of these particularly significant parts.

Ms PALASZCZUK: The government will be opposing the opposition’s amendments. The amendments proposed to this clause as suggested by the member for Burdekin would reflect the separate recognition of the grandparent carers charter that would, in addition to the Queensland Carers Charter, have to be taken into consideration by public authorities and human resource policies and reflect the separate recognition of grandparent carers.

In response to that, I say that currently under the existing act public authorities must ensure they consult with representative bodies when making strategic policy or planning decisions relevant to carers and the people they care for. The government bill adds an additional obligation providing that public authorities must ensure that human resource policies are developed taking into consideration the Queensland Carers Charter.

Mrs MENKENS: I thank the minister for that comment. I would like to pose a question to the minister. Will that include the grandparent carers as well? Will they be given the opportunity to be part of this as well? I appreciate it is the Carers Charter. However, how much significance will the grandparents be given in the government’s bill as well as the carers?
Ms PALASZCZUK: All of the above. Yes, they will be taken into consideration.
Mrs MENKENS (11.39 am): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: ‘(c) be accompanied by a report detailing all consultation undertaken for each strategic policy or planning decision in compliance with section 9(3).’.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (2) Section 10(3), definition annual report --
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent2: ‘ annual report see the Financial Accountability Act 2009 , schedule 3.’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Amendment 6 deletes clause 7 and replaces it. With this amendment, section 10, ‘Reporting obligations’, will have an additional provision, that is, that a report under this section must be accompanied by a report detailing all consultation for each strategic policy or planning decision in compliance with section 9(3). This provision is intended to ensure transparent compliance with the need to consult representatives of carers and grandparent carers. This is a replacement for the original clause.

It is very important that significant information is obtained from the actual stakeholders. The major concern is that the process is transparent and that the stakeholders--that is, the grandparent carers and the carers--have input into all policy making, strategic planning and decisions that are made that will affect them or their charges, the people that they may be caring for.

Ms PALASZCZUK: The government will be opposing the amendment because we believe that at the moment the reporting requirements that we have under the Carers (Recognition) Act are quite detailed. I would like to advise the House that currently all public authorities must include in their annual report certain information about how they have complied with the obligations in the act to consult with representative bodies when making policy and planning decisions relevant to carers. This requirement would mean detailing who they have consulted with on each occasion in their annual report. The reporting requirements under the Carers (Recognition) Act 2008 are already very comprehensive. I see that there is no reason to add an extra reporting requirement.
Mrs MENKENS (11.42 am): I move the following amendment--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: ‘7A Amendment of s 12 (Functions of the Carers Advisory Council)

XML.Hansard-Body: This is a very simple amendment. It involves the inclusion of the grandparents charter into the functions of the Carers Advisory Council so that it becomes part of the Carers Advisory Council. It is a simplistic word addition at this stage. I will explain this in greater detail when I introduce my further amendments.

Ms PALASZCZUK: In relation to the opposition’s amendment, we have already voted on the proposed amendment to include an additional charter, the Grandparents Carers Charter. These consequential amendments cannot be supported. The government bill extends the role of the Carers Advisory Council to grandparent carers by virtue of the amendment of the definition of carer to include grandparent carers. As discussed previously, two new principles have been added to the charter to specifically recognise grandparent carers. I have spoken with the Queensland carers council, as has my parliamentary secretary, the member for Mount Ommaney, about these amendments.
Mrs MENKENS (11.43 am): I move the following amendments--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: ‘(2) Section 14(2), ‘Four’--
‘(5) Three members must be grandparent carers.’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Amendment No. 8 deletes part of clause 8 to state that under section 14 of the act the new membership of the Carers Advisory Council should be 11. I move on to amendments Nos 9 and 10. The existing arrangement under the original bill is that the membership shall be 10 members--four public servants, three carers and three carer representatives. The government’s amendment has made this four public servants, three carers, three carers representatives but only two grandparent carer representatives. That is a little bit disappointing for the grandparent carers. Their representation is not as high as the carers’ representation.

The amendments that I am proposing here will actually bring the council numbers down to 11. We are proposing that the council comprise two public servants, three carers, three grandparent carers--as are currently there--and three grandparent carer representatives. This will ensure that grandparents have similar representation to the carers. I believe that is totally fair. It is reducing the number of public servants.

This is the area where the government should be looking for input from the sector--from the stakeholders, from the people who really matter, from the people who are on the ground and have the understanding. That is why we propose that the need for public servants is not as great. Having four public servants we believe is an imbalance.

What we are looking for is much greater representation for the people who really understand. The council is about carers and grandparent carers; it is not about the Public Service. It is important, I believe, that we have equal representation for grandparent carers and carers. Under our amendments the carers and the grandparent carers will have parallel charters with equal strength and therefore their representation on the council should be equal. They are two distinct groups and neither should assume priority over the other, just as their concerns in the charters need to be separate and distinct.

Ms PALASZCZUK: I want to make some comments so the House is very aware of what is happening here. When I sat down after doing my reply last night the opposition sought to circulate a large number of amendments in the House. These amendments had not been seen by members of the government. I do not know whether they were seen by the Independents. These are substantially different amendments.

What I say to the opposition is that it would have been appreciated if we could have had some discussion about these or if it could have tabled them beforehand so members on both sides of the House could have had the opportunity to examine the amendments in detail and make comments in detail. I do not think that is being respectful to the members of this House.

What is now being proposed is making substantial changes to the membership of the council. What we on this side of the House have done is we have actually gone out and consulted extensively. The stakeholders are happy with the composition of the council. What I would like to do is go through these amendments in detail for the benefit of the House now that I have had time overnight to examine these amendments, so we are very clear what we are voting on here.

The member for Burdekin’s amendment No. 8 relating to membership seeks to amend the total number of members of the Carers Advisory Council. The government bill increases the council from 10 to 12 members as it adds a grandparent carer and a grandparent carer representative to the three carer representatives and the four public servants. The opposition’s amendment seeks to have 11 members in total. This would include two public servants and three grandparent carers in addition to three carers and three carer representatives. With the addition of a grandparent carer and a representative of grandparent carers, I believe the composition of the Carers Advisory Council is indeed appropriate.

Currently the Carers Council consists of 10 members in total. This is made up of three carer members, three members who are representative of carers associations and four public servant employees. With the addition of the grandparent carer and a representative of grandparent carers, there will be 12 in total. I think that this is an adequate mix of carers, members of associations representative of carers’ interests and public servants. There is an incredible wealth of knowledge and experience between the members of the council, and the addition of the grandparent carer and a representative of grandparent carers will result in a well-balanced council that will be perfectly placed to understand the challenges faced by carers on a daily basis. As I said at the beginning, we believe that the composition is adequate.

With regard to the public servants, it is very important that public servants continue on this council because they have to implement the charter and make sure that their agencies are complying, and this is an issue that the Independents raised. The member for Nicklin and the member for Maryborough raised this issue. It is very important for them that public servants are acting in relation to this charter to ensure that these grandparent carers will now get the information that they require. The current representatives represent the key portfolios that play a significant and positive role in the provision of carer services in Queensland, and they are Education, Health, Justice and Attorney-General, and Communities. All members here would agree with me that it is very important to have the most senior representatives of these agencies represented on the council.

When we spoke to the Carers Council about this issue it was very clear that it did not want a very large council and that it wanted to keep the composition to a minimum increase. I think the government has struck the right balance here. We have consulted. The Independents would agree with me that it is very important to have the public servants on the council to carry out the implementation. Therefore, the government will not accept the opposition amendments that were tabled for the first time last night when I sat down after giving my reply to the comprehensive debate that we had in this chamber.

Mrs MENKENS: I thank the minister for those comments, but there are a couple of things that I want to draw to her attention. First of all, the suggestion we are making is for a smaller council and not a larger council, and the minister spoke about a larger council. The reason the amendments were tabled late is that, as the minister would realise, the majority of these amendments were part of my original private member’s bill. The majority of them were from that bill and, because that bill was still alive, it was impossible for me to actually move--
Mr Cripps: Most of them. Most of them are directly from the bill.

Mrs MENKENS: Yes, most of them, and it was impossible to put those amendments in the public arena by that stage. That is why these amendments were not released, but there again under the circumstances it was the government’s decision to make this a cognate bill. That is why it became very difficult and that is what created the difficulties.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That the member for Burdekin’s amendments be agreed to.
