XML.Hansard-Body: Mr CRIPPS (12.01 pm): My question to the minister in relation to clause 9 of the bill is that proposed point 11 of the charter provides access to information for grandparents. I understand from the clarification provided by the minister to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee that the information that will be made available to grandparent carers will be of a general nature that is already publicly available. So in effect the bill gives grandparent carers access to general information that they already have access to. Can the minister please advise the House what this bill will achieve additionally for grandparents in terms of access to information when they become grandparent carers?

Ms PALASZCZUK: I would like to thank the shadow minister for his interest in this very important issue. I think he might recall that in my summing-up I addressed this question quite comprehensively. One of the main ways in which these newly recognised grandparent carers will be able to access more information is through Carers Queensland. Carers Queensland has a great lot of resources. I have visited their premises. They will be able to provide these grandparent carers with information about services that are available locally in their communities and also information in relation to counselling. Carers Queensland has said to us that they will try to keep a list of how many of these grandparent carers are contacting them for information. I have said quite publicly that if they need some extra funding to cater for this new group that is being added to our carers recognition charter the government is prepared to give them that extra funding.

This funding comes on top of the extra funding that I announced last week as part of Queensland Carers Week, which was very well attended right across the state. The member for Albert ran a fantastic Carers Recognition Awards ceremony in her local community and I spoke to many grandparent carers there. They explained to me the issues that they have to deal with on an ongoing basis. Some of the extra $2.5 million that we will provide over three years will also be used right across Queensland to connect different carers groups together to share their experiences and to give them the extra resources that they need.

The one issue that carers across-the-board raise with me as I travel around the state is respite. I think all members would agree with me that respite is very important. Through my portfolio we have large contributions of respite, not just through the disability component of my portfolio but also through Home and Community Care. My aim is to increase respite services right across this state.

The other avenue through which we can provide assistance is my own department, which has the Office for Carers, which is there to assist people. We would be more than happy to point people in the right direction in relation to information that they need in fulfilling their caring role for their grandchildren.

Mr CRIPPS: I thank the minister for her response. Once again in terms of point 11 of the charter which provides access to information for grandparents, I ask the minister to clarify, in relation to the response that was forwarded to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee, that information provided to grandparent carers when they become a carer for their grandchild would be of a general nature that is already publicly available.

I note that the minister outlined that grandparent carers would be eligible to access information, either through Carers Queensland or through the Office for Carers within Disability and Care Services, relating to the delivery of support services provided in local communities and the delivery of counselling services provided in local communities. But my specific question--the question that I asked very clearly previously--is: what information would be additionally available to grandparent carers that is not already publicly available to them at this point in time? What additional information would be available to grandparent carers as a result of them becoming the carers for their grandchild?

Information about support services locally and information about counselling services locally is available publicly at this point in time. So from what I can see in the bill, the provisions of clause 9 that we are talking about now do not provide any additional information whatsoever to a grandparent carer when they become a carer for their grandchild. They will simply have continuing access to information that is currently available to them publicly.

Ms PALASZCZUK: I will be very brief. The one issue that grandparent carers who look after their grandchildren full time and who are the day-to-day decision makers often raise with members of parliament and with members of the community is that they do not know where to go for information. So we have responded by saying, ‘Now you can go to Carers Queensland to get the information that you need.’ So it is about providing that extra assistance to help them in their caring role.

Consistent with principle 11, the government already provides information, in conjunction with Lifeline, to assist grandparents raising grandchildren by way of the grandparents information line. This includes general information about carer support issues, access to legal advice, accommodation issues and financial matters. So now, under this new recognition, grandparents who are coming into members’ electorate offices or going into Centrelink to ask for advice for Commonwealth assistance will be able to be referred to Carers Queensland so that they can get the information and advice that they need. I think it is very important that we provide that information to them to support them in their caring role.
Mrs MENKENS (12.10 pm): I move the following amendment--

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1.Hansard-Bold: 11 Clause 9 (Amendment of schedule (The Queensland carers charter))

XML.Hansard-Body: This amendment deletes the whole of the amended clause 9 included in the government amendment bill. The government amendment bill amends the schedule, the Queensland Carers Charter, and inserts the two principles relating to grandparent carers to the original carers charter. Clause 9 is the government’s contribution to the grandparents, shall we say, and clause 11 actually deletes that and inserts the charter that I will talk about when I get to the next amendment.

Firstly, though, I would like to agree with the member for Hinchinbrook about access to information. I spoke about this at length last night. It is referring to information that is already available. I certainly commend the minister for the efforts that the government has put into acknowledging the grandparents and the carers. It is excellent that these now do exist. Certainly some years ago they did not. It is very good that there is recognition of our carers. Hopefully we will be getting more recognition for our grandparent carers. I think we have been playing with words in this area because this is information that is available and they are able to access it. The processes are there, the government departments are there, the carers organisations are there. I have no doubt that the people in need of the information are able to access it. We are still a little bit intrigued about this extra information that would be available only to them but not available to somebody else, which is what this tends to imply. This particular amendment is just deleting clause 9.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Before calling the minister, I would like to acknowledge in the gallery a Chinese delegation from All-China Federation of Trade Unions who are guests of Mr Speaker.

Ms PALASZCZUK: I think we are going over the same ground. The government will oppose the opposition’s amendment. I think I have fully covered that under the new charter principle that access to information is very important. What this gives grandparent carers who look after their grandchildren full time and who are the primary decision makers is, for the first time, basically a one-stop shop. They will be able to go to Carers Queensland to get that information. I take on board the member for Burdekin’s comments that there is information out there. Yes, I do agree. But these grandparent carers have said they do not know where to go to get the information and this will make it easier for them. Sometimes government can be a bit of a maze for people to navigate their way through. The Office of Carers and Carers Queensland will now make it easier for these grandparent carers to get the information that they need.
Mrs MENKENS (12.12 pm): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: section 7
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent2: the Parliament recognises that grandparents who provide accommodation and care for their grandchildren make a significant contribution to the lives of their grandchildren and deserve respect and support for their roles as full-time carers;

Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent2.Hansard-Bold: this Act establishes the following Queensland grandparent carers charter--

XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent3: 1 The State recognises the effort and dedication of grandparents in our community and the vital community service they perform.
2 The State recognises that grandparents who provide full-time care to their grandchildren are primary care givers and deserve the same rights as other primary care givers.
3 The relationship between grandparent and grandchild should be honoured and respected.
4 Grandparents providing full-time care to their grandchildren should be respected by our community and supported by all levels of government, institutions and organisations.

5 The views and needs of grandparents, providing full-time care to their grandchildren, should be taken into account, together with the views, needs and best interests of their grandchildren, when making decisions that may affect either the grandchild or the ability of the grandparent to provide full-time care.
6 Grandparents should be recognised for the unique knowledge, love and experience they contribute to their grandchildren’s growth through formative years.
7 The State recognises that a lone grandparent who single-handedly provides full-time care to a grandchild faces additional difficulties and deserves specific recognition.

8 Ageing and senior grandparents should be recognised for both the specific sacrifices they make and the additional difficulties they face in providing support and stability in the lives of their grandchildren.

9 Younger grandparents who assume responsibility for the primary care of their grandchildren deserve recognition for their vital service to the community and the nurture and love they provide to their grandchildren.

10 Other non-parent family members who assume responsibility for the primary care of a child should be recognised for the dedication they show and the effort they make to care for the best interests of the child.’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Amendment 12 actually inserts the most important part of the amendments that I have circulated. That is, of course, inserting a separate charter for Queensland grandparent carers. This is the same as existed in my original private member’s bill which, of course, was debated cognately and has been transferred across as an amendment to this bill.

I am disappointed that the government is not supporting this amendment. The LNP wants to see grandparent carers being given the same status as other carers. We do not believe that two extra points put on the end of the carers charter really gives these people the recognition they deserve. Their needs are vastly different--we have talked about that at length during the debate--but they do deserve the same amount of recognition.

To that extent, I will outline the 10 points contained in the charter for the benefit of the House. The charter states that the parliament recognises that grandparents who are providing full-time care for their grandchildren make a significant contribution to the lives of their grandchildren and that they deserve respect and support for their roles. The 10 points of the charter are: the state recognises the effort and dedication of grandparents in our community and the vital community service they perform; the state recognises that grandparents who provide full-time care to their grandchildren are primary caregivers and deserve the same rights as other primary caregivers; the relationship between grandparent and grandchild should be honoured and respected; grandparents providing full-time care to their grandchildren should be respected by our community and supported by all levels of government, institutions and organisations; the views and needs of grandparents providing full-time care to their grandchildren should be taken into account, together with the views, needs and best interests of their grandchildren, when making decisions that may affect either the grandchild or the ability of the grandparent to provide full-time care; grandparents should be recognised for the unique knowledge, love and experience they contribute to their grandchildren’s growth through formative years; the state recognises that a lone grandparent who single-handedly provides full-time care to a grandchild faces additional difficulties and deserves specific recognition; ageing and senior grandparents should be recognised for both the specific sacrifices they make and the additional difficulties they face in providing support and stability in the lives of their grandchildren; younger grandparents who assume responsibility for the primary care of their grandchildren deserve recognition for their vital service to the community and the nurture and love they provide to their grandchildren; other non-parent family members who assume responsibility for the primary care of a child should be recognised for the dedication they show and the effort they make to care for the best interests of the child.

I want to qualify a couple of points. In the original grandparents charter that came under the seniors recognition bill, it was pointed out that perhaps younger grandparents were being disadvantaged. This is why an extra point is put in here about the younger grandparents. We have also brought in other non-parent family members who assume responsibility for primary care. In many cases they can be an aunt or a great-aunt. In fact, I am currently trying to assist a poor lady in a very sad situation.

Ms PALASZCZUK: In relation to the member for Burdekin’s comments, as I have stated previously, the government bill does not include a separate grandparents charter. The existing carers charter in the Carers (Recognition) Act will also apply to grandparent carers. Many of the principles in the existing charter are also applicable to grandparent carers, which I think is very important to point out to the House. In addition, the government bill seeks to add two new principles specifically in relation to grandparent carers. I think they are important. I will read them out again for the benefit of the House: grandparents who are carers for their grandchildren after having raised their own children should be supported in their important and challenging role; secondly, grandparents who are carers for their grandchildren need easy access to information that is clear and relevant to their role as carers.

Unfortunately, the shadow minister’s amendments are seeking to identify different types of grandparent carers. I think that is inevitably exclusive. To go back to a comment that the member made earlier that her amendment is exactly the same as what was originally circulated in the opposition’s bill, I point out to the House that I have gone through the bill and where there were six points, in her amendments now she is actually raising 10 points. It is a substantial addition that was only circulated last night at about nine o’clock. So the government will be opposing the opposition amendments.

Dr DOUGLAS: I thank the minister for being so patient through all of this. It is a very difficult bill. I have some serious issues that I would like to raise. I would like to endorse the comments made by the shadow minister. I have actually felt so strongly about this that I have come into this House to discuss this. I do not believe that the department understands the problem that has been consistently raised. This amendment is critical because it defines the grandparents’ role and it clearly establishes that which the department does not want to acknowledge.

I need to point out that grandparents are basically an intervention expert because they have been parents themselves. They have special skills. They are experienced. They are available. They are willing and they are related. We do need to clarify their special skills. I am having a lot of difficulty understanding why, on the one hand, the government would do anything for one parent group in a variety of other departments and then not for a group of grandparents who are only really one small step away from the same role. It does not follow. I think it is actually a flawed strategy.

The best aspect about having a charter is--and this is a point that I raised in the briefing with the minister. I said that I am a GP and I get the problem, and I can give a hundred examples. In these areas the minister needs to understand that there are a hundred examples. We have a whole lot of bills at the moment being discussed that talk about exceptional circumstances and we are defining what these exceptional circumstances are. The great beauty of what is being raised here is that it is defining all of those clear roles.

What the minister has just raised--and I do not want to criticise the minister--is the idea of using the generic classification. The generic classification under these circumstances is a flawed strategy. There is plenty of evidence in medical terms where you do not use generic terms. You specify because that is the way to do it. The great beauty here is that in 10 steps what we have is a clear step forward. I will not go through each one of them, but I will talk about some of them because I have a few points to raise.

I want to take the minister back to the issue where she said that you can just refer back to Carers Queensland and they will answer all of your questions. I would like to know what sort of budget the minister has provided them, what information these people are going to have with regard to grandparents, what changes are we going to see for Carers Queensland with regard to grandparents--
Ms Palaszczuk: I have said all that. You weren’t here.
Dr DOUGLAS: I listened, but I did not hear it.
Ms Palaszczuk: Go back and read the Hansard .

Dr DOUGLAS: Having said that, what I would like to hear is the acknowledgement that this is a sensible idea, that this is a good idea. It is a good idea for all the points that have been consistently raised. It is a good idea because the original bill that was raised as a private member’s bill encompassed a lot of these points which have now been put as an amendment. This will make the minister’s task so much easier. It will make everybody--
Ms Palaszczuk: No, it won’t.
Dr DOUGLAS: It will.
Ms Palaszczuk: Because you are defining it. You’re being prescriptive.
Dr DOUGLAS: No, it is not.
Ms Palaszczuk: You are. You are being prescriptive.
Dr DOUGLAS: When you are prescriptive about certain things it works.
Ms Palaszczuk: You can have your medical terminology and I will stick to my legal definition.

Dr DOUGLAS: We can agree to disagree over certain points. I want to say that there are some good points in this amendment. The issue of the lone grandparent who single-handedly provides full-time care to a grandchild faces difficulty and deserves specific recognition. This is an important point. A lot of grandmothers are widows and divorcees and are providing these kinds of services to children. People need to recognise that. It is common. It is very, very common.
Ms Grace: Yes, but you can’t provide for all scenarios.
Dr DOUGLAS: You can have your view and you can get up and speak on it.
Ms Grace: You can’t provide for all scenarios.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Member for Brisbane Central, please.

Dr DOUGLAS: The member for Brisbane Central obviously has some good points. Let us bring them up. The other thing is that we need to understand that grandparents are really only one step away from parents. They are interventional experts and we need to recognise that. By specifying it and not using the generic classification, we give this bill power, and that is what we should be doing. I think it is a great step that has been initiated here today, and I strongly urge the minister to endorse it.

Ms PALASZCZUK: The member for Gaven can have his own medical interpretations here, but I am actually using the legal definition. What the opposition bill does is seek to be very prescriptive. What tends to happen from a legal interpretation is that if you are very prescriptive there is every chance that you are going to exclude so many other relationships and so many particular groups of grandparents.

I have gone extensively through how much funding we are giving to Carers Queensland. I have gone extensively through how much additional funding I have given in Carers Week last week. I do not want to go over ground that I have gone over many times before. The government will be opposing the opposition’s amendment because we believe that the Carers Charter is sufficient in that it covers a lot of aspects in relation to grandparent carers, but we are also adding two extra clauses which, through our consultations, have been supported.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That the member for Burdekin’s amendment be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: AYES, 32--Bates, Bleijie, Crandon, Cripps, Davis, Dempsey, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Elmes, Emerson, Flegg, Gibson, Hobbs, Hopper, Johnson, Langbroek, McArdle, Malone, Menkens, Messenger, Nicholls, Powell, Rickuss, Robinson, Seeney, Simpson, Springborg, Stevens, Stuckey. Tellers: Horan, Sorensen

NOES, 53--Attwood, Bligh, Boyle, Choi, Croft, Cunningham, Dick, Farmer, Finn, Foley, Fraser, Grace, Hinchliffe, Hoolihan, Jarratt, Johnstone, Jones, Kiernan, Kilburn, Lawlor, Lucas, McLindon, Male, Miller, Moorhead, Mulherin, Nelson-Carr, Nolan, O’Brien, O’Neill, Palaszczuk, Pitt, Pratt, Reeves, Roberts, Ryan, Schwarten, Scott, Shine, Smith, Spence, Stone, Struthers, Sullivan, van Litsenburg, Wallace, Watt, Wellington, Wells, Wettenhall, Wilson. Tellers: Keech, Darling
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (12.33 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a third time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a third time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Hon. A PALASZCZUK (Inala--ALP) (Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs) (12.34 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long title of the bill be agreed to.

XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 27 October (see p. 3935), on motion of Mr Dick--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr MESSENGER (Burnett--Ind) (12.34 pm), continuing: In continuing my speech on the Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill, I would like to bring to the attention of this place the good work of Heather Steinberg. Heather Steinberg is a Gympie solicitor, former police prosecutor, community activist and passionate advocate for children, especially those children who have suffered child sex abuse. I believe that Heather is a possible candidate for membership of the Sentencing Advisory Council and would be a great choice. Heather has shared with me her thoughts and observations on this legislation which I will bring to the attention of the House. In his speech, the minister said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The bill provides that an offender convicted of an offence of a sexual nature committed in relation to a child must serve an actual term of imprisonment unless there are exceptional circumstances in the case.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: In reply to that, Heather commented--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: When a person commits an offence against a child there should be no exceptional circumstances warranting a term of no imprisonment.

Offences involving boyfriend/girlfriend of similar ages should be a separate offence to avoid coming under this provision thereby allowing for all sex offenders against a child receiving an actual term of imprisonment.
XML.Hansard-Body: I think that is an eminently sensible suggestion on Heather’s behalf. By splitting those offences and creating a separate offence involving a boyfriend and girlfriend of similar ages, we could make sure there is no offence whatsoever for which there would be no imprisonment. In the minister’s speech he said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Judicial discretion is retained, but it will only be where it can be demonstrated that the most extraordinary circumstances exist that an offender may be sentenced to anything other than an actual term of imprisonment.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mrs Steinberg commented--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The problem with judicial discretion being retained is what is currently seen now--the offenders are not given actual terms of imprisonment, more attention is paid to the defence solicitor then the victim and the prosecutor.
The discretion should be taken out of their hands and the decision be made mandatory.
Defence solicitors will always come up with a way to claim the matter is “extraordinary circumstance” to prevent his/her client from getting an actual jail term.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The minister also said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The result of this amendment is that the court will increase the penalty to be given to the offender within the established common law sentencing range for that conduct. The penalty must, however, still be proportionate to the gravity of the current offence.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Heather commented--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This is what is supposed to happen now with the judicial system--the penalty is increased each time the offender comes before the court.
However, as has been seen on many many occasions it does not always happen. How does this provision change the current status and how does it make the court give a greater penalty?
XML.Hansard-Body: I think that particular question has been asked by a number of members on this side of the chamber and also by those on the crossbenches. The minister said in relation to the Penalties and Sentences Act--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Currently, an offender convicted of a serious violent offence must serve 80 per cent of their sentence before being eligible to apply for parole release. The bill provides that, in the case of an offender convicted of an offence of violence committed against a young child or an offence that caused the death of a young child, the court must treat the age of the child as an aggravating factor when determining whether a serious violent offender declaration should be made.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Mrs Steinberg said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The age of the child should not be the aggravating factor when determining if a serious violent offender declaration should be made.
If the offence is against any child the declaration should be made and the offender made to serve out his full penalty not 80% here and 100% there--everyone serves their full penalty.
Age of the victim should not be the deciding factor.
XML.Hansard-Body: As a way of explaining that, I raise this issue. If the child is under 12, the offender is required to serve the full term but if the child has turned 13 and the offences are more horrific the offender may still only have to serve 80 per cent. Page 9 of the legislation deals with 15AF, ‘Right of appearance in a guideline proceeding’. The legislation states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The following persons may appear in a guideline proceeding--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) the Attorney-General;
(b) the director of public prosecutions;
(c) the chief executive officer of Legal Aid Queensland.
XML.Hansard-Body: They are the principal people who may appear in a guideline proceeding. Heather’s comment, which I wholeheartedly agree with, states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Why doesn’t the victim have a right to appear. The AG, DPP, Legal Aid and the offender can appear BUT WHAT ABOUT THE VICTIM. Why can’t the victim appear or have a legal rep appear on their behalf.
XML.Hansard-Body: The one comment from Mrs Steinberg that strikes me here is that everyone forgets the victim. This is a comment coming from a practising solicitor who sees what happens day in, day out.
Mr Hoolihan: Nobody forgets the victim.

Mr MESSENGER: Everyone forgets the victim. That is the reality of legal matters in Queensland in 2010. We see the same mistake again on page 11 of this legislation at 15AI, ‘Procedural requirements if court decides to give or review guideline judgment’.

There is a category of sex offender in Queensland officially known as a dangerous sex offender. I believe that they will be affected by clause 7 of this legislation, the Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill 2010. Clause 7 amends 161B, ‘Declaration of conviction of serious violent offence.’ Dangerous sex offenders are the worst of the worst of sex offenders because they have committed heinous crimes against mainly children and women. A judge has to officially designate them as a dangerous sex offender under that particular legislation. It is much harder for these people to be released from prison but, ultimately, as we have seen, they are released. Right now I believe there are about 90 dangerous sex offenders living in secret in communities all over Queensland. I will just repeat that. They are living in secret in communities all over Queensland.

In a recent parliamentary question on notice I tried to find out the number--not the names and the locations, but the number--of officially declared dangerous sex offenders living in the Burnett-Bundaberg region but the minister refused to even supply that basic information. The fact is that, after this bill passes through this place, dangerous sex offenders will still have their right to privacy, they will still have their civil liberties intact. It is these dangerous sex offenders who will be targeted by a private member’s bill which I believe will be Australia’s first sex offender laws, likened to the American law called Megan’s law.

I have just received from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel a first draft of the bill that I intend to introduce. I will be consulting with my independent colleagues, the people of the Burnett community, legal experts, child protection stakeholders and parents and grandparents. In the coming months I will introduce a private member’s bill which will name and locate dangerous sex offenders throughout Queensland so they will not be able to live in secret. I remind this place once again that it is only the most predatory, vile and heinous sex offender who would be forced to reveal their location. Should that bill be debated and should that bill be passed, ordinary Queensland mums and dads will then have the right to know if the government decides to release a dangerous sex offender or repeat child rapist into their street. Combined with this legislation, my private member’s bill will offer a chance for parents and grandparents to have what they do not have now, and that is their right to say to their children, ‘Stay away from that man. He is a bad man.’ When this bill is debated, as happened with this bill, the Penalties and Sentences Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill 2010, both sides of this chamber will have an opportunity to vote and show how tough they are on sex offenders.

If I remained a member of the LNP, I would not have been allowed to introduce a Megan’s law. In the meetings I attended there was overwhelming opposition, mainly from the former Liberal members of the LNP, against a Megan’s law. They talk the talk, but they lack the courage to walk the walk. This was one of the reasons that I decided to become an independent member of this House: so I had the freedom to introduce a bill that, as the minister has said in his second reading speech, strengthens the penalties imposed upon repeat offenders, those who commit sexual offences against children and offenders who are violent to young children or who cause the death of a young child.
In closing, I would like to quote one of my independent colleagues, the member for Nicklin, who said that magistrates and judges can do better. We all can. I commend this bill to the House.

Mr McARDLE (Caloundra--LNP) (12.45 pm): I rise to make a short contribution to the bill before the House. I will limit my comments to those parts of the bill that deal with the Queensland Sentencing Advisory Council.
If one goes to the second reading of the Attorney-General, one finds these three sentences. They state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The Queensland Sentencing Advisory Council will seek to further promote consistency in sentencing; to stimulate balanced public debate on sentencing issues; and to incorporate informed community opinion into the sentencing process, thereby enhancing confidence in Queensland’s sentencing regime. The Sentencing Advisory Council will achieve these objectives through its functions of advising, informing, researching and educating on sentencing issues. In performing its functions, it is anticipated that the Queensland council will consult widely, including with the judiciary, the legal profession, government agencies and the community.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: They are certainly words that are well worthwhile echoing. Without a doubt the bill, if it is passed today--and it certainly will be--will provide an avenue for the people of Queensland to have a more direct say on the sentencing regime under which they live.
XML.Hansard-Body: Of course, those words refer to the Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill 2010. Those exact same words could, of course, apply with equal force and effect to the Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill 2005. The words are interchangeable between the two because the bills, when they are compared--and I will do that in a few moments time--actually mirror each other if not in direct language, then certainly in intent, format, desire and proposed outcome. In fact, the body that the bills attempt to put into place are indeed identical. The Sentencing Advisory Council is the term used in both the 2005 bill and the 2010 bill. The 2005 bill was a creature of the LNP which was voted down by the government, some of whose members are still in the House today and I will refer to the comments they made both back then and, indeed, today as well.

This government is so bereft of ideas and so unable to establish anything of difference and style or outcome that it could not even muster the energy to change the terminology to distinguish the Sentencing Advisory Council in 2005 from the Sentencing Advisory Council in 2010. So meagre was its intellectual capacity that it could not even gather the evidence to put a new name to the body that it intends to incorporate into our justice system. It is worthwhile going through both bills because they do deal with very similar matters, as I said earlier.

Of course, I mentioned the council now shares the common name. Let us look at the functions of the council under the bill in 2005 and under the bill in 2010. One of the criticisms--and I will come back to it later--was that there was a claim that the 2005 bill would direct the Court of Appeal as to what it could or could not do.
The 2005 bill stated, in relation to the functions of the council--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘The functions of the council are--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) to state in writing to the Court of Appeal its views in relation to the application by courts of the sentencing guidelines and principles in section 9;
XML.Hansard-Body: The 2010 bill uses different terminology, different phraseology, but it says this--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The council has the function of stating in writing to the Court of Appeal its views on the giving, or review, of a guideline judgment within the meaning of part 2A.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That is the new provision in the bill.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr Springborg: That’s the same thing.

Mr McARDLE: I take the Deputy Leader of the Opposition’s interjection. They are exactly the same thing. In both bills the council has the capacity to the write to the Court of Appeal and present its views on sentencing and other matters. There is absolutely no distinction between the clauses in the 2005 bill and the 2010 bill.
The 2005 bill empowered the council--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (b) to provide statistical information on sentencing, including information on current sentencing practices, to members of the judiciary and other interested persons; and
(c) to conduct research, and disseminate information to members of the judiciary and other interested persons ...
(d) to gauge public opinion on sentencing matters; and
(e) to consult, on sentencing matters ...
(f) to advise the Minister on sentencing matters.
XML.Hansard-Body: The 2010 bill enables the council--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... to advise the Attorney-General on matters relating to sentencing; and
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (b) to provide information to the community to enhance knowledge and understanding of matters relating to sentencing; and
(c) to publish information relating to sentencing; and
(d) to research matters ... and
(e) to obtain the community’s views on sentencing ...
XML.Hansard-Body: The terminology and phraseology is different but the outcome is exactly the same. There is no distinction between the 2005 bill and the 2010 bill with regard to the functions to be performed. What it then does say in the 2005 bill is--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ‘In performing its functions, the council may obtain expert help from anyone whom the council considers to be appropriately qualified to help.
XML.Hansard-Body: The 2010 bill states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: ‘(2) To assist in performing its functions under subsection (1), the council may consult with the judiciary, government departments, any person or class of person and any other entity or class of entity.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is different terminology, different phraseology, but exactly the same outcome. The outcome and the intent of the two bills is mirrored. Then we go on to the composition of the membership of the council. The 2005 bill stated that it should comprise nine members but no more than 12. It then identified in the bill the type of persons or in fact the persons who would be appointed to the council. The 2010 bill says that it will comprise 12 members. It is certainly slightly more. But when one reads the proposed composition of the council and who may sit on the council, one finds that the terminology is different, the phraseology is different, but at the end of the day it is exactly the same body, it is exactly the same composition. This government, with a $40 billion budget this year alone, can do nothing more than cut and paste a 2005 bill, change the words, whack it into the parliament and then say, ‘We’re the heroes.’
Mr Springborg: The Attorney should be charged with plagiarism.

Mr McARDLE: The Attorney should be charged with plagiarism. Five years has passed and the intellectual rigour of the government is such that it has said that the bill proposed by the LNP in 2005 was right. It has said, ‘We will rejig the language to make it look as though we have done something different.’ It has not done anything different. The bill remains exactly the same. But one group of people has lost out. The people of Queensland have for the past five years lost out when it comes to having a direct say in the sentencing regime under which they reside--a sentencing regime that we identified five years ago required, called for, begged for community consultation and input. This government turned its back on those people until suddenly it realised that it needed to be doing something to bolster its coffers and its polling in the lead-up to the next election campaign. That is what this is all about: make no mistake about it.

So what is different? Let us have a look at some of the comments that were made when the debate ensued in 2005 and see what arguments the government used in 2005 to say that that bill, which is a mirror image of the 2010 bill, should not be put in place or does not achieve its goals. I refer to the library brief in relation to this bill, No. 19 of 2010. It deals with the issue of sentencing councils and an overview of models from Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. At page 4 of that document there is a synopsis of some comments made by ministers and the government, some of whom are in the House today and some of whom have left the House.

The Attorney-General at that time was the Hon. Linda Lavarch. She said the bill was ‘unworkable in the context of current sentencing practices’. If the bill in 2005 was unworkable on that basis and it mirrors the 2010 bill, is the government now saying that there has been some metamorphosis in relation to the sentencing practices in 2005 that allows this bill to go ahead today? The then Attorney-General made this comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: It failed to recognise that is the role of the elected parliament to determine the appropriate sentencing framework for our courts to work within.
XML.Hansard-Body: That is what the then Attorney-General said five years ago. Here we have a bill put forward by this government that is purportedly doing exactly what the Attorney-General said back in 2005 it should not do. We now have the government saying that that is okay. The bills mirror each other.
The Hon. Dean Wells made this comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The parliament--
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr O’Brien): Order! The member will refer to the member by his proper title.
Mr McARDLE: My apologies. The honourable member for Murrumba made this comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: This parliament actually determines the sentences that are to be imposed for different categories of offences.
XML.Hansard-Body: The 2005 bill mirrors the 2010 bill. What has happened to cause this change? In this House yesterday the member for Toowoomba North made this comment when referring to the 2005 bill--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That model sought to remove the discretion of the court by allowing a sentencing advisory council to direct the Court of Appeal.
XML.Hansard-Body: What it means is that somehow the 2005 bill directed the Court of Appeal but the same powers in the 2010 bill do not direct the Court of Appeal. They are exactly the same powers, exactly the same rights and exactly the same entitlements, but they do not direct the Court of Appeal. A base political motive was the 2005 agenda in relation to this whole matter.

The member for Toowoomba North is also a former Attorney-General. He knows very well that the 2005 bill would not have directed the Court of Appeal in any circumstances. His comment on the 2005 bill is absolutely incorrect, false and a complete and absolute fabrication. The member for Toowoomba North also makes this comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the establishment of ‘a sentencing advisory council could seriously compromise the discretionary powers of the judiciary’ ...
XML.Hansard-Body: The 2005 bill provided for a compromise situation to exist. The 2010 bill--that is, exactly the same bill--does not. This was done for base political motives. The member then goes on to make this comment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The sentencing function is a judicial function and, as such, should be administered by judicial officers subject to the relevant law.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The 2005 bill is mirrored in the 2010 bill. There is no difference. The member knew at that time that the bill was correct. He knows that the 2010 bill is identical. It allows the people of Queensland to have a say in the sentencing regime. As a former Attorney-General, he well knows that.
XML.Hansard-Body: What we have quite clearly is this. We have before the House a bill that, as I have said many times--and I will keep saying--is exactly the same as the bill that was introduced in 2005. What is different is that the government is struggling to gain ascendency in the minds of the public of this state. It is grappling with how best to achieve that outcome. The outcome can only be achieved by stealing the ideas of the LNP and making them its own. But it did not take the time and the rigour to make it reflect its own intellectual capacity. What it has done is simply cut and paste a bill that existed in 2005 and was under the stamp of the LNP and then claim it as its own. It is shameful hypocrisy.
Sitting suspended from 1.00 pm to 2.30 pm.
Debate, on motion of Mr Springborg, adjourned.
Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (2.31 pm), by leave, without notice: I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That, notwithstanding standing order 165(1), the Treasurer be permitted to present from Her Excellency the Governor a message recommending an appropriation for the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill, which has already been read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Motion agreed to.
Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (2.31 pm): I present a message from the Governor.
The Deputy Speaker (Mr Kilburn) read the following message--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: MESSAGE
OCCUPATIONAL LICENSING NATIONAL LAW (QUEENSLAND) BILL 2010
I, PENELOPE ANNE WENSLEY, Governor, recommend to the Legislative Assembly a Bill intituled--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent1: A Bill for an Act to provide for a national law to regulate the licensing of particular occupations and for related purposes.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: (sgd)
GOVERNOR
Date: 25 0CT 2010

XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Liquor and Other Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (2.32 pm): I present a bill for an act to amend the Adult Proof of Age Card Act 2008, the Bail Act 1980, the Gaming Machine Act 1991, the Liquor Act 1992, the Liquor Regulation 2002 and the Penalties and Sentences Act 1992 for particular purposes and to make consequential amendments of the Police Service Administration Act 1990 and the Public Service Act 2008. I present the explanatory notes, and I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a first time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a first time.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Liquor and Other Legislation Amendment Bill [ 3462 ].
Tabled paper: Liquor and Other Legislation Amendment Bill, explanatory notes [ 3463 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. PJ LAWLOR (Southport--ALP) (Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading) (2.33 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: The introduction of the Liquor and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 enables important liquor reforms for Queensland. One of the government’s Toward Q2 commitments is to support safe and caring communities. In 2008 the government undertook significant alcohol reform, including making harm minimisation the first object of the Liquor Act 1992. During 2009 and 2010 the government further amended the Liquor Act to ensure that the industry’s regulation is consistent with the public interest objective of minimising harm caused by alcohol abuse and misuse. This bill builds and expands on that approach. In developing this bill, the government has balanced the interests and expectations of industry and community whilst ensuring that the potential harm from liquor is minimised as much as possible. However, the reforms do not seek to remove the right of Queenslanders to enjoy themselves and partake of alcohol in a responsible manner, nor prevent liquor licensees from making a living and employing their fellow Queenslanders.

On 4 August 2009 this parliament requested that the Law, Justice and Safety Committee conduct an inquiry into alcohol related violence in Queensland with a focus on community safety and preventative measures that might reduce levels of alcohol related violence. The final report of the parliamentary committee was tabled on 18 March 2010 with 68 recommendations to reduce the incidence and impacts, both social and economic, of alcohol related violence in Queensland. After comprehensive consultation with community and industry, the government’s response to the committee’s report was tabled in parliament on 30 August 2010. This bill implements part of the government’s response to the inquiry.

The central policy principle of the government’s response was a commitment to a place based management approach targeting key late-night entertainment areas where issues such as crowding, queuing, traffic and inadequate amenities impact upon safety. These entertainment precincts--to be known as drink safe precincts--will be managed similar to a major sporting event, with coordinated use of police and other state and local government resources. Drink safe precincts will be piloted in Fortitude Valley, Surfers Paradise and Townsville for two years from December 2010, with the government committing funding of $4.267 million for the first year. Existing trading hours and lockout times will remain to provide certainty to licensees and patrons and give the new approach a chance to work. If the pilots are successful, there is potential to implement them in other areas throughout Queensland as required. The bill allows for these drink safe precincts to be prescribed in a regulation.

The bill also provides for new powers to ban people from specified areas. It establishes a civil banning order regime under the Liquor Act which enables the court to issue a banning order upon adults who engage in prescribed behaviour within a drink safe precinct and where the order is necessary to ensure the safety, welfare and good order of licensed premises, and the surrounding public areas, within a drink safe precinct. They may be up to 12 months in duration. A civil ban applied to persons not charged with an offence may be perceived as harsh, but the government is determined to protect the public from individuals who perpetrate alcohol related violence in our community. It is intended that during the drink safe precinct pilots the civil banning regime will be monitored to ensure that it achieves its desired effect whilst minimising the impact on the rights and liberties of persons.

The bill also amends the Penalties and Sentences Act to create a banning order as a sentencing option in its own right. This option is not limited to offending within a drink safe precinct. It may be imposed if the offender is convicted of an offence that involved violence to a person or property which occurred in or around licensed premises and the court is satisfied that, unless the order is made, the offender poses an unacceptable risk to the safety, welfare and good order of licensed premises. The bill also amends the Bail Act 1980 to specify a ‘special condition’ to a grant of bail can include a banning order. It places a mandatory requirement on the bail granting authority to consider including a banning condition in certain circumstances.

The bill includes amendments to the Liquor Act and the Gaming Machine Act to expand the responsibility of the Queensland Gaming Commission so that it becomes the Queensland Liquor and Gaming Commission and makes key liquor licensing decisions of significant community impact, including decisions on new hotel licences, nightclubs and extended trading hours. The expanded role of the commission will build on the significant expertise and success that has ensured an appropriate balance in the provision of gambling services. This is a streamlining process that was commenced with the government’s April 2000 policy direction for gambling in Queensland which called for synergies in liquor and gaming licensing processes to avoid duplication. The government is committed to reducing the regulatory burden for industry and the community to promote productivity, foster innovation and increase competitiveness.

The bill also amends the Liquor Act to allow standard licence conditions to be prescribed in a regulation. This will allow for a more efficient method of regulating licensees, with common conditions--for example, safety initiatives--being applied in a standard manner rather than individually for each licence. The bill provides for a retitling of the ‘objectives’ of the Liquor Act to the ‘main purposes’ of the Liquor Act. It provides for a new main purpose of the act which is to regulate the liquor industry, and areas surrounding licensed premises, in a way compatible with three outcomes.

The first of these outcomes is the minimisation of harm, and the potential harm, from alcohol abuse, misuse and associated violence. The second is the minimisation of adverse impacts on the health or safety of members of the public. The third is one that minimises adverse impacts on the amenity of the community.

Placing these matters as the main purposes of the Liquor Act is intended to strengthen the commission’s and chief executive’s ability to have regard to these primary policy objectives when making decisions. To ensure commission decisions take into account the concerns of the whole community, the bill provides an amendment to the Liquor Act that allows the responsible minister to make a direct objection to an application of significant community impact. The commission must have regard to any ministerial objection when it considers the application.

The bill also provides the commission with the power to delegate its decision-making authority. It is intended this will allow the commission to delegate decisions of minimal impact or risk to allow the commission to focus on higher risk applications and to ensure the timeliness of decision making. For example, the commission may wish to delegate temporary, one-off applications to extend the licensed area, increase trading hours or vary the conditions of licence to allow amplified music for a special event or function, for example, on Australia Day or New Year’s Eve. The commission will specify which minor decisions will be delegated to the chief executive in an instrument of delegation made by the commission.

The bill extends the current moratorium on extended trading hours, currently due to expire at midnight on 15 December 2010, until 31 December 2013. This extension allows time for evidence from the evaluation of the drink safe precinct pilots to inform government policy regarding harm minimisation strategies. The bill also amends the Liquor Act to provide new trading hours for bottle shops and other takeaway liquor outlets. New applications relating to bottle shops and takeaway liquor outlets will be restricted to ordinary trading hours between 10 am and 10 pm, with the ability to apply for extended trading hours between 9 am and 10 am, and 10 pm and midnight, if there is demonstrated community need. It is intended that the threshold for the commission in deciding what constitutes demonstrated community need will be a balance of factors, including demand that may result from the premises being located in a tourist or dining area, but also community amenity and safety and the social impact of the extended trading hours on the local area. Also, the bill, consistent with the government response to the parliamentary inquiry, prescribes the definition of ‘amenity’ in the Liquor Act to provide further clarity in decision making by the commission or chief executive.

The bill also amends the Adult Proof of Age Card Act 2008 to allow a person who is at least 17 years and 11 months to apply for an adult proof of age card. The amendments provide that if an applicant is under 18 years the chief executive must not issue the adult proof of age card until the applicant is at least 18 years of age. The Queensland government is introducing a more reliable, secure and durable adult proof of age card to replace the existing Card 18+. In contrast to a Card 18+, an adult proof of age card will no longer be issued over the counter but will be mailed from a secure central location. These amendments provide a means by which a person can obtain an adult proof of age card on or immediately following their 18th birthday.

The amendments in the bill demonstrate this government’s ongoing and evident commitment to reducing harm, and the potential for harm, from alcohol in the community. It also provides another example of our commitment to reducing the regulatory burden on business and the community. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate, on motion of Mr Springborg, adjourned.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from p. 4018, on motion of Mr Dick--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (2.43 pm): I rise to speak in support of this reforming legislation and I commend the Attorney-General for introducing this bill to the House. Public confidence in the criminal justice system is integral to the operation of this bill. That is what it is all about. It has been disappointing to listen to this debate in the chamber with member after member of the opposition seeking to decline public confidence through ridicule of our judges and magistrates for sentences that they have imposed. Prior to today’s debate, the recent debate on the Dangerous Prisoners (Sexual Offenders) and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 2009 was similarly a disgrace. We heard members opposite constantly decrying sentences as a slap on the wrist or of weak judges and magistrates imposing pathetic sentences. Yet did the members opposite ever name the weak judges or tell us what the weak penalties were? No. They were deafening in their silence.

The fact is that everyone in this House supports tough penalties for violent offenders and sex offenders and for crimes against children. Indeed, participation in the Australian democracy requires acceptance of a criminal justice system that can imprison people for crimes against society and on both sides of this House there is no tolerance for criminal activity. On many occasions I have spoken in this place of my dismay at the preparedness of members opposite to engage in low-rent law and order fearmongering. This fearmongering, which effectively says to the community, ‘You are at great risk of being a victim--of being hurt, killed or raped--and the offender will get off lightly,’ is totally irresponsible. It is disgraceful.

Laws must be enforced and sentencing must be adequate. Indeed, sentencing must be very tough for serious crimes. But our responsibility as community leaders is not to foster fear of crime in the community. The tactic of fearmongering is a tool of both the dictator and the directionless and it is our responsibility as members of parliament to lead. But the great tragedy of fearmongering is often that those in our community with a lower risk of being a victim of crime develop the greatest fear of being a victim, and that is at the core of the irresponsibility of the rhetoric of those opposite.

Most of what we have heard from opposition members is in stark contrast to the reality of what is going on in Queensland. Crime rates are down, police clearance rates are up and more offenders are spending time in jail than ever before. But we do not hear that from members opposite, and that is because the facts belie their cheap political rhetoric.

Let me put some of the facts in relation to crime, policing and sentencing on the record. Firstly, in relation to police resourcing, this government has continued to deliver on its commitment to increase police numbers and ensure that in Queensland the ratio of police to population remains above the national average. The facts show that. Before the current government came to power in 1998, the police-to-population ratio was one officer for every 501 Queenslanders. Since this government came to office, the police-to-population ratio has improved significantly and remains better than the national average. The ratio is currently around one officer for every 427 people in Queensland, with a national average of one officer for every 440 people. Additionally, police numbers have risen by almost 4,000--from 6,833 in 1998 to 10,400 officers in Queensland today--and in this year’s budget the Treasurer advised of provision for a further 203 police officers in Queensland.

When we look at capital expenditure, the facts show that spending by the Bligh government on policing infrastructure and capital works leads the nation. According to the 2009 Report on government services , in 2008-09 Queensland spent more than 40 per cent of all of the capital expenditure spent on policing across Australia and Queensland’s expenditure was $219.6 million--more than three times the national average of $67.3 million.

But what about crime rates and the perception of crime? Members opposite often raise the fear of rising crime rates, and I am concerned about a public perception that there is increasing violence and criminal activity in the community. These perceptions build on the rhetoric of the LNP and are not supported by statistics. In July 2010 the report of the Australian Institute of Criminology titled (Mis)perceptions of crime in Australia revealed that more than 60 per cent of respondents held an incorrect perception that crime rates were increasing when, in fact, they are going down and that more than a third of respondents believed that violence was involved in more than 70 per cent of crimes when the reality is that violence is involved in less than 10 per cent of all crimes.

When we look at crime rate statistics, we see that since this current government was first elected crime rates have fallen. The overall rate of crime has dropped by 21.5 per cent and, additionally, property offences are down 42.5 per cent and offences against the person are down 18.7 per cent. Important also are clearance rates, where the facts show that more crimes are now being solved. The clearance rate--that is, the rate of reported crimes that are solved for offences against the person--has increased from 62 per cent in 1997-98 to 72 per cent in 2007-08. For property offences the rate increased from 24 per cent in 1997-98 to 31 per cent in 2007-08.

We also know that imprisonment rates in Queensland are high. I get no joy from imprisonment rates in Queensland being high, but it belies the rhetoric of the opposition. As the Attorney-General has pointed out, there are one million more people in Victoria than in Queensland and yet Queensland has more people in jail. Queensland courts are locking up criminals at a rate above the national and international average with only two jurisdictions, New South Wales and the Northern Territory, having a higher rate of imprisonment for serious criminal offending. In light of all of these facts, this government recognises that there remains a need for ensuring that sentencing outcomes continue to meet community expectations.

Before moving on to some of the specific amendments contained in this bill, I will comment on what we have heard from members opposite about this bill and their 2005 bill. I was here for the contribution by the ‘Dennis Denuto’ of Caloundra where he talked about how this bill was exactly the same.
Mr Shine: That is unfair on Dennis.
Mr Dick: I thought that was Kawana, but it is unfair on Dennis.

Mr FINN: He was a great Australian. The member tried to promulgate the argument that this bill is exactly the same as the 2005 bill that the opposition introduced. There was nothing in there about guideline judgements. What was in there was a sentencing council having the power to direct a court. It was fundamentally different. That was simply a stunt. The members opposite know that they regularly put up private members’ bills to run political rhetoric on a law and order, low rent auction. They did not come in here with a well-researched, factually based, considered bill. In fact, in the 6 years that I have been in this place I have seen plenty of private members’ bills. Has a member of the LNP ever sought me out to consult with me as a member of parliament about what their bill means? Has one of them ever come to me and said, ‘Hey, we would like to brief you on this bill’? No, not once--not interested. Does government brief opposition members on its bills? All the time. Does government go out to stakeholders in development of its legislation? All the time. It belies reality for the members opposite to come in here and say that this bill is a stunt when the record clearly shows that is their record, that is their activity. What they do is come in here with political rhetoric; what we do is come in with measured, balanced legislation to put through the House.

In this bill we see a proposed Sentencing Advisory Council. What this council is about is enhancing community dialogue about sentencing and injecting community opinion into sentencing principles. The council of 12 members will have a broad based membership with representation spread across many community groups and it will be enabled to advise on sentencing matters. It will also advise the Court of Appeal on its views on giving or reviewing guideline judgements. The council will also have an educative role in the community through enhancing knowledge and understanding of sentencing as well as conducting research and publishing its findings on topics relating to sentencing. One of the important roles of the council will be to gather the community’s views on sentencing and particular matters relating to sentencing.

The bill also makes amendments to section 9 of the Penalties and Sentences Act to add an additional provision that the court must consider when sentencing an offender for offences of a sexual nature against a child under 16 years of age. In these cases the offender must serve an actual term of imprisonment unless there are exceptional circumstances. That is not a soft-on-crime position. The description of this by members opposite as a get-out-of-jail-free card and their hue and cry about the provision again belies the facts. Before a court chooses not to jail an offender it must be satisfied that there are exceptional circumstances. Exceptional has its ordinary meaning, not the somewhat watered down meaning that the opposition try to imply. The act provides that when determining whether extraordinary circumstances exist, the court can look at the closeness in age between the offender and the child. Such closeness does not automatically constitute exceptional circumstances; it is just a factor that the court may look at. This is not new. It is not a new principle of law. The government is enshrining this sentencing principle in legislation, ensuring that it remains law in Queensland. In a similar vein, repeat offenders will be subject to a new provision which ensures that the court, when determining the appropriate penalty for a person with a previous conviction, must treat each conviction as an aggravating factor. The court must of course consider previous convictions in relation to relevance to the current offence and time factors. Once again, it is not a soft-on-crime amendment.

The Queensland government is particularly committed to the protection of the vulnerable in our society, especially children. The last amendment contained in this bill relates to perpetrators who commit acts of violence against young children. Where an offence involves violence against a child under 12 years of age or causes the death of a child under 12, the sentencing court must treat the age of the child as an aggravating factor when considering whether to impose a serious violent offender order. Again, that is not a soft-on-crime provision. These are innovative provisions which strengthen the power of the courts to provide appropriate sentences.

The Labor government is tough on crime and the causes of crime and through this bill empowers the courts to determine tough and appropriate sentences. The government does this through reliance on proper policy responses informed by research and statistics. This is in stark contrast to the LNP opposition whose members simply pluck up an idea around which to build fear and hide their complete lack of policy direction behind the baseless rhetoric of the uninformed.

Members of the community expect safety and protection and a robust criminal justice system, but they also expect rationality and leadership from their lawmakers. Our job is to build confidence in the justice system and ensure that it meets the needs of society and the reasonable expectations of the community. That is what this bill is about and I commend the bill to the House.

Hon. CR DICK (Greenslopes--ALP) (Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations)
(2.56 pm), in reply: I am pleased to be able to speak in response to a number of matters raised in this important debate on the Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill 2010. At the outset I thank all honourable members for their contribution, particularly those members of the government who spoke on the bill. A number of those speeches stood out: the member for Woodridge and her very thoughtful analysis of what actually happens in Queensland courts each and every day and the role that a whole range of individuals and groups play in that; and the address by the member for Chatsworth who, along with the member for Yeerongpilly, comprehensively demolished the falsehoods perpetrated by the Liberal National Party opposition in relation to crime and law and order in this state.
The highlight of the debate for me overall was that it illustrated that the opposition is a long-term, lazy, fundamentally ignorant opposition in this state. We know they are lazy.
Mr Springborg: You don’t even know the sub judice rule!
Mr DICK: All members of the Queensland community need to know that this is the best resourced opposition in Queensland.
Mr Springborg: Is that what they teach you in Tuvalu? You didn’t know it yesterday.
Mr DICK: I take the interjection from the member opposite. When the member for Southern Downs, as he does often, seeks to criticise me for having served the community as a volunteer in Tuvalu--
Mr Springborg: They must have a different sub judice rule over there.

Mr DICK: I served in Tuvalu very proudly for three years as a volunteer under Australian Volunteers Abroad. When I came into this parliament I thought that there would be some things that would be above politics. I thought that there would be some things outside of the nature of political debate. When the pressure is put on the member for Southern Downs on various issues by me as the Attorney-General and Minister for Industrial Relations he resorts to this denigration not just of me as a volunteer--I do not care about his denigration of me personally--but of Australians who serve their country as a volunteer and he denigrates those people, the overwhelming majority of the world, who live in poverty and disadvantage.

I will not be criticised by the member for Southern Downs about my service as an international volunteer. I do not care about myself but he denigrates all Australians who have served overseas. I remind the member for Southern Downs to read some of the first speeches by the members of the Liberal National Party who were elected to this place in 2009. I ask him to read some of those speeches where they talk about their service as volunteers overseas. I look forward to him denigrating the member for Cleveland and others for being volunteers who have worked overseas. He belittles volunteers. He belittles international volunteering. But most of all he belittles himself. I will say more about the member for Southern Downs as we go through this debate.

Both the member for Chatsworth and the member for Yeerongpilly demolished the criticisms of the LNP about law and order and crime in this state. One statistic that never crosses the lips of members of the Liberal National Party is that crime is down 20 per cent under Labor. That is all I ask them to acknowledge--that crime in Queensland has dropped 20 per cent since Labor was elected to power in 1998. It is one simple fact. If they are unable to acknowledge that, everything they say must be seen through the prism of falsehood and political populism. That is all. That is the only way you can demonstrate it. We do need to lift debate in this state about law and order, but it will never be lifted if the Liberal National Party fails to acknowledge facts about the safety of the Queensland community delivered by Labor governments successively over 12 years.

Let us turn to some of the other issues. I want to talk about some of the fundamental principles in this bill and then I will talk about some of those matters that were raised by the opposition in the debate. Firstly, the bill amends the Penalties and Sentences Act 1992 to create the state’s first Sentencing Advisory Council and to confer power upon the Queensland Court of Appeal to deliver and review guideline judgements. The bill also reflects the Bligh government’s tough-on-crime approach in its three discrete amendments relating to child sexual offenders, repeat offenders and those who commit violence upon or who cause the death of a young child. These are serious matters and are deserving of serious debate in this parliament but debate based on facts.

These amendments represent significant initiatives to strengthen our criminal justice system--a system that plays an important role in creating a safe community for all Queenslanders. Central to our criminal justice system must be a strong and fair sentencing regime. The amendments are best understood in two parts but parts that form a continuum of reforms aimed at improving the clarity and transparency of our sentencing processes and providing a robust foundation upon which our courts can undertake the complex task of sentencing criminal offenders.

The first part of the amendments create a Sentencing Advisory Council for Queensland that will help bridge any gap between community expectations, the courts and the government on the issue of sentencing. Through its education role, the Sentencing Advisory Council will foster greater public understanding of the sentencing processes and competing issues, thereby enhancing public support for sentencing decisions and reforms. Through its community engagement role, the Sentencing Advisory Council will provide an opportunity for the community to have a voice in the development of sentencing policy. Through its research, advice and consultation, the Sentencing Advisory Council will promote sentencing reforms that are well grounded and reflect best practice.

The structure of the Sentencing Advisory Council will ensure a broad range of membership, including community representation. It will recognise the impact of sentencing options on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in Queensland and vulnerable persons facing the criminal justice system. The bill ensures flexibility in the selection of members and provides considerable detail as to the depth of experience or expertise members will possess. This will ensure a fair and representative balance of members. The function of the Sentencing Advisory Council in providing its views to the Court of Appeal on the issue of guideline judgements offers an important new mechanism by which properly gauged and informed public opinion can be injected into the sentencing system. The conferral of jurisdiction on the Queensland Court of Appeal to give or review guideline judgements provides a means by which the Court of Appeal can give guidance to sentencing courts.

The second part of the reforms aims to strengthen the penalties imposed upon child sexual offenders, repeat offenders and offenders who commit violence upon a young child or who cause the death of a young child. Two judicial sentencing principles currently applied by the Queensland courts will be inserted into the Penalties and Sentences Act to make crystal clear to the courts and the community that these sentencing principles are to be followed. Enshrining these principles in statute gives permanency to the principles and clearly signals parliament’s intention with regard to offenders who sexually abuse children and offenders who continue to disregard the law. It will give the community greater certainty and confidence as to the principles that the courts must apply when passing sentence.

The first principle, which relates to child sexual offenders, complements the existing legislative measures aimed at protecting our must vulnerable members of the community. The bill provides that offenders convicted of an offence of a sexual nature in relation to a child under 16 years must serve an actual period of imprisonment, unless there are exceptional circumstances. I want to talk to that issue of exceptional circumstances and about the need to maintain discretion in Queensland courts. There is a line that is now forming between the position consistently held by Labor governments and that of the opposition.

Mandatory sentencing, which removes all aspects of discretion from a court, as the opposition well knows, does not work in reducing crime or delivering just outcomes for Queenslanders. What in fact happens--and the opposition knows it well--is that the criminal justice system is distorted by mandatory sentencing. Firstly, it leads to unjust results. Why? Because all offenders are treated the same. Whether it be a first-time juvenile offender or someone who is a serious criminal with a history of offending, all are treated the same under mandatory sentencing principles. It takes proportionality out of it, and I do not think it represents community values or Queensland values to treat them all the same when there are clearly different types of criminal offending that the court must admit.

Judicial discretion is a fundamental part of our criminal justice system and is retained in this amendment through the inclusion of the ‘exceptional circumstances’ proviso. The most disturbing part of this debate--and there was much to be disturbed by from the comments of members of the Liberal National Party--was their untrammelled desire to remove the exceptional circumstances provision from the amendment. As my second reading speech clearly demonstrates, there are cases where the court must take into account--and should quite properly take into account--matters relating to exceptional circumstances. It is worth repeating the comments that I made during my second reading address to the parliament. I said--
