XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: While it is difficult, if not impossible, to envisage circumstances in which a violent sexual offender might satisfy such a provision and, in doing so, not be sentenced to an actual term of imprisonment, there may be some offences that will be caught by this provision which involve circumstances that warrant further careful consideration. For example, where a 17-year-old and 15-year-old were in a consensual relationship, it might seem unjust that one of them be imprisoned for conduct in the course of the relationship that raised no other inference of criminality but for the fact of their respective ages. These are not easy cases, and nor are they cases in which the appropriate sentence in each case will be non-custodial. As such, the law must be capable of providing a just and appropriate sentence based upon all the facts in a case, most notably where those facts are unusual and differ from more straightforward examples. As a general principle, the strength of our legal system must be measured not only by its capacity to imprison those who transgress the law but also by whether it is sufficiently robust and fair so as to guard against injustice that might be visited upon the few.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is perhaps in the nature of the Liberal National Party that they never seek to defend the few--those who are vulnerable, those without a voice, those who are marginalised. They are swept away in the mad desire by the Liberal National Party to impose mandatory sentencing in Queensland. All I would say to all honourable members opposite, as I say to members on this side of the chamber, is that we have sons and daughters. We have young people who may go into the criminal justice system. How could it possibly be just for one person to be imprisoned--sent to a prison in Queensland to serve actual jail time--in circumstances where the only fundamental factor about their criminal transgression may be their age when all other aspects of their relationship may be consensual? That may not excuse them from a breach of the criminal law. It may not excuse them from punishment. But it is cruel and profoundly wrong for the Liberal National Party to continue to say that young people must go to jail for entering into consensual relationships with each other as young people. It is profoundly wrong and cruel for that to continue to be perpetrated by the Liberal National Party in this state.

It is easy to come into this place and to sloganeer and seek to run public policy on the basis of slogans without substance. We see that every day in this parliament by the Liberal National Party seeking to obtain political advantage, but we must take this debate to a higher place. Labor will always stand for discretion in the criminal justice system and discretion in our courts.

The second principle I mentioned reinforces the government’s and the community’s denunciation of recidivists who continue to disobey the law. The bill ensures that, when sentencing a repeat offender, the court must treat previous relevant convictions as an aggravating factor in determining the appropriate sentence. The result of this is that the court will increase the penalty to be given to the offender within the established common law sentencing range for that conduct. So we leave it to the courts. It is another factor that must be taken into account when determining a sentence. As a safeguard, the bill expressly provides that the penalty imposed must not be disproportionate to the gravity of the current offence--another safeguard that we respect within the government.

Lastly, the bill makes an important amendment to the serious violent offence provisions of the Penalties and Sentences Act. The effect of a serious violent offence declaration is that the offender must serve 80 per cent of their sentence before being eligible to apply for parole release. The amendment targets the small cohort of prisoners who commit the most serious offences--namely, those who commit violence upon a young child or who cause the death of a young child. The amendment recognises the special vulnerability of very young children and the need to legislatively protect them.

The bill provides that, in the case of an offender convicted of an offence of violence committed against a young child or an offence that caused the death of a young child, where the court has the discretion to declare the offender to be convicted of a serious violent offence, the court must treat the age of the child as an aggravating factor in making that determination. We leave it to the courts to determine those categories of individuals who should be declared serious violent offenders--when all of the facts in the case are considered and determined by the court. We leave it to the courts to make that decision. If you remove discretion, if you say that courts must sentence on a mandatory basis--which the opposition suggests--then we may as well bring offenders in Queensland to the bar of this parliament and judge them here ourselves and impose the penalty.
Mr Shine: Get rid of the judicial system.

Mr DICK: We might as well move away from a judicial based justice system. I do not understand the concern when the courts in Queensland have served our state in an overwhelmingly positive way for 150 years. I do not think we should be seeking to attack and denigrate them, as the Liberal National Party does.

I make the point again: under successive Labor governments since 1998, the rate of crime in Queensland has dropped 20 per cent. People are safer in their homes under Labor. They are safer than they have ever been. We have these falsehoods perpetrated by the Liberal National Party. The rate of crime is down 20 per cent. All I ask for is a genuine and good faith acknowledgement of that by those members opposite. When Liberal National Party members talk about crime the way they do, all it does is inflame community concern and anxiety.
Mr Kilburn: Unnecessary.

Mr DICK: It makes people frightened unnecessarily, I take the interjection by the member for Chatsworth. It unnecessarily concerns people in the community. We want to be tough on crime, and we have demonstrated that over 12 years and we will demonstrate it again by introducing standard non-parole periods in Queensland courts. But the difference between mandatory sentencing and standard non-parole periods is this: we will admit discretion in the process. We will say that a court can determine that the sentence can be increased or decreased, but if there is a deviation the court must explain that in accordance with set criteria.

There may be a case where a non-custodial sentence may be imposed, but the court will need to explain that in its judgement. Why? Because every case is different. We cannot move away from a system of individualised justice in Queensland. I say to the member for Southern Downs, as I say to all families, one day it might be your son, your daughter or a relative of yours who goes before a Queensland court and, if you go down the path of mandatory sentencing, all you will do is send more people to jail on an unjust basis and you will not make Queensland safer.

I want to talk to a number of those matters raised by the opposition in this debate. The member for Southern Downs asserted that the presentation of this bill before the House was a recognition that the current sentencing regime had failed. Nothing could be further from the truth. This is a government that listens and responds to the community. We have always done that and we will continue to do that.

Most notably, the member for Southern Downs expressed great dissatisfaction with the Dangerous Prisoners (Sexual Offenders) Act. It is worth noting that, despite all of the honourable member’s complaints and crocodile tears, he cannot escape the fact that under the Liberal and National governments in this state, recidivist sex offenders were released free and clear into the community, without any measure of control. Members of his political organisation were unwilling or unable to keep them in custody. They were unable to bring the appropriate legislation into this place, and that is what Labor did. The most dangerous people in the Queensland community either continue in custody or are released into the community under very strict supervision. For some of those offenders, that means that those provisions prohibit where they can live, who they can associate with, where they can go at what times during the day or night, whether they can consume alcohol--all of those prohibitions are on their lives. Some have up to 40 or 50 different prohibitions. Why? Because we put community safety first.

The member for Southern Downs then went on an extraordinary attack against the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions and the hardworking prosecutors in this state. He claimed that prosecutors were ‘forced into plea bargains’, that they were forced to ‘settle quick and settle easy’. This is a disgraceful slur on the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. It is a cowardly attack. The member for Southern Downs is happy to attack them here but he will not attack them in the community, he will not attack them outside of this chamber where he is protected by parliamentary privilege. It is a craven attack on the Director of Public Prosecutions and his hardworking staff to suggest that they make decisions on any basis other than the publicly available and published guidelines.
Mr Shine: What does it do for their morale?

Mr DICK: That is right; I take the interjection from the member for Toowoomba North. What does that do for the morale of Queensland prosecutors who work at the hard edge of the criminal justice system every day?

The legal community should be on notice once again that it is clear that Liberal National Party members have no respect for the independence of the DPP and would be only too willing to interfere and direct the DPP about what they should prosecute and what they should not. Again, we leave the prosecutorial direction in Queensland to the independent DPP, and I for one as the Attorney-General will never seek to interfere in that. More than that, the member for Southern Downs then went on to complain that the police had too much discretion in charging individuals. So the police are also on notice by the Liberal National Party.

The member for Southern Downs also indulged himself in a complaint about the use of suspended sentences and that they were somehow evidence of improper discretion. What the honourable member ignores, and what LNP members have always ignored--either because they do not understand them or they are too scared to repeat them--is that the statistics tell a very different story. The Australian Bureau of Statistics figures released at the start of this year demonstrate that, for serious offences, Queensland courts are using fully suspended sentences at the second lowest rate in the nation. In the Magistrates Court, Queensland has the lowest rate of suspended sentences in the nation.

The LNP member for Buderim was also interested in the ABS figures but could not quite bring himself to develop a clear understanding of the document. Despite the issues primarily in question in this bill concerning serious sexual and violent offending, the member for Buderim seemed intent on discussing Magistrates Courts figures. Why? Because it fitted their argument to continue to cause concern and distress in the Queensland community about the rate of crime.

The member for Buderim seemed intent on discussing Magistrates Courts figures, where, yes, the Queensland magistrates do not sentence a high proportion of offenders to imprisonment. Why is that? Is it because they have too much discretion? Is it because they love to let criminals walk free in Queensland? No, it is because the vast majority of offences sentenced in the Magistrates Courts are minor offences--things like public nuisance and traffic offences. I would say that the majority of Queenslanders would not expect people who commit public nuisance offences or traffic offences to be going to jail. Should those people go to prison, the question might be asked? According to the member for Buderim, everyone should go to prison because that is all he knows and that is all he wishes to push to cause concern in the community.

The day before the member for Buderim spoke we had a debate in this House about moving those offences out of the Magistrates Court. We talked about an overwhelming number of cases, particularly public nuisance offences, being moved out of the Magistrates Court so they could be ticketable offences--so we could free up courts to deal with the most serious offending and have individuals ticketed by police. That was a debate we had the day before the member for Buderim spoke on the bill.

Finally on this issue, it seemed to me that the member for Buderim sought to deliberately misread chapter 2 of the ABS report containing his figures, which relates to the higher courts. In his address to the parliament he kept mentioning the ‘High Court’. It was not, in fact, the High Court of Australia; it referred to ‘higher courts’. The member seemed to flagrantly ignore the distinction drawn by the ABS between a custodial order, which includes custody in the community and suspended sentences, and custody in a correctional institution, which means exactly what it is: time in prison. To make it clear for the honourable member: when I talk about imprisonment rates in the higher courts, I have used the time in prison figure as the most appropriate and accurate indicator. In order to measure how regularly courts send people to prison it seems sensible to look at a direct measure of how regularly courts send people to jail.

As would be predicted, the member for Southern Downs, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, was at his most shrill when complaining that the Sentencing Advisory Council--as he sought to do--was his own idea. On 11 May 2005 the opposition introduced a private member’s bill to create a Sentencing Advisory Council modelled on the approach in Victoria but with a number of key differences. Quite properly, the private member’s bill was defeated in the House on 29 September 2005. The Sentencing Advisory Council proposed in this bill differs from the opposition’s model in a number of critical and important respects. Unlike the opposition’s model, the bill confers jurisdiction on the Queensland Court of Appeal to give or review guideline judgements and inserts a new part 2A into the Penalties and Sentences Act 1992. One of the statutory functions of the Sentencing Advisory Council will be to provide advice to the Court of Appeal on guideline judgements. This offers an important new mechanism by which properly gauged and informed public opinion can be injected into the sentencing system.

Unlike the opposition’s model, this bill provides a legitimate interface between the council and the Court of Appeal. The council would not be able to give unsolicited advice to the Court of Appeal directly, and that is precisely what the opposition sought to do in its bill in 2005. What did proposed new section 198 of its 2005 bill say? It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The functions of the council are--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) to state in writing to the Court of Appeal its views in relation to the application by courts of the sentencing guidelines and principles in section 9--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is of the Penalties and Sentences Act. We had the opposition setting up a body appointed by the executive to state its views in writing anywhere, any time, on any basis to the Court of Appeal. We would have had a body created by the executive providing its views and directing the Court of Appeal on what it says the applicability of sentencing principles should be.
XML.Hansard-Body: I said earlier in this debate that this is a lazy, fundamentally ignorant, long-term opposition and its members demonstrate it again by their complete failure to understand the doctrine of the separation of powers, that the executive and the legislature are separate from an independent judiciary. They seem to play with these ideas. As one of the opposition members said in the debate two weeks ago, ‘Don’t lecture to us’--meaning the opposition--‘about the doctrine of the separation of powers.’ Why would we want to do that? It is only fundamental to the way in which Queensland democracy works. They seemed to conflate these ideas in their shrill attack during the law and order debate. It is completely improper for a body of the executive to give unsolicited advice to a court--that is, the executive seeking to monster, seeking to direct, seeking to put pressure on the judiciary. We say that the judiciary needs to be separate and independent to make its decisions.

Under the model put forward by the government that is before the House today, the council can only provide advice where the Court of Appeal is considering whether to give or review a guideline judgement. The advice is to be given upon notification by the court of its intention in that regard. The approach maintains the integrity and independence of the court. We put that first. We have this shrill argument put forward, including by a qualified lawyer, the member for Caloundra, that there was no difference between these bills. I can excuse the member for Southern Downs for his ignorance about the matter, but it was stunning to hear the member for Caloundra saying that the bills were ‘exactly the same’. They are far from being exactly the same.

There was an attack on the last resort principle, as we see by the LNP all the time. Its members want to remove that. Of course, for the LNP, justice equals jail. It is their only response. If they looked at the statistics, if they had seen crime drop 20 per cent, they would know there is an interaction between a whole range of sentencing principles and outcomes including, much to the horror of the LNP, non-custodial orders made by courts and non-custodial measures so that people can go back into the community. Why? So they can become productive and functioning members of society where they do not re-offend and do not go back into the justice system--that is what we want to see--resulting in a reduction in crime by 20 per cent under Labor.

There were a number of other stunning contributions in the debate by members opposite. The member for Kawana, joining in the rancid tradition of what is a lazy, ignorant, long-term opposition, said that it was time to ‘listen to the LNP on law and order’. Let us take that invitation and think about the depth of the LNP law and order plan. I will take the advice of the member for Gaven and say it like it is, as he said. The LNP wants to publicly name persons who may be part of the witness protection program. The LNP wants to force the DPP to report to parliament if they do not like his independent decisions. This is what they have done in the last 18 months. The LNP wants to discipline wayward judges for political reasons. That is what they said in the debate two weeks ago. The LNP wants to treat first-time offenders in the same way as career criminals. For the LNP, the member for Gaven and all those members opposite, that is how it is. It would be a sad day, indeed, if the LNP ever got their hands on a justice system because it would not be a justice system; it would be an injustice system. With those concluding remarks, I commend this bill to the parliament.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 4, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr SPRINGBORG (3.27 pm): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Indent2: Page 4, lines 23 and 24, ‘, unless there are exceptional circumstances’--
‘that ensures the offender has adequate time to access and complete a rehabilitation program’.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Explanatory notes to Mr Springborg’s amendments to the Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill [ 3464 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: As I indicated in my contribution to the second reading speech, whilst being generally supportive of the principle of the bill, the LNP has some very serious reservations with regard to the way that the bill will be used and the way that it will be interpreted. Chief amongst those is the fact that the government promises to get really tough and really consistent when it comes to the application of the criminal law in Queensland with regard to violent sexual offences or sexual offences against children. However, if we read the provisions of the legislation, nothing could be further from the truth.

The first amendment that I am moving here today deals very much with the issue of the sentencing of that offender and making sure that the person is subjected to a period of incarceration which will ensure that they undertake a process of compulsory rehabilitation. We know that under this government there is not a formal, proper, consistent process of people undertaking sex offenders rehabilitation courses in Queensland. It is just not happening. Indeed, some 80 to 90 per cent of sexual offenders in our prison system go through the prison system--and that is a statistic that we cannot argue about--without, firstly, being offered a sexual offenders rehabilitation course or, secondly, successfully completing that particular course. That is of real concern.

If the government is serious about breaking the cycle of sex offending by these people who often have predatory behaviour and if the government is serious about ensuring a rehabilitative environment then the least it can do is support this amendment, which is about ensuring that the period of incarceration considered by the sentencing court is commensurate with the amount of time it would take a person to undertake a sex offenders rehabilitation course. I think the community at large is absolutely dumbfounded by the notion that we have people graduating from the jail system who have been charged, convicted and then ordered to complete a sex offenders rehabilitation course who are not completing that sex offender rehabilitation course in our jails.

This ties in with the other amendment that I intend to move in relation to prescribing the circumstances under which a person can be considered for what the Attorney-General says are exceptional circumstances. I will say some more on that when I move that amendment.

I will turn to the fallacy, the fabrication--deliberate or otherwise--and the almost deliberate verballing by the Attorney-General about what I have actually indicated in this place. I have no problem with the courts actually handing down their sentence--as they do and as they should appropriately do--but this parliament is the one that is responsible for laying down the guidelines that will guide our courts. If we completely trusted the courts to meet community expectations, if we had absolute faith and confidence in them, we would not have codified criminal law. We would have a common law environment in Queensland where it is up to the courts to decide how to deal with and sentence offenders, as used to exist before the codification of the criminal law.

Every time this government comes into this place and seeks to move an amendment to the Criminal Code, seeks to move an amendment to the Penalties and Sentences Act or seeks to move an amendment to what are now going to be minimum standard non-parole periods--which is all but minimum sentences dressed up in a form of sentencing drag--it is simply restricting and watering down the discretion of the courts. It takes away the courts’ discretion.

The reason for that is that the government is now having to react to the community at large who are seeing some sentences--not the majority but some--which are inconsistently being handed down or have endangered the community as a consequence of the release of a particular person. That is why the government has belatedly been forced to react in this particular way. The reason the Premier had to say in a very grandiose way on Monday that we are going to now have minimum standard non-parole periods is that the community has concerns and community expectation is not being properly met by the courts. As the honourable member for Hinchinbrook said in another debate yesterday, we have had this conversion on the road to Damascus.

The other thing the Attorney did not and could not answer and needs to answer as part of any response is what happened in Victoria when that government tried to address community concerns with regard to what was a worry about the overuse of suspended sentences for repeat and violent offenders. They actually said, ‘We are going to change the laws so you can suspend sentences, but they can only be granted in exceptional circumstances.’ What has all the academic research actually shown since that time? What has all the data actually shown since that time? It has shown--and this comes from people who are experienced in this area--that the courts are now interpreting exceptional circumstances in the most broad way and finding a whole range of ways to get around that.

The rate of release on suspended sentences has not tightened up. If anything, it is the same or getting worse. When the courts have a broad extrapolation of the term ‘exceptional circumstances’, they will always find a way to address what they--and justifiably for them--see as their province--that is, complete judicial discretion. We have to understand that the courts and the judges who sit in courts have rightly been appointed for what is basically a lifetime. Regardless of our political arguments in this place, they do not have to feel the pressure of being re-elected and being directly accountable to the community. They find it quite reprehensible that the actions we take in here--in Victoria in that circumstance--absolutely impugn, mitigate and water down their judicial discretion--that which they see as a birthright of a judicial officer. They find a way of doing it. That is the basis on which they start, and that is fair enough.

However, we are the judge of community opinion. We are the people who are out there in our communities hearing their concerns. It is our responsibility to legislate. People will be extremely cynical if a government passes a law which seems to give the community more support and greater security by saying that people can only be released under exceptional circumstances and then nothing really changes--that is, that the courts find a way to interpret exceptional circumstances, as they do. This parliament will have done nothing other than breed justifiable community cynicism. That has been the experience with regard to this particular exceptional circumstance provision. It is a get-out-of-jail-free clause in many ways.

This first amendment relates to the criteria that a judge must consider when actually deciding whether to incarcerate a person. It requires that the judge has to take into consideration the availability of a sex offender rehabilitation program. I think that should be a primary concern.

This government talks first and foremost about the issue of rehabilitation. That is fair enough from their viewpoint. I actually also support the notion of rehabilitation but not at the exclusion of community protection, which should be one of the other major considerations. Mixed in amongst that, there has to be an amount of accountability for the person’s actions--that is, punishment for what they have done.

Jail should very much be about community protection. It should be about making someone fully accountable and punishing them for their actions and appropriately rehabilitating them. This amendment is about making sure that that rehabilitative environment is front and centre in the judges’ minds when they decide the sentences of offenders. I do not know how anyone would not be prepared to actually support that particular principle.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order! Before calling the Attorney, I would like to acknowledge in the gallery members of the Mount Tamborine Probus Club.

Mr DICK: I also welcome those Queenslanders to their House. Can I just go to the clause first before I respond to the whirling dervish of an address by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition covering a whole range of issues. I might actually deal with the clause first.

In relation to the amending clause, the inclusion of the exceptional circumstances provision is important. I addressed that in the second reading debate. In the vast majority of these types of cases, it is indeed inconceivable that circumstances exist that may justify an offender not serving time in prison. But the provision in this bill about circumstances is about exceptional circumstances.

The phrase is one with which the courts are familiar. I am of the view that the circumstances that amount to exceptional are better able to be assessed on a case-by-case basis. I do not want to take individualised justice out of our system of justice in Queensland because every case is different, every offender is different, the effect on offenders is different, the nature of offending is different in every case and the circumstances and the antecedents of offenders is different in every case. If we move away from individualised justice, we might as well get rid of the courts and bring offenders here and put them at the bar of the House and tell them what every sentence is going to be by setting a penalty of imprisonment, which is what the LNP wishes to do by introducing mandatory sentencing.

The phrase in the context of this sentencing principle has previously been interpreted by the Court of Appeal. The Chief Justice observed that synonyms for ‘exceptional’ are ‘unusual’ and ‘extraordinary’. Justice Chesterman stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: To qualify as exceptional, the circumstances of the offender or the offence must be properly identifiable as truly out of the ordinary or extraordinary.
XML.Hansard-Body: The Chief Justice and a justice of the Court of Appeal have both said words to that effect. The bill also provides that, in deciding whether there are exceptional circumstances, a court must have regard to the closeness in age between the offender and the child. This will be particularly relevant when sentencing, for example, a young offender for conduct that occurred in the context of a consensual relationship with a partner aged just less than 16 years, and I do not think we should be excluding that from our justice system. The law must be capable of providing a just and appropriate sentence based on all of the facts in a case, most notably where those facts are unusual and extraordinary. As a general principle, the strength of our legal system must be measured not only by its capacity to imprison those who transgress the law but also by whether it is sufficiently robust and fair so as to guard against injustices that might be visited upon the few.

During the course of the debate the member for Southern Downs, as is his wont, as he often does, completely changed his position from the second reading debate to the clauses. During the debate he made reference to and quoted positively I think, if I am not mistaken, from an article by Bravehearts--a very fine group in the community working with victims of child sexual abuse. He said that that article--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... concluded that all sex offenders constitute a real risk to children and that this risk is lifelong.
XML.Hansard-Body: The member for Southern Downs quoted that with approval during the debate. If that is his view--if he genuinely believes that all sex offenders constitute a real risk to children and that this risk is lifelong--what possible purpose would rehabilitation form if he genuinely believes that? But maybe he changed his view from the second reading debate to today.

In relation to rehabilitation--and I have asked this in the House before and I am yet to receive a response from the LNP--what is the LNP’s legal advice that says you can detain people in custody until they have very satisfactorily--and it is undetermined what ‘satisfactorily’ means--completed a rehabilitation course? What is the legal authority that says you can detain prisoners indefinitely in Queensland? I am very happy for you to table the advice. I am very happy for you to table the advice of the Senior Counsel or Queen’s Counsel that you have, the constitutional advice. I ask the member for Southern Downs: does he have that advice? Has he ever sought legal advice? That is the policy of the LNP--that sex offenders must be kept in custody until they satisfactorily complete a sexual offenders course. Have you got the advice?
Mr Springborg: Just sit down. I’ll answer the question.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Wendt): Order, members!
Mr DICK: No, you will not provide the advice now, but I ask him to table it.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Attorney, you will direct your comments through the chair.

Mr DICK: I ask him to table the advice. We fell back on the old get-out-of-jail-free card. We had that. Another slogan that was thrown out there was that individuals who are released on parole--that is, not finished their sentence--are sent out into the community but under strict supervision. That is a get-out-of-jail-free card--suspended sentences, get out of jail, notwithstanding the fact that an individual may be convicted of an offence. That may go on their record. It may damage their prospects of employment for the rest of their life, branding them a criminal. It seems those things do not matter to the LNP--unless, of course, it is jail. I have not been persuaded by the arguments of the Liberal National Party in relation to that matter. I have not been persuaded that excluding exceptional circumstances will lead to more justice in Queensland. In fact, I think it will lead to injustice in our state, and I ask him again to table the advice that says that individuals can be detained in custody indefinitely--contrary to the decision of the High Court and Kable, Fardon and a whole range of other cases. I ask him--
Mr Shine: Don’t worry about that!

Mr DICK: Don’t worry about the High Court. That is right; I take the interjection from the member for Toowoomba North--only the highest legal authority in the nation! I ask him to demonstrate to this House the legal authority that he has--the advice that he has--that it is possible to detain prisoners in jail indefinitely until they complete satisfactorily to the LNP’s requirements--undefined--a sexual offenders rehabilitation course.
Mr SPRINGBORG: In responding to one of the world’s great verballers, who would have loved to have been around in the 1980s in Queensland--
Government members interjected.
Mr DICK: Mr Deputy Speaker--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Is there a point of order?

Mr DICK: There is a point of order. I argue on the merits of the case, but I reject utterly that reflection on my personal character that I am a verballer or that I would have fitted into Queensland in the 1980s. I seek that the honourable member withdraw that comment.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: The member finds it personally offensive. Would you withdraw please?
Mr SPRINGBORG: I withdraw.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Thank you.

Mr SPRINGBORG: I would like to refer the Attorney to a whole range of absolutely outrageous and scurrilous allegations that he has thrown towards me in recent times in debates which were completely and absolutely without foundation. Nowhere have I ever said in this place--
Honourable members interjected.
Mr Bleijie interjected.
Honourable members interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order, members! The member for Southern Downs has the call.

Mr SPRINGBORG: Paraphaser, as the honourable member for Kawana said. Nowhere have I ever said that a person can successfully be held ad infinitum beyond the time for which they have been given a finite sentence. Indeed, if the Attorney goes back to the debate that we had in this place a couple of weeks ago on legislation that was supposedly about ensuring that an offender could be kept or monitored for a particular period of time, I said then that I felt that the legislation which the government put in place with regard to serious dangerous sex offenders a number of years ago was probably pushing the envelope as much as one possibly could.

However, there is another way of doing it, and that is ensuring that all repeat violent sex offenders receive an indefinite sentence at the time of sentencing and then you are able to keep them virtually at Her Majesty’s pleasure. That is how you do it--that is, have the infinite sentence up here and then start to work back from there. That is how you deal with that. I make no excuses for quoting Bravehearts in this place because it was only indicating its concerns about these people not being able to be rehabilitated. I am not sure that it is impossible to rehabilitate all of these people, and I have never said that all of them could never be rehabilitated. However, I have said that there is a track record and history, research and data shows that many of these offenders--a higher rate than any other category of offender--go on to reoffend, so therefore if they are to be released we need to be very concerned about ensuring there are ultimate protection regimes in place for the community at large. That is what I have indicated all the way along completely and absolutely consistently, and if members read what I have said in this place I think they will find verification of that.

I want to explain these two amendments for honourable members. The first amendment relates to adult offenders. It basically says that an adult offender cannot be released by the court until that offender has been sentenced to a period of detention which ensures that they have adequate time to access and complete a rehabilitation program. The Attorney might want to argue about that, but one would actually hope that within a few months in prison there should be available such a program for that person. The amendment does not even prescribe the successful completion of that program, but one would hope that that particular program should be made available to that offender and that that offender should undertake that program. That is what it says. Nowhere does this amendment say that that person is to be kept in prison forever. Nowhere does this amendment say that. I have previously said that I have no problems with the Bravehearts proposition that subsequent serious violent sex offenders--that is, people who have offended, been to prison and do it again--should be locked up indefinitely. I have no problem with that whatsoever. I support that absolutely, but that is not what this amendment is about because this deals with the sentencing of potentially first-time offenders. The amendment does not prescribe that particular period, so therefore the issue of legal advice is an absolute erroneous argument.

The subsequent amendment relates to the issue of how we deal with juvenile offenders. I understand that there may be this circumstance, even though the Attorney has not provided statistics, where somebody young might be maintaining what has otherwise been a consensual relationship with some childhood sweetheart and they come into the age where they can be held criminally responsible. Therefore, this amendment seeks to limit that particular judicial discretion which the government says is exceptional circumstances in the case of juveniles only. That is the next amendment which I intend to move.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I want to make just a short contribution. I understand where the member for Southern Downs is coming from in terms of the amendment to clause 5, which removes ‘unless there are exceptional circumstances’ to ensure that an offender who is serving a custodial sentence should have and should be made to have adequate time to access and complete a rehabilitation program. It is a difficult job to get perpetrators incarcerated for sex crimes, especially against children. But it is difficult for the victims of those crimes to see a perpetrator perhaps get a custodial sentence but during that time never once admit their guilt. So they do not do a sex crimes rehabilitation program. They come out and still claim their innocence, and that is devastating for victims of those types of crimes.

However, I am concerned about removing ‘unless there are exceptional circumstances’. It is important to go to clause 5A to see what the Attorney-General means by ‘exceptional circumstances’. I am not a lawyer--there are plenty of those in here--but I am assuming that the example in clause 5A would be used by the courts to interpret the intent of this legislation. The clause states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... a court may have regard to the closeness in age between the offender and the child.
XML.Hansard-Body: So if the child is a 14- or 15-year-old person and they have an active sexual relationship with another person who may be 17 or 18, the courts would have regard to exceptional circumstances--and I believe that the Attorney-General has already confirmed that and I value that confirmation. I understand from talking with the shadow minister, the member for Southern Downs, that his exemption would be only in those circumstances where both offenders were below the age of majority that is recognised in Queensland.

I am using the term ‘exceptional circumstances’, and I hope that is what the minister means and intends in his bill, but I am concerned that there could be people who are over the age of 17 or 18 and who should be dealt with as juveniles simply because of their state of mind--not because they are diagnosed as having any kind of impairment but because of their state of mind. I would like to think that judges would have some discretion to be able to take into account the circumstances and the state of mind of all of the participants in the incident.

I am not in any way, shape or form condoning or agreeing with or saying that it is in any way acceptable for harm to be done to children, but I do not support mandatory sentencing for the reason--and I have already said this in a previous debate--that there are at times circumstances of mitigation or provocation that the courts need to be able to consider. I am very concerned that if ‘exceptional circumstances’ is removed altogether it could mean that somebody will have their life impacted--or both parties--when perhaps the matter should have been considered differently.

Mr DICK: I thank the member for Gladstone for her thoughtful contribution to the debate on this clause. I think she has really summarised the argument very well in the sense that we need to retain the ability of the court on a discretionary basis to consider who falls outside this sort of principle. It is a significant principle to say that anyone who commits a sex offence against an individual under the age of 16 years must serve an actual term of imprisonment. An ‘actual term of imprisonment’ is defined in the legislation to require somebody to serve time in a custodial facility. So it is a very important matter.

I acknowledge the point that the member for Gladstone made about someone with perhaps an impairment of mind which might mean that their adult age may be a certain age but their functioning age may be less. Those individuals may not necessarily go into the formal criminal justice system--they may go into the mental health system--but I think the argument that the member makes is a very important one. I have said, probably in different ways during the debate, that we must always admit discretion into the system. If we do not, we go down a very rocky and dark path towards mandatory sentencing, which will have unjust results for individuals.

On the issue of what is ‘exceptional circumstances’, I do not know whether the honourable member was here earlier to hear the debate on the clause, but I made reference earlier to how I do not think it is possible to define in legislation what exceptional circumstances are. I think you need to look at it on a case-by-case basis, but by saying ‘exceptional circumstances’ it already narrows the field.

In short compass I point out to the member for Gladstone that the Chief Justice has observed previously that synonyms for ‘exceptional’ are ‘unusual’ and ‘extraordinary’ and that encompasses the cases that we have been talking about earlier about someone who may not function at the same level as other individuals because of an impairment of some description. Justice Chesterman, who is a justice of the Court of Appeal, has stated that to qualify as ‘exceptional’ the circumstances of the offender or the offence must be properly identifiable as truly out of the ordinary or extraordinary. So we have ‘unusual’, ‘extraordinary’ and ‘out of the ordinary’ and you have to identify that criteria.

So this is a very significant thing. Effectively, we are enshrining that sentencing principle that the Court of Appeal has adopted for the best part of a decade and a half in Queensland. But it makes it crystal clear in legislation that those who offend against children in a sexual nature should spend an actual period of time in imprisonment. I hope that clarifies the issue for the honourable member. I agree with the honourable member when it comes to the enormous frustration that victims of crime in particular but also members of the general community feel about individuals--not just individuals who commit sex offences but anyone who offends and who is convicted of a crime--who forever proclaim their innocence. In fact, that happens in Queensland courts all the time. I am sure that as recently as yesterday in a court in Queensland there were individuals who were proclaiming their innocence notwithstanding a conviction. That is deeply frustrating for people.

The balance there, of course, is that individuals are autonomous, free people and, no matter what the offending, some people will never admit to their guilt. In fact, there is a saying that is often heard in the Queensland legal profession that there are many prisoners who believe they are innocent and they constantly proclaim their innocence, notwithstanding the overwhelming evidence that may have convicted them. That is very frustrating. I do not know how you can change that. I do not know how you can change people. We have a very significant number of programs that are offered in prisons. Often the best way to change people is by people making the decision to change their own lives, as I am sure the honourable member would accept and would have experience of. But how you get people to make that decision is the great challenge, I think, sometimes.

Mr SPRINGBORG:
In response to the member for Gladstone’s concerns--and I acknowledge that they are consistent and heartfelt--I just want to explain these two amendments again. This first amendment would indicate that a person is not eligible for exceptional circumstances if they are an adult offender and they would have to be sentenced to a period of incarceration which would see them have adequate time in which to complete a rehabilitation program. I could have put in ‘compulsorily’ complete a rehabilitation program, but I have not done that. So it is ‘complete a rehabilitation program’.

The next amendment, which I intend to move, will make it clear that that particular provision does not apply to those who are juvenile offenders. The honourable member may feel that that amendment still restricts the discretion of the court too much and may feel that there may be circumstances in which those people who are outside the category of juvenile offender--that is, those people who are aged 17 years and over--should also be subject to that circumstance of exception, which I am seeking to clarify in regard to this particular legislation. However, that debate about the age at which somebody is a juvenile and the age at which somebody is no longer a juvenile is a debate that we have not really had in this parliament. Certainly, that debate has been held in other jurisdictions around Australia from time to time. Occasionally, the issue raises its head in a bit of byplay in Queensland.

I keep reading the clause over and over again. The government’s clause 5, which is the next one that I am hoping to have amended--and obviously on the numbers I would imagine that is not going to happen with the government refusing to support it--says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: For subsection (5)(b), in deciding whether there are exceptional circumstances, a court may have regard to the closeness in age between the offender and the child.
XML.Hansard-Body: It does not say ‘must only have regard’, it says ‘may have regard’. My subsequent amendment will seek to ensure that that is the circumstance, by classifying that it could only apply to a juvenile offender. If the government does not like it maybe it should move another amendment in this place and say that it is the age criteria that should be the consideration for exceptional circumstances. That has been the only argument that the government has been able to use here and in the community: you have to consider the issue of statutory rape and the age difference of the offender. That is what it keeps talking about. There does not seem to be any other extrapolation of exceptional circumstance. If that is the issue then the government should move an amendment to ensure that it only relates to an age criteria.

I suggest that the honourable member for Gladstone and other honourable members here--and this point has not been able to be undermined in any way by the Attorney--look at what the Victorian Sentencing Advisory Council, a very similar body to this one that the Attorney is establishing today, has said about what happened in that state when they put an exceptional circumstances clause into the application of suspended sentencing. They reviewed it and said that the judiciary found all sorts of ways to define and utilise the terminology ‘exceptional circumstances’, so it did not really change anything. There was no significant reduction in the number of suspended sentences that were being applied to offenders in the circumstances that they were hoping to avoid. Judges found a way to extrapolate and define exceptional circumstances to go about doing the things that they were always doing and wanted to do, as is their wont and as is their right as historically judges have been able to do because of their judicial discretion. That is the concern.

I say to the honourable member for Gladstone that I suspect--and I hope I am wrong--that at some time in the future we will be having a debate in this place after a review by the Sentencing Advisory Council, or someone else who collects this data, finds that exceptional circumstances are applied in very broad circumstances well outside of what the government has been seeking to talk about as its only safe haven to justify this, and that is the relative closeness of age when it comes to the offender and the victim. This is much broader than what one would think and we should at least be defining that in a way so that it is not open to abuse.

Mr WELLINGTON: I would like to thank the member for Southern Downs for introducing his amendments. My understanding is that by introducing those amendments it has put on the parliamentary record, not only for the records of parliament but also for the judiciary should it come to pass that the judiciary need some clarification, what the Attorney-General is intending. There will be an opportunity for clarification by reference specifically to the amendments the member for Southern Downs has moved, the questions he has asked, the comments made by my colleague the member for Gladstone, and the comments made by the Attorney-General and other members during this consideration.

During my contribution earlier I made the comment that I was looking forward to this stage of the debate so that we could better flesh out what was intended both by the opposition in the opposition’s amendment and also better clarification of the wording of the bill that the Attorney-General has proposed. I am comfortable with proceeding and supporting the Attorney-General in his proposal. I believe that the concerns that the shadow Attorney-General, the member for Southern Downs, has raised will certainly send a very clear message to the judiciary. The way that the Attorney-General has responded should also send a very clear message to the judiciary. If they need any clarification as to what is intended, simply refer to the debate on this bill and the debate on the clauses. There should be no doubt what is intended.

I am flagging that I am intending to support my colleague, the member for Gladstone, and the Attorney-General in his proposal and not support the member for Southern Downs. If the shadow Attorney-General’s concerns are realised, I am more than happy, if I happen to be returned at the next election, to stand in this chamber and support further refinement and amendments. If it comes to pass that the judiciary ignores the very clear direction that this parliament is making, we have a responsibility to review and further refine the legislation and the directions that we provide to the judiciary.

I will be supporting my colleague, the member for Gladstone. I thank her for her contribution. Can I say that boys of 17 years of age may be at different stages of maturity. Some may well be beyond their years and others may be far below it. I personally believe that we need to ensure that the judiciary does have the capacity to exercise its discretion. I believe the Attorney-General has clarified very clearly what we are intending to achieve. Again, I thank the shadow Attorney-General for introducing these clauses and I look forward to the debate on the further amendments that he intends to move to provide clarification and, can I say, very clear direction to the judiciary on the way this parliament wants these amendments to be interpreted.

Mr DICK: I thank the member for Nicklin for his contribution. There is one matter I would seek to clarify. Earlier in the debate I had said that my understanding was that the Liberal National Party had stated publicly previously that sexual offenders should not be released unless they had completed a sexual offender’s rehabilitation course. I asked the member for Southern Downs on what basis did they hold the view that Queensland courts would be committed to do that and I asked him to table advice. Of course, he resorted to seeking to criticise me by saying I was verballing him. For the benefit of the parliament and all Queenslanders, on 16 July this year in a quote in a media release issued by the member for Southern Downs--and these words are in a quote, they are not paraphrased, they are attributed to him--the member for Southern Downs stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Repeat sex offenders who commit further offences should be jailed and made to complete rehabilitation programs and prove they are no longer a risk before they are released back into the community.
XML.Hansard-Body: The reality is that the policy position of the Liberal National Party is that repeat sexual offenders must be made--it is a mandatory process--to complete a rehabilitation program and prove they are no longer a risk before they are released. So it is continuing detention unless the convicted offender can do that. He should not be saying that that is not the policy of the LNP when clearly it is.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Division: Question put--That the member for Southern Downs’s amendment be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: AYES, 31--Bates, Bleijie, Crandon, Cripps, Davis, Dempsey, Dickson, Douglas, Dowling, Emerson, Flegg, Gibson, Hopper, Johnson, Langbroek, McArdle, McLindon, Malone, Menkens, Messenger, Nicholls, Powell, Pratt, Robinson, Seeney, Simpson, Springborg, Stevens, Stuckey. Hon. RE SCHWARTEN (Rockhampton--ALP) (Minister for Public Works and Information and Communication Technology) (4.14 pm), by leave: I would like to respond to issues raised in the Bundaberg NewsMail today, supported by the member for Burnett, by a number of consumers affected by the collapse of Coral Coast Homes and/or Steel Smart Homes. At the outset let me say that, after Coral Coast Homes collapsed, the BSA paid out $1.3 million in insurance claims in 28 claims. So the suggestion that nothing was done for those people is simply incorrect and can be proven to be incorrect, and it ought to be recanted.

I wish to firstly advise the House that, as a company conducting construction work, Coral Coast Homes held a BSA licence while Steel Smart Homes, as a supplier of kit homes, did not require one. This is why the Building Services Authority took action for homeowners affected by the collapse of Coral Coast Homes and the Office of Fair Trading took action against Steel Smart Homes.

It is disappointing to see successful claimants of the BSA’s Home Warranty Insurance Scheme criticising the BSA. As they have decided to complain to the media, I feel it only right that I explain what has been done to assist them. Senior BSA staff personally met with many claimants and guided them through the process to secure payments under the scheme.

These critics include Mr Denis Seth, who contracted Steel Smart Homes to supply a kit home and Coral Coast Homes to construct it. I am informed that Mr Seth was offered the chance to have his home completed at no cost to him by another licensed builder selected through a tender process. So he was offered to have his home completed by a licensed builder at no cost to him, and what did Mr Seth do? He declined to do so. He declined this offer and chose to complete the home as an owner-builder. As such, he chose to provide his own labour, thereby excluding him from claiming it as an expense under the scheme.

Mr Seth agreed to these terms prior to restarting work on his house, knowing he could not be reimbursed for his personal expenses. The BSA assisted Mr Seth to the full extent of the agreement but, despite this and after receiving almost $46,000 under the scheme, he has complained he is out of pocket after completing his home. No-one forced him to become an owner-builder. He chose to do that himself.

The article also quotes Nola Binder, who built with Coral Coast Homes, as saying the BSA payment ‘eventually covered her cost but she went in circles trying to get help’. Let us look at the facts. Ms Binder claims that the BSA was not interested in her claim until political pressure occurred. This is plainly incorrect, given that she lodged a non-completion claim on 19 June 2009 and an inspection of her property by BSA inspectors occurred four days later--just four days later. She received approval of--wait for it--$71,833 within two months, allowing for work to recommence.

I just recently made an insurance claim myself and I had to wait about five months. It was a personal item that was lost--an iPad as a matter of fact. I claimed insurance on that and I had to wait four or five months to get all of the evidence correct and all the rest of it. It is not unusual for people to have to wait a period of time. I would suggest that two months is not that long. I do appreciate that it is difficult circumstances for people but to suggest that there was no help available is simply incorrect.

Another customer of Coral Coast Homes, David Kapp, also made a number of allegations in the article. I am advised Kapp entered into a contract with Coral Coast Homes for the supply and construction of a kit home for $134,607 on 13 February 2008. On 19 January 2009, Kapp terminated the contract before the house was completed, and took up occupancy. The amount paid by Kapp under the contract before termination was $121,434, leaving $13,173 in his own pocket unpaid.

Mr Kapp later lodged a defect claim in relation to plumbing and drainage work. On top of the defects claim, Mr Kapp claimed liquidated damages, personal costs to remove trees, loss due to damage to a fence and legal costs. In relation to the defective plumbing work, Mr Kapp has been advised that, as he still retains $13,173 of the contract price, the insurance scheme will only pay any cost overrun beyond the $13,173. You cannot double dip. However, Kapp has not provided any further information and the BSA is of the belief that Kapp cannot substantiate expenses in excess of the $13,173. All Mr Kapp has to do is to provide the evidence. The BSA, like every other insurer, requires evidence before it pays out. Kapp has never provided that evidence.

Today’s Bundaberg NewsMail also mentions Chris Dalby, an owner-builder. Let me advise the House that owner-builders are not provided with cover under the Home Warranty Insurance Scheme, and this is made very clear to them on the owner-builder application form. Dalby purchased a kit home in 2008 from materials supplier Steel Smart Homes, who are not required to hold a BSA licence. He did not have a contract with construction company Coral Coast Homes, and as an owner-builder was well aware of the risks and his responsibility when he applied for the permit. In other words, Dalby is trying to claim an insurance payout for a policy he has not purchased. Even the most basic understanding of insurance tells us that you cannot claim insurance if you do not have a policy and have not paid a premium. I wonder who needs a reality check on that issue.

If the Bundaberg NewsMail editor believes that people who do not pay for a policy are entitled to insurance cover, all I can say is that that is a novel idea. The fact is that kit homes are not covered by the BSA and nor will they be, and anyone who owner-builds one knows this. Owner-builders are not covered, and they again know that. Yet Mr Seth, with the support of the NewsMail editor, continues to try to claim for something that he is not entitled to.

Ms Binder got $71,833 from the Home Warranty Insurance Scheme within two months of claiming, yet the editor of the NewsMail claims that the BSA gave not one iota of help. The Bundaberg NewsMail wants the BSA insurance to pay Mr Kapp, who refuses to provide evidence of his claims. One wonders if this is the official position of APN. Is it really their view that insurance should be paid when there is no supporting evidence given by people about it? I do not think most sensible people would believe that. I certainly do not believe that APN would have a policy that says that if you do not have any evidence you should be paid.
In the editorial today, the NewsMail editor said that most victims of housing collapses had not received one iota of help from the state government. The facts prove something different.
Mr Wendt: Shame on them.

Mr SCHWARTEN: It is a shame. There has been $1.3 million paid out to 28 people. Two of the people named on the front page of the NewsMail today say in the story that they got a payment from the BSA. One said they were very happy with it. The other people have had extensive dealings with the BSA. The editor’s claim that not one iota of help came from the state government is contradicted by her own paper, and one wonders if she reads her own front page. The facts speak for themselves.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Penalties and Sentences (Sentencing Advisory Council) Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from p. 4034
Resumed on clause 5--
Mr SPRINGBORG (4.23 pm): I move the following amendment--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: ‘(5A) However, if the offender is convicted as a child under the Youth Justice Act 1992 , subsection (5) does not apply if the court is satisfied exceptional circumstances exist.’.’.
XML.Hansard-Body: As I indicated when I spoke previously, there has been a significant assertion from the government, the Attorney and other people during this debate that this particular exceptional circumstance clause should generally only apply when there is a not insignificant age difference between the offender and the victim--that is, if they have been involved in some sort of sweetheart juvenile relationship and it would be unjust to actually punish them in such a way. This amendment seeks to ensure that the circumstances under which a person can be considered for exceptional circumstances only relate to the case of juvenile offenders and I believe prescribes those circumstances.

It is important to establish these facts. If indeed the Attorney is concerned that this is such a problem, I would like the Attorney to provide this parliament with some figures on how many of these people are actually charged each year in Queensland and how many of these people are successfully prosecuted each year in Queensland. An existing amount of discretion is being used by both the Queensland Police Service in choosing whether to investigate and charge these cases--that is beyond doubt--and the Director of Public Prosecutions in choosing whether to actually prosecute those cases.

If members think what I am saying is wrong, I draw their attention to the 2008-09 annual report of the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions. With regard to the decision to prosecute, page 40 talks about public interest criteria. It states that they consider ‘the youth, age, physical or mental health or special infirmity of the alleged offender or a necessary witness’. So ‘youth’ would indicate that they already consider anyone who is classified as a youth, and I would imagine that does not necessarily even prescribe it to where I am trying to prescribe it, which is ‘juvenile’. I think anyone up to the age of 18 or 19 in Queensland is considered to be a youth.

It is quite conceivable, under those prosecutorial guidelines which are now being used by the Director of Public Prosecutions to look at the prosecution of offenders, that we could have a situation in Queensland where somebody who is 18 years of age and who is maintaining a consensual relationship with somebody who falls in the category of somebody who can be offended against may not be prosecuted because of those particular exceptional circumstances.

Further, page 43 at section 5(v)(b) states that anyone who is a child should not necessarily be prosecuted in a range of circumstances, and one of them is ‘for sexual experimentation involving children of similar ages in consensual activity’. If the Attorney is going to continue to proffer this argument that there is such a problem with regard to people being charged and pursued through the prosecutorial process and indeed sentenced in our courts because they have maintained a consensual relationship and they are very close in age and they are young people, then I think it behoves the Attorney to indicate to this parliament how many of these circumstances he is aware of.

Over the last few days of this argument we have seen something we could all be concerned about--that is, the undue and unjust prosecution of one young person when two young people have been in a relationship where one of them is not at the age of consent and the other is at the age of consent but they have their own version of juvenile love. If that is the case, the Attorney needs to explain to the parliament. Otherwise, it is a very cynical argument to couch what is a very, very broad get-out-of-jail-free card in very emotional terms and use the emotional excuse which is being used in this parliament to try to make members balk at refining or even doing away with exceptional circumstances criteria altogether.

I think the Attorney needs to give this parliament some idea of how many times we have seen these sorts of relationships. I am not talking about a violent circumstance, where somebody at the age of 17 has actually set out and had unlawful carnal knowledge of somebody under the age of consent, or indeed even somebody who is 15 years of age who has sexually abused somebody of a similar age. We are talking here about consensual sexual relationships between youth where there are these so-called unjust circumstances. I think it is very necessary for the Attorney to clarify it to this parliament.

Mr DICK: The reality is that there are two choices in the criminal justice system and in the courts: either you have discretion or you do not. In the amendment put forward--and I will go to the heart of this amendment shortly--the opposition does not want discretion in sentencing courts. During the debate we had this denigration of the DPP by the member opposite, including on plea bargaining and how people were getting out of jail free. He was criticising the exercise of discretion by prosecutors in the debate, and now he says that discretion is fine: ‘There’s nothing wrong with that. That’s what the guidelines provide.’

The reality is that opposition members wish to take discretion out of the system altogether by the amendments put forward by the member for Southern Downs. By doing so, they will distort the justice system. His own argument proves the case because what will happen is that police prosecutors and staff in the Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions will use the guidelines to find a way around prosecuting offences where this is a mandatory sentence. That has been demonstrated in other jurisdictions where mandatory sentencing has been imposed. By his own argument he proves the case.

Let us go to the heart of what the opposition wants to do with this amendment. The reality is that the Penalties and Sentences Act does not apply to juveniles. Members only have to read section 6 of the act to know that this very act does not apply to juveniles. The Youth Justice Act applies to juveniles. What the member is trying to do is exclude the operation of the Youth Justice Act by this second amendment when it does not apply in the first place.

I was criticised during the debate for being embarrassing in amendments brought into this House. This is a spectacular example of the laziness and the ignorance of this long-term opposition. Why? Because the member for Southern Downs is the shadow attorney-general and the shadow minister responsible for the youth justice system. He knows that he is responsible for both acts, the Penalties and Sentences Act and the Youth Justice Act, and he does not even know how they operate. He comes in here and presumes to lecture the government about what is embarrassing.

The reality is that this amendment is a complete nonsense when regard is had to the provisions of the Penalties and Sentences Act. Section 6 of the Penalties and Sentences Act expressly provides that the act does not apply to a child. It is not hard to read. It is about the 16th or 17th page or, if you take out the index at the front, it is about page 4 or 5 of the act. Section 6 of the Penalties and Sentences Act expressly provides that the act does not apply to a child within the meaning of the Youth Justice Act. It is the Youth Justice Act that governs the sentencing of juveniles in Queensland. We have used one example of what a court might regard as exceptional circumstances, and it is a very important example. That is why it has been put in the legislation. It is important to make exclusions for young people coming into the criminal justice system.

Firstly, the act does not apply to juveniles and we have set an example of a 17-year-old who, I would hope the honourable member knows, would be sentenced as an adult in Queensland. So the Penalties and Sentences Act applies to people 17 years or older. The reality is that we need to carve out that exclusion. We cannot completely define exceptional circumstances, nor would the government. We let qualified judges do that. It is a spectacular failure by the member for Southern Downs to understand the operation of the Penalties and Sentences Act and its interaction with the Youth Justice Act. This is an embarrassing amendment that should not be before the parliament.
Mr Lawlor: Own goal.
Mr DICK: I take the interjection from the minister. It is an own goal of spectacular proportions and once again demonstrates that this is a lazy, out-of-touch, long-term, ignorant opposition.

Mr SPRINGBORG: In amongst all of the Attorney’s puffery, which is probably more synonymous with the previous Attorney in this place, he has still failed to actually provide the statistics for which we have asked in this place. How many examples have we actually seen of these circumstances in Queensland? How many young people, supposedly in some form of consensual relationship, have been caught up in the application of statutory rape and, therefore, have been unfairly, improperly or unjustly prosecuted in Queensland? Listening to the Attorney over the last 24 to 48 hours we would think that we would see the floodgates open if the government does not put in an exceptional circumstances clause because there are all these young people in Queensland maintaining what are otherwise known as loving, consensual relationships, albeit a criminal one. He has not been able to point to this plethora of examples across the state of Queensland.

Nowhere have I ever said that we argue against the issue of the prosecution being able to consider the individual and special circumstances when deciding whether to prosecute somebody. The issue of prosecution is totally different from the issue of being forced to plea bargain because they do not necessarily have the resources. The prosecution is at a disadvantage because in many cases the defence is at an advantage over the prosecution in Queensland both in seniority and resources. So they try to cut a deal and get what they can. I think very few people would argue that that has not been the case with regard to the pursuit of Gabriel Watson in Queensland.

I simply asked the question and the Attorney has not touched on it. Currently, a prosecutorial guideline exists in Queensland that says that the prosecution can consider the youth, age, physical or mental health, or special infirmity of the alleged offender or a necessary witness. I would be arguing at the moment that, notwithstanding the discretion the police have in looking at these issues, if it then goes to the DPP, they would be considering those factors. As I indicated in this debate yesterday, I am personally aware--and I am sure many other members are also aware--of a teenage girl in our community becoming pregnant and we know that her partner is much older, not under the age of 16, but 17 or 18, and would not have been pursued because of the nature of that particular relationship. What we have here is the government trying to couch some sort of emotional excuse which tugs at the heartstrings of everyone here as a justification as to why it is prepared to leave a ‘get out of jail free’ clause in this legislation.

The other issue that the Attorney has not addressed here today, despite being asked over and over again, relates to the Victorian Sentencing Advisory Council. When it looked at the exceptional circumstances clause which existed for the use of suspended sentences in that state, it concluded that the judiciary was interpreting exceptional circumstances very broadly. Indeed, there had been little change in the number of people who had been given suspended sentences in Victoria before they made the change of exceptional circumstances compared with after. That is what happens in reality.

If the Attorney does not like a particular clause and if the Attorney tends to want to fret about the relative closeness in age of the so-called offender and the victim, then the Attorney should prescribe. If he does not like our amendment, if he says it is an embarrassment then he should go and prescribe it because it is all he has been talking about. He has not been able to give one other practical example of exceptional circumstances other than the close ages of the alleged offender and the person who is the alleged victim. He should tighten it up so that the court must only consider circumstances of the closeness of age between the victim and the offender. That is not there. This is an excuse for having a ‘get out of jail free’ clause from a government that wants to be seen to be acting tough but knowing, in effect, that after it passes this legislation today nothing is going to change the application of this law by the courts in Queensland.
