XML.Hansard-Body: Mr NICHOLLS (Clayfield--LNP) (4.46 pm): The LNP will be supporting the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill 2010. When I adjourned the second reading debate some two weeks ago, I remarked on the bill being a riveting piece of legislation. But, on reflection, that was perhaps not the best description of the bill and somewhat unfair to all those who work on the sometimes thankless task of regulatory reform. To those people I do want to say thank you, because I do appreciate the hard work involved. I also thank Cathy and Eleanor, who provided some information and assistance, and the Treasurer’s office for providing some answers to questions we raised in the briefing. I record my thanks.

I want to touch on the issue of regulatory reform before moving on to the discussion of the provisions of this legislation which, at its heart, is about the seamless national economy. Since the 1980s Australia has undergone a period of sustained and sweeping structural reforms. These have in the main been supported by both sides of politics--not always, perhaps unfortunately, but in the main. It has often been described as the reform consensus. Massive change has occurred in the way our economy works.

Until that change, what Paul Kelly from the Australian described as the ‘Australian settlement’ ruled. That regime was a highly regulated, anticompetitive and redistributive regime that probably, as Gary Banks from the Productivity Commission described it, is best summed up as protection all round. Manufacturers were protected, unions were protected, consumers were supposedly protected and we lived in this happy state of affairs quite comfortably up until the 1970s. Then there was a need for change when the oil shock came through and we found that we were not quite as competitive as we thought we might have been. We found that Australia was not the lucky country that it had been.

What often seems like common-sense change to an economist or to a financial commentator is often more complex for the legislators charged with delivering an acceptable policy outcome for the community. Unfortunately, that does lead to occasional forays into populism, mainly from extremes on the politic wings--mainly, might I say, from the old Socialist Left, who like the idea of feather-bedding and vested interest, where patronage and power reside as happy bedfellows. Of course, the full cost of protectionism and excessive and bad regulation is borne by the whole community in the form of higher prices, lack of innovation, barriers to entry by new business, loss of new jobs from new industries and, most importantly for us in Australia and Queensland, a decline in real income.

Nevertheless, over the last two decades Australia has transformed from a small, protected, inwardly focused economy benefiting from entrenched interests and loud minorities to a diversified, outward-looking trading economy that has boosted productivity and incomes and, importantly, has increased its resilience--its ability to stand shocks throughout the global economy. Productivity has also changed markedly.

According to the Productivity Commission, Australia was ranked fifth in the world in 1950 in terms of GDP per person and had fallen to ninth by 1973 and as low as 15th by the late 1980s. We have to ask how Australia and how Queensland would have been able to compete with those sorts of productivity numbers--15th in the world--especially against emerging economies like China, India and other near Asia tigers. How would we have been able to make our way in the world if our productivity was continuing to decline while those closest to us were growing and growing rapidly?

So after structural reforms our labour productivity growth came to exceed even that of the benchmark of the United States and this led to income growth of around 2 per cent during the decade of the 1990s, well above the OECD average of 1.7 per cent for the decade, and Australia’s per capita GDP--that is, our productivity--rose from 15th back up to eighth. There is certainly a very strong case for micro-economic reform and there is a strong case that micro-economic reform has been the real driver of Australia’s recent productivity growth--that productivity growth through the nineties supported, I might say, by both sides of politics in the main--and regulatory reform is a substantial component of that micro-economic reform. It is one component of it.

What we find out and what we know through careful analysis and investigation is that regulation is not free. It is an activity, particularly an activity of government, that comes with a price. At the federal level, the Productivity Commission estimated that government agencies with explicit regulatory functions employed more than 30,000 staff and spent some $4 billion in 2001-02 administering those regulations. There is also of course the role of state and territory regulation, which is not included in those numbers that have been prepared by the Productivity Commission, and it is possibly the case that state and territory regulation is more intrusive on a day-to-day basis and covers more activities. So truly the hand of government intrudes everywhere. From home to work to holidays, there will be a regulation and it costs a lot of money. Getting a sense of the full cost of regulation is extremely difficult over and above the $4 billion and the 30,000 people directly attributed to it by the Productivity Commission at the federal level. The commission assessed regulatory compliance costs for businesses of around $11 billion in 1994-95, with small and medium sized enterprises bearing 85 per cent of the cost. Those numbers give us a sense of just how big an effect bad regulations have on our economy and the free working of our economy.

The current state government pays lip-service to the idea of regulatory efficiency and indeed Budget Paper No. 2 on page 55 sets out the government’s statement on regulatory efficiency, and it is there that we find reference to the National Partnership Agreement to Deliver a Seamless National Economy--this document that I have here--and it is that agreement that has led to the bill that we are debating here today. As we talk about regulatory reform and as we debate a bill that is in fact dealing with regulatory reform, perhaps it is also opportune to look at the most recent report of the Queensland Office for Regulatory Efficiency, QORE. According to its website, the office is meant to lead a program of regulatory reform designed to increase the productivity and competitiveness of Queensland and to enhance the attractiveness of Queensland to individuals and business investment. When we look at that statement, I think it is important that we test it and we ask the question: does the Queensland Office for Regulatory Efficiency actually do those things that it says on its website it wants to do--increase productivity and competitiveness and enhance the attractiveness of business investment?

In its latest nine-page report--the first page is a nice big picture of a building and there is a foreword by the Treasurer, so we are down to seven pages of effective report--the Treasurer claims $67 million in savings for the 2008-09 year as part of the outcomes, if you like, of the regulatory reform process. But of that $67 million that has been quantified, $60 million of it did not actually come from regulatory reform; it came from the early abolition of mortgage duty and revised land tax thresholds. So it was not about making the regulation process any easier. It was not about reducing the regulatory complexity. It was not about removing regulations. It was about the announcements that had already been made about land tax and mortgage duty. That is $60 million of the $67 million taken out of the equation as this government attempts to achieve a $150 million saving to government and business through regulatory reform.

The next largest saving of $3.3 million comes from a new plan to get the best from procurement spending--not actually getting the best from procurement spending but to have a plan about doing it. Just more paper! Let us look at some of the other initiatives that are being proposed under the work that the government is proposing that is being reported on in the 2008-09 annual report. Under ‘Queensland Regulatory Simplification Plan’ the report states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Phase 1 agencies, those commencing their simplification plan in 2009, are:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: • Employment, Economic Development and Innovation
• Environment and Resource Management
• Justice and Attorney-General
• Infrastructure and Planning
• Communities
• Treasury
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: The report states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Agency reform initiatives to reduce the regulatory burdens on business, community and government are to be set out in agency regulatory simplification plans and focused on opportunities to reduce unnecessary and excessive legislative requirements, and streamline administrative and procurement processes.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: So all we have here at this stage of proceedings is a plan to have a plan to have phase 1 of the plan prepared, and then we have phase 2 agencies that are meant to commence their simplification plan in 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: This report is a report on a lack of achievement. This is a report that fudges the numbers. This is a report that shows that this government has quite clearly squibbed its responsibilities and is failing to obtain the full benefits of regulatory reform. While it may not be easy, it seems no comprehensive report of the number of regulations in Queensland has been compiled, nor has any assessment of the number of regulations removed from the statutes--removed from operation--ever been reported. The number of regulations may not necessarily be the best measure of whether there is regulatory burden on business and on Queenslanders, but surely it would do to start off with us having a reported number that tells us how many regulations affect business and Queenslanders in their daily lives.

It is time for more and better regulatory reform in Queensland to lighten the burden on business and make our economy as competitive and free flowing as it can be while providing the necessary protection to community and environment. That is why I constantly advocate the need for a new round of regulation review in Queensland, one that is championed by a government that is not enthralled to its union paymasters--the promoters of the closed shop--but a government dedicated to more private endeavour, more innovation and more employment, sustainable long-term employment, and the government that can deliver on those reforms is an LNP government. No-one should, and I certainly do not, underestimate the difficulty of regulatory reform, both in terms of vested interests and sheer complexity. It is incumbent on elected representatives to understand what it involves, what the regulatory reforms require and to explain the benefits as well as the changes the community should expect.

For those interested in knowing a little more on the subject, I can recommend two books. The first is a collection of public speeches--and I know people will be enthralled to know that there are books written on regulatory reform and how to enhance our competitive basis--by Gary Banks, the Chairman of the Productivity Commission, titled An economy-wide view: Speeches on structural reform. Members can get that book out at the library. I have it in my desk here. It was sent to me and it actually sits beside my bed at night-time now. The Premier obviously wants some more light reading, so I will send her a complimentary copy.

The other book that might help is a little older and it is called One More Nail by a former Liberal politician from South Australia called Bert Kelly, who was a longstanding Liberal member for the seat of Wakefield in South Australia and who pushed for tariff reform. As a farmer, he knew firsthand just how debilitating protectionism and regulatory burden was for Australia and Australians. Both of these books cover the subject in their own way and both of them make clear the benefits of economic reform, particularly micro-economic reform.

That is the sort of framework within which the current bill that we are debating is set--the framework of micro-economic reform, regulatory reform and economic reform--and which is designed to achieve productivity growth not for its own sake but for the benefit that it provides for all of us who are living in Australia, which is a small trading country that is trade exposed to the rest of the world. We cannot be an inward-looking economy. We cannot rely on our own production; we have to trade with the rest of the world. We have to get the best terms that we possibly can.
Mr Hoolihan interjected.

Mr NICHOLLS: That includes reform across-the-board. We know that the Labor Party opposed economic reform in the late 1990s as it sought to get some popular gain. Whether it was a free trade agreement, whether it was labour market reform or whether it was tax reform, at that time it chose the cheap, shallow popular path in order to achieve its own aims.
Government members interjected.
Mr NICHOLLS: There they are, the great defenders of the Mark Latham theory of economics--that great hero of the Labor Party who steadfastly opposed reform every step of the way.
Mr Hoolihan: What are you talking about? We floated the dollar, 12 December 1983.

Mr NICHOLLS: They get all testy when their own past is brought back to haunt them. As I said, the old Socialist Left, the owners of the closed shop and the vested interests, are lining up to protect their own heritage and are not able to accept the magnanimous way in which I said both sides in the main contributed to economic reform. That is what I said at the beginning.
Mr Schwarten: And then you went on to bucket us like you always do.
Mr NICHOLLS: If you have the opportunity and the materials there, then a good bucket is as good as anything to drop on the member for Rockhampton, as he well knows.
Mr Schwarten: As long as you can cop it back.
Mr NICHOLLS: Absolutely. Has the member for Rockhampton ever had a problem with me copping it and not giving it back to him? Never. Not once.
Mr Schwarten: You’re a sook.

Mr NICHOLLS: ‘Mr pop up and drop in a ministerial statement’! Every time a newspaper prints a bad story about him he is up on his high horse immediately complaining and whingeing about how he is being misquoted. The old glass jaw over there always falls over himself to get up and say that he has been misquoted.

This bill gives effect to the COAG intergovernmental agreement that was signed in April 2009 for the establishment of a national licensing system as part of the agreement to deliver a seamless national economy. The national licensing system will initially be applied to seven broad occupational areas: air conditioning and refrigeration; electrical; plumbing and gasfitting; property related occupations; building and building related occupations; land transport, including passenger vehicle drivers, taxidrivers and bus drivers--those types of operations--and dangerous goods; and maritime.

The air conditioning and refrigeration, electrical, plumbing and gasfitting and property related occupations will be the first four groups of occupations that will be covered by the national licensing scheme, beginning on 1 July 2012. The remaining three groups of occupations--building and building related occupations, land transport and maritime--are currently contemplated to be added to the national licensing scheme sometime after July 2013. But I should point out that there is no guarantee that that will be the case. That is currently the contemplation. As I understand it, there is a lot more work yet to be done and I suspect that some of that work may well be affected by the make-up and composition of the new federal parliament and what the federal government is able to achieve.

The occupations chosen to be included in the system are ones that were identified as being important to the economy in terms of the level of demand for those jobs, the intrinsic mobility of the people who are in those occupations, the number of licensees and where existing mutual recognition agreements between the states and territories were simply not working. The mobility of workers and the ability of Queensland businesses to attract skilled workers are important for a well-functioning labour market and for productivity growth. Perhaps the experience is none more so than in Queensland and Western Australia, where the demand for trades and skilled workers is as high as we have experienced in a long time. We know what happened in 2007 as we completed, if you like, the run-up to the mining boom. We had capacity constraints in terms of skilled labour and we had capacity constraints in terms of fixed capital and that impacted on our productivity; that is, we had the demand but we just did not have the people and the input to be able to make materials into a product that we could sell and market. So we need to have a highly mobile, agile and well-trained workforce in order to be able to meet that need and to grow markets.

It is the case that the existence of up to eight different occupational licensing regimes for some professions across Australia undermines the goal of mobility and adds to red tape and costs. In his report titled Rethinking regulation: report of the taskforce on reducing regulatory burdens on business, the task force chairman, Gary Banks, who himself is obviously a fairly productive fellow, made the following observation--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Not only do different jurisdictions require different levels and types of competency and related training to be undertaken to obtain a specific occupational licence, but coverage of the licences may also differ across jurisdictions. There may also be different entry requirements in terms of individual experience, character tests and background checks. The real estate sector is an example, with eight different eligibility regimes for obtaining a real estate agent licence.
XML.Hansard-Body: That regulation task force estimated that red tape could be adding up to $8 billion per annum to the costs of doing business and the removal of those regulations could add up to $12 billion to gross domestic product. That 2006 report, along with a number of other reports and reviews over a number of years, prompted COAG into pursuing wide-ranging regulatory reform to achieve a seamless national economy. That then led to the national partnership agreement, which I have referred to, which was signed as part of COAG’s reform agenda to deliver more consistent regulation across jurisdictions to address unnecessary or poorly designed regulation, to reduce excessive compliance costs on business, restrictions on competition and distortions in the allocation of resources in the economy. By being a signatory to the seamless national economy agreement Queensland committed to continuing to reduce the level of unnecessary regulation and inconsistent regulation across jurisdictions, delivering agreed COAG deregulation and competition priorities--and there are 27 of those--and improving processes for regulation making and review.

Following on from the seamless national economy agreement was the 2009 intergovernmental agreement for a licensing system for specified occupations, to which Queensland also signed up. That agreement is to set up a national licensing scheme for selected occupations as one of 27 separate reforms identified to improve productivity in the national economy. As I said earlier, it is a complex and time-consuming process.

I turn to the details of the bill and the national law. The bill adopts the occupational licensing national law, which is set out in the schedule to the Occupational Licensing National Law Act 2010 of Victoria, and it adopts that law as the law of Queensland. So rather than having our own legislation that incorporates it all--effectively mirror legislation--we are setting out a skeleton, or a framework, or the architecture of the legislation and we are importing as a schedule and applying it as a law the legislation that applies in Victoria.

The law gives effect to the governmental agreement for a national licensing system as signed in that COAG agreement in 2009. The COAG agreement sets out the framework for the national licensing scheme. It is important to note that this is cooperative national legislation and not a referral of powers to the Commonwealth. It is not the federal government that is setting the agenda here; the federal government and the states together are driving an agenda and using a cooperative scheme that is, I guess, a method of creating uniformity that has been around for a long time.

Occupational licensing has been done by the states on an historic basis resulting in, as I have said, a whole range of different processes, standards and policy settings across jurisdictions. While some attempts have been made to address those issues through mutual recognition agreements--that is, one state recognising the qualifications of another--those mutual recognition agreements still contain problems for licensees who want to move among the states. My colleague the member for Currumbin will detail some of the issues that particularly face people and businesses in her part of the state where she sits on the border and where there is a great deal of interaction between New South Wales and Queensland, although it does affect us all these days. If one goes to the Brisbane Airport one can catch a plane straight out of Brisbane to Karratha to work on the gas projects in Western Australia and, equally, people can come here or move interstate. People fly out from all over the country to work on the big resource projects. Mutual recognition did not solve those problems and provides increased cost burdens on individuals and increased cost burdens on the economy.

People are still required to apply for a state based licence. They may be required to meet different non-skills requirements and may have to pay multiple licence fees. Ultimately, those are paid for by the consumer. The policy objectives of this bill are to improve business efficiency, reduce red tape, improve mobility and enhance productivity by removing overlapping and inconsistent regulation between Queensland and other jurisdictions. It will achieve national consistency in licensing policy and the approach to disciplinary arrangements so that if someone does do the wrong thing everyone is satisfied that they will be disciplined in the appropriate fashion. It will promote consumer confidence and protection for consumers.

The law that this bill adopts sets out the framework for the national licensing system. The fairly large document that is appended as a schedule to the act contains the framework for the system including licensing eligibility requirements, disciplinary arrangements, monitoring and licence policy enforcement powers, financial and disciplinary arrangements and appeal rights and other governing arrangements. We did ask about this in the briefing and I am pleased to see that the penalties and disciplinary arrangements for people doing the wrong thing are, for the most part, as tough as those that presently exist in Queensland for the occupations that are being regulated under this scheme from 1 July 2012.

The bill adopts a regulatory framework and a set of comprehensive general licensing requirements and it will also set up a national register to enable verification. There will be one central register to deal with the registration of these professions. It establishes a National Occupational Licensing Authority and occupational licensing advisory committees as well as a board. The ministerial council comprises Commonwealth, state and territory ministers and will be responsible for the implementation and operation of the national licensing system. The National Occupational Licensing Authority--no doubt it will be called NOLA before too much longer--will be established on 1 January 2011 and will be governed by a board appointed by the ministerial council. So the authority is set up, the people to run the authority are a board and they have to appoint a CEO. The National Occupational Licensing Authority will be responsible for administering the licensing system and developing policy for approval by the ministerial council.

For each occupation covered by the scheme, an occupational licensing advisory committee can be created to provide advice on licensing policy to the authority. Members of the occupational licensing advisory committees are to be appointed by the licensing authority board after inviting nominations from national peak bodies, but if there are no national peak bodies then other peak bodies, which would obviously be state peak bodies. The board of the National Occupational Licensing Authority will comprise 10 members or less and the board must have a chair who is not a licensee or involved in a licensed occupation. There must also be two jurisdictional regulator members who are appointed across from the jurisdictions involved and they are appointed for two-year terms. The national law does not specify who the other seven members of the board must be except to say that they must be persons with skills or experience in unions, employer representation, consumer advocacy or training.

The scheme will operate under a delegated agency model. This model involves the body responsible for policy for each occupational area, whilst overseeing its consistent application remains the responsibility of existing jurisdictional regulators. In Queensland electrical workers are licensed by the Department of Justice and Attorney-General, builders by the Building Services Authority and plumbers and gasfitters by the Building Services Authority as well as the Department of Mines and Energy and the Plumbing Industry Council. Property related professions in Queensland have their licenses issued and managed by the Office of Fair Trading, maritime occupations by Maritime Safety Queensland and transport related occupations by the Department of Transport and Main Roads. Are members not glad we are getting some simplification? Under this bill, these Queensland regulators will continue to perform their function but under the guidance of the national licensing system.

Stakeholders I have spoken to are strongly supportive of the concept of uniform national occupational licensing that will, for the first time, allow licensees to move across Australia under one consistent set of rules without the burden of applying for multiple licences. The benefits of uniformity are obvious as it is very easy to identify the additional costs and red tape that businesses and licensees who operate in and outside of Queensland face--that is, if a person wants to work in Victoria they will not have to apply and go through the time delays. For these reasons, and I have outlined our support for micro-economic reform, the LNP will support the bill. However, we will be watching very closely how the scheme operates in practice and particularly as so much of the scheme as it will operate will be left to regulations that are still to come and that we have not yet seen. Although I do note that according to the time frame set out in the intergovernmental agreement for the national licensing system those regulations should be complete by November 2010, the RIS should be approved by the ministerial council and provided to the Office of Best Practice Regulation and we should commence public consultation. For those people still involved in drafting those regulations, their time frame is rapidly approaching in order to comply with the time frame set out in the agreement.

A concern that the LNP has is with how the National Occupational Licensing Authority will operate in practice. It is quite telling that the Treasurer devoted three paragraphs in his second reading speech to the importance of union representation on the board of the licensing authority but did not once mention the importance of having business representation. The LNP believes there needs to be a balance on the board and that it must not be stacked with union members or Labor Party hacks. Another concern the LNP has is that because the benefits of uniformity are quite immediate and identifiable they can easily be overstated relative to the cost of poor and/or excessive regulation. So just because they are uniform regulations and they apply across the board does not necessarily mean that they are good regulations. They still have a plethora of other tests to go through in order to make sure that they do achieve the aim of making regulations less of a burden on business.

There is a risk that the regulations that eventually get drawn up under this scheme will turn out to be so excessive or poor in their design that they could impose costs on Queensland businesses in excess of the benefits that are hoped to be delivered through uniformity. As one goes through some of the material in relation to regulatory reform what one does find, and what the Productivity Commission found time and time and time again, is a failure on the part of governments to assess the regulations, to actually look at them and ask, ‘Are they achieving what they are put in place for?’ whether that be consumer safety, environmental safety or occupational health and safety, and whether that was being done in the most cost-effective way possible. A constant theme was the failure to actually measure the effect of the regulatory regime in all sorts of areas. Just because it is uniform does not mean it is good. We need to make sure that we monitor those regulations to make sure that they do achieve their aim. While we support the bill and will be voting for the bill, we will be watching very closely the development of the regulations.

Another concern that we have is that there does not appear to have been a thorough assessment by COAG or others of both the benefits and the costs of pursuing uniformity in occupational licensing. The benefits are, as I said, easy to identify. Pursuing uniformity does remove the potential benefits of competitive federalism. When each state and territory has its own occupational licensing scheme for those that do move to innovate or want to innovate, it may be more likely to happen when they have the capacity to do it. When each state and territory has its own licensing system, it is potentially able to act more quickly to implement good regulations and remove bad ones. This last point is very important: without jurisdictional competition, governments are able to maintain bad regulations indefinitely with weak or little pressure for change. I am not saying that the benefits of competitive federalism outweigh the benefits of uniformity but simply expressing some disappointment that this issue appears to not have been given due consideration.

There are also issues arising from the intergovernmental agreement that I would like to put to the Treasurer. As these are not detailed in the bill--the bill is only a framework--this is really the only opportunity I have to raise those issues, and I would like to point them out to him. They go to the Intergovernmental Agreement for a National Licensing System for Specified Occupations.

Clause 3.7 of the IGA, as I will call it, provides that the national licensing system will not compromise Queensland’s existing Home Warranty Insurance Scheme. That is the scheme operated under the auspices of the Building Services Authority. The bill itself does not address this issue, and I have not been able to see an exclusion in the law itself--that is, the schedule. I ask the Treasurer to confirm that this aspect has been covered and that the operation of the BSA legislation will still be there in terms of the Home Warranty Insurance Scheme.

I also raise the issue of whether the operation of the Building Services Authority legislation in effect will still have a restrictive effect on the mobility of licensees. That is, people who move here to Queensland to work will still have to have the necessary registration and consumer protections under the BSA. So they still have to comply with the BSA. Does that really free up the mobility of people wanting to operate in Queensland?
Clause 4.3 deals with training and skills. This is an issue that we want to deal with. It refers to input into training packages. The clause says that, for the purposes of the agreement--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the national licensing system will facilitate a consistent skill base for licensed occupational areas by:
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: a. Providing input into Training Package development and review processes on the skill and education eligibility requirements of occupational licences;

c. In cases where there are both VET and higher education pathways, using the Training Package qualifications/skill sets that meet the skill and education eligibility requirements of occupational licences as the benchmark for the skill standards to be achieved by other learning pathways ...
XML.Hansard-Body: My question in relation to that clause is: what action is being taken to ensure training and skills are being developed to meet these licensing requirements of the national scheme? Does Queensland have in place the requisite training regimes? Are our current training regimes adequate to meet those training and skills requirements?

Clause 5.5 deals with changes to the scheme occupations and refers to ‘consensus’. ‘Consensus’ is defined as 100 per cent agreement. A number of other areas of the agreement refer to consensus. If we refer to section 103 of the law itself, the members of the Occupational Licensing Board are appointed by the ministerial council. So the law that is going to be the law of Queensland says that the appointees to the board are to be appointed by the ministerial council. But the rules for the ministerial council do not refer to how the council is to appoint the board members. Is it to be a majority? Is it to be a consensus? What are the rules?

One of the issues that is raised consistently with uniform legislation like this is the ceding of this parliament’s power to an agreement entered into by executive government because it is not anywhere in the statute books that anyone would be able to look at. If you went to the Queensland statutes you would find the bill. You might, if you are lucky, find the schedule to it that was tabled by the Treasurer. But you certainly would not find the intergovernmental agreement that was signed by all the parties of executive government back in 2009. So here we have a process designed to set in place a board on a very important body to deal with occupational licences, the details of which are not available to anyone who might want to look at them or find them in any sensible or short fashion.

So is it the case that the intergovernmental agreement then operates to provide for consensus to appoint people to the board? The question to the Treasurer is: how much control is ceded as a result of this consensus requirement? Is it the case that the Treasurer’s stated intention in his second reading speech not to support a board that does not include a union representative is, in effect, a veto? He can control who is on that board by not voting for it because of the requirement for consensus set out in the intergovernmental agreement.

I am concerned at the amount of power being delegated by this House under the law--in particular, section 160 dealing with the regulations to be promulgated under the law. Those regulations are of critical importance, as I have outlined. I draw the attention of the House to subsection (2) for the full scope of the regulations. I also refer to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee report No. 13 of 2010 and its comments, particularly about the parliamentary scrutiny of delegated power.

Section 164 of the law purports to deal with disallowance of regulations but at subsection (4) says that, even if a regulation is disallowed, it does not cease to have effect unless the regulation is disallowed in a majority of jurisdictions. Subsection (3) says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A regulation made under this Law may be disallowed in a participating jurisdiction by a House of the Parliament of that jurisdiction in the same way, and within the same period, that a regulation made under an Act of that jurisdiction may be disallowed.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: So the normal processes for disallowance are to be followed. Subsection (4) then says--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: A regulation disallowed under subsection (3)--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: so we have gone through the process: we have come in here, we have had the debate, the parliament has agreed to disallow the regulation and hopefully there is a good reason for it to be disallowed--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: does not cease to have effect in the participating jurisdiction, or any other participating jurisdiction, unless the regulation is disallowed in a majority of the participating jurisdictions.
XML.Hansard-Body: So it is a case of--not quite but almost--one in, all in. The effect of being able to have a disallowance motion in relation to the regulation under this bill seems to be illusory. It is, in effect, a Clayton’s process that is provided for. Although this type of clause may be supported by the rationale of national scheme legislation, it is yet another derogation of this House’s authority. I think it is interesting to note that in Western Australia they are not adopting this framework. They are in fact passing an entire bill rather than just a framework and the adoption of a schedule to a bill to incorporate the law.

I think concerns have also been raised in the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee report in relation to some of the powers that can be exercised without reference to this parliament. I think concerns have been raised in the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee report in relation to the impact of some of the checks and charges. One I would like to identify is the criminal history check--the fact that someone who has been charged is to be included in the information to be provided when assessing whether someone is of a suitable character to be carrying out the occupation. I think it is a pretty long bow to draw for a charge against someone to be included in the consideration of whether they are a suitable person to carry out that occupation--a charge unproven and untested. Who knows whether it was true or false? For that information to be used in that way to assess whether someone ought to be given a licence to operate as an electrician or as a plumber or as an air-conditioning maintenance person seems to me to be a very extreme example of the lengths that the licensing authority will be going to in order to satisfy themselves that someone ought to be carrying out that job.

Even after the national scheme is fully operational, there will still be work to be done in reducing red tape and costs when it comes to occupational licensing. It is still not clear at this stage how the scheme will treat contractor licensing. If contractor licensing is not covered by the national scheme, this means that--although, for example, a Queensland plumber who also operates in New South Wales may only be required to apply for and obtain one plumbing licence once the national licensing scheme is fully operational--they may still be required to apply for a contracting licence in both states. That is under the BSA type of scheme.

A second issue this scheme does not address is some of the hoops that businesses and individuals must jump through even when they operate solely within Queensland. Take the example of a Queensland plumber and gasfitter. Firstly, they must deal with the Plumbing Industry Council and the Department of Mines and Energy to obtain an occupational licence, but then they also need to go to the Building Services Authority to obtain their contractor licence. As the new licensing scheme will operate under a delegated agency model, it does not necessarily address any of the inefficiencies of having to deal with multiple regulatory agencies within the same jurisdiction.

A number of issues still need to be dealt with. This is the first step in addressing some of these issues. I note there is a time frame attached to the intergovernmental agreement, and compliance with that time frame is also necessary in order for us to be able to get incentive payments and facilitation payments totalling some $90 million.

There will be some revenue implications. The Treasurer came into the House just after lunch to introduce a message from the Governor. I presume that is to do with the fact that the fees and charges that are to be dealt with, and which are covered for in the bill rather than in the act itself, will need to be remitted somewhere. I would ask for clarification on that as well. It is obvious that the appropriation of the fees collected will have to either go to a central authority or be used in a way that is different from that which is currently contemplated.

Micro-economic reform is vital. As I said, there has been a broad reform consensus for the best part of 30 years in relation to the need for it and the need to increase productivity. This is another step along the way. I have to say it is a very tortuous step. The complexity of it is well understood and we do hope this bill achieves the reforms it has set out to achieve.

Mrs STUCKEY (Currumbin--LNP) (5.30 pm): I rise to speak in the debate on the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill 2010, which was introduced into the House on 6 October by the honourable the Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development. The purpose of this bill is to apply the occupational licensing national law set out in the schedule to the Occupational Licensing National Law Act 2010 of Victoria--known as the law--as a law of Queensland. The law is the legislative framework for a national occupational licensing system, the NLS. As honourable members have heard from my learned colleague the shadow Treasurer and honourable member for Clayfield in his well-researched speech, the LNP is supporting this bill but he highlighted our reservations about the future implementation and also the need for a regulation review.

States and territories have historically been charged with developing their own licensing systems, with variations and irregularities causing frustration and duplication between jurisdictions. At present, mutual recognition allows licensees who wish to move between states to apply to be registered in a second jurisdiction without further assessment of their skills. Despite this, a number of impositions still exist, including meeting different non-skills requirements, additional fees and application processes. This is particularly onerous for workers in cross-border areas, such as my own electorate of Currumbin, which straddles the state boundary with New South Wales. Recognising these difficulties, the Council of Australian Governments--COAG--entered into the National Partnership Agreement to Deliver a Seamless National Economy in July 2008 and as such developed the NLS to remove inconsistencies across jurisdictional borders and allow for a more mobile workforce.

Essentially, the national licensing scheme will allow for current holders of state and territory licences to be automatically recognised under the new licence system and a public national register of licensees to be established. It was agreed that the Commonwealth has no legislative role in the establishment of the new system. Subsequently, in April 2009, COAG agreed to the intergovernmental agreement for a national licensing system for specified occupations--known as the COAG agreement--to establish a licensing body to develop policy and administer the NLS. Under this COAG agreement, the NLS will initially apply to seven occupational areas. These are air conditioning and refrigeration, electrical, plumbing and gasfitting, property related occupations, building and building related occupations, land transport, and maritime.

The law has been designed to allow for additional occupations to be added over time. This would require amendments to legislation as this transpires. Phase 1 is expected to commence from 1 July 2012 and will cover the first occupations I just listed. Prior to implementation, each state will be required to enact amendments to its jurisdictional legislation applying to the relevant occupational areas to allow the facilitation of the national law.

Living in and representing the southern most coastal cross-border electorate in Queensland, I can attest to the fact that the provisions of this bill are very pertinent to the constituents of Currumbin. Indeed, the topic of licensing is also particularly relevant to my role as shadow minister for public works and ICT, a portfolio with responsibility for a range of licensing concerns for various industries across this great state. Currently, differences in licensing requirements between states--including classification, eligibility, duration and fee structures--can cause prohibitive costs to individuals and businesses, wasting both time and money. A nationally consistent framework is welcomed to iron out these inconsistencies and promote greater business activity among states, particularly in cross-border areas. Creation of a truly seamless community between Queensland and New South Wales becomes a step closer to reality with the passage of this bill.

Tom Senti, from the Tweed Economic Development Corporation, informed me of the following statistics: the Tweed--my geographic neighbour--currently has one of the lowest work participation rates in Australia at 42 per cent; New South Wales, in which it sits, has a work population rate of 62 per cent; Queensland sits at 62.3 per cent; and Australia generally sits at 65 per cent. This equates to some 32,000 people in the Tweed--self-employed and employees as full-time equivalents--earning an income and living in the Tweed. However, the point here is that more than 12,000 of these 32,000 leave the Tweed on a daily basis to work in other places, mostly in South-East Queensland, which clearly demonstrates once again the interconnectivity of the two cross-border economies.

Other research by TEDC over the last 10 years--including the joint Gold Coast City Council and TEDC Seamless Borders Project and the Tweed and Gold Coast Aviation Transport Hub Project--confirms that the two economies of South-East Queensland and the Tweed are inextricably linked and to a very large extent are interdependent. The Tweed as a population-driven growth area and the occupational areas listed under the COAG agreement are all part of the services and trades sector which cross the border on a daily basis. As such, the issue of compliance is seen as a major impediment to the growth of both regional economies. Recognition of interstate licences can only assist employment, generating growth of both economies. I thank Tom Senti for this information and wish him a speedy recovery from his recent operation. It would, however, be remiss of me not to mention the impact of dual time zones, which places further imposts on the daily activities of a large number of people who live, work and play in our region.

Robert Wright, a local builder who works the border region, is favourable to reform but says it needs to go further. This builder is of the opinion that there is a need for uniform regulations across the nation: ‘After all,’ he says, ‘we are one country.’ Borders are not physical, touchable structures in our modern world and mean nothing to the people conducting business day to day, except for varying standards and regulations which impede and complicate business transactions. In terms of industry standards, Robert questioned whether there should be building to one standard throughout Australia. Different workplace health and safety standards exist between the states. Essentially they are the same but with small variations, and it is frustrating, not to mention time consuming, getting certificates for both Queensland and New South Wales.

Robert said that news that a national standard for workplace health and safety is also going to be implemented in the next couple of years is welcome. However, reapplying for the national certificate will also be a time-consuming exercise. This is the kind of superfluous and repetitive red tape that hits small businesses the hardest. The shadow Treasurer made a comment about the form these qualifications will take, with concerns that as standards elsewhere vary it may open the door for standards to drop. Many tradespeople may qualify with lower standards and skills, and that would be to the detriment of the consumer.

I consulted with the Master Builders Association here in Queensland, which supports a comprehensive licensing system that is focused on the protection of consumers. It believes that protecting the interests of consumers is best achieved by, firstly, maintaining and improving building standards by ensuring that accredited training is a condition of licensing and, secondly, ensuring the financial viability of building contractors by requiring all contractors to meet regular and ongoing financial tests as a condition of licensing. These objectives, they say, will be achieved--or not--through the regulations.

The national licensing scheme is anticipated to function under a delegated agency model, meaning that the licensing authority created by this law will delegate its regulatory licensing functions to existing regulatory authorities. Notably, the law does not permit the delegation of the licensing authority’s function for policy development.

According to the Treasurer’s second reading speech, this legislation will not involve a referral of powers to the Commonwealth government. This bill, however, is designed as skeletal legislation, creating a legislative superstructure and leaving significant elements of the licensing system to be dealt with by regulations that are still to come. Honourable members have heard the concerns of the shadow Treasurer in relation to these coming regulations.

As the regulations associated with the first phase of this bill will not be enacted until 2012, what we have before us will need to be the subject of further legislation before it is fully implemented. Interim advisory committees--IACs--are to be established for each first-phase occupation to provide advice on licensing policy for the development of national regulations. The IACs will consist of union, employer, regulator and consumer representatives.

The cost to the Queensland government as a result of this legislation will be twofold. Direct funding to the tune of $1.4 million between 2009 and 2011 has been contributed to the establishment of the licensing authority. Additionally, there will be an indirect financial consequence to the state in the form of lost revenue from interstate licence fees as the requirement to obtain multiple licences across jurisdictions is being eradicated by the national scheme. It would be interesting to learn just how much revenue is estimated to be lost once this legislation is implemented. I would ask the Treasurer if he has those figures to share them with the House in his reply.

I would like to raise a couple of other issues arising from the provisions in the bill. Collection of criminal history information presents some privacy issues, and the collection and publication of personal information also raises concerns. In its submission to the Victorian government on the initial national law bill, the Office of the Victorian Privacy Commissioner highlighted the lack of voluntary participation in the scheme, cemented by the penalties relating to the offence of not being licensed and the mandatory disclosure of personal information of licensees raising significant privacy challenges. The Deputy Privacy Commissioner had this to say on the topic of national registers--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The proposed national registers will collectively contain thousands of records relating to licensees. All matters in relation to how information on the registers will be collected, recorded and kept and inspection, access and publication of public registers has been left to national regulation. This means it is currently not possible to analyse the privacy implications of the national register, and protection will be dependent on the Ministerial Council.
XML.Hansard-Body: Not surprisingly, the LNP also shares this sentiment. An absence of analysis of the benefits that this scheme may bring to national and state economies raises a certain degree of uncertainty as to whether this scheme really will achieve positive results in the long term. It is to be hoped that it will.

Also of concern is the limited parliamentary oversight involved with this national scheme. National regulations, on which the majority of this scheme will be reliant, are to be made by the ministerial council, at this stage being the Ministerial Council for Federal Financial Relations. The process by which regulations are proposed to be made appears to bypass significant parliamentary scrutiny. To ensure legislative consistency, any disallowance of a regulation by a jurisdiction can only be approved if the majority of participating jurisdictions have disallowed the regulation. Further concerns about abrogating the rights of parliaments will undoubtedly arise once the system begins. I note at this point that Western Australia is the only state that has indicated that it will not enact the national legislation. However, WA has indicated that it will draft legislation that mirrors the law.

Under the new national law, an individual carrying out work without a licence or relevant exemption will face a $50,000 fine for a first or second offence or $50,000, 12 months imprisonment or both for a third or subsequent offence. Advertising to perform work without a licence or exemption will incur the same penalty, as will the offence of holding out an unlicensed person as being licensed or a licensee allowing the use of their licence by another person.

The provision of harsh penalties is particularly important when considering the nature of the specified occupations. For example, electrical and building work that is repeatedly carried out by an unlicensed individual can produce a serious and even deadly risk to public safety. Penalties for offences prescribed by this bill are harsher than some existing penalties. Under section 42 of the Queensland Building Services Authority Act 1991, unlicensed contracting currently attracts a maximum fine of $25,000, or 250 penalty units. Doubling of penalties is certainly an effective means of stamping out the frequency of illegal business practices. However, there are concerns as to how this new national law will be able to monitor industry to detect these offences when our state based agencies, which were supposedly designed to perform this function, are failing to do so. That is, of course, unless dishonest and unprincipled practices or bad press puts pressure on this government to take action.

A number of the occupations encapsulated in this bill fall under the jurisdiction of the QBSA. At present, this statutory body is undergoing a review being conducted for the government by KPMG. The LNP has put out a discussion paper that encourages industry stakeholders and consumers to have their say about aspects of the BSA that work well and also those that they think require improvement or change.

The shadow Treasurer highlighted the need for a regulation review. In some ways, it could be said that the QBSA is a good example. A recent CMC report identified a raft of serious flaws with organisational and governance structures and made seven recommendations. Inadequate policies and lack of guidance led to oversight of serious breaches of the law and eroded the confidence of affected consumers in the BSA’s ability to protect them. The CMC report into the Queensland BSA is largely an attempt to defend the current organisation by asserting that past problems have been fixed. Looking at the report in terms of governance, it is clear that the major problem was the failure of management to accept the responsibilities of their position. That situation is whitewashed in the report with its bureaucratic reference to all of the new practices that now are claimed to be in operation.

Management is required to manage and is expected to ensure that operational staff are trained, monitored and supervised on a continuous basis. The report confirms that management failed in all of these responsibilities. Neither they nor their staff were properly qualified in the accountancy skills required to deal with the analysis of builders’ financial status. The excuse given was that the salary classification for staff doing this work was too low to attract trained accountancy staff but that the GFC had made the position more attractive to accountants from the private sector. One would hope that any future regulations would not bow to this excuse.

We have been told that this is skeletal legislation and that the regulations are to follow. The episode under discussion relating to this CMC report reveals that the finance division was simply overloaded with unresolved cases and an inability to attract senior officers because it was not equipped to handle the job. So too many cases of financial uncertainty were allowed to go unresolved, leading to more and more complaints. Whether these recommendations have resolved the concerns remains a mystery.

Cases of licence lending in the building industry have left Queenslanders facing a significant financial burden. I was contacted recently by an individual who had seen the devastating effects that the inadequate policing of this practice has had on the public purse. Indeed, it is the QBSA that is left to foot the bill of outstanding payments to debtors when a building company goes into liquidation because of poor workmanship. It is the responsibility of the nominee of the company, being a licence holder, to ensure adequate supervision of work done under the name of the company. This individual put it down to a lack of monitoring controls by state and local governments that led to such practices occurring.

In closing, a national licensing system for specified occupations under the COAG agreement will enable the facilitation of workplace flexibility that has been denied to interstate workers until now. From stakeholder comments, there will undoubtedly be a lot of angst as the regulations are developed. This will involve industry, unions and regulators from across the country, each with a different view. Hopefully, the benefits from this uniformity will outweigh any anticipated problems.

Mr HOOLIHAN (Keppel--ALP)
(5.49 pm): In speaking to the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill, I think it is painfully evident to everyone that the only way that industry operations can be undertaken is under a national scheme. COAG has actually achieved that in a number of other areas. We have had a recent referral of our registers to a national scheme. We started out by having a mutual recognition act. Although it allowed people to be acknowledged in separate jurisdictions within the same area of law, it was quite apparent that it did not work properly. Each state still continued to operate its own system of laws.

This national law agreed by COAG is designed to cover five key areas, those being: licensing, disciplinary proceedings and actions, monitoring and enforcement, reviews, and appeals. I have made the comment in this House before that it really pleases me that we are not giving away the powers of the state. This is a cooperative scheme. In actual fact, it is not a referral of powers. The states will still retain their power to deal with the regulation. In a lot of cases there are different aspects and different needs, albeit rather small. Each state has slight variations.

The method by which this was to be achieved was that Victoria would pass the first stage in the process which set out the national law. The second stage is that each participating jurisdiction would introduce legislation that applies that law. It is interesting that Western Australia has chosen to enact its own legislation. It says that it will achieve the same result. Western Australia did the same thing with the family law act and there were some substantial differences in approach in the Western Australian family court. Hopefully, it will achieve the same result, but only time will tell.

I endorse some of the comments made by the shadow Treasurer in relation to this method of regulation, but I am afraid I cannot agree with him as to the outcome of deregulation or simplified regulation of our financial system. Perhaps he could have a look at the date 12 December 1983 when gentlemen named Paul Keating and Bob Hawke floated the Australian dollar.

Mr Schwarten:
No conservative government would ever do that because the National Party would not let them do it.
Mr HOOLIHAN: I take the minister’s interjection. Some 27 years on this country is in the best position that it has been for a long time.

The actual national licensing system was, as we have heard, to apply to seven broad occupational areas. There are four in the first phase. They are air conditioning, and refrigeration, plumbing and gasfitting, electrical, and property related occupations. The second phase is building and building related occupations, maritime and land transport--passenger vehicle drivers and dangerous goods only. That second phase is to look at regulation as soon as possible after 2013. Hopefully, that will not be affected by the current make-up of the federal government.

I was very pleased to see one thing in relation to the advisory committee and the appointments and that is that the Treasurer remains in strong support of union representation on that advisory committee. I think that blind Freddy could see that where we are dealing with the operation of trades it is very often the union representative or union perspective which really supports the way those trades operate.

The key objectives of this law were set out by the COAG agreement. The key objectives are: licensees would be able to operate in all jurisdictions, there would be consistent skill and knowledge for those occupations, there would be effective coordination between the licensing authority and jurisdictional regulators, and there would be national consistency in licensing structures and policy across comparable occupations. I do not think that anyone in this House--and I note that the LNP is supporting this bill--could argue that seamless business operation can occur throughout Australia even though each state and the territories retain their ability to regulate operations according to the needs of their own jurisdiction. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM (Gladstone--Ind) (5.55 pm): I rise to speak to the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill 2010. In doing so, I acknowledge that more and more of these kinds of professions are transportable and very mobile. In my electorate we currently are, and will be in the future, looking more and more for some of these tradespeople. The ability to recruit locally first and then within the state and interstate is very important in meeting skill demands. The nationalisation of these sorts of skills, the registration of these skills, the hearing of any breaches of these skills and the hearing of disciplinary matters will--theoretically at least--be effective.

I only have a couple of questions that I would like cleared up. In terms of the trades affected, will people be properly informed of the changes and not just their overarching bodies--that is, the plumbers association, air conditioners association or the gasfitting association? Will the government, which has records of all of the people with these licences, contact them and let them know what the changes are and how they will affect them in terms of process? Will the information get to those who hold these qualifications?

Given that previous speakers have said that the state administrative structure will remain but there will be an overarching structure, will it incur greater costs to those holding these licences or will it be cost effective? I am sure many of those holding these transportable qualifications will be pleased to be able to move interstate where necessary to do work but they would have concerns if there were significant additional costs involved in getting their licences. They are the main things that I wanted to have clarified.

I have heard that this is a skeleton bill, an act that will be built on as time progresses given that the first rollout will not happen until 2012. I do think it is critically important that those affected know in detail how it will affect them and what the new process will be so that none are caught at the time of their renewal not knowing the process that is required. They also need to know upfront what costs are going to be incurred by them--because they will have to pay them--and whether that cost is going to be significantly greater or more acceptably less than what they are currently paying. I look forward to the response.

Ms JARRATT (Whitsunday--ALP) (6.00 pm): I am pleased to rise in support of the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill which will establish an important milestone in COAG’s determination to harmonise specified occupational licensing across the nation. The bill before the House has its genesis in COAG’s 2008 commitment to the National Partnership Agreement to Deliver a Seamless National Economy. The COAG reform agenda outlined under this agreement intends to deliver a more consistent and better designed regulatory platform across jurisdictions in this nation. There is no doubt that a successfully implemented national partnership agreement will deliver a reduction in red tape and compliance costs and a less restrictive business environment. Not all of the agenda will be easy as the states and Commonwealth vie to retain long-held systems and reporting regimes. I do not expect that harmonising occupational licensing regulations will be any different, but that does not make it a worthy goal. In many ways the National Partnership Agreement to Deliver a Seamless National Economy was a cornerstone of the Rudd government that will continue to reap benefits for many years to come.

This bill has a specific purpose, and that is to apply the occupational licensing national law set out in the schedule to the Occupational Licensing National Law Act 2010 of Victoria as a law of Queensland. In other words, the Victorian government has enacted the template framework that other jurisdictions must adopt to allow the reform to move forward. It is important to note that the measures in the bill before us today are just the beginning of this particular reform agenda. There remains a large body of work yet to be done. This includes national regulations and amendments to jurisdictional legislation.

The COAG National Licensing Task Force is in the process of developing the national regulations. These regulations will include eligibility which will cover qualifications, skills and knowledge; scope of work for each category of licence; general regulations, which will include matters such as criminal history requirements; and transitional regulations. The national regulations will also be subjected to the Commonwealth regulation impact statement process, which will involve public consultation. In addition, the national regulations will need to be approved by the ministerial council and, importantly, unanimous agreement to the national regulations will be required.

This process will undoubtedly take some time to complete. It will take considerable time to obtain agreement from all jurisdictions. Also, once the national regulations are developed, jurisdictions will need to pass consequential and transitional legislation to the relevant licensing statutes. This does not mean that we are at the very beginning of the process, however. In accordance with the COAG agreement, interim advisory committees comprising union, employer, regulator and consumer representatives have been established for each of the first phase occupational areas. The interim advisory committees are providing advice on licensing policy for specific occupational areas, and this will inform the regulations that will be made. Ultimately, an occupational licence advisory committee will be set up for each occupation in the national system. The members of these advisory committees will be appointed by the National Occupational Licensing Board and will include representatives from national peak bodies that represent that occupation. Meanwhile, Queensland has strong representation on the existing interim advisory committees which are to be replaced by the occupational licence advisory committees and there will be an opportunity for Queensland to maintain or increase this level of representation when nominations are sought.

Once established, how will the national occupational licensing system benefit Queenslanders? At present each state or jurisdiction oversees its own set of regulations around occupational licensing and, just like the rail line gauges, each state has a unique set of eligibility criteria. That is fine if, say, as an electrician you only want to work in Queensland, but we know of course that these days many companies and individual tradespeople tender for work in multiple states and often on a national basis. I might say that the first phase of these reforms will focus on four specific occupational areas--air conditioning and refrigeration, electrical, plumbing and gasfitting, and property related occupations. It is not hard to think of instances where individuals or companies within these fields extend beyond state boundaries. Notwithstanding the existence of the Mutual Recognition Act 1992, which allows licence holders from one jurisdiction to apply to be registered in another, there remained disincentives for licensees to operate in a truly national context. With the assistance of the internet and other forms of ICT, it is not unusual for businesses and individuals to operate in multiple jurisdictions, so the end result of the reform that we will begin with this bill today will certainly provide a financial and operational boost for existing and future businesses.

Once the national licensing system is established, licence holders in relevant occupational areas will be licensed in all participating jurisdictions using the one licence for the occupation. It will no longer be necessary to hold a licence in each jurisdiction in which the licensee operates. Applicants and licensees will need to meet a nationally consistent set of licensing requirements. The only fees applicable will be those in the jurisdiction where the licence is granted. Therefore, there will be one application fee, one renewal fee et cetera for the one occupational licence. Licensees will be licensed in all participating jurisdictions without the burden of having to hold or apply for multiple licences. This will facilitate a much more mobile workforce, enabling licensees to move across Australia going where they are needed without the administrative burden of current structures.

Licensees, businesses and consumers will also benefit from greater national consistency in licensing structures and policy, including standard qualification requirements. It is anticipated these changes will allow a business to become more efficient and competitive. There will also be benefits to consumers who will benefit through the establishment of a national register of all licensees. This will enable the public to verify that particular individuals or businesses are appropriately licensed for the work they are being asked to undertake. Given that this bill is an important step in the realisation of a national system for occupational licensing, I definitely commend it to this House.
Mr Schwarten interjected.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (6.06 pm): I rise to speak on the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill 2010. I would have taken that interjection from the member for Rockhampton, but I did not actually hear it so I cannot comment on it. It sort of bounced back. I say at the outset that I perhaps do not share the zeal of the member for Clayfield and indeed the member for Whitsunday for regulatory reform, but I thank the member for Clayfield for identifying a couple of books that I might read which I will look out for in the second-hand shops in Annerley so that I can perhaps embark on a new-found zeal for regulatory reform. But I do understand it is a very important matter before this House.
Mr Nicholls: No need. I’ve got a copy of it right here for you.

Mr FINN: If you have a copy for me and if you would sign it for me, I would appreciate that. This bill forms part of a national scheme to implement new national occupational licensing. It is part of the national reform agenda and importantly does not involve referral of powers to the Commonwealth but is about a bill that will apply a national law as the law of Queensland. I want to make a few very brief comments on this bill. I recognise the efforts of COAG and the efforts of the states to develop a national licensing scheme that seeks to provide benefits across the country. Some of those benefits are business efficiencies, reductions in red tape and, importantly I think, skills mobility and the ability for workers who travel across the country to have a consistent licensing regime, and these are aspirational aspects of the national agenda that are worth supporting.

I do need to acknowledge that in my parliamentary secretary role I have had some involvement with the harmonisation and nationalisation process. Whilst there are good intentions with much of our harmonisation, we must all be working very hard in that process to ensure that we are delivering benefit for all. Harmonisation and nationalisation and schemes that deliver these things need to be providing benefit. Importantly, we have seen a bit of comment in the media about harmonisation and the often quoted phrase is that it needs to lift us up and not be a race to the bottom and that we need to be picking those things that provide the highest standards across the country and adopting them so that, whilst we get those efficiencies and we get those reductions of red tape, we do not get a reduction in standards.

In my experience of safety harmonisation, a lot of that challenge comes down to the states. You often experience a reluctance of some states to adopt a higher standard because of the costs or the issues involved for that state in adopting a new regime. The state that has the highest standard has concerns about losing some of the benefits of the standards that it has. The main issue that I wanted to comment on was in relation to the make-up of the board that will advise the authority in relation to the national licensing scheme. There was a comment in the Treasurer’s speech about the representation on those boards. I have received a number of representations from members of trade unions, and in particular I acknowledge Allen Hicks and Keith McKenzie of the Electrical Trades Union who spoke to me about their issues in relation to this legislation. I have also met with departmental officers of the Electoral Safety Office in the portfolio that I work in who have been closely involved in this matter.

The intent of national licensing and national regimes is to ensure boards have merit based appointments. There are some people who think there is a difference between a representative board and a merit based board. My view is that you can have representative boards and merit based boards. They should be the same thing. It is appropriate to find representation from industries and sectors that are relevant, and that should deliver merit as well.

In the representations that I received from officials of the Electrical Trades Union, they talked to me about how licensing is their bread and butter, how licensing is intricately linked to safety in their workplace, how licensing is critical to skills development in their industry--
An honourable member: The same as plumbers.

Mr FINN: Yes, just like plumbers as well. Licensing is fundamental to those aspects of their industry and it is important for them to have representation at board level. Similarly--and I note the comment of the member for Clayfield that boards should not be, I think his words were, full of unionists or ALP hacks--the advice that I received from the ETU was that they thought a representative board must include peak employer organisations in the industry as well, that there were benefits for the union in having those people on the board as well, and that they were not seeking for the board to be representative of a single sector of the industry. In any case, I was pleased to raise with the Treasurer the representative nature of the board. Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (6.12 pm): I rise to make a short contribution to the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill 2010. As outlined in the explanatory notes, the objective of this bill is to apply the occupational licensing national law set out in the schedule to the Occupational Licensing National Law Act 2010 of Victoria--the law--as a law of Queensland. The bill gives effect to a COAG agreement signed in April 2009 for the establishment of a national licensing system--the NLS--for specified occupations. The law is the legislative framework for a national occupational licensing system whose purpose is to remove overlapping and inconsistent regulation between jurisdictions for the licensing of the specified occupations and aims to improve business efficiency and the competitiveness of the national economy, reduce red tape, improve labour mobility and enhance productivity. It is hoped that the NLS will promote consumer confidence and protection without imposing unnecessary costs on consumers or substantially lessening competition.

As the licensing of occupational areas is predominately a state and territory function and is currently conducted by a range of regulatory bodies in each state and territory, in the past approaches to licensing have not been consistent. Currently, regulatory bodies have the responsibility for administering threshold licence entry criteria and ongoing conduct requirements for licensees. They monitor compliance and administer disciplinary procedures, maintain registers of licensees and oversee skills maintenance requirements, such as continuing professional development. Due to differing jurisdictional policies and practices, licences issued for the same occupational area by individual jurisdictions often have different parameters, eligibility requirements and permitted scopes of work. These include the costs of multiple licence fees and complying with multiple regulatory regimes. Both direct and indirect costs are particularly high for small to medium sized businesses where they constitute a significant proportion of total costs.
