Under the Mutual Recognition Act 1992, individual occupational licence holders from one jurisdiction can apply to be registered in a second jurisdiction on the basis of their existing licence and without a further assessment of their skills. Regulators in a second jurisdiction have an obligation under mutual recognition requirements to issue an applicant with a licence to undertake activities that are substantially the same as those permitted under their licence in the first jurisdiction. This is not unlike the situation that existed for nurses whereby they had to be registered in each state to be able to practise. I am very pleased that the federal government and all the states have introduced legislation to make sure that nurses do not have to pay registration in multiple states, as I had to to practise in New South Wales and Queensland. This legislation is very similar.

Regulators may use conditions on licences to achieve equivalence. Despite mutual recognition, while each state and territory maintains different licensing regimes, licensees who want to move between jurisdictions must still apply for a licence, meet different non-skills requirements and pay a separate licence fee for the equivalent licence in each jurisdiction in which they wish to work. These arrangements are particularly difficult for individuals and/or businesses operating in multiple jurisdictions and for those working in border areas, both of which must comply with different licensing and regulatory requirements. They are also a disincentive to pursuing work in other jurisdictions, particularly work of a shorter duration.

In this context, the Council of Australian Governments--COAG--entered into the National Partnership Agreement to Deliver a Seamless National Economy--the NPA--on 3 July 2008. As part of that agreement, COAG agreed to develop an NLS that would remove inconsistencies across jurisdictional borders and allow for a more mobile workforce. On 30 April 2009, COAG agreed to the Intergovernmental Agreement for a National Licensing System for Specified Occupations. The NLS will initially be applied to seven of these occupations: air conditioning and refrigeration; electrical; plumbing and gasfitting; property related occupations; building and building related occupations; land transport, particularly passenger vehicle drivers and dangerous goods only; and maritime. The objective of the NLS is to improve business efficiency, reduce red tape, improve labour mobility and enhance productivity by removing overlapping and inconsistent regulation between jurisdictions.

The bill is designed to allow licensees to move across Australia without the burden of applying for additional licences and create national consistency in licensing policy and the approach to disciplinary arrangements whilst retaining some flexibility for issues specific to jurisdictions or occupations. It is also meant to promote consumer confidence and protection without unnecessary costs on consumers. I have a company in my electorate that is very keen to protect some of their issues, particularly in relation to an invention that they have for apex seals in a rotary piston engine, described as swinging slipper seals.

The Queensland bill has the effect of applying that occupational licensing law as set out in the schedule to the Occupational Licensing National Law Act 2010 of Victoria as a law of Queensland. Each other state and territory will introduce a similar bill before the end of the year. This is national legislation, not a referral of powers to the Commonwealth. The NLS is a component of COAG’s seamless national economy reforms. This bill is essentially skeletal legislation, as outlined by the shadow Treasurer, creating a legislative superstructure and some general licensing requirements with many of the significant elements of the NLS left to regulations that are still to come.

All stakeholders contacted supported the concept of national licensing and acknowledge the benefits that a single national licence will bring. Stakeholders also support the delegated agency model and some specifically lobbied for the delegated agency model in their submissions to COAG. As I said, all stakeholders who were contacted supported the concept of this national licensing and acknowledged the benefits. The Liberal National Party will not be opposing this bill.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP)
(6.18 pm): As we have heard this evening, the shadow Treasurer has a recommended reading list for bills such as this. So impressed was he by Gary Banks’s An economy-wide view: Speeches on structural reform , he shared it around the opposition members. Contrary to popular opinion, not only is it educational; it is actually incredibly easy to read and it does not put you to sleep. I too highly recommend it to any members on the government benches who need to brush up on their knowledge of these areas.
Gary Banks in that book writes--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Australia has undergone sweeping structural reforms over the past two decades that have helped transform its economic performance.
Structural reforms of the kind Australia has implemented have long been recognised as economically desirable by most economists, but have faced strong political obstacles in all countries.

... in some countries, including Australia, there are the additional challenges for nationally beneficial structural reforms posed by a Federal system of government. In Australia, the six states have regulatory powers and responsibilities in all relevant areas.
... in areas that require national systems, diversity can merely manifest itself as productivity-sapping fragmentation.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This bill addresses one such productivity-sapping fragmentation so it is a welcome addition to our nation’s ongoing economic structural reform.
XML.Hansard-Body: As mentioned by others, the objectives of the NLS are to improve business efficiency across seven occupations, reduce red tape, improve labour mobility and enhance productivity by removing overlapping and inconsistent regulation between jurisdictions. The bill is designed to allow licensees to move across Australia without the burden of applying for additional licences, create national consistency in licensing policy and the approach to disciplinary arrangements whilst retaining some flexibility for issues specific to jurisdictions or occupations and promote consumer confidence and protection without unnecessary costs to consumers.

These benefits of the legislation are immediately clear and obvious. Uniformity will deliver efficiencies for business and licensees, but there is a bit of a wait and see approach to some elements of the legislation as highlighted by the shadow Treasurer in his contribution this evening. We are giving powers to a ministerial council that really is accountable to no-one. If Queensland desires to amend the laws at any time in the future we must basically go cap in hand seeking consensus from that ministerial council. But given that this legislation is skeletal and will be supported by regulation, perhaps more concerning is the potential, as mentioned by the member for Mudgeeraba, that that supporting regulation may become excessively large and/or inferior to existing Queensland regulations and therefore could negate the benefits of uniformity.

It is worth acknowledging the comments of the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee in its most recent Legislation Alert . The Scrutiny of Legislation Committee does look at parliamentary scrutiny of delegated power, and whether a bill has sufficient regard to the institution of parliament depends on whether, for example, the bill sufficiently subjects the exercise of the delegated legislative power to the scrutiny of the Legislative Assembly. There has been growing concern within the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee around parliamentary scrutiny of national regulations. The Legislation Alert states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: In the past, the committee has expressed concern about nationally consistent regulation which failed to require the tabling in the Legislative Assembly of regulations made under a national law.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Fortunately, though, this piece of legislation is perhaps the first that we have seen as a committee come across our tables that addresses that particular concern. The committee goes on--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Therefore, the committee is pleased to note that although clause 5 would exclude the operation of the Statutory Instruments Act generally, section 164(1) would require the tabling in the Legislative Assembly of national regulations. Section 164(1) requires the member of the Ministerial Council representing a participating jurisdiction to make arrangements for the tabling of a regulation made under the National Law in each House of the Parliament of the participating jurisdiction.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is worth pointing out, though, that perhaps we have really only taken half a step forward in this instance. As the shadow Treasurer pointed out in his comments, if we were to disallow a regulation related to this national legislation, it still needs to be disallowed in a majority of the other states for it to actually take effect in this state. In closing, I acknowledge the contribution of the shadow Treasurer and member for Clayfield and that the LNP will not be opposing this legislation.

Ms JOHNSTONE (Townsville--ALP)
(6.23 pm): I am pleased to contribute to the debate on the Occupational Licensing National Law (Queensland) Bill. The objective of the bill is to apply the Occupational Licensing National Law Act 2010, as passed in the Victorian parliament in September, as a law of Queensland. The national law is a schedule to that act and this bill applies the national law in Queensland. The national law, as has been said by previous speakers, is the legislative framework for the national occupational licensing system which aims to allow for more practical movement of people working in the occupations covered by this legislation across jurisdictions in Australia.

Consumers will also benefit from these changes by having access to information about the licensees in a national register. The occupations that are covered by this bill were selected by COAG based on selection criteria, including the importance of the occupation to the economy and being subject to previous mutual recognition schemes. As has been stated, the national system will be implemented in two phases: phase 1 from 1 July 2012 and phase 2 from 1 July 2013. The national law will have built-in flexibility which will also allow for additional occupational areas to be added in future through nomination by participating jurisdictions and by agreement with the ministerial council.

History tells us that because licensing has traditionally been a state and territory function, licensing systems have developed in different ways across jurisdictions which has resulted in approaches to licensing that are not consistent across the country. While mutual recognition schemes have made some attempt to address this, inconsistencies remain and have continued to impact on both small and large businesses and individuals who want to work in more than one jurisdiction. The impact of this has been acknowledged in a number of ways, including in the 2006 Productivity Commission report, Re-thinking regulation: Report of the taskforce on reducing regulatory burdens on business . COAG agreed to the National Partnership Agreement to Deliver a Seamless National Economy in response to these reports. The NLS is one of the many reforms being undertaken as part of the national partnership. COAG also established the business regulation and competition working group to oversee the range of reforms being undertaken by the national partnership and the National Licensing Steering Committee is supporting the working group in relation to the NLS reform.

Aside from COAG-level reforms, the Queensland government is also committed to reducing regulatory burden across business, community and government. Our government’s Smart Regulation Reform Agenda is addressing regulatory burden in Queensland on several fronts. We have set a target of reducing compliance costs to both business and government by some $150 million per year by June 2013. To achieve this the government is simultaneously reviewing the stock of existing regulation and enhancing the quality of future regulation.

Under the Queensland Regulatory Simplification Plan of 2009-13, government agencies are reviewing the existing stock of regulation, removing unnecessary and excessive legislation and streamlining administrative and procurement processes. The regulatory assessment statement system introduced in March this year implements the government’s enhanced regulatory development and review processes which are focused on improving the quality of our new regulation. These initiatives are already delivering savings on top of the national initiatives which will further harmonise and simplify requirements across jurisdictions.

It is important to note that the NLS is not harmonising every aspect of regulations of these occupations. For example, ‘conduct’ requirements will remain the responsibility of participating jurisdictions. It is also important to note that our state based regulators will continue to accept licence applications and administer the licensing system. Finally and importantly, I note and support the Treasurer’s comments in his second reading speech where he puts on the record the Bligh government’s continued support of union representation during the COAG process. I fully support the case for unions to be represented on the National Occupational Licensing Board when the time comes for such appointments to be made. I support the bill and commend it to the House.

Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development)
(6.27 pm), in reply: I thank all members for their contribution. Can I deal with the issues that were raised in the discussion on this bill this afternoon. In relation to the issues raised about awareness of the changes, it is intended that at a national level, both in the lead-up to implementation and post implementation, there will be extensive communication campaigns that will not just be through associations. That is in answer to the questions from the member for Gladstone.

Secondly, in relation to costs, obviously for those licensees who are presently paying fees in more than one jurisdiction, by definition the costs will be reduced for those individuals in those circumstances. Beyond that, it is important to emphasise that the individual fees will continue to be set under the arrangements that are proposed by individual states. Therefore, by and of itself, a move to a national system does not necessarily increase the costs that are relevant to any individual. In relation to costs more generally, it is envisaged that the revenue lost because of the lack of need for entities or individuals to hold more than one licence across jurisdictional borders will be in the order of $3 million. That is a very rough estimate, but nevertheless it is the likely estimate given that, of course, we do not have a national system from which to benchmark.

The message from the Governor that was provided earlier is merely a precautionary measure. There is no contemplation in the current arrangements that fees would be paid outside of the consolidated fund in Queensland. But if it was the case that into the future a new arrangement was put in place where those monies were, for instance, for a particular profession, collected at a national level, then in order to observe the requirements of the Queensland Constitution such a message needs to be provided for in the passage of the bill in this instance so as not to provide that such a collection into the future would be unconstitutional.

In relation to the appointment process, it will be the ministerial council on which all ministers sit--not unions--that will make the appointment. Obviously it is intended that the board will be competent, skill based and representative. Ultimately that is the position that the state has advanced through this process. In relation to the intergovernmental agreement, which of course represents the basis for the work, I am happy to table a copy of the intergovernmental agreement for the benefit of the record and all members of the House.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Council of Australian Governments Intergovernmental Agreement for a National Licensing System for Specified Occupations [ 3465 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: An issue was raised in relation to the disallowance process. It is the case that the disallowance process here is, in fact, more generous than is the case in other national laws--that is, a majority only is required. But ultimately, it is worth making the point that we are not ceding powers irrevocably; that if it was the case that the matter was such that it was felt by this parliament, or indeed the next one or the one beyond that, that the matter was so inappropriate and unable to be endured in Queensland, then there is the ultimate ability to withdraw in a legislative sense. By definition, however, a national system requires a national system of disallowance in order to provide for its efficacy. Ultimately this is, as I said, a national system.

In relation to the requirements about charges, it is the case that charges would only be contemplated on a case-by-case basis. For instance, it is already the case for some occupations such as taxidrivers. I cannot see it being particularly relevant in other occupations, but where the interaction is required; of course, it is required in general terms in this skeletal bill, but the regulations themselves, when they are determined, will work it out into the future.

Regulatory reform is complex, and there are many issues that have been raised through this process. There are a lot of issues that are always to be worked through. It is fair to say that a lot of that will take place over the next 12 months. The challenge here is to not resort to the lowest common denominator; it is to lift up to appropriate higher standards. We are not, as a government, baselining here or wasting time on conducting a baseline exercise. What we are doing is getting on with the job of regulatory reform, putting it into the public arena and inviting industry to make comment on it on the way through.

The other major issue that was raised was in relation to the BSA, which will continue to have a role. It is envisaged that it will continue to have a role. Issues around insurance and consumer protection are contemplated to remain within the bailiwick of individual states and territories under the licensing arrangements. With that, I thank all members for their contribution to the bill and commend the bill to the House.
Sitting suspended from 6.33 pm to 7.30 pm.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 3, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 4--

Mr NICHOLLS (7.31 pm): Clause 4 is the operative part of the legislation. It draws into operation in Queensland the national law that was passed in Victoria as the host, if you like, of the substantive provisions of the bill. As it appears as a schedule to this bill, I cannot go through it piece by piece, nor would I want to. But I thought I would use this opportunity to raise any issues that may apply in terms of the bill. There are only a couple. I did raise these issues in my speech on the second reading, and the Treasurer did briefly respond to a couple of the issues that I raised so far as the provision of section 4 of the law is concerned.

Section 4 is the definitions clause of the law. It sets out the definitions including the definition of ‘criminal history’, which I raised in my address on the second reading. Subsection 4(c) refers to ‘charges made against the person for an offence, in a participating jurisdiction or elsewhere, and whether before or after the commencement of this law’. This goes to the issue that I raised previously in terms of criminal history including a charge rather than a conviction for an offence. It has applicability because section 18 of the law covers eligibility for a licence and sets out the principles for eligibility for a licence for an occupation. Then section 19 deals with personal probity. Personal probity includes the requirement of personal probity information. It is the case that sections 4, 18 and 19 all come together in terms of the suitability of people to carry out their job. This would cover a very substantial number of people.

It is also something that has been pointed out by the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee in their report. In items 13 through to 20 of their report, they raise a number of issues regarding ambiguity about the operation of these clauses and how they inherently stack up. It also relates to the operation of clause 8 of the bill itself, because clause 8 of the bill provides that the licensing authority may ask the Commissioner of Police--so that would be our commissioner--for information relevant to whether the person satisfies personal probity requirements under the occupational licensing national law. So there are a number of provisions of both the law and our bill which all come together in an effort to provide information for the licensing authority when it considers whether it is going to be granting someone a licence to operate in one of the four occupations that are covered here. There are a number of ambiguities in terms of having regard to rights and liberties of individuals.
I also raise the question of spent convictions. If you go to section 19, subsection (2) has a provision which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Matters relating to the criminal history of persons will be subject to legislation of participating jurisdictions that prohibits, or does not require, the disclosure of spent convictions.
XML.Hansard-Body: We have that type of legislation here in Queensland that prohibits the disclosure of spent convictions in five and 10 years time. I am just wondering if the Treasurer is satisfied with these requirements, particularly in relation to charges and spent convictions. We like to give people a chance; a charge is not a conviction. Things come to light that mean charges are dropped or cannot be proceeded with. Also, with spent convictions, it would not be an unusual case for someone perhaps to have a spent conviction who wants to get one of these jobs. Is the Treasurer satisfied that there are sufficient safeguards to make sure that people are not unduly prohibited because of those areas in terms of taking on the job? The Treasurer during his reply referred to driving offences. I can certainly see why driving offences would be a part of it, particularly for personal transport services, but that is not charges nor spent convictions. So there is a difference there. Could the Treasurer perhaps address that issue and the resolution of that ambiguity because we will not get a response to the Scrutiny of Legislation Committee report until after this legislation is passed.

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer for the question. In my remarks in summing up what I was seeking to explain was not in relation to driving convictions but that charges in relation to a criminal matter are relevant to those areas, for example, where the licence relates to a passenger driving licence--for instance, a taxidriver or a bus driver. So this is to traverse the types of arrangements which are in place both in this state and in other jurisdictions where charges can be considered--for instance, in a blue card scenario where there is interaction with children. The same applies for bus drivers and taxidrivers--charges can be taken into account in terms of making an assessment about the appropriateness of that individual to hold that licence.

This does no more in a legislative sense than to seek to provide, because this is skeletal legislation, the head of power in which by individual occupation those matters can be taken into account. I do not envisage that the nature of previous charges that may or may not have fallen away or spent convictions are going to be particularly relevant to the issue of a plumbing licence. I do, however, consider that, as is the case in the law in Queensland at the moment, where such matters are already taken into account in the issue of a licence, they will continue to be allowed to be provided for being taken into account in the future. The reality of course here is that these are matters which will, as the shadow Treasurer rightfully points out, be considered substantively in the regulation-making task that will take place during 2011.

In essence then, it is required that the national architecture legislation provides for this to occur, because in some instances in some professions in some states already this is the case. Where that applies to individual occupations will be a matter that is determined ultimately by regulation. It is one where--I agree with the shadow Treasurer--all parliaments need to be mindful of the balance between ensuring that individual liberties are protected and the community interest.
Clause 5--

Mr NICHOLLS (7.38 pm): I understand the Treasurer’s response to the last question. Clause 5 deals with the nonapplicability of certain provisions of Queensland legislation to the operation of the national law. There is quite a lot there. Some of them are quite significant pieces of legislation--obviously the Auditor-General Act, the Financial Administration and Audit Act and the Information Privacy Act.

My understanding is that, so far as the law itself is concerned, where it provides for something to be done by the national licensing authority, then the application of those acts to that particular authority is not to apply. But, because it is the delegated model authority, if, for example, one of the delegated licensing authorities in Queensland--one of our departments or offices--is given an obligation to issue licences or to carry out the work under the national licensing authority, then the laws and the rules that are set out in clause 5 and all those subclauses would continue to apply to the operation in Queensland of those Queensland departments and reports would be provided. For example, an RTI application about the number of applications processed by a particular Queensland department or the fees charged or any of those other matters would still be applicable. So that information would still be available under RTI legislation, even though those departments are, in effect, applying the national scheme legislation under the delegated model authority. Can I get clarification that particularly the RTI Act, the Auditor-General Act, the FAA Act and so on are still available, if you like, as part of the accountability measures in relation to the operations of those departments?

In passing, in my speech during the second reading debate, I referred to the training and skills system and I am not sure if the Treasurer responded to that in his reply. That is a training package development to ensure that training is available for potential licensees to be able to hold those licences. Can the Treasurer also talk about the idea of consensus, which is the 100 per cent agreement in terms of the appointment of the board, and how that will be resolved.

Mr FRASER: I thank the shadow Treasurer. In relation to the matters relating to consensus, it is, if you like, a new vogue COAG principle that consensus in fact means 100 per cent agreement. That is a new principle of Commonwealth-state financial relations that has been authored in recent times. That is in the establishment phase. After that, there is an element of majority rule, I have to warrant to the parliament this evening during the debate. Consensus will be required, which is 100 per cent support, for the constitution of the board. Therefore, I expect the matter will ultimately be, in those circumstances, a negotiated outcome.

In relation to training, the point made is a relevant one, and it is one which the National Occupational Licensing Authority, or NOLA, through its board will have to be mindful of. It is certainly one in which I believe an element of effort will be required by participating jurisdictions to ensure that the models of training in different jurisdictions are in fact recognised through the regulatory making process that will occur in 2011. I consider that to be just one part of the substantive part of the work that will go on during 2011.

In relation to the issue here, we need to be clear. The explanatory notes to the bill, as tabled, point out that under a delegated agency model the laws of Queensland will all apply to actions undertaken by a state entity. That is, where it is a state department, a state agency or a state statutory authority undertaking one of the aspects or functions contemplated under the law, then all of the laws--whether it is the Auditor-General Act, the Financial Accountability Act, the Right to Information Act or the Judicial Review Act--will apply to those functions of a Queensland agency. But, given that the national authority will also be undertaking activities by and of itself, it is necessary to exclude individual jurisdiction over the efforts of the national authority, otherwise you would find you have seven or eight freedom of information legislations applying and seven or eight Auditor-General acts applying. The potential for nuances in the way those acts are drafted in each jurisdiction would provide for conflict and obviously a level of unworkability.

Therefore, to be clear, the complete architecture of legislation applies whenever it is a state entity undertaking and the architecture at a Commonwealth level applies when it is a Commonwealth entity. In sections 135, 137, 141 and 150 of the national law, it calls up the various pieces of Commonwealth legislation--be it the Ombudsman Act, the Privacy Act, the FOI Act and the Archives Act explicitly on that point.

Mr NICHOLLS: I appreciate the Treasurer making those points. So far as the consensus issue is concerned, I questioned whether that then gives Queensland, through the ministerial council, effectively a power of veto, but it gives any one member a power of veto ultimately if a member of that council is unhappy with any of the appointments there. In relation to the actions required for training and skills, is that something that would require action by another agency in Queensland? Or is it something that regulations set and then, say, TAFE in Queensland has to take up and put into a training program that requires further action in the state in order to make sure those services are provided and are available?

Mr FRASER: Ultimately, for each jurisdiction, it is the Treasurers--the members of the Commonwealth-state federal financial relations ministerial council--who have the sign-off on these arrangements. As it happens, in a practical sense, that means that through the cabinet process the various elements of licensing, of training elements and other attaching issues--whether they are consumer affairs issues or others--are incorporated into the position that each jurisdiction will take. Therefore, the call-up of training issues is one that will occur, as it does in relation to the COAG agenda more generally.

In relation to the issue of 100 per cent consensus being required, your characterisation is correct. My experience of the COAG process of the last couple of months tells me that it is a different beast to where it was a couple of years ago. A couple of years ago, it might have occurred once a year whenever the political theatre of the day required it. It was generally setpiece theatre, such that each actor knew their part, each actor knew when they would exit stage left and everyone was home for dinner. The experience over the last couple of years has been that the bar has been raised to expect that issues are resolved before anyone gets home. I for one have spent a lot longer in places that I would rather not because the idea of those at the table was that the problem needed to be solved, not the theatre engaged in.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 6 to 10, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (7.46 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a third time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a third time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Hon. AP FRASER (Mount Coot-tha--ALP) (Treasurer and Minister for Employment and Economic Development) (7.46 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Level-1-Heading: Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill
XML.Hansard-Body: Resumed from 18 May (see p. 1545), on motion of Mr Wilson--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Dr FLEGG (Moggill--LNP) (7.47 pm): The Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 has three components. First, it makes a number of largely consequential administrative changes in the VET area; second, it makes some more substantial changes in the area of collection of information from day-care providers; and, third, arguably the principal provision of the bill is that it gives school principals the power to suspend or expel students.

Speaking on the child-care information collection initially, these provisions in the bill amend the Child Care Act 2002. They add a new section under clause 4 as an exemption for maintaining confidentiality of child-care service records. The only other current exemption is for legal processes, court presentation and tribunals. In relation to the issue around unaggregated data, there are no provisions on aggregation for disclosure to the Australian Bureau of Statistics or the AIHW.

Obviously, the collection of data from the unit records of children in child-care centres is a sensitive area. There are concerns--and certainly some concerns have been expressed by the industry in relation to this--that data will be available not just at a statistical level but also through what are called the governing bodies for the child-care industry. There are concerns that the data on individual children will not be used simply for the purposes of statistics but will be used for a range of other uses including the determination and provision of funding within the sector in the case of governing bodies of the quality assurance areas. It would be fair to say that, in common with some participants in the industry, the opposition shares some concerns in relation to information of this nature.

The government announced a new funding model and new arrangements for early childhood education including the new governing bodies and quite significant changes to the funding arrangements. That is part of the reason for these changes. We have some reservations, of course, in the sense that it will add a layer of bureaucracy to the administration of child-care centres. It does indisputably raise the issue that information at the level of individual children will be used more broadly and quite possibly, despite the safeguards in the bill, will be more broadly available. The opposition will not oppose these changes, but we will take the opportunity to express certain concerns that we have in relation to it. Hopefully, putting those on record might contribute to the awareness of them. I will speak to some of those concerns a little later.

The principle change under the bill is one that was flagged by the government prior to the introduction of the bill back in May, and that was an increase in the power of principals. This is another example of the many that we have seen in this parliament whereby policies put forward by the LNP in this case have been adopted by the government in large part or, in some cases, in entirety. These particular measures fall into the latter category; they mirror exactly the policy that the LNP took to the last state election and that we subsequently reiterated federally.

The education policy of the Liberal National Party at the 2009 state election was that, if the LNP was elected, school principals would be responsible for school discipline with the authority to make the decision at the local level to expel or suspend the student within the approved behaviour or conduct code. Further, it was stated that an LNP government would fund more teachers to provide for rehabilitative programs for suspended or expelled students. These provisions are, in fact, a direct take-out from the LNP policy at the last state election. I am sure that the minister has gathered from the comments that I have made that the LNP will be in full support of what the government is doing here.
Mr Wilson: Thank you for your support of our very good idea.
Dr FLEGG: And why should we not, because it was us who not only put it forward but also took it to an election as part of our platform.

Following that state election, on Tuesday, 7 July 2009 I went to Canberra and issued a joint press release with the federal Liberal shadow minister for education, Christopher Pyne. In that press release we jointly--at the federal and state level--supported new powers to provide greater flexibility for principals to deal with bullying in their schools including suspension and expulsion powers where they do not exist.

There is an array of areas in which the government has been influenced. On 30 October 2009, I was delighted to introduce to this parliament the first piece of legislation aimed at addressing the issue of cyberbullying by outlawing that practice. The government released its cyberbullying brochure to the public on 4 May 2010. Although sometimes it is hard to understand why the government opposes opposition measures, I think most people would be pleased to see a government that will pick up and run with some of the measures put forward by the opposition.

In relation to principal powers to suspend and expel, I would like to make a very significant point. On 20 April 2009 I read a piece in the Townsville Bulletin in which the Kirwan police officer-in-charge, Senior Sergeant Gary Eddiehausen, said that the biggest problems came from children who had been suspended from school. In common with many stakeholders, we accept that principals need to have this power. We accept that every child who goes to a school in Queensland has a right to an undisturbed education. Where behaviour is so poor as to justify suspension or expulsion, then that becomes necessary to protect the right of another child to a peaceful education. However, it would be a very big mistake to think that, in simply suspending or expelling students, we are solving the problem.

A whole range of educational experts have made comment in this area. Suspension and expulsion, firstly, works as a punishment and, hopefully, a deterrent for children who are on the borderline. It also functions to protect the behaviour within the classroom and the right of the other children to access their education. It does not necessarily fix the underlying problem with the child who has been suspended or expelled.

Our Queensland schools are, in our view, best managed by local leaders and local leadership. This is an instance in which the right to make a decision in relation to a suspension or expulsion--and I believe the overwhelming majority of Queenslanders would have believed principals already had this--is being taken away from the bureaucratic and administrative level where that decision lay and being returned to where we believe decision making in schools is most effectively made and that is with the principal. There has really been a philosophical argument over this point. We believe that principals who are given the authority, the rights and the responsibilities for dealing with students and teachers in our schools should, wherever possible, be given the power to make the decisions that affect those children and that they are best placed to make those decisions, not a bureaucrat from a much more remote government department. It has been a very long time since Queensland principals have had this power. In fact, I understand it has been around four decades since this current system was introduced.
Mr Wilson: So it was not changed when you were in government?

Dr FLEGG: My understanding is that it was about 1964 that this system was changed. That is certainly the information I have in front of me. It has been like that for a very long time. I ran this past a lot of people, even people involved in education. The majority thought that principals already had that power.

This bill inserts a new section into chapter 12 part 3 division 1A, ‘Exclusion of students by principals’. 288A will give the principal the power to exclude a student on grounds such as disobedience, misconduct or other conduct that is so serious that suspension is inadequate to deal with the behaviour. As it states in the proposed legislation, an exclusion can also occur if a student breaches a behaviour improvement condition that has been imposed by the principal.

Echoing the words of Norm Fuller, the President of the Queensland Secondary Principals Association, ‘It is more than appropriate for principals to have this power as we want to ensure that our schools are safe places for students to learn and safe places for our staff to operate and teach.’ I think there are many people who believe parents make choices in relation to where their children are sent to school based significantly on their perception of the level of discipline and order within the school. For parents it is a deal breaking issue if control is seen to be poor within schools.

These practices have been in place for over a decade in New South Wales. They were introduced by a Liberal government in the Education Act 1990. These practices are also present in Victoria and South Australia. In these states the power to discipline students with expulsion has rightly been delegated to the principals of schools.

There is a burning need for discipline within our schools. Violence in our schools is on the rise. Queensland Teachers Union President, Steve Ryan, stated in the Brisbane Times on 29 June this year that ‘the level of violence in schools was escalating in line with society.’ I think I share that belief with Steve Ryan from the Teachers Union. I do not think it is particular to schools. I am pretty sure that the minister would support me on that. The instances of violence that we see are across the community. This violence can be impressed upon young people in particular.

If we go back a generation the worst of violence was perhaps in the cinema or places like that. There was limited exposure to violence. We have moved to a new era now where some children can be exposed to significantly more violence for greater lengths of time through things like the internet. There is a risk of desensitising children. When senior people like Steve Ryan affirm that there is increasing violence in schools I think it is something that we should be very concerned about.
Queensland criminologist Professor Paul Mazerolle, the director of Griffith University’s violence research program, told the ABC News on 16 February this year--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: We hear of more events and we certainly hear of more serious high-profile incidents. They seem to be increasing.
XML.Hansard-Body: Melbourne based psychologist Dr Michael Carr-Gregg, who is frequently quoted on the other side of the chamber and is recognised as an authority on teenage behaviour--he has been endorsed by this government--spoke on the ABC’s 7.30 Report on 16 February this year. He stated that bullying in our schools is definitely there and appears to be getting worse.
Mr Wilson: He’s actually been supported by the three education sectors--Cath Ed, the independent and state schools.

Dr FLEGG: Thank you. He based his claim on the fact that in 1990 Ken Rigby’s figures showed that about one in six school children had been bullied. In 2005 Gene Healy from the University of Western Sydney showed that it had risen to one in five. Last year Professor Donna Cross reported that one in four children are bullied.

These figures are alarming. With such a high percentage--in fact a quarter--of our students being subject to bullying and harassment, it is imperative that principals have the power to deliver discipline, to deter and to resolve bullying on the ground in our schools. The fact that these bullying figures are increasing, and increasing rapidly, shows that for too long this government has sat on its hands and ignored discipline problems in our school, even though everyone else has been aware of the problem. That also harks back to my earlier comments about our efforts to get the government to act in the area of cyber bullying.

Students cannot learn in a disrupted learning environment. School safety and a calm learning atmosphere are essential for our students to achieve the academic excellence that they are capable of. We have cases in Queensland of teachers undergoing courses to learn how to restrain unruly students using the body hold--as occurred at East Ipswich State School in January this year and reported in the Brisbane Times on 22 January 2010. Our teachers and our headmasters are a vital resource in the education of young people and, in fact, vital figures in the lives of our young people. It is more than appropriate that we should entrust them with the powers that they need to influence that sort of behaviour.

The rate of expulsions and suspensions in Queensland schools is soaring. I know that the minister would say that this represents a tougher crackdown within schools. There may be some basis for that. But it also suggests that behaviour in our schools is not improving and may even be getting worse.

Expulsions jumped 20 per cent in state schools last year as reported in the Courier-Mail on 20 June 2010. In 2008 there were 804 expulsions. In 2009 there were 943. In 2008 short suspensions numbered 51,177 and long suspensions 5,819. By 2009 short suspensions had jumped to 53,405 and long suspensions had soared to 6,794. In 2008-09 average suspensions were 278 students per day, as reported in the Brisbane Times on 29 June. With South-East Queensland students there were 650 suspensions each week. Some 60,200 suspensions of up to 20 days were issued across the state last year with only 48,684 in 2006.

These figures are actually quite disturbing. They do reflect on the fact that there are major discipline problems. I would accept from the minister a claim that it does indicate a tougher approach from staff within schools in an effort to try to get behaviour under control. But I think it also represents the fact that there is an underlying problem that we are a long way from getting on top of.

I found two quotes that are pertinent to this particular issue before us. The issue of giving decision making to the local authority within a school--as we see with the issue of suspensions in this bill--is a major philosophical issue within education in this state. One of the quotes is from John Goodlad who is an educational researcher and theorist who has published influential models for renewing schools and teacher education and is in fact the author of around 30 books, 80 chapters and 200 journal articles. John Goodlad said that the guiding principle being put forward is that schools must be self-directing. If we move away from that principle of schools and principals having sufficient autonomy to run and control their schools, then we will see the situation spiral even worse than we appear to have seen already.

The other quote is from Terrence Deal. Terrence Deal is a professor at the University of Southern California and an internationally known lecturer and author who has written numerous books on leadership and organisations. Terrence Deal says that the pathway to educational excellence lies within each school. The experts in education understand very comprehensively that if you do not have good decision making, good leadership and appropriate authority within the individual school you cannot get the quality high-level outcomes that we would like to see for all children in Queensland.

The amendments that I have been referring to are amendments to the Education (General Provisions) Act 2006. Those amendments--and I will not necessarily go through all of the clause as I have them laid out before me--lay out the procedures and guidelines that principals must use in relation to excluding a student and the grounds on which they can be either suspended or excluded. They also lay down some of the more practical procedures that the principal must follow in terms of what notice should be given; the roles and rights of the student’s parents; the right of replying to the charges that have been put forward as a reason for that action; and the submissions that a child or their family may make, and there is a five-day period for submissions to be made, a period which, by mutual agreement, could be extended. There are also explanations contained in the bill of how a principal must proceed if he decides not to proceed with the expulsion.

In supporting these measures, it comes down to the issue of allowing principals their decisions in relation to running schools and showing them that respect. I am a great believer that if you treat people with respect--if you give them the authority to do the job with which you have charged them, particularly highly professional people--then they are much more likely to rise to that challenge and that level of respect. I will give the House an example that occurs in some schools which shows just how little respect there sometimes is for headmasters and their rights.

One such example occurred at the Jindalee State School where for quite a number of years the local councillor, Matthew Bourke, has sponsored the local fete. Prior to Matthew Bourke sponsoring the fete, Felicity Farmer, the Labor councillor for Jamboree ward, sponsored the local fete. On this occasion the headmaster had to ring the councillor and say that he had had a call from local member Julie Attwood and had been instructed that, even though he contributed financially to the fete, he was not to be allowed to sponsor the fete. I rang the school myself to confirm that this was the case. It is absolutely outrageous that a headmaster--someone whom under this bill we are giving the right to suspend or even exclude students--would be directed by a state MP, who said, as I understand, to that headmaster that if he proceeded and allowed the councillor to sponsor the fete, as had been their practice, the minister would not be impressed. That indicates the extent to which the position of a headmaster can be undermined, and that is certainly not something that we would find acceptable in any way, shape or form. The position of headmaster should be respected and when headmasters make decisions in their schools that should also be respected.
I turn now to the other major part of the bill, and I am getting to the end of my contribution. I have not taken as much time tonight as I would normally take, but I am getting towards the end.
Mr Wilson: We’re grateful!

Dr FLEGG: In relation to the area of child care, there are many changes in the pipeline for early childhood education and care, some of which are causing considerable consternation and a lot of anxiety within the sector. The provisions in this bill are significantly involved in those changes. What this bill does in terms of early childhood education and care is create indisputably an additional layer of bureaucracy and it has created concerns in relation to the privacy of data on children in child-care centres. The URL, the unit record level, data can be disclosed under these amendments to an authorised officer of a central governing body or the chief executive of a relevant service. Information that can be disclosed includes the child’s name, the child’s date of birth, the child’s gender, the child’s primary residential address, their Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander descent, the primary language of the child or their family, the healthcare card status of the child’s parents, the diagnosis of medical or disability conditions, assistance required because of a diagnosis, and the hours of kindergarten attended by the child.

The breadth of this information should make us look very carefully at any procedures that allow the use of this information. That is pretty much the life story of a child of this age, and much of that information, particularly in relation to addresses and medical diagnosis and disability, is very personal information for those children. With regard to a disability or special need, it may well be that it is useful information. As I have indicated, we are taking it on trust that the safety precautions that this information cannot be misused will be effective. However, I would urge the minister, particularly as this bill is implemented, to ensure that we are very vigilant about the safety measures that are imposed on this information. This is information that is potentially very disadvantageous to a child or their family to have released into the wrong hands. The data can be disaggregated for use by AIHW or the ABS, and again the use of disaggregated and identifying data in dealing with these sorts of specifics is of concern and should lead to a high level of vigilance. The chief executive may use or disclose the data for quality assurance; funding, which is of particular relevance at the present time, with the flux within the funding system; monitoring and reporting on early childhood initiatives; and preparing data for disclosure to the ABS or the AIHW.

The amendment allows the use of data in what is essentially government policy practice. An authorised employee of a central governing body--and there have been about five central governing bodies that have been set up in Queensland--may use the URL data for quality assuring, funding, planning and developing services for children, parents and guardians and staff members, implementing curriculum development and reporting on the central governing body’s performance. A person authorised to give the information is the licensee of the service, staff member or employee who administers the data.

Although the information can be used for positive measures, the important concern is the impost on centres. These child-care centres, some of which will be involved in the government’s kindergarten programs, are working in an industry that is subject to very rapid change. Much of that change is quite costly to the industry--changing staff ratios, changing qualification levels for staff. So we have a natural, quite strong concern about any measure that will increase reporting, that will increase the amount of administration and the amount of red tape that these centres will have to deal with. We understand that some changes are necessary because of changes within the industry. To give an indication of the sort of administrative problems that we are very worried about, and which I sincerely hope are not aggravated by the additional reporting contained in this bill, I refer to Condy Park Preschool and Kindergarten, which wrote to me outlining its concerns. The letter states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: I have just been on the phone to the new Kindergartens QLD Smart Service call centre (as directed by the OECEC--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is the Office for Early Childhood Education and Care--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: new promotional brochure) and was very disappointed and shocked to see that they were unable to find Condy Park as a Kindergarten service provider in Hervey Bay. The only two services found offering the kindergarten services in Hervey Bay were East street and the St James Lutheran and to add to the confusion apparently neither of these are C&K??? After much discussion with the call centre assistant and further investigation on my request, Condy Park was finally found under the Long Day Care Centres Pialba (not anything to do with Hervey Bay) The call centre lady was concerned that I had the post code wrong as Condy Park is not listed as a Hervey Bay Centre. There needs to be immediate attention and changes to this system, as it is not providing accurate information or, for that matter any information about Condy Park as a kindergarten service in Hervey Bay. Condy Park has always been a Kindergarten providing Quality programs run by teachers to the target age group. WE are a triple unit kindergarten service, currently catering for the large majority of Hervey Bay Families with our innovative programs. We are currently affiliated with C&K and are in the process of weighing up all our options as are all kindergartens across the state. We were told that this great new service--
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This is the telephone call centre service--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: for families would inform families of their options and assist them by confirming the centres offering the program they require. My experience was that it was more like a directory assistance number. Actually when calling Telstra directory assistance number they were more helpful in finding Condy Park as a kindergarten in Hervey Bay.
XML.Hansard-Body: I have quoted at length from that letter from Condy Park kindergarten--which is one that I am personally familiar with and one that I know to be a very high-quality kindergarten--to show the sort of administrative burden that is falling on these centres. This C&K affiliated kindergarten has been classified by this government as a long-day-care centre and, as such, had its funding imperilled despite assurances that have been given to this House and elsewhere by the minister. They will always, of course, come under the reporting requirements contained in this bill for the information from the URL file for each of their children.

I think we are getting a very clear message from Condy Park--and I do not think that it is the only kindergarten--that there are administrative hiccups in the system. Under this bill, we are now moving to an arrangement where the most personal and intimate details of children will be required by the law we pass here tonight to be given to an array of bodies, including the government, the central governing bodies, the Bureau of Statistics and others. It is very important to ensure that administration is efficient and confidentiality provisions are effective and work. When this bill comes into operation I request of the minister that great vigilance be applied to the administrative processes that are imposed on the state’s many child-care centres.

In closing, I note that this bill was introduced on 16 May, which is quite some months ago, and at the time it was indicated to be an urgent bill. The bill seems to have continually dropped down the list in the Notice Paper as though there was absolutely no urgency whatsoever to pass it. So I hope that the minister in his summing-up explains--there may be some perfectly logical reason--why it has taken so long to debate this bill, given the urgency that was indicated when this bill was introduced. The minister might be able to give us the reasons for the delay in debating the bill.

Ms BATES (Mudgeeraba--LNP) (8.26 pm): I rise today to contribute to the debate on the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. The main objectives are to amend the Child Care Act 2002 to enable the recording, use and disclosure of unit record level data, or URL; to amend the Education (General Provisions) Act 2006 to give state school principals the power to exclude a student enrolled at the principal’s school for a period of not more than one year or permanently; and to amend the Vocational Education, Training and Employment Act 2000 to achieve consistency with national curriculum arrangements.

On 6 November 2009, the Ministerial Council for Education, Early Childhood Development and Youth Affairs endorsed a National Information Agreement on Early Childhood Education and Care to support the development of nationally consistent, quality early childhood education and care information. The Queensland government signed the agreement on 19 February 2010. These two agencies required jurisdictions to develop the capability for the collection and reporting of unit record level data. Under the agreement, ‘URL’ refers to data on an individual child, which includes their name, date of birth, address and demographic information such as Indigenous status, language background and whether the child has a disability or special needs of some sort or another. The main source of URL data to meet the obligations under the agreement will be the Early Childhood Education and Care Services Census.

A new funding scheme has been set up to support kindergartens and long-day-care services to deliver approved kindergarten programs. I am happy to announce to the House that two such providers in my electorate were issued with funding grants in the last distribution of funds. Queensland requires URL data to be recorded for the purposes of quality, assuring approved kindergarten provider funding entitlements in 2011 and in the future. Therefore, the amendments to the bill are needed to enable Queensland to collect and report URL data in order to meet its obligations under the National Information Agreement on Early Childhood Education and Care and to make sure that Queensland kindergartens receive the correct funding entitlements for their programs.

I turn now to another example of this Bligh Labor government trying to imitate the Liberal National Party. As the saying goes, imitation is definitely the highest form of flattery. On 18 December 2009, the Minister for Education and Training announced the government’s commitment to grant state school principals the power to exclude students from their schools. One does not have to look too far back in history to see that that formed part of the Liberal National Party policy that was taken to the last state election, which states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The school principal will have authority to speak on behalf of the school community and will be responsible for school discipline with the authority to make the decision, at a local level, to expel or suspend a student within the approved (School Behavior) code
XML.Hansard-Body: Once again we find a lazy Labor government taking our ideas and making them its own. Queenslanders are not fooled by such tricks. It is clear that this policy of handing power back to school principals and school P&Cs is well aligned with Liberal National Party policy. It is very similar to our health policy of handing back control of local hospitals to local boards made up from locals in the community. This policy has always been Liberal-National policy and will remain so into the future. Yet again it was another one of our policies stolen not only by the state ALP but also by the federal ALP. No amount of smoke and mirrors from those opposite will change the fact that it was initially part of our policy.

I do have a new and novel idea for the Minister for Education: I have been calling for a feasibility study into the need for a new state high school on the western side of the M1 in Mudgeeraba for five years. When I am out in the electorate of Mudgeeraba I am asked time and time again, ‘When are we going to get our own state high school on the western side of the M1?’ With 36 per cent of our children travelling from west of the M1 to Robina State High School, this rapidly growing young electorate is crying out for a new state high school.

At the last sitting of parliament I had the pleasure of hosting the student leaders and principal of my only state high school, Robina State High School. They had a very educational and informative visit to the House and were very impressed, not only with their meeting with the honourable Speaker and the Leader of the Opposition but also with the work that the Parliamentary Library does. I take the time tonight to thank the Speaker and the Parliamentary Library staff for their time during the last sitting.

I would also like to take this opportunity to thank my hardworking principals and their fabulous staff for their dedication, particularly the principals of Mudgeeraba Special School, Mudgeeraba State School, Mudgeeraba Creek State School, Gilston State School, Clover Hill State School and Springbrook, Numbinbah Valley, Merrimac and Robina state high schools. Up until the last redistribution Mudgeeraba was the only electorate on the Gold Coast with eight feeder primary schools and no state high school. Currently the school has 1,367 enrolled students with a capacity of 1,878.

Mr WILSON: I rise to a point of order. Could I direct the Deputy Speaker’s attention to the fact that the member is not addressing any element of the bill that is before the House. I ask the Deputy Speaker to rule on the question of relevance.
Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Ms Farmer): Order! I have given the member some leniency, but I do ask you to address the specific clauses of this bill.

Ms BATES: In closing, I again ask the minister to desist with the political point scoring and commit to this feasibility study for a new state high school. This is one Liberal National Party idea that I and the residents of Mudgeeraba would happily allow the Bligh Labor government and the minister to claim as their own idea.

Ms DAVIS (Aspley--LNP)
(8.31 pm): I rise to speak to the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. In doing so, I acknowledge the government’s adoption of one of the LNP’s policies for the 2009 election. Behaviour is, without a doubt, one of the most common concerns voiced by teachers. Students who disrupt classes continually do not just exasperate the teacher; they also sharply diminish the ability of the teacher to communicate with other students. Every minute spent dealing with the bad behaviour of one, two or more students is a minute not spent in teaching and learning. It is a vicious circle. A teacher who must spend the majority of their teaching time dealing with the bad behaviour of a noisy minority of children cannot devote the time they would like to the majority of their students. Some of the better behaving students may fall behind or lose interest, some may succumb to peer pressure adding to the ranks of the badly behaved. Meanwhile the teacher finds it harder and harder to get the class to behave and perform decently.

Early education is vital education. Any shortfall, particularly in early basic skills such as literacy and numeracy, can follow through to impact on all subsequent education and training. This is indeed a trend that must be nipped in the bud. When a student’s behaviour gets so bad that there is no alternative but suspension or expulsion, doing that has been hindered in the past by layers of bureaucracy and the fact that the principal could not make the decision to exclude a student at a local level. The Bligh Labor government has steadily been eroding the authority of principals, taking away their voice and their power.

In September 2008 the LNP promised that the school principal would have authority to speak on behalf of the school community and would be responsible for school discipline with the authority to make the decision at a local level to expel or suspend a student within the approved school behaviour code. This is only common sense. Principals need to have affective, simple, standard and autonomous powers to deal with issues arising in the daily environment within their school. Antisocial behaviour is one of the biggest problems that occurs and the power of principals to deal with it has been steadily eaten away by this government. Under this bill amendments to the Education (General Provisions) Act will allow a principal to exclude a student from his or her school. This replaces the previous ineffective process where a principal supervisor or chief executive had to act on a recommendation from the principal. The new process finally gives the power to a principal, albeit in a highly bureaucratic manner. The grounds for expulsion are serious disobedience or misconduct. Under this process the principal must give the student a notice proposing exclusion and suspend the student pending a final decision. If a child disagrees with the decision then a review process is available.

While this amendment is overdue and welcome there are other issues that require attention. Schools do require more autonomy. There do need to be better methods and alternatives for implementing order and discipline in our schools and improving the learning environment. Parents do need to be able to trust the school to deliver a safe environment to their children, one where their son or daughter is not going to be terrified of bullying or deprived of the best possible education because of other children’s behaviours. A lot of the problem is in resourcing. Many of our schools are struggling to cope with overcrowded classes and facilities, short-staffing and a burden of administration at the expense of class contact.

Not all bad behaviour is wilful. Sometimes it can be the result of medical conditions such as autism and the failure of the education department to provide adequate resources to help children with autism spectrum disorders, or ASDs, to engage in the education system. It is pleasing to see that ASDs are now included in the definition of disabilities under this bill in dealing with child-care centres. If only they were included as a recognised separate and countable condition in schools generally, the chances are that resources would be better applied and allocated and parents would have an easier time in accessing services to help their children through school.

The fact that Education Queensland was the only agency that declined to be involved in the Australian Advisory Board on Autism Spectrum Disorders report in 2007 dealing with the prevalence of autism was bad enough. Its reason for failing to cooperate was worse. The report states that the Queensland education department declined to provide data to the study due to concerns that--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: ... the use of the term autism is not based on a nationally agreed definition so will lead to inappropriate data comparisons across jurisdictions.
In addition, there is some contextual information that would be useful to accompany the data to ensure any interpretations and elaborations are based on qualitative as well as quantitative findings.
XML.Hansard-Body: It does not get any better. The report details that Queensland was the only state known to have diagnosticians upgrade systems to enable the child to access limited funding resources that were tied to specific diagnoses. As the report says, the practice occurred more frequently in regard to meeting Queensland’s access requirements for special education services than in the completion of Centrelink forms. In other words, Education Queensland does not have the resources to deal with the problems encountered by students with special needs, whether it be the lack of resources for expert support, the lack of programs for teacher training or the lack of funds for learning resources. Early intervention is essential in these conditions so it is pleasing to see the Child Care Act now at least distinguishing ASDs. Now is the time for funding and resourcing to follow.

Ms NELSON-CARR (Mundingburra--ALP)
(8.36 pm): I rise in support of the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. As a former teacher I understand that these new changes will make very big differences in the future, particularly for principals. On the eve of World Teachers Day I would like to congratulate all teachers, particularly those in my electorate where I know many of the schools because I have taught in many of them. I know just how dedicated and committed teachers have to be but also how committed and dedicated they are to our young people, and I send them a very, very big congratulations for tomorrow. We need them and we thank them.

This government is definitely committed to ensuring that state schools remain safe places for students to learn and for teachers to teach. Without that commitment of safety then we cannot really teach and people do not feel happy about going to work. The new power for principals to exclude students is only one part of helping principals to manage poor behaviour in schools--only one part. As a former teacher I used to have an alternative program at Townsville State High School.
A government member interjected.

Ms NELSON-CARR: Yes, it is a great school. I take that interjection. It was one of the ways which we dealt with children having difficulties behaviourally and in a learning capacity at that school. It was an excellent method and idea in order to keep these young people at school and to give them an opportunity for their future.

We are implementing a range of other initiatives to promote positive behaviour in schools. I will not go into that tonight. I think most people have already spoken on that. I would like to congratulate the government, which has shown its commitment to addressing behaviour in schools through the engagement of two consultants in the past year--Dr Ken Rigby and Dr Michael Carr-Gregg--to enhance the responses to bullying. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs SMITH (Burleigh--ALP) (8.40 pm): I rise in support of the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill. I am particularly interested in a principal’s power to exclude students. This government takes school safety very seriously and is committed to making every effort to enhance the safety of staff, students and the school community. Schools are among the safest places in the community for young people. However, we will not hesitate to take any necessary action to make schools even safer.

There is already a range of strategies in place in Queensland state schools to promote safe and disciplined learning environments. State school principals have extensive decision-making powers about school operational issues which enable them to take swift, firm and decisive action to ensure the safety of staff and students. Every state school has a responsible behaviour plan for students which outlines the standards of behaviour expected from students in a school and the disciplinary measures that may be given to students when those standards are not met.

I have spoken in this House before about a wonderful program called 3R--Retrieval, Resilience and Reintegration. The program identifies students between the ages of eight and 14 years who are at risk of being expelled from school. It provides students with the skills to be able to cope more effectively and strategies to enable them to respond appropriately in the classroom, improving their social abilities as well as their learning abilities. The whole purpose of the program is to enable children to return to their own schools and resume their education with the ability to actively participate in school life.

3R is based at the Tallebudgera Beach Outdoor Education School, and I commend the principal, Allan Rafton, for his commitment to this very worthwhile program. This week I hosted a lunch in the dining room for Tanika, Jack, Cooper, Jay and Jordan--five students from 3R--together with their three teachers. They had won the invitation based on their good behaviour and were so proud of themselves. I want to acknowledge the support and encouragement given to these young children, aged between eight and 11, by their teachers Di Bowerman, Krystal Kiss and Jan Large. These are teachers who put an enormous amount of time and effort into giving children an opportunity to change their behaviour and attitude and, hopefully, be returned to their school. While there was some concern about how the children would behave, I can report that everything went well, much to the delight of the teachers and full credit to the children.

Behaviour that puts the safety and learning of other students at risk should not be tolerated in our schools, and behaviour such as physical assault, drug or weapon possession and property damage can now be addressed. Giving state school principals the power to directly exclude students enrolled at their school will send a strong message to students and parents that poor behaviour is not tolerated in our schools. These new principal powers, in combination with the Queensland Schools Alliance Against Violence and other existing departmental initiatives, are the key to maintaining safe school communities. I commend the bill to the House.

Mrs SCOTT (Woodridge--ALP) (8.43 pm): At the outset I would like to say how much I appreciate what the principals and teachers are doing in my schools. Schools are the most exciting places in our electorates at the moment. Who would ever have dreamed that in the face of a great economic downturn we would end up with such a wealth of new facilities. In my case with national partnership schools, the extra money is making a real difference. So there are good things happening in our schools.

This is a very important piece of legislation because it is designed to give power to principals to ensure their schoolrooms are places where students are able to learn in a healthy, safe environment, free from disruption and inappropriate behaviour. However, it goes further than that and seeks to ensure that students who are excluded from a school are then able to access an alternative form of education until a final decision is made and, should they not be able to return to the school, then to continue their education in a facility which might be more appropriate to their needs.

It has always been a great concern of mine as to where our students go who either drop out of school or are excluded. I remember when Matt Foley was in this place and spoke about 10,000 young people in Queensland not in work and not in school.
Ms Nelson-Carr interjected.
Mrs SCOTT: He did.
Mr Wilson: Between the ages of 15 and 17.

Mrs SCOTT: That is true. Our district director of education at the time, Kerry Holst, did a survey and indications were that there were at least 2,000 of those in Logan City. It was at that time that the ETRF--the Education and Training Reforms for the Future--was implemented and many innovative programs commenced. For many and sometimes complex reasons, some young people do not fit into our normal school regime. I believe my electorate of Woodridge is well served with a number of alternatives, and I have witnessed many, many lives turned around and young people re-engaged through these alternative options. Sometimes it is as simple as smaller student groups and building confidence and self-esteem in a young person. The words often repeated are, ‘This is the first time anyone has taken any interest in me or said “well done”.’

I would like to compliment our alternative schools and behavioural management units in Logan.
