Woodridge High has long had a behavioural management unit and the Centre Education Program, under the leadership of Lorraine Brown and operated under the Edmund Rice tradition by the Christian Brothers, has enjoyed incredible success with a high percentage of Indigenous students. BoysTown, with manager, Anne Chandra, has for many years worked with young people at risk in vocational training, Skilling Queenslanders for Work, literacy, numeracy and a very diverse range of both dynamic practical subjects and skills.

Early in the first phase of Community Renewal in the Woodridge-Kingston area, an unused wing of Kingston College was converted into a continuing education centre, where we have now seen thousands of mostly young people return for a second chance at education. Several years ago, I and a number of my colleagues received an email from Michelle Venables from the YMCA seeking a shed to work with at-risk young people. I remember ringing Michelle and telling her that my community was already out looking for a shed and to tell anyone else who rang, ‘Sorry, it’s already taken.’ We quickly found a shed and it was here that the very successful U-Turn program was run, turning many, many lives around. The YMCA has now built their own facility beside BoysTown in Mary Street, Kingston, and have just commenced their alternative school--the Clem Jones Campus, under the direction of Matthew Swift--where I know many young people will receive tuition, vocational training and a holistic education which will see many young lives affected in a very positive way.

Our principals, teachers and other staff in our schools work extremely hard and it is simply wonderful to see our improved facilities thanks to the BER by our federal government, as well as increased funding for staff and improved programs under the national partnership arrangements. We are witnessing great results. However, for our students who do need an alternative--and our schools make exclusion an absolute last resort--help is available. What is often needed is an attitude change and it is the special teachers and social workers who have skills to work with young people at risk who can often get alongside a young person to inspire them to continue with their education or to seek skills training.

Every young life is of great worth. I recall one manager at the YMCA saying to me, ‘Don’t bring the bright young people to me. I want to work with those who haven’t had a chance in life, who are behind the eight ball. I want to work with them to see their lives change for the better.’

Education and training is the key for every individual, and this bill will allow our principals to better manage their schools, with the safeguards of an appeal mechanism to the director-general should a student or parent feel the decision is flawed or unfair. I want to thank those who worked on bringing this bill to the House. I commend the bill to the House.

Mr EMERSON (Indooroopilly--LNP) (8.49 pm): Firstly, I want to say how privileged I have been to be able to share the 100th anniversary of one of the leading educational institutions in this state, the University of Queensland. It has celebrated its 100th anniversary and I have had the opportunity to join in a number of those celebrations. I am very fortunate to have the University of Queensland in my electorate. I also have a number of very fine schools. I had the opportunity to attend the 57th annual awards night at the Indooroopilly State High School this week. I want to congratulate all of the students who did win awards that night. On a personal note, I would like to acknowledge that a family friend of ours, Lucy Tonge, has been elected as the head girl at Brisbane Girls Grammar. It has been a real privilege to watch Lucy grow up to be such a fine, enthusiastic, caring and inspiring young woman.
Many of the students at those institutions obviously study Oscar Wilde. Oscar Wilde once said that talent borrows but genius steals. I know there is no talent or genius on the Labor side--
Ms Nelson-Carr: Oh, that’s a bit rough.
Mr EMERSON: --but they do seem to have a gift for plagiarism. I heard one of the ministers describe himself before as a man of modest ability--I think that is what he said.
Mr Watt interjected.
Mr EMERSON: I will take the interjection from the member for Everton, because clearly he does not understand what the word ‘plagiarism’ means. It means--
Mr Watt interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ryan): Order! The House will come to order!

Mr EMERSON: As I was pointing out, obviously the member for Everton does not grasp the idea of what plagiarism is. What we do not see tonight is the acknowledgement from our opponents of how often they steal the LNP’s policies. What we are really seeing here is a government that is bereft of ideas. It has not seen anything new for this term at all. It is time for government members to leave. Once again, we have seen this minister steal an idea from the LNP. Of course, stealing is not unusual from those on that side of the House either.

As I said, this policy we are discussing tonight--particularly the issue of giving principals greater powers--mirrors almost exactly what the LNP policy was at the election 18 months ago. Under the LNP’s 2009 education policy, it was proposed that if the LNP were elected school principals would be responsible for school discipline, with the authority to make the decision at a local level to expel or suspend a student within the approved behaviour code. Further, it was stated that an LNP government would fund more teachers to provide for rehabilitation programs for suspended or expelled students.
Let me read from that policy, entitled ‘Empowering parents and maintaining school discipline’. It stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Parents don’t only need a greater say in their child’s school; they have a right to a greater say.
An LNP government will stop the policies of the Beattie-Bligh Labor government that are seeing our schools become failed social experiments controlled from a centralised office in Brisbane.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: How many parents come and see me at P&C meetings and say that is exactly what has been happening under this government and this minister. The policy continued--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: An LNP government will ensure:
Parents have a say on school behaviour codes:
Parents will be empowered to determine behaviour codes for their child’s school in consultation with the school principal.
XML.Hansard-Body: This next bit is the important part and the member for Everton should listen to this to understand plagiarism. He should note the government’s policy that we are discussing tonight and then listen as I tell him what the LNP policy was 18 months ago. The LNP policy stated--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The school principal will have authority to speak on behalf of the school community and will be responsible for school discipline with the authority to make the decision, at a local level, to expel or suspend a student within the approved code.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That sounds very similar to what we are debating tonight--we have the LNP policy and then we see the ALP once again plagiarising that LNP policy. As I said before, this is a government that is bereft of ideas.
XML.Hansard-Body: What did government members do when the LNP announced that policy 18 months ago? You guessed it: they attacked that policy 18 months ago, and now 18 months on they are adopting the policy. Have we not heard that before in this place over and over again on numerous pieces of legislation, including just this week. This government rules out something and then steals that idea, and we have seen it again tonight. We now have Labor doing exactly what the LNP said should be done. One could say it is better late than never.

The education minister said it had become crucial for principals to take a stand on behaviour. He said, ‘We make no excuse about making sure tough action is taken,’ so why has Labor taken 18 months to adopt the LNP’s policy? The minister now admits that Queensland state school principals seeking to expel problem students get bogged down in too much red tape and are often overruled by regional supervisors. Again, this revelation, this epiphany for this minister, is 18 months too late.

It was interesting that Professor Geoff Masters’s report into Queensland education confirmed what the LNP already knew. In his April 2009 report, A shared challenge: Improving literacy, numeracy and science learning in Queensland primary schools , Professor Masters identified ways of improving the performance of Queensland students and noted that highly effective schools were those in which--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Class time is used as learning time, classrooms are calm and busy, and interruptions to learning are discouraged ... The school provides an environment that is safe and caring ... and values of respect, tolerance and inclusion are promoted throughout the school.
XML.Hansard-Body: It is interesting to note that my colleague the excellent member for Aspley, Tracy Davis, indicated that earlier as well. She said how important that was when she goes to P&C meetings. I know how hard she works in her electorate, and that electorate loves the fact that they have a new member who is out there doing the work, going to the schools. That is what P&C members tell her too--how important it is to have a classroom where teachers have the opportunity to teach and students have a chance to learn in a classroom that is calm and not damaged by disruptive behaviour.

As the Parliamentary Library research brief indicates, there has been mounting concern among parents about increasing incidents of bullying and school violence, highlighted by the fatal stabbing at a school in Brisbane’s north-east in February 2010. Attacks at other Queensland schools have also been reported as teachers attempt to reassure parents that schools are still safe places. Even more alarming is that, within days of that Queensland incident, there appeared to be a spate of knife attacks on students by students across the country, in what an Age newspaper reporter described as a ‘week of knives’.

It has also been reported that teachers are becoming disenchanted with students who are rude and disengaged and who disrupt the classroom. New teachers are resigning and retiring early, with a 2008 Australian Education Union survey of new secondary school teachers ranking student misbehaviour as the chief cause of complaint while primary school teachers ranked it second. It has been said that these concerns have increased since 2005.

The Queensland principals association president, Norm Hart, has said that principals would exercise this exclusion power as a last resort and that he did not believe it would lead to a greater number of exclusions. The Queensland Council of Parents and Citizens’ Associations president, Margaret Black, said she did not believe the changes would have a major impact on the way expulsions were handed out. She said--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Currently, a principal prepares all the paperwork and someone else signs it. Now, a principal will sign the paperwork instead.
I’m sure principals will make sure everything’s in order before they sign it.
XML.Hansard-Body: Given the LNP proposed this 18 months ago--and the ALP attacked it--the LNP will not be opposing these changes. In conclusion, can I say to this minister that it is better late than never, but we wish ALP members had actually listened to us 18 months ago, rather than attacking our policy then and now claiming it for themselves. This is another example of ALP plagiarism.

Mr POWELL (Glass House--LNP) (8.59 pm): I, too, rise to contribute to the debate on the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill. The Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 addresses several important but, as the member for Indooroopilly just highlighted, long overdue changes to education and child care. Firstly, I acknowledge that I am pleased to see the inclusion of autistic spectrum disorders in the definition of disabilities. Assisting the development of young children with autism spectrum disorders places significant stress on families, and it is my hope that the acknowledgement of this disorder will provide much needed support to these families. According to Autism Spectrum Australia, one in 160 Australians has an autistic spectrum disorder, emphasising the need for support for these children in our child-care system.

A child who has trouble communicating can face many difficulties when first beginning their schooling, and this acknowledgement of autistic spectrum disorders in the child-care sector will help provide a framework of support for the development of these children. Information collected from the child-care sector could provide important insight into planning and monitoring of outcomes of early childhood initiatives as well as ensuring that relevant services and approved kindergarten programs receive the appropriate funding. This kind of statistical information can be used to tailor kindergarten programs directly to students’ needs.

Clearly, great minds think alike--or at least this legislation lends itself to the obvious--as my next comments echo those of my good colleague the member for Indooroopilly. Yet again the Bligh Labor government has used its powers of plagiarism to pilfer yet another LNP policy. Let me quote--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The school principal will have authority to speak on behalf of the school community and will be responsible for school discipline with the authority to make the decision, at a local level, to expel or suspend a student within the approved (school behaviour) code.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: This next quote is from a slightly different source. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: The ability to make decisions about discipline within their school, including the exclusion of students, is key to confirming principals’ authority to the school community and in driving improved student behaviour, school performance and increased principal accountability.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: School principals will have the ‘power to exclude a student enrolled at their school for a period of not more than one year or permanently’.
XML.Hansard-Body: The similarity is blinding. To the untrained eye it would be very difficult to tell which quote came from the LNP’s education revival to make Queensland top of the class again released prior to March last year and which quote came from the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 2010 explanatory notes. Astonishing! Does the Bligh Labor government really think that it can continue to hoodwink the media and hoodwink Queensland voters into believing the LNP is a policy free zone? How can it honestly believe it can get away with that when for the third time this week we are debating legislation that mirrors LNP policy and private members’ bills? First there was the carers bill, then the penalties and sentences bill and now the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill. Let me thank the Bligh Labor government, because by presenting this bill to the House it has put paid to its own propaganda and spin once and for all that the LNP has no policies.

Before I conclude, I have not yet had an opportunity to acknowledge a success for the parents, students and staff at Elimbah State School. Back in June I raised in this House the concerns of the Elimbah school community that the government continued to deny them a safe pedestrian crossing on Beerburrum Road. The government’s prevarication meant that young Grace Giampino was struck by a vehicle when crossing the road with her older brother. Fortunately, Grace was not seriously injured, but this incident was the last in a decade of incidents and rightly pushed the school to breaking point. Finally, after a decade of despair and a concerted campaign during the past six months, the school community can rejoice. We have succeeded in getting not only a new and improved physical crossing, but also a funded crossing supervisor.

As I conclude, I thank Sharon Webb, the tireless P&C president and her band of passionate mums and dads. I would like to thank Grace Giampino and her family. I would like to acknowledge the extraordinary efforts and financial contribution made by Councillor Adrian Raedel and the Moreton Bay Regional Council and also the staff at the Department of Transport and Main Roads.
I received the following email from Grace’s father, John. It states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: My name is John Giampino and I am the father of Grace ... who was knocked down at a pedestrian crossing near Elimbah state school on 10 June 2010. I, as a current serving member within the defence force would like to thank you and your staff for fighting to get funding to have a guard positioned at that particular crossing. I believe that my daughter’s life is worth a lot more than the $15,000. As a serving member I am proud to serve and protect this fine country of ours, I thank you for your service and for protecting my daughter and other children and averting a catastrophe. Thankyou.
XML.Hansard-Body: In conclusion, all I can say is that I am relieved that finally common sense has prevailed and Elimbah students can now cross this busy road with greater certainty that they will stay safe.

Mr WELLINGTON (Nicklin--Ind) (9.04 pm): It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise to participate in the debate on the Education and Training Legislation Amendment Bill 2010. I notice that it is now five past nine in the evening. I welcome the member for Nanango, who is joining in this exciting debate. It is great news.

I have heard members of the opposition speaking. They have been saying that it is terrible and shocking that the government has stolen some of their ideas. I would love to see the government steal some of my ideas. I think they are great ideas. I say to members of the opposition that they should be excited and proud that the government is actually acting on some suggestions that they have brought to this chamber. I say to them that they should not be disappointed or disheartened; be excited that the government is adopting some ideas that they have brought to the chamber.
Mrs Pratt: Form of flattery.

Mr WELLINGTON: It is a form of flattery. That is right. I say to the government: thank you for moving these amendments. I think all Queenslanders will be proud and pleased to see that the government is finally going to empower our principals to be able to take very important, decisive action to exclude students who are simply doing the wrong thing. We certainly need to empower our principals. They know what is happening in their schools. Minister, thank you for listening to the calls that have been made for a long time.

Before I resume my seat I will also touch on one other matter, which relates to the amendment to the Vocational Education, Training and Employment Act 2000 which, the minister said in his second reading speech, was to achieve consistency with national arrangements. I remind the minister of a meeting we held some time ago with small training organisations that do not receive any state or federal government funding to provide their training to people who want to improve their skills in a whole range of services. The issue that was raised with the minister and his departmental officers at that meeting was a concern that the compliance requirement basically challenged the very ability of these small training organisations to actually deliver the training programs to students.

I am hoping the minister will clarify what is intended by these amendments that he is proposing in this bill. I would be very disappointed if it is the case that this amendment is actually going to make it more difficult for small Queensland training organisations that do not receive state or federal government funding to be able to continue to provide the very important training services that they are currently providing in this great state of Queensland. If it is the case that we are simply adopting national scheme legislation because the bureaucracy says that’s the way we have to go, if it is because we are adopting this national scheme legislation because the major training organisations which receive state or federal government funding say, ‘Yes, we will do it because we have to because we are receiving state government funding,’ then I would say that we need to have another look at it to ensure this national scheme legislation and these amendments are not going to challenge the viability of the very small business operators who are training people in Queensland. They are doing a great job. I will resume my seat. I look forward to the minister’s reply to the concerns I have raised. I seek clarification of the implications of this second part of the amendment dealing with the Vocational Education, Training and Employment Act 2000.

Ms van LITSENBURG (Redcliffe--ALP) (9.08 pm): I support this bill because it allow teachers to do their jobs and gives parents the confidence that their children will be safe in schools. I commend this bill to the House.

Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (9.08 pm), in reply: I thank honourable members for the opportunity to speak in reply to this debate. I thank honourable members for their contributions to the second reading debate on this bill. I will make some general observations and respond accordingly to some comments that have been made.

Firstly, I will take up some of the issues raised by the member for Moggill. The member’s claim that Labor stole some of their policies is, of course, ludicrous. Principals are responsible for the safety and education of our students every day. This is the highest level of responsibility that they could have.

I thank the honourable member for Nicklin, who has identified well that we need to be far more thoughtful about responding to the needs of principals as the supreme leaders of our schools--school by school--and that is what we are seeking to do.

I have been in this very privileged position of Minister for Education and Training for 18 months and I have talked to as many principals and as many teachers as I can, school by school, around the state. More importantly, I have spoken to many, many parents. They have confirmed my own sense as a parent that we need to affirm the leadership role and responsibility of principals of our schools.

We give them the responsibility for managing a large financial budget for that school and the livelihood of students between 50 in number to 2,500 in number. If we have trusted them with that responsibility then we should be able to put this particular power that we are providing in this bill in their hands to use in a most wise and careful way. It is only natural that principals would have, in addition to the extraordinary range of powers and responsibilities that they have, the responsibility to exclude students as a last resort--and I underline as a last resort--who for whatever reason are not able to meet the high expectations that we know parents expect teachers and principals to demand of students in their schools.

I would remind the member for Moggill that the responsible behaviour plans for students that are in each state school are developed in consultation with school communities. At the end of the third quarter of last year I requested all state schools--all 1,230 of them--to, in consultation with their P&Cs, review their responsible behaviour plans to ensure that every school plan reflects the expectation of the school community about the appropriate behaviour of principals. Principals have acknowledged that these are important powers and that they will use them in a very wise way.

In addition to that, the state government in the state school sector will provide more than $33 million to strengthen school discipline, promote positive student behaviour and support better initiatives in the financial year 2010-11. These resources are used to employ behaviour specialists and provide alternative facilities for students, such as positive learning centres, to address their behaviours.

A key objective of the bill is for state schools to achieve better learning outcomes for all students by having adequate powers at the local school level to maintain appropriate high levels of discipline and promote positive student behaviour. The decision to exclude a student is not made lightly. Schools use all available means to support students to change their behaviour before considering exclusion. Every principal and every teacher wants nothing better than the full engagement of every student that they have in every class in every school. It is a matter of considerable moment that a teacher and a principal would be considering as a last resort the potential exclusion of a particular student.

Students are only excluded if their behaviour is extremely serious and other support strategies and disciplinary measures implemented by the school have regrettably been unsuccessful. The government will provide, as I said, $33 million to strengthen school discipline and promote positive student behaviour in this financial year.

These amendments are part of a strategic response to managing student behaviour which includes enhancement of the case management of students who are excluded to ensure their continued engagement in education. The case management guidelines will specify the responsibilities for regions of Education Queensland to appoint case managers who will in turn record all contact made with students and their families, track student destinations, monitor the student’s education program and work with other agencies if required.

The case management guidelines will focus not only on ensuring that all students are provided with an appropriate educational program during the process of exclusion but also on ensuring the continued education of students in another state school, alternative education program, TAFE or other training or work placement following the exclusion to enable students to reach their full potential. Principals, school administrators and regional staff will be provided with training to enhance their decision-making skills to ensure consistency, transparency and fairness in the decision-making process.

I emphasise that the new process for exclusion of a student by a state school principal is the same as the existing process for a principal’s supervisor. This means that a principal will be able to exclude a student enrolled at the principal’s school on the same grounds as previously the principal’s supervisor unless it would be inappropriate for the principal to make the exclusion decision.

What is critically different is that we are repositioning the power of exclusion from that of the principal’s supervisor to the principal themselves. Students and their parents will be afforded natural justice by having the ability to make submissions to the principal about a proposed exclusion and to appeal the principal’s exclusion decision. I want to make the important point that, at the moment, in 90 per cent of cases a principal’s decision to recommend the exclusion of a student is presently confirmed by the principal’s supervisor. This indicates that state school principals are already making, in the main, sound decisions in the vast majority of cases.

I turn to the amendments relating to record level data. These amendments serve a dual purpose. Firstly, they ensure Queensland meets its obligation under the national information agreement on early childhood education and care. Secondly, allow the Department of Education and Training to quality assure funding provided to approved kindergarten providers. That is ultimately for the purpose of serving the needs of parents whose children are in kindergarten services.

The collection of unit record level data will only apply to children enrolled in an approved kindergarten program and to staff members of relevant services who deliver an approved kindergarten program. A relevant service may only disclose unit record level data to the director-general of the Department of Education and Training and authorised officers of a central governing body. The director-general may only disclose the data to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare or an authorised officer of a central governing body. The Department of Education and Training will code information such as names and addresses before providing it to the Australian Bureau of Statistics and the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare.

Any reports, based upon this data, can only refer to aggregated data level and cannot identify directly or indirectly any individual child or staff member. Unit record level data about individual children is the type of data that is already collected by services as part of the existing enrolment process.

Once the amendments commence, parents of affected children will be asked to update their child’s enrolment information to ensure that records are accurate. Relevant services will be required to provide a privacy notice to parents with this request to explain the terms under which the information is being collected and the purposes for which it will be used. Although there will be some additional reporting involved in providing unit record level data about staff members, it will be to ensure that services receive the correct funding entitlements for providing a kindergarten program and that child-care services are well targeted to meet the needs of Queensland children. I should underline that I am advised by the department that this amendment reflects similar legislation that has been adopted in other states as they seek to fulfil their obligations under the national quality agreement with the federal government supporting the increased federal funding of kindergarten teaching throughout the nation.

We will work closely with the relevant services to minimise the reporting burden while ensuring that the requirements for funding and accountability are met. I emphasise that the bill ensures a person’s privacy is protected by establishing adequate safeguards to ensure that information is only recorded, used and disclosed for the purposes set out in the legislation.

The bill also makes minor amendments to the Vocational Education, Training and Employment Act 2000 to ensure compliance with the national skills framework by expanding the definition of ‘statement of attainment’ to include a skills set as an additional category of achievement that may be certified by a registered training organisation.

Before concluding I want to respond to the particular matter raised by the member for Nicklin. The member for Nicklin raised quite a legitimate point about the importance of ensuring that either state regulation regarding the training sector or the gradual transition to a nationally regulated training sector across the country must ultimately ensure that it is designed in such a way that we facilitate and not hinder or hamper the delivery of training on the ground community by community, particularly by small training organisations that are often times the greatest in number of the training organisations that we have in the training sector.

I hear well his exultation that red tape and the burden of accreditation, the burden of document compliance and the filling out of information requirements is one that needs to be carefully guarded against to ensure that the good purpose and worthwhile objective of national regulation to ensure high-level quality of training being provided to apprentices and trainees around the country does not become overburdened by excessive regulation and red tape. I can assure the member for Nicklin that the issue that he has raised and which he raised with me some long time ago is one that Queensland has actively pursued at the national level with the council of education and training ministers. We will continue to push that concern to ensure that ultimately the very good purpose that we are pursuing--that is, of assisting training organisations on the ground delivering high-quality training--is one that is well promoted by the regulation and the national regulatory systems that we are setting up and not one that is impeded and made more difficult for those very good training organisations, including the TAFE system, that are doing such fantastic work around the state and around the nation. With those comments, I commend the bill to the House.
Question put--That the bill be now read a second time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a second time.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 1 to 3, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 5--

Dr FLEGG (9.23 pm): I note that clause 5 recognises an autistic spectrum disorder as a disability. I ask the minister to clarify a little more for us. There are two areas of concern, Minister, with this aspect of the bill. One is the administrative burden on early childhood centres and the other one is the deal of highly confidential information on children in play as a result of the liberalisation of access to it in this clause. Given that, what process will be in place--I do not mean simply the provisions in the bill but ongoing monitoring--to ensure that this information on young children is treated in the strictest of confidence?

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the question. In relation to the point that he asks about, the same approach will be taken to the administration of the legal obligation attaching to privacy and confidentiality as presently pertains to privacy and confidentiality requirements in other legislation that is the responsibility of my department to administer and legislation throughout government. That is the high standard that will be continued and replicated in the administration of the privacy and confidentiality requirements in this legislation and in this amendment. I certainly recognise the point that the member is making, and it is a point fairly raised. One can understand that it is a concern that people naturally have, and that is why I say that the standard of administration of this legal obligation attaching to confidentiality and privacy is the same high-level standard that presently applies to the administration of similar obligations of privacy and confidentiality that already attach to the Child Care Act and other relevant acts within the responsibility of the Department of Education and Training.

Dr FLEGG: Thanks, Minister. I appreciate that. In the case of this very sensitive information on three- and four-year-old children, the level of care actually needs to be even higher than in some other circumstances. Does the minister propose to have any ongoing surveillance of the way this clause works out in practice--because it is something that is going to affect the industry widely--with a view to, if there are areas where information may not be safeguarded as stringently as it needs to be, review and coming back and modifying the procedures?

Mr WILSON: The implementation of the state’s obligations under the national quality agreement with the federal government, as well as the obligations attaching to the rollout of universal access to kindergarten, require that the Office for Early Childhood Education and Care engages closely and regularly with all industry stakeholders not only in the kindergarten sector, the creche and kindergarten sector and community kindergarten sector but also in the child-care sector. That close engagement is well underway and it is a foundational element of the rollout of this major reform that is taking place throughout Queensland over the next several years. Part of that close engagement involves regularly seeking feedback from child-care providers and kindergarten providers of the way in which the program is being rolled out and the opportunities to improve the effectiveness of that rollout as we go month by month. That would include--and I would look to it including--any feedback by those services regarding improvements and additions that we can make to the way in which confidentiality and privacy attaches quite firmly to the collection of this important information that is sensitive but important for the effective delivery of this very important program.

Mr CRIPPS: Clause 5 of the bill proposes to insert a number of new definitions into the Child Care Act, including a new definition of what may be considered to be a disability for any purpose relating to the application of that act. The new definition states the following--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Disability includes a condition attributable to--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) a physical, intellectual, hearing, vision or speech-language impairment, or a developmental delay; or
(b) an autistic spectrum disorder; or
(c) a combination of impairments mentioned in paragraph (a), a developmental delay or an autistic spectrum disorder.
XML.Hansard-Body: Subclauses (b) and (c) of this definition are significant because for the first time autism spectrum disorder will be included within the broader definition of ‘disability’ for the purposes of the Child Care Act. This means that behaviour management programs, remedial, or special needs learning programs can be justified and funded on the basis of this data. Previously, Education Queensland has not had access to ASD specific records for this purpose.

During the hearing of Estimates Committee D this year I referred to a 2007 report from the Australian Advisory Board on autism spectrum disorders that stated that it could not use Queensland figures because Education Queensland declined to provide any data on the basis that there is no nationally agreed definition of autism and that Disability Services Queensland did not keep ASD specific data. Is the definition of ASD in this bill a nationally agreed definition? Will Queensland now be able to provide statistics to national reports concerning ASD?

Mr WILSON: I will take some advice from the department on the question raised. Firstly, I was not a member of Estimates Committee D so I make no comment about what the member did say or did not say and what anyone else may have said or not said in the context of the Estimates Committee D hearings. Secondly, I am advised by the department that the expression ‘autistic spectrum disorder’ has been included in the definition of ‘disability’ by the Office for Early Childhood Education and Care for the purpose, in its view, of fulfilling the obligations that the department has under the national quality agenda and the universal access to kindergarten agreements with the federal government and not for the purpose of aligning or not aligning with what might be definitions of autistic spectrum disorder in other states or at a national level in respect of which statistics are collected.

Mr CRIPPS: Clause 5 of the bill also inserts into the Child Care Act a definition requiring that, to be counted and collected, the child diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder must be (a) diagnosed by a health practitioner as having, or is suspected by a health practitioner of having, a disability or long-term medical condition and (b) needs additional assistance because of the disability or medical condition. In addition to the inadequacies that I pointed out earlier in terms of the ability of Education Queensland to collect data pertaining to ASD until the provisions of this bill make it a possibility for the department to inform funding arrangements and have the allocation of resources for the support of children diagnosed with ASD, a concern that has been regularly expressed by people in the community, and indeed by members of this House over a long period of time, is the manner in which health practitioners have diagnosed autism spectrum disorder.

At this point I would like to place on the record a considerable campaign mounted by the member for Murrumba over the past six years to draw the attention of the government to his concerns about what appears to be an inordinate rate of diagnoses of autism spectrum disorder among children in Queensland. For the benefit of the House, I table the contribution during the budget reply by the member for Murrumba on 17 June 2004, I table the member for Murrumba’s contribution of 29 November 2006 during the Education Legislation Amendment Bill, I table a speech by the member for Murrumba on 11 November 2008 pertaining to autism and I table a contribution to the House by the member for Murrumba on 19 June 2009 in respect of autism.
XML.Hansard-Paper-Heading: Tabled paper: Extract from Hansard , dated 17 June 2004, in relation to a speech by the member for Murrumba, the Hon. Dean Wells MP, to the State Budget 2004 [ 3466 ].
Tabled paper: Extract from Hansard , dated 29 November 2006, in relation to a speech by the member for Murrumba, the Hon. Dean Wells MP, to the Education Legislation Amendment Bill [ 3467 ].
Tabled paper: Extract from Hansard , dated 11 November 2008, in relation to a speech by the member for Murrumba, the Hon. Dean Wells MP, regarding autism [ 3468 ].
Tabled paper: Extract from Hansard , dated 19 June 2009, in relation to a speech by the member for Murrumba, the Hon. Dean Wells MP, regarding autism [ 3469 ].
XML.Hansard-Body: Over the past six years the member for Murrumba has demonstrated a commitment to raising awareness in this House and in Queensland of his concerns about a perceived overdiagnosis of autism spectrum disorder among children in Queensland. His commitment has been hampered by the fact that neither Education Queensland nor Disability Services Queensland has had an adequate mechanism to collect data pertaining to the rate of diagnoses of children suffering from ASD in this state. I draw that to the attention of the Minister for Education in the hope that, as the provisions of this bill now allow for the collection of data for ASD among children in Queensland, the aggregation of that data may lead to a more detailed analysis of what is a significant overdiagnosis of ASD among children in Queensland.

The member for Murrumba must be acknowledged for his persistent campaign to raise awareness of this issue and in particular to draw to the attention of the government the serious problems associated with the rate of diagnosis of ASD in Queensland. All I can say to the member for Murrumba is that we ought to welcome this small step--the collection of unit level data pertaining to the number of children being diagnosed with ASD in Queensland--in the hope that it may lead to the government taking seriously the excessive and worrying rate of ASD diagnosis among children in Queensland.

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for the points that he has raised. Firstly, I rely upon my earlier response to his first question regarding the addition of the expression ‘autistic spectrum disorder’ to the definitions in this bill and also make him aware, if he is not otherwise already aware, that Education Queensland is--and has been for a short time at least--endeavouring to identify a new approach to the whole question of not just autistic spectrum disorder but the broader question of the diagnosis of particular identified disabilities.

Education Queensland has commenced a special research trial in a number of areas, one of which is in the Logan area, called the response and recognition trial, which the member may not be aware of. That trial is in a number of schools and is taking place over a year or so. The objective of that trial is to identify whether there is an opportunity to go beyond the device of relying upon a particular medical diagnosis for the purpose of identifying what is the appropriate level of educational support that should be provided to a student to assist them to have the opportunity of an educational experience to an acceptable level or standard.

The purpose of the trial is, as I suppose the title of the trial indicates, to try to shift from medical diagnosis as a trigger for additional educational support to one of assessing what are the educational needs of a particular student and what might be the educational support provided to that child to meet those educational needs, however so arising those needs might be through whatever particular type of disability, so that the educational support is delivered to match the identified educational need, to release the process of assessing what is the appropriate educational support from its current dependency upon a particular medical diagnosis or not diagnosis. That will take some time to work through. It is being done as a thorough, serious, comprehensive exercise. Should it be successful, and of course we are hopeful that it will be, then we may be able to ultimately move beyond the position of some differences that occur between states and at a national level about not only this particular condition but also other disability conditions and how they are differently defined state by state and how they may be differently measured and counted state by state.
Mrs CUNNINGHAM: In part the minister has responded to the concerns that I wanted to raise. In the definitions it states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: disability includes a condition attributable to--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (a) a physical, intellectual, hearing, vision or speech-language impairment, or a developmental delay; or
(b) an autistic spectrum disorder; or
(c) a combination of impairments mentioned in paragraph (a), a developmental delay or an autistic spectrum disorder.
XML.Hansard-Body: There are many instances where families have a child and their disability is actually recognised and diagnosed, but in the scheme of things some families find it difficult to confront a disability in the family. I heard the minister mention diagnosed and not diagnosed incidents issues. I wonder how much consideration will be given to those family circumstances where the child may have an obvious behavioural, intellectual, emotional or physical disability but the family has not had the--fortitude is the word that I would use but I use it advisedly--fortitude or the courage to acknowledge that disability and have it diagnosed. Will that child, whose family may not perhaps have been confident enough to confront the issues in their child, be able to receive the necessary supports irrespective of whether the disability has been specifically and clinically diagnosed?

Mr WILSON: Firstly, I would say that every teacher in every classroom and every principal of every school endeavours to ensure that the educational experience that each child has is appropriate to the needs of that child in that classroom and in that school no matter what their circumstances, personal or otherwise. There are a full range of programs that teachers and principals access to assist in providing that educational experience that each child needs.

Secondly, I would say that it would be my hope that the response and recognition trial would be a vehicle for identifying the educational needs of those students and perhaps bypassing the challenge that some parents may understandably find it difficult to meet, and that is dealing overtly with the issue of whether or not their child exhibits or is diagnosed as having a particular disability. The response and recognition trial is preoccupied with the issue of what are the educational needs of the particular child dependant upon whatever might be their intellectual or physical circumstances but not contingent upon a particularly prescribed medical diagnosis.

I would be hopeful that the circumstance that you identify, which no doubt occurs from time to time, is one that could be more compassionately managed by this response and recognition trial being successful in identifying potentially a new way forward for addressing the educational needs of particularly students who presently are more conventionally described as exhibiting a particular disability that is medically identified and assessed and provided to the school.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 6 to 10, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 11--

Mr MESSENGER
(9.46 pm): Clause 11 deals with the exclusion of students by principals. It states a whole raft of legislation that indicates how a principal should go about excluding a student. I do not think any principal would take the decision to expel a student lightly. Expulsion for some students would be like water off a duck’s back but for other students it would be quite a traumatic experience. I understand that this clause is virtually the heart of this legislation. It would equip state school principals with powers to expel students at their discretion without the red tape they currently face.

I was hoping that the minister might be able to quickly compare the old system with the new system and just give practical examples of what red tape is excluded and done away with. Of course every student should have the right to go to a safe schooling environment undisrupted and the teachers and principals themselves have a right to a safe working environment and should not have to put up with disruptive or sometimes dangerous student behaviour.

It brings to mind a couple of questions. Now that it is easier to expel students on the principal’s behalf, first of all do students in state schools run by the Queensland government have to sign up to a code of conduct so that they know upfront what sort of behaviour is expected of them? I know that some private schools have that sort of paperwork. You take your children along and are told, ‘Here is how we expect you to behave and if you break these codes of behaviour you will be excluded.’ If there are those codes of conduct, are they uniform for the state or are they flexible and on a school-by-school basis and is that code of conduct then decided on by principals and the P&C?

As we go through clause 11, and it is quite a large clause with a number of pages, 288D, ‘Continuing education during suspension’, states that if the principal suspends the student from the school under section 288C, the principal must arrange for the student’s access to an educational program that allows students to continue with their education during the suspension.

That of course begs the question: where will the children go once they are suspended? I am sure that the department has thought about this. I know that there are programs in the Wide Bay-Burnett where children who are suspended do go. But unfortunately some students end up on the street and not in proper programs. I was hoping that the minister might be able to expand a little bit on the plans for dealing with those students who have been suspended and especially in rural and regional areas. There are more facilities in capital cities available for those students who are suspended or expelled, but in rural and regional areas there are limited resources, especially for the principals and the parents.

I would like to find out whether the minister has actually set aside extra funding for those suspended students for their welfare and educational experiences while they are suspended. Is there also special consideration given to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children? I have had some wonderful conversations with Dr Chris Sarra, and I was wondering whether the minister can expand on that as well.

Dr FLEGG: Clause 11, as the member for Burnett has said, is probably the critical clause in this bill. I have some strong concerns in relation to this. We all agree that it is a step in the right direction for these principals to have the power of suspension and expulsion. But I think we would all equally agree that suspending or expelling kids from school does not solve the problems with those kids. The suspended ones return to school and the excluded ones have to find some other place to get their education.

Section 288D in clause 11 provides a responsibility for the principal to arrange for the continuation of a student’s education once they are suspended and further on there are some implications for resumption. It would be no secret to the minister that I think the government has done a very poor job on the programs that look after kids who are suspended or expelled. I have raised this issue many times in this place. I travelled myself to the Fraser Coast to look at the GAP program there, which is a state funded program under the Flexible Learning Program, which had its funding cut in the last state budget. Another program on the Fraser Coast was the Triple S program, which was specially targeted at children who had been excluded from state schools. It was federally funded.
Mr Wilson: So don’t criticise this government. It was federally funded and you wouldn’t admit that during estimates.

Dr FLEGG:
Minister, it is not a case of criticising anybody. This is a very serious issue because when you suspend or expel children the problem does not stop there. Those children are part of society: they return to school or they become statistics in the criminal justice system. In common with every parent in Queensland, I do not care whether the state government or the federal government funds them, but someone has to put the programs in place for these children. Triple S, which was federally funded, was working well on the Fraser Coast and the federal government cut the funding. That is certainly not a criticism of the state government, but that program was dealing with students who had been suspended from your state schools, and I would like to have seen the state government either pick up that program or ensure that adequate programs were in place. I have no doubt that in this state we do not have anything like the programs that we need for children who are suspended or excluded.

In my speech on the second reading, I read out the numbers of short and long suspensions and exclusions, and they are going through the roof. We have thousands of kids, tens of thousands of kids, being given short suspensions and many, many kids--an increasing number--being given long suspensions or excluded from schools. They are out on the streets. They are in the shopping centres. They are providing a problem to the community. They are providing a problem to the police.

I undertook a study of disengaged youth. I studied a whole range of strategies that were being used on the Fraser Coast in particular because I think some of their programs were fabulous. The GAP program, for example, was staffed by very experienced teachers from the Urangan State High School. It was a fabulous program and it was a travesty to see it closed. The Glendyne school in the same area deals with 103 disengaged youths, many of whom have been involved with the juvenile justice system.

This is a really significant growing problem. I support wholeheartedly the principals having this power, but if we leave it at that and we do not acknowledge that the numbers are going through the roof and that the programs simply do not exist to re-engage these kids, to give them a good education and to make them positive contributors to society, it is going to be nothing other than a short-term response.

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable members for their contributions. I will take the last contribution first. This Labor government in the last five years, more than any other government in the last 20 years, including the Liberals and the Nationals when they were in government, takes absolutely seriously the issue of ensuring the maximum engagement of each and every student in the opportunity for learning every day in every school. That is why this government and its predecessor--and this Premier when she was education minister--brought in the Education and Training Reforms for the Future that brought trade training into schools and, with Matt Foley as employment and training minister, brought in youth support coordinators to address the issue that the member for Woodridge raised that in 2005 there were quite a number of young people between the ages of 15 and 17 who were out of school, out of work and out of training. So these youth support coordinators, of which there are 113 this very moment, funded by $10 million between Minister Struthers’ department and mine, work with those young people in that compulsory phase of schooling to keep them, as best as they can, engaged in the schooling experience.

On top of that, we have over 330 specialist teachers engaged in addressing the challenges of students with significant behaviour management issues at risk of disengaging from schools. We have over 100 alternative education programs that are able to be deployed by teachers generally in the state school system in addition to the more than 330 specialist teachers focusing on maximising the engagement of students.

We have 15 positive learning centres throughout the state, and we are funding the Edmund Rice bridge program at Morayfield, Townsville and Mount Isa, and we will continue to do so. Unlike the Liberals and the Nationals when they were in government, we are spending more money than they ever did, and paying more regard than they ever did, on the effort of ensuring that not only do students in the classroom setting and their parents have access to an uninterrupted learning and teaching environment but that those students who, for whatever good or bad reason, are not able to engage in the learning opportunity in the classroom setting and perform with and exhibit that high level of appropriate behaviour in that setting also have the opportunity to have access to a world-class education. We have done more than anyone else.

That is not to say that there is not a lot more that should be done. We will continue on the path of doing that because we are committed to those students who for whatever reason--and oftentimes through circumstances over which they have very little control--find themselves in a position where they cannot engage like we would like them to be able to engage in a conventional mainstream educational experience. We want them to have the best opportunity in learning and life.

If you are going to take a position of exhorting us to be concerned about this cohort of students, it is also incumbent upon you to ensure that your public discourse about this important issue is well and truly balanced and does not distort what is taking place and does not exaggerate or underplay the significance of this issue. Every student who is excluded is a student one too many. In 2009-10, regrettably 775 students were excluded from an individual state school experience--that is, not from the state school system as a whole. I trust that the statistics given to me compute accurately, but I am advised that there are 485,000 students in the state school system and about 1.5 per cent of those have been excluded. We welcome you joining with us in our concern about those students, but we welcome it if you do so on the basis of ensuring that what you say about this problem does not exaggerate or underplay the extent of it.
In relation to the student disciplinary absence data that we release every six months, I understand the Liberals and the Nationals did not even publish that at all when you were in government.

Mr SEENEY: I rise to a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The minister continues to offend the standing orders of this House by referring to the shadow minister in the first person. Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask you to enforce the ruling that has been made consistently by the Speaker to ensure that the standards of this House are upheld.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): I would ask the minister to direct all his comments through the chair.

Mr WILSON: I thank the honourable member for his illuminating contribution to this serious matter. I am sure we are all so much better off because of this wonderful intellectual contribution which will help us to better understand the challenge we face of having every child in every school fully engaged in their education. I am grateful to you. Thank you very much.
Mr Seeney interjected.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! That is unparliamentary, and you will withdraw it.
Mr Seeney: I withdraw.

Mr WILSON: I note that the shadow spokesperson for education would not allow himself to speak in such a way, so I recognise him for the difference he has displayed in his contribution to this debate. I welcome his support of our concern to ensure that all students are engaged in an appropriate opportunity for their educational experience.

The member for Burnett raised four questions. The fourth was in relation to the third and it related to Indigenous students. The third was about the opportunities for alternative education for students who had been excluded. I refer him to the remarks I have just made. In relation to the first two questions he asked, I refer him to my closing submissions--and, unfortunately, he was not here when I made them.

Mr MESSENGER: Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not think the minister has replied in sufficient detail and in a way that is a little bit accommodating at this time of night. I have simply asked some questions that I would hope he would answer in a very gracious manner, but he has answered them in a less than gracious manner. I simply asked the minister--and I will ask it again through you, Mr Deputy Speaker--whether students and parents have to sign up to a code of conduct. It is a fairly simple question. Is that code of conduct for all students state-wide or are their varying codes of conduct? If the minister puts forward the argument that he cares for the children, he can at least honour the people of Burnett and answer it in a fulsome way.

I note that the minister was quite proud of some of the information he told us, and he probably has some reason to be proud of the 330 teachers on the special learning programs for the disengaged people, the 100 alternative education services, the 15 positive learning services and the Edmund Rice learning centres in all of those different areas. I appreciate that they are quite impressive statistics, as is the boast that this government is spending the most amount of money on education.

However, I would also like to remind the minister of a frightening statistic for Queensland which I have only recently thought about in a critical way--the fact that Queensland has the highest youth suicide rate in Australia. Part of the risk of suspending students, as I mentioned in my first contribution on clause 11, is that for some students a suspension might be like water off a duck’s back but for other students a suspension is quite a traumatic event. Queensland has the highest youth suicide rate in the whole of Australia--and indeed Australia has one of the highest youth suicide rates compared to the OECD countries--and I would suggest that the minister should think about that statistic and become a little bit more humble in the way he approaches the debate tonight and show a little bit more humility when he answers the questions.

Members on the crossbenches and on the other side of the House are simply trying to ask for some detail. When the minister arrogantly lectures those on this side, it does nothing to improve how this government is seen in the eyes of the community--that is, that it has become a very arrogant, out-of-touch government. I would appreciate it if the minister would inform this place and in doing so inform the people of the Burnett whom I represent about some of the issues that I am asking about.

I would like to know whether the minister consulted with Dr Chris Sarra in constructing this legislation. The minister still has not answered the question about how his policy and this legislation will deal with the suspension of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children. Dr Chris Sarra was Queenslander of the Year. He heads a special institute now, the Stronger Smarter Institute. He has a wealth of knowledge and he achieved miracles when he was the principal at Cherbourg State School. Could the minister please inform this place of some of the details that I have asked for?
Mr WILSON: I refer the honourable member to my remarks in my closing speech, which the opposition shadow spokesperson was good enough to be here to listen to.

Dr FLEGG: There is no area of my portfolio of education that I am more passionate about than the issues surrounding disengaged youth and youth at risk of disengagement. I say that with the utmost respect. I hope I should not take the minister’s comments as suggesting that I am exaggerating the problem, because I can assure him I am not. There are 60,000 short suspensions a year in Queensland. I do not need to exaggerate the problem.

Those figures indicate the magnitude of the issue that we are dealing with. I fully appreciate and am very supportive of the programs that the minister has raised. Many of them, however, equate to support in schools. We are talking here about kids who have been separated from school for a short or a longer time. Trade training centres obviously play a significant role, particularly for boys, as well as youth support coordinators. One that the minister left out is school chaplains, who I think make an enormously valuable contribution in supporting our young people.

The minister was very correct in one comment he made and that was that many of these students who are excluded from school or have a lengthy suspension have very little control. Many of them are victims of circumstance themselves. I have taken the trouble to have a look at these issues in this state firsthand. Many of them come from very dysfunctional backgrounds. They might come from parents who suffer substance abuse, who live itinerant lifestyles, who are sometimes victims of abuse and who are frequently victims of neglect. There is a whole--I would be reluctant to use the word ‘class’--cohort of people, particularly in certain parts of the state--and I do not want to single out particular ones, but most of us would be aware where these problems are most acute.

The comment I made that I would really like to reinforce--and I hope that the minister will take this on board tonight because I have looked at it very seriously--is the need for a program specifically aimed at the disengaged youth. I did name a number from the Fraser Coast and there are other examples around the state. I have no doubt that they are by no means adequate, numerous or widespread enough across the state to cope with this very dramatic increase in the number of young people who are disengaged. That number of 775 exclusions would in the main be disengaged youth, and many others would also be at risk of disengagement.

It is a big challenge for us. From the LNP’s point of view, we would be more than happy to work with the government if anything constructive can be achieved. As the minister knows, I raise these issues pretty frequently. I have raised GAP, SSS and flexible learning funding on numerous occasions. I am very concerned that here we are giving principals powers that they should have already. We know that these numbers are going through the roof.
Mr Wilson: It is that expression, which is one of exaggeration, which I do not think is appropriate for you to use.
Dr FLEGG: You do not think a 10 to 20 per cent annual compound increase is ‘going through the roof’?
Mr Wilson: I’ll explain when you finish.

Dr FLEGG: The numbers speak for themselves and I did mention them in my second reading contribution. Putting in place programs to deal with these young people to get them back on track, to get them back into vocational training or education, will be among some of the most important things a government does in this state. It is not just the future of those individuals, their education and whether or not they are able to participate in society and obtain a job that is at stake; it is also that of their partners, their children, their families and the community in which they live. For every child we turn around who is disengaged with education, we make an enormous difference to the people around them for decades to come.

Mr WILSON: Let us agree on at least one thing, that we are in heated agreement about our respective concerns for this particular cohort of students, and that is a good thing. I am particularly keen to ensure that we address the description of the size or extent of the issue that we are in heated agreement about as best we can and that it is done in as fully rounded a way as possible. If you look only at the total number of suspensions--and I stand to be corrected--which was 63,000, taking that figure, it is a very big figure. But then there is a number of other dimensions that need to be examined to see the full or the appropriate extent of the issue.

There are 485,000 students attending state schools every day. I am advised that on any one day there are, on average, about 288 to 290 students who are the subject of a suspension, short or long. I rely upon professionally trained statisticians to provide me with this material; I am not such a person. That is what I am advised, and I am not seeking to minimise the challenge we face here by reciting these figures. I seek to have a fully rounded appreciation of its size. This amounts to approximately 0.04 per cent. That is 0.04 per cent too much from my point of view. Nonetheless, that is the figure. We will leave it to someone else to double-check the statistics.

I will give you a further statistic to give a sense of the proportion of the issue. Of all of the students who are suspended, 60 per cent are suspended for three days or fewer. Of the suspensions, 86 per cent are for five days or fewer. The member would be aware that the categories are one to five days and then six to 20. So 86 per cent of suspensions are in that short suspension period of one to five days. When we look then at the number of students, 60 per cent of the students are suspended for three days or fewer. We can look at it in terms of the number of suspensions and the number of students. We need to look at all of the figures to get a fully rounded position. At the end of the day, it is a serious problem, no matter its size. We as a government are very focused on addressing it. I welcome the member’s earlier comments.

Mrs CUNNINGHAM: I seek a couple of clarifications. Exclusion is a serious matter. I acknowledge the minister’s comments that, given the number of students at state schools in this state, the students who are excluded for one to five days, six to 20 days, permanently or less than one year is a small percentage, and I acknowledge that. The schoolteachers in our state do a brilliant job of handling a very wide cross-section of behaviours, both acquiescent and challenging behaviours. It would be only fair to put on the record that teachers do a brilliant job of managing a broad range of individual children.
Clause 11, in part, states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: (3) The notice proposing exclusion must state each of the following--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent2: (a) the principal proposes to exclude the student from the school for a stated period of not more than 1 year or permanently;
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: That statement is repeated on a couple of occasions. I am taking it that the exclusion period that is being dealt with in this clause--and I did not have a chance to clarify it during the second reading debate--is less than a year or permanent. They are two fairly contradictory periods. So it deals with an exclusion of less than one year or a permanent exclusion. I would just like that clarified.
XML.Hansard-Body: The minister talked about programs at Morayfield, Townsville and Mount Isa, which are all in Labor electorates--and that is good. However, I wonder what programs are available in the rest of the state for students who are excluded given that the adopted principle in this state is learn or earn. What programs are going to be available for students who are excluded, whether it is for less than a year or permanently? What will be available to them?

I know that the resources in my electorate are pressed at times for children with challenging behaviours who have been excluded for a protracted period of time. When this legislation passes, what additional resources will be made available to schools in rural and regional Queensland where students are excluded, albeit for very bad behaviours--again, I am not saying that bad behaviour should be condoned; it should not be. If teachers and principals are finding students too difficult to manage then they should have this as an alternative.

Mr WILSON: Can I just correct the record. I should have said when responding to the shadow spokesperson earlier that an average of 188 or 190 students are suspended on any one day out of 485. Apparently I may have said 288. I did mean to say 188 or 190 on average.

I come to the member for Gladstone’s comments. We have been responding to joint venture opportunities that we have identified with the Edmund Rice Foundation, a very significant educational institution associated with the Catholic Church in Queensland and unrelated to whatever electoral district in which it might be found in Queensland. The Catholic Church has not had the habit of arranging its activities according to electoral boundaries in Queensland to my knowledge.

In relation to the issue that the member raised about the opportunities available for disengaged students, with respect I did outline earlier in my response to the shadow spokesperson a whole range of opportunities. Sure, we would like there to be more, just as I would like there to be 0.00 students excluded or suspended. I did outline those to the House.

Finally the member asked questions about the exclusion being up to a year or permanently. I want the House to understand that that is already the position. What is changing is that the decision maker in relation to an exclusion is not the principal’s supervisor but the principal. The same framework of decision making applies after this bill is passed as before. It is the locus of the power that is relocating to the principal, down from the principal’s supervisors.

We can draw some confidence from the fact that the extent of the exclusion time frame--up to a year or permanently--is presently what has been operating for some number of years in the hands of principals’ supervisors. That, I believe from experience, has been managed responsibly. However, we are relocating to the principal from the principal’s supervisor the express power of making that decision. We would expect that it would be exercised with no less level of responsibility and discretion than has historically been displayed by the principal’s supervisor.
XML.Hansard-Level-3-Heading: Clauses 12 to 23, as read, agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Clause 24--

Mr WELLINGTON (10.24 pm): I listened to the minister’s reply to my contribution in the debate on the bill. In particular, I seek clarification of clause 24 which states, ‘This part amends the Vocational Education, Training and Employment Act 2000’. In the explanatory notes on page 7 under ‘Administrative costs’ it states--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Implementation of the Bill is not expected to result in any additional administrative costs to the Government.
XML.Hansard-Body: What about the administrative costs to small training organisations? There is nothing that recognises and acknowledges the bureaucratic red tape that this bill is proposing to require small training organisations to comply with. Why have we not got in this explanatory note acknowledgement or comment on the possible implications of those proposed changes on small training organisations?

Why is it that the department does not want to hear the concerns that the small training organisations in Queensland have? I am aware of the discussions the department is having on the national scheme legislation. It seems to me that, quite frankly, this government is going down the road of creating more bureaucracy, more red tape which I believe is totally unnecessary and at a time when Queenslanders are calling out for a reduction in red tape, a reduction in unnecessary bureaucracy.

I have a list of questions here that small training organisations which provide, say, a course for two hours to train people in first aid or CPR will have to answer. These are the questions that under this bill the government is proposing small training organisations will have to comply with and the questions that students will have to complete. I think it is bureaucracy gone mad.

Minister, I do not believe your department is properly informing you of the possible implications that this will have on small training organisations. I will read some of the questions that a small training organisation is going to be required to answer. We are talking about a training organisation that is going to run a course for two hours and receives no state or federal funding. It is not a university, it is not a technical college, but a small business running a course for two hours. Under this proposal they are going to be required to complete these questionnaires. The students are going to be required to complete a questionnaire. I understand that the students say that they are a jolly waste of time.

Who is requiring this to happen? It is your senior departmental staff meeting with their colleagues and the federal government who, quite frankly, I believe have no understanding of the possible implications of what you are proposing here tonight, and that is going to affect our small businesses which are creating jobs in Queensland.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): Order! Member for Nicklin, can you direct your comments through the chair.
Mr WELLINGTON: I am. To give an example for the record, the questionnaire asks--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Are you Aboriginal or of Torres Strait Islander origin? Yes or no, or both Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander? What is your age--under 15, 15 to 19, 20 to 24 or over 65?
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: There is a range of boxes there. These are the details that are going to be required to be submitted for a course on first aid that is going to run for two hours. It goes on--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: What type of qualifications are you currently enrolled in--certificate I, certificate II, certificate III?
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: There is half a page of lists.
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: What is the full title of your current qualifications or training?
XML.Hansard-Body: Let us look at some of the questions that the employer will have to answer--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Please tell us about the training provided by the organisation that sent you this questionnaire. Your feedback will play an important role in developing the quality of training at this organisation. In this questionnaire the term ‘training’ refers to learning experiences provided by the training organisation. The term ‘trainer’ refers to trainers, teachers, lecturers or instructors.
XML.Hansard-Body: It goes on. I am aware of the time. They can strongly disagree, disagree, agree, or strongly agree. There is a whole page of questions.

There are questions about the employer’s training. Were the trainers effective in their teaching? Did the trainers have a good knowledge and experience of the industry? Were the trainers able to relate material to the workplace? Overall were they satisfied with the training? It goes on and on and on.
