Mr WILSON: With respect, member for Nicklin, I indicated earlier that I recognise the issues that you have raised and Queensland is doing some things about that. Those issues that you have raised--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Kilburn): Order! Minister, can you direct your comments through the chair as well please.

Mr WILSON: The issues that the member has raised are separate from what is provided for in this amendment bill. This amendment bill goes nowhere near the issues that the member has raised. The issues the member has raised arise, if they arise at all--and I recognise that they do for small business--in the context of the shift to a national set of regulations for the training sector.

Mr WELLINGTON: Is it anticipated that there will be regulations introduced as a result of this bill passing through the parliament? If it is the case that there will be follow-on regulations introduced, will you require that there be an explanatory note to go with those regulations when they are tabled and presented to this parliament--
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER: Order! Member for Nicklin, address your comments through the chair instead of directly to the minister.

Mr WELLINGTON: I am, Mr Deputy Speaker. Minister, is it the case that as a result of this proposed bill being passed by this House regulations will be introduced? Will there be explanatory notes introduced with those supporting regulations so that members of this parliament--be they government, opposition or crossbenches--will clearly understand the possible implications of those regulations? My understanding at the moment is that the only way we can question that is when that document is tabled in here and we have to move a disallowance motion and then, not knowing what is contained in that regulation, we have to have a debate in this parliament that will last for up to two hours simply because the government has not introduced an explanatory note to go with those regulations.
Mr WILSON: I respond to the member’s question by referring specifically to the amendment that is in this bill, and the answer is no.
Mr WELLINGTON: Thank you.
Clause 25--
Mr WELLINGTON (10.32 pm): I seek clarification. The explanatory notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Clause 25 inserts ‘skill set’ as a new definition in section 19. Skill set is defined as a unit of competency, or a combination of units of competency, that links to a licensing or regulatory requirement or a particular industry need.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Can the minister please clarify exactly what that means? What are the possible implications as a result of this definition?
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WILSON: This definition is recognising that we are dealing with a competency based training system. Not only is that competency based training system one that allows accreditation and qualification when an apprentice or a trainee acquires a sufficient level of skills to be accorded a certificate I or a certificate II or a certificate III or indeed a certificate IV level of qualification; more than that, what this definition is now going to permit under the Queensland legislation is that any worker who acquires in a training program a number of skills that are less than the number of skills required to be given or accredited with a certificate I, II or whatever it might be, that number of skills is recognised as a skill set. That can then be relied upon by that worker in that, at whatever later time they wish to resume their training, they have a recognition that that set of skills--short of the full package that might be needed for the purpose of being accorded the certificate I, II or III qualification--is nonetheless a recognised set of skills and therefore can be built upon by further training such that they then can ultimately reach the point of being accredited for the complete set of skills available for a recognised level of qualification such as certificate I, II, III, IV or indeed diploma level. That is to the worker’s benefit and indeed to the employer’s benefit, because the worker can turn up with, in a sense, a certificate attainment saying that out of a package of 20 skills needed for certificate I they have received training for 15 of that 20.
Clause 26--
Mr WELLINGTON (10.35 pm): Can the minister please explain the reason or need for this amendment? The explanatory notes state--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: Clause 26(1) omits the reference to the National Training Information Service and substitutes it with a reference to ‘register of vocational education and training matters’.
XML.Hansard-Body-Continued: Clause 26 omits the reference to the service and it is substituted by the reference to ‘register of vocational education and training matters’.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr WILSON: As I understand it, member for Nicklin, historically at a national level there was an institution formerly identified as the National Training Information Service as an entity in itself by that name. That, as I understand it, has since changed. The facility has continued, but it now does not have that formal name. So it is described by its function rather than its name, and its function is a register of vocational education and training matters.
Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.37 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the bill be now read a third time.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the bill be now read a third time.
Motion agreed to.
Bill read a third time.
Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Minister for Education and Training) (10.37 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the long title of the bill be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (10.37 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House, at its rising, do adjourn until 9.30 am on Tuesday, 23 November 2010.
XML.Hansard-Body: Question put--That the motion be agreed to.
Motion agreed to.
Hon. GJ WILSON (Ferny Grove--ALP) (Acting Leader of the House) (10.38 pm): I move--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font: That the House do now adjourn.
XML.Hansard-Body: Mr DICKSON (Buderim--LNP) (10.38 pm): I rise to speak in order to support the crime prevention strategy of Neighbourhood Watch. The Neighbourhood Watch program was developed in order to bring the police and the community closer together after the realisation that police needed to work more closely with the community in preventing and solving crime. Neighbourhood Watch had its roots in the United States in the early 1960s. In June 1988 Neighbourhood Watch was launched in Queensland. Neighbourhood Watch focuses on improving home security, reducing the fear of crime and reporting suspicious activities to police. The evolution of Neighbourhood Watch has seen groups become involved in broader community safety issues and working to identify and address local problems that may not necessarily involve crime.

It is my understanding that currently there are about 31 Neighbourhood Watch districts throughout Queensland. The program and associated Neighbourhood Watch groups are well supported by the Queensland police, with officers attending the group meetings. Neighbourhood Watch enhances cohesion within the local community and there is plenty of evidence to suggest that the program can actually help in improving relationships between neighbours. Traditionally, Neighbourhood Watch has had a very strong and committed volunteer base and has a symbol that is recognised worldwide by potential victims and offenders.

Sadly though, there is some evidence to suggest that the community spirit around Neighbourhood Watch may be waning slightly. Certainly, on the Sunshine Coast a few of the local Neighbourhood Watch groups are fighting for survival. One group has been operating for almost 20 years, but is one of many Neighbourhood Watch groups across the region that is now struggling to maintain numbers. One in particular has had its numbers fall to about 30 from almost 800 residents in the area. The coordinator of this particular group is predicting that crime will increase if Neighbourhood Watch groups like his begin to close down owing to lack of support. It seems that the basic guidelines of the Neighbourhood Watch, which require a simple telephone tree of neighbours’ contact numbers, are now almost nonexistent, with most people no longer knowing their neighbours.

It would be an utter tragedy if this once robust and highly successful community program were to fail. I encourage all members of this House and the community to promote and, if possible, become involved in their local Neighbourhood Watch program.

I would like to pay tribute to a gentleman in my area by the name of Mr Mel Fletcher, who was a member of the Kuluin Neighbourhood Watch. He passed away on Tuesday night. To his wife, Dawn, and to their family, I pay the greatest respect and I hope that this parliament would pay that to him as well. He was a wonderful man.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Brothers Juniors Rugby League Football Club
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. SJ HINCHLIFFE (Stafford--ALP) (Minister for Infrastructure and Planning) (10.41 pm): I rise to celebrate 75 years of the Brothers Juniors Rugby League Football Club, which is based in my electorate at Gibson Park, Stafford. The proud traditions of the Brethren started in 1935 and while the senior club wound up a number of years ago, the blue and white butcher striped jersey has been carried on by Brisbane Brothers Juniors. The year 2010 has been a wonderful year of successes on and off the field. Brothers’ 530 registered players formed 26 junior teams and two senior teams--all supported by a legion of loyal supporters including coaches, managers, trainers, family and other assorted volunteering Brothers’ faithful. Eight sides contested grand finals and three won premierships.

It is my very great honour to be the patron of Brothers Juniors and I was very pleased to join this family club at a number of great events where this 75th anniversary year was celebrated. In June, I was joined by my colleague the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport, himself a Brothers stalwart--
Mr Reeves: Love the club.

Mr HINCHLIFFE: I take that interjection from the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport. At the club’s 75th anniversary dinner we heard from great names of the club over the decades, including a recorded interview with 93-year-old Neil Murdoch, who played in the butcher stripes against Norths in the 1940 A-grade grand final. Sadly, Mr Murdoch has since passed on, but it was a pleasure to support the presentation of a special anniversary Brothers jersey No. 4, recognising Neil’s position as a centre in the 1940 side, to the Murdoch family at his funeral.

Past President Scott Munro’s presentation on the club’s history was most poignant, given the Munro family’s involvement with the club over many decades. Alongside his fellow life member father, Don, Scott has served the club tirelessly. I know how proud he is of his sons Daniel and Ben, the seniors and juniors club captains respectively.

In October, I was joined at the annual trophy day by the President of the Senate, Senator John Hogg, whose father, Frank, was very firmly associated with Brothers Juniors in particular and development of junior rugby league in this state.
Mr Reeves interjected.
Mr HINCHLIFFE: I take that interjection from the Minister for Child Safety and Minister for Sport. Senator Hogg has been particularly involved in the development of junior rugby league in this state.

The trophy day, as with the anniversary dinner, was ably presided over by President Roger Whyte, who was buoyed by the enthusiasm of the more than 800 attendees to celebrate the season with all the players and their supporters. This has been a tremendous year for the Brethren, but it would not have been possible without the loyal army of volunteers supporting the 28 teams, running the canteen and preparing the grounds at Gibson Park or, indeed, the many generous sponsors of the club. It would not be possible to mention all these volunteers, but I will highlight Roger Whyte’s hardworking committee: the efforts of long-time and tireless secretary, Graham Brennan--better known as Bruno--and vice-president cum canteen manager Mario Licastro and other committee members and general helpers around the club, including Peter Gill, John Pezzimenti, Charles Larosa, Debbie Hiscock, Paul McSween, Damian Smith, Andrew Hedger, John Geaney, Patricia Licastro, Jeff Leitch, Michael Lynch, Craig Grauf, Davida Boyd and many more besides. Up the Brethren!

Mr CRANDON (Coomera--LNP) (10.44 pm): October is Sexual Violence Awareness Month. The teal ribbon that I am wearing is the symbol for the month and is intended to remind us that we must remain vigilant and we all have a role to play in preventing violence of all sorts and working towards a safer Queensland. During the past month I have attended two candle lighting remembrance ceremonies. At the first of these I was joined by the member for Albert, who was a guest speaker. We both agree that the stories shared with the participants by the brave women who have been victims of sexual violence were horrific but at the same time inspiring because of the way these women are fighting back to regain their lives with the help of the people of the Logan Centre Against Sexual Violence.

The second candle lighting remembrance ceremony was at the Gold Coast Centre Against Sexual Violence in Southport at their brand-new premises that was purpose built to provide the facilities to better help them in their support role. What they need now is certainty of funding beyond 2011 to ensure that their important work can continue. I was joined at that event by the member for Gaven. Once again, the stories that the brave victims of sexual violence shared with us were both horrific but inspiring and a testament to the valuable work that the support staff at the centre do.

Members may remember the Right to choose report that was launched in this place just a few weeks ago. Many members attended the launch of that report, which was held in the Undumbi Room. The report proposes an evidence based, holistic response to sexual assault in Queensland. It advocates a system designed to enable Queensland to move towards the reduction and ultimate elimination of sexual violence. It also proposes a service delivery system designed to better address the diverse needs of the Queensland community. I know that the 20 sexual assault services that contributed to the development of that report urge the minister to read the document, to take on board the initiatives that it contains and to respond to them with a view to producing better outcomes for sexual assault victims in Queensland.

Another worthwhile and, may I suggest, linked organisation is CEO Challenge. Recently I attended the AGM of CEO Challenge and was pleased to witness the recruitment of two new corporate sponsors who have taken up the challenge to support a local domestic violence refuge. That takes the total of corporate sponsors that are supporting domestic violence refuges around Queensland to 16. The two new sponsors are GHD, a project management firm, and Australia Post. They join the likes of the Brisbane City Council, the Gold Coast City Council, Minter Ellison, Clayton Utz and others. Members may remember CEO Challenge being our guest here to commemorate White Ribbon Day in November last year. At that time members took the oath: ‘I swear not to commit, excuse or be silent about violence against women.’ Should members receive an invitation this year to attend a White Ribbon Day event, I urge them to take the time to attend.

In closing, members, we should all carry these statistics with us as a reminder: one in three women experience domestic violence in their relationship; domestic violence is the major cause of death for women aged between 15 and 44.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Albert Carer of the Year Awards
XML.Hansard-Body: Hon. MM KEECH (Albert--ALP) (10.47 pm): On Thursday, 14 October at the Studio Village Community Centre I held a very special ceremony to recognise some wonderful constituents with my inaugural 2010 Albert Carer of the Year Awards. Together with my special guest, the Minister for Disability Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon. Annastacia Palaszczuk, I was privileged to recognise, with trophies and certificates, the hard work and loving dedication of eight wonderful people. No carer ever expects any sort of award or recognition. Caring is a duty that they undertake out of love, compassion and commitment. Yet given how significant their role is in making a real difference in the lives of their loved ones, as the member for Albert, I felt compelled during Carers Week to celebrate their achievements with the inaugural awards.

Often we call caring a full-time job, but after listening to the stories of the award winners I know that this is simply not true. Full-time work is eight hours a day, five days a week and one receives a pay packet at the end of the week. On the other hand, caring is 24 hours a day, seven days a week and, even during rare times of respite, the person in one’s care is never far from the carer’s mind.

At the awards I recognised three different types of carers: young carers, senior carers and grandparent carers. The recognition of Albert grandparents as carers is particularly timely, with the passing today through this parliament of amendments to the Carers (Recognition) Act. Thanks to the commitment of the Labor government and Minister Annastacia Palaszczuk, the amendments will extend the coverage of the Carers (Recognition) Act 2008 to grandparents who are the full-time carers for their grandchildren. The amendments mean that Queensland will become the first state in Australia to legislatively recognise the tireless work of our state’s grandparents.

At the event I was particularly pleased to thank Maree Lubach founder of KinKare, Carers Queensland, and MAD--Mothers Against Drugs--for their significant contribution to the success of the awards by nominating worthy recipients.

It was clear to me at the event that there is one thing common to all carers. That one thing is the great love and generous heart which brings them to do what they do. To the carers Jazzmyn Pybus, Andrew Pearce, Cindy Hancock, Sharon Kelly, Marie Currie, Robert and Jacqueline Morris and Nora Lleuful: I say thank you for your tireless dedication to those you care for. Through your selfless love you provide important role models to me and the rest of the community. You are most worthy winners of the inaugural 2010 Albert Carer of the Year Awards.

Mr McLINDON (Beaudesert--TQP)
(10.50 pm): It was fantastic news this morning from the Deputy Premier and Minister for Health in relation to the Beaudesert Hospital. I welcome the announcement that the government will make a commitment in terms of enhancing the maternity services for low-risk births at the Beaudesert Hospital. This will no doubt take some pressure off the Logan Hospital as well. I know there have been prenatal and postnatal services since 1 July, but that announcement is extremely welcome. It has been almost 10 years that the community has been fighting long and hard for this and I look forward to a further announcement in the future.

I also thank the minister for coming out for some 2 hours to meet with the staff. The Beaudesert Hospital auxiliary were thrilled and are now knitting a pair of socks for him which I have to deliver. They were very happy to have the Deputy Premier rock up to see the good work that the Beaudesert Hospital auxiliary does.

Speaking of maternity wards and children, there has been the controversial issue of the abortion debate in the public arena. I appreciate the Premier has a different position to the legislation that exists in the House. I quite happily put on the public record that I support the existing legislation in regard to abortion and also note that the Premier did say that there was not a majority of support within the chamber to decriminalise abortion.

A new high school in the Beaudesert region is certainly needed. The Beaudesert State High School awards were announced last night. It was a fantastic event. That school is at capacity. Out of the 34 schools in the Beaudesert electorate, the high schools are certainly reaching their capacity. So I would like to see in a five-year plan the possibility of the construction of a new high school. I would like to acknowledge all the teachers across the 34 schools in the Beaudesert electorate. Given it is World Teachers Day tomorrow, I think it is fitting that we all understand the great work that they do to make sure that we educate future generations.

I also want to thank the Minister for Infrastructure and Planning for his visit to the Wyaralong Dam. It was great to see him out there with the members for Logan, Ipswich West, Redcliffe, Morayfield, Bulimba and the deputy mayor for the Scenic Rim Regional Council to see how the trail bike facility is coming along. Thank you very much for the good work that is happening there and the local employment that the Wyaralong Dam and the trail bike facility will be generating in that region. It is a very welcome addition to the area.

Turning to the Tamborine Mountain urban and rural firefighters, I have raised with the Minister for Police, Corrective Services and Emergency Services that they are in dire need of a shower and toilet facility. I would be pushing for both of those services to move together next to the ambulance station on Mount Tamborine and next to the helipad so that they can share those services.

I also thank the Minister for Tourism and Fair Trading and the Minister for Climate Change and Sustainability for their announcement tomorrow in relation to expressions of interest for investors to develop and operate semi-permanent, low-impact ecotourism accommodation at Green Mountain campground in Lamington National Park. I look forward to ecotourism to boost the tourism industry in the Beaudesert region.

Ms JARRATT (Whitsunday--ALP)
(10.51 pm): The week of 6 to 12 November is an important week in North Queensland because it is Marine Stinger Awareness Week. What are marine stingers? They are basically jellyfish. While there are many stinging jellyfish in the world, there are two main types that are of concern in North Queensland. The first of these is the irukandji which, contrary to popular myth, is not a newly discovered jellyfish. It is actually named after the Irukandji Aboriginal tribe from the hinterland of Cairns who knew something about the syndrome that people developed after swimming in the ocean off Cairns. We know of at least 10 species of irukandji and one thing they all have in common is that they are quite small, between 1 and 2 centimetres across the bell. They are not of themselves lethal, although people with underlying pulminary or respiratory conditions are at greater risk.

The other type of jellyfish of concern is the box jellyfish, or the chironex fleckeri. It is the most lethal marine creature in the world. It can kill an adult in just two to three minutes with just a five-centimetre piece of its tentacle contacting the skin. There have been at least 63 deaths in Australian tropical waters between 1884 and 1996.

The point of Marine Stinger Awareness Week is to raise awareness in the community and especially amongst our local children with visits to schools to give information and education to these children so that they are alert but not alarmed. They do not need to be alarmed because, just like we have learned to live with mosquitoes that sometimes carry dengue fever in the natural environment in North Queensland, so we have to learn to live with these creatures of the sea because they are a natural part of the environment. We need to learn to manage them, not to fear them.

I have been fortunate to attend several meetings of the Whitsunday Marine Stingers Management Committee. I applaud the role and the participation of all the members including the Whitsunday Regional Council, Surf Life Saving Queensland, Tourism Whitsunday, the Whitsunday Charter Boat Industry Association, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and local marine operators. I have been given a task by them to work with ministers of this government to establish a protocol for the reporting of sting incidents in the Whitsundays and more broadly in the state. This is about compiling data that will help us to learn more because so little is known about these creatures so that we may be able to better manage these stings. Knowing more means less fear.

Dr ROBINSON (Cleveland--LNP) (10.54 pm): I rise to update the House about the senseless and wanton destruction of the Cleveland Ambulance Station in the very early hours of Wednesday, 27 October. The ambulance station in Wellington Street, Cleveland, was set alight and the fire burned out the entire building, causing major structural damage and destroying everything within the building. Police and fire officers quickly attended the blaze, but despite their valiant efforts the building could not be saved. I want to acknowledge the good work on site of our local police, fire and SES personnel.

In addition to the damage to the building, an ambulance vehicle was stolen and set on fire, two others were burned inside the building, along with at least six defibrillators, other equipment, training implements and personal belongings of ambulance officers. I am able to report that a 23-year-old woman from Wellington Point was arrested and charged last night with arson, break and enter and unlawful use of a motor vehicle, among other charges.

The damage is so extensive that the early assessment by fire officers is that the building will likely have to be demolished and rebuilt. The early estimate of the replacement cost of the station is in the range of $4 million, plus three new ambulances and all other equipment. The cost of the arson attack goes beyond the material damage to the station, vehicles and equipment. The ambulance officers based at the station are doing it tough. The place where they live, call home and work from is now gone. It has been an emotional time for them and their families. I want to commend the ambulance officers of the Cleveland station for their service to the community and for their steadfastness under extreme pressure.

I want to also acknowledge the Queensland Ambulance Service for its quick response that insured minimal disruption to services. I note that a temporary operation centre has been set up at the Cleveland SES until an interim centre can be established and then the station fully rebuilt. I want to particularly acknowledge the following individuals: QAS Area Director Steve Clarke, Cleveland OIC Jamie Smith, the LAC leadership team led by Neville Coventry and Robyn Tennant. Can I also acknowledge the role of both the minister, Neil Roberts, and shadow minister, Ted Malone, for their swift and meaningful response. I appreciate the minister’s immediate commitment to the Cleveland community to rebuild the station to its former operational capacity, including all vehicles and equipment. I agree with the shadow minister that a review of security and surveillance at all ambulance stations should be undertaken to prevent further incidents from occurring.

I offer tonight to the minister and government all the resources of my office to assist them wherever possible in the rebuilding of the station in the shortest time possible. As a patron of the Cleveland Local Ambulance Committee, I also look forward to working with the team to do everything possible to support our officers and the service.
XML.Hansard-Level-2-Heading: Older People Speak Out Media Awards
XML.Hansard-Body:
Ms JOHNSTONE (Townsville--ALP)
(10.57 pm): On Monday night this week I had the pleasure of representing the Minister for Community Services and Housing, Karen Struthers, at the Older People Speak Out Media Awards at the Queensland State Library. It was a fantastic night. In attendance on the night were Val French, President of OPSO, the wonderful Noeline Brown, Australia’s Ambassador for Ageing, and Rosemary Menkens, member for Burdekin. These awards, which are just one of a number of key initiatives of OPSO, are an opportunity to recognise media professionals who portray older people accurately, fairly and positively, and help to break down negative stereotypes in the community.

I know that in my own electorate of Townsville we have a very vocal and active senior community who never miss an opportunity to talk with me about their needs and wants and who always bring to the table both practical suggestions and the broader vision that is required to promote a positive image of older people in our community. It is the media that plays an important role in raising community awareness of those needs and in creating an age-friendly Queensland. By partnering with our local media networks, older people can get this important message across to the broader community and ensure that older people are not taken for granted, are shown respect and are not ignored.

Having said that, I could not have been more pleased to see no less than four of this year’s OPSO awards go to the Townsville and Burdekin region. The Townsville Bulletin ’s prime time journalist Emma Chadwick picked up two awards. The first was the Queensland Award for the Elements Daily Newspapers for her article ‘Older workers share skills’. For the same article, Emma also collected the national special OPSO media award for excellence in the coverage of positive ageing in the workforce for workers aged 50 to 67. The very wonderful Alex Chambers from 630 ABC North Queensland was the winner of the Queensland Award for Radio News, Interviews and Current Affairs for his entry ‘Good old talk--Facebook for the over-60s’. Finally, but certainly not least, Robert Lesca from the Burdekin Community Association won the Queensland Award for Seniors Newsletters--Presentation and Content for their new newsletter Round-a-bout for Seniors .

I would like to congratulate Emma, Alex and Robert for the work that you do to accurately portray older people as active and valued members of our society. It is your efforts that will continue to improve the way seniors are perceived throughout Queensland.

In closing, I wish all Townsville grandparents a happy Grandparents Day for Sunday, 7 November. I encourage everyone to take the time to make a phone call, have a picnic with or send a card to their grandparents and tell them how much they love and value having them in their lives. On behalf of my children, Ethan and Paige, can I send a special wish to their grandparents: Grandma June, and Grandpa Phil Johnstone in Ayr and their Grandad Terry and Nana Val Thompson in Townsville.

Mr BLEIJIE (Kawana--LNP) (11.00 pm): It gives me pleasure to rise this evening and announce to the House what is a coup for all prep students and their families in the Kawana electorate. We have previously debated in this House the importance of pool safety regulations, with specific reference to pool fencing. But tonight I would like to address the House on a different aspect of pool safety.

I am sure that all members would have heard of the legendary Australian swimming identity Mr Laurie Lawrence. Honourable members will remember Laurie’s famous reaction at the 1988 Seoul Olympics when Duncan Armstrong famously won the 200-metre freestyle gold medal over the favourite Matt Biondi, in a world record breaking performance. Immediately after the race when asked if he thought Duncan could do it, in a typical fashion, Laurie replied, ‘Mate, why do you think we come here for, for silver ... stuff the silver, we come for the gold.’

Laurie’s passion is still in the pool but is solely focused on educational purposes. He now runs the Laurie Lawrence Swim School in Brisbane, which specialises in teaching people about safety aspects of pool safety. Laurie has pioneered the Kids Alive--Do the Five program and DVD. I am honoured to announce tonight that next month Laurie Lawrence is visiting the Kawana electorate to present a copy of his DVD to all prep students in the electorate. I have the privilege of accompanying Laurie on a tour around the electorate as we visit 661 prep students in the seven primary schools to present them each with a copy of the DVD. That will mean 661 students and their families will have a valuable instructional, interactive and educational DVD on water safety leading into summer and the busy Christmas period.
For all those who are unaware, Kids Alive--Do the Five refers to the following five water safety lessons that are sung with a catchy tune, which I will refrain from doing--
XML.Hansard-Body-Small-Font-Hanging-Indent1: 1. Fence the pool
2. Shut the gate
3. Teach your kids to swim--it’s great
4. Supervise--watch your mate and
5. Learn how to resuscitate
XML.Hansard-Body: Laurie created the Kids Alive--Do the Five water safety program in 1988 to highlight the awareness of the increase in drowning of pre-school-aged children. I am very pleased that Laurie has taken the time out of his busy schedule on 10 November to come to Kawana to continue the promotion of his water safety initiatives.

This also follows on from the CPR certification initiatives undertaken by the Talara Primary College for their year 7 students. I was delighted to be able to sponsor the initiative with two local businesses--Swimart Currimundi and Jim’s Mowing Aroona. All year 7 students at the Talara school undertook the course and are now accredited with the CPR certification. I would like to congratulate College Director Steve Adams and Deputy Principal Lisa Johnson for the coordination of this course, as well as the two local businesses which were able to join with me and financially contribute to the funding of the program. This is the second year that I have sponsored the CPR certification and I look forward to a continued involvement in years to come.

I am looking forward to the 10th when Laurie Lawrence comes to the Kawana electorate. As I said, 661 students will walk away that day with the Kids Alive--Do the Five DVD. I think that is great for the society and for swimming in general.

Mr FINN (Yeerongpilly--ALP) (11.04 pm): Tonight I pay tribute to Mrs Dell Luxton and recognise her contribution in the local community I am honoured to represent. I think Dell would describe herself as an ordinary Queenslander. Dell was a mum and a grandma, a baker and a gardener, a watcher of the Bold and the Beautiful and someone who cared about the community around her.

Dell’s daughter Shelley conveyed to me that she was not sure her mum was important enough to be talked about in the parliament, but I assure you, Shelley, that is not the case. There is no better place than in here, the people’s house, to acknowledge those stoic members of our community who have not only lived through some tough times but have done so with a compassion for their fellow Queenslanders and a preparedness to speak up for their community.

Last week, a few months after her 80th birthday, Dell passed away as a result of a tragic accident, an accident that could never have been foreseen. I have known Dell for a short part of her 80 years. I first spoke to her in 2002 when we were neighbours in Annerley, with Dell living in Waldheim Street and I was living in Bower Street.

In our local community was an Army Reserve facility that had been identified as surplus to requirements and listed for sale by the Commonwealth. Dell saw this facility and particularly the drill halls as important to the heritage and character of the local community and formed a local community group to develop alternative uses for the site but particularly to ensure recognition of the heritage value. Dell’s campaign to protect this site did not see her vision of a Queensland military heritage museum being developed, but she did succeed in having the two drill halls heritage listed. I know Dell’s vision of the military heritage centre would have been the best outcome for the site, but without her determination to protect as much of the site as possible, much of the local heritage would have been lost.

Following my election in 2004, I continued to see Dell regularly around the community and she kept raising community issues with me. She wrote to me about public liability insurance for not-for-profit organisations; the State Tennis Centre development; access to local railway stations; provision of taxi vouchers; preservation of Yeronga Park; the Community Memorials Restoration Program and other things. Most recently Dell had raised her concerns with me about the Cross River Rail project and the protection of parkland in Stevens Street, Yeronga.

Dell regularly attended her local Neighbourhood Watch meetings and always spoke to me about local issues. Just a few days before her accident we talked together about the briefing for the TOD development where Dell raised her concern about ensuring that development included space for local children to play.

Dell’s contribution to her community included many years on the P&C at Junction Park State School and as a volunteer reader to children at the school. Earlier this week at the service in celebration of Dell’s life, I heard her grandchildren speak of their life with their granny. What I saw was a group of confident and proud young people who could all talk about how Dell provided guidance and assurance for them in growing up and determining their life plans.

Dell was a special person to her family and her community--a loyal and stoic woman who was prepared to speak up for what was right. Dell had an opinion and was not afraid to say it but did so at all times with respect, kindness, warmth and good intentions. Dell was in fact an extraordinary Queenslander, and in her passing I thank her for her passion, spirit and commitment to her community.
Question put--That the House do now adjourn.
Motion agreed to.
The House adjourned at 11.08 pm.
